HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
In a Realm Less Grand, A 'King' Still Grooves

BYLINE:  By MIKE HALE; Mike Hale is an editor of Arts and Leisure.

DATELINE: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. 

 BODY:
BEHIND the stage you can see the kitchen, where cheeseburgers flying Hard Rock Cafe flags are picked up by waitresses in very short, very tight white uniforms. One waitress wears a flashing red taillight right where you'd expect a taillight to be, and the shiny plastic disc bobs in and out behind the seven men onstage like an angry firefly.
 This hangarlike restaurant in the parking lot of an Orange County mall is no place to play or to listen to music; the band's snaky, stuttering groove and the singer's smoky voice get lost somewhere up around the tail fins of the Chevy suspended over the bar. And it's an almost unimaginable distance from the factories and pubs of Birmingham, England, circa 1978-1982, which is where most of the songs the band is playing have their roots. But people are dancing, and for Dave Wakeling, the king of ska, that's always been at least half the battle. 
 The title is lightly worn, no matter how well deserved. (Perusing the Hard Rock menu before the show, Mr. Wakeling mused, "A cup of soup for the king of ska?") As a 22-year-old Birmingham construction worker with radical political leanings and a gift for writing haunting yet catchy tunes, he became a founding member of the Beat, later known as the English Beat. Born the year the Sex Pistols dissolved, 1978, the Beat channeled punk's energy into its own ska-dub-reggae Jamaican hybrid and became, briefly, a major force in British pop. After four years, three albums and little success cracking the American market, the band fell apart.
Now, 45 years old and a Californian for nearly 15 years, Mr. Wakeling -- author of a handful of the best pop songs of the late 70's and early 80's -- goes up and down the coast, playing the clubs, surf bars and beach festivals. But the young, working-class Brummie is still visible in his compact body and rough-hewn face, and Birmingham is still audible when he talks, rendering Los Angeles as Los ANG-gull-eez. The Beat's image in its heyday was of a crack dance band with a sharper-than-usual political sensibility, and that's how it remains in the fond memory of its cultists. But the real draw was always the way Mr. Wakeling, a singer-songwriter trapped in a punk-ska band, could imbue propulsive numbers like "Mirror in the Bathroom," "I Confess" and "Save It for Later" with his own melancholy romanticism, in both words and melody.
"There's definitely a melancholia, and a beauty through that, certainly," he said, cautiously, while submitting to an interview during his preshow dinner. "Virginia Woolf's notion that everything of beauty is cut with a certain singular sadness. And I like to try to stretch that and do it with a wry grin as well, so that there's a sense of irony about it: Yes, it's a tragedy, isn't it? Can we have a dance?"
A quarter-century after the Beat, along with its 2-Tone Records labelmates the Specials and Madness, got Britain dancing in what was to become known as the first ska revival, there is a flurry of interest in Mr. Wakeling's first band. London-Sire Records, which reissued the long-out-of-print Beat albums in 1999, will put out a new greatest-hits CD later this year, and he confirms that the former Beat members have been talking about a reunion to tie in with it. Mr. Wakeling has been doing his part to stoke this interest, serving up Beat standards on recent tours with his own band (which plays at Irving Plaza in Manhattan on Wednesday).
It helps that ska itself -- the infectious, skittering predecessor of reggae that was born in Jamaican dance halls and recording studios in the late 50's -- had another comeback. He credits this latest wave of ska, spearheaded in the late 90's by groups like No Doubt and the Mighty Mighty Bosstones, with stirring interest in the 2-Tone groups. "And at the same time, perversely enough, this 80's retro thing," he said, "which here in Los Angeles, much to my delight, seems to be fueled mainly with either late-teens or early-20's Latinos."
On this April night, his band -- the latest in a series of groups he has assembled since moving here -- is saddled with more than the awful acoustics and the seemingly endless choruses of "Happy Birthday" from every section of the restaurant. There's also its odd and unwieldy name: "The English Beat's Dave Wakeling." This is how Mr. Wakeling, in consultation with the other former members of the Beat, has agreed to bill himself for now.
"In exchange for getting to use the fabulous group name, I'm the only thing out helping the catalog get a mention," he said. "So that's fair, I believe."
The band is a more than reasonable facsimile of the original, easily conjuring the staccato beats, swirling guitars and dark saxophone riffs that defined the Beat as well as General Public, the on-again, off-again group formed by Mr. Wakeling and the Beat's other vocalist, Ranking Roger. (The Beat's guitarist and bass player, Andy Cox and David Steele, went on to found Fine Young Cannibals with the singer Roland Gift; their mix of power pop and Jamaican rhythms came together in one huge hit, the 1989 album "The Raw and the Cooked.") And the band has something else in common with its predecessor: a balanced multiracial makeup (in this case, white, black and Latino), something that in 1978, a decade after Sly and the Family Stone, was still unusual on either side of the Atlantic.
"We were lucky, I suppose, coming from Birmingham, where there had been a loosening of the boundaries between people of different colors," Mr. Wake ling said. "So when we wanted to blend punk and reggae, it never occurred to us that it would be an odd thing to have people of different color in the same group.
"I would love to take credit, like it was a marvelous contrivance. But it was just what was going on around us. It wasn't a big deal, until we went to London and people first commented on it. Then, when we came to America, it was obviously some huge sociological movement."
Also rising out of the Beat's time and place, and out of Mr. Wakeling's affection for the music of Bob Marley, was the band's overt emphasis on politics (not to mention political action, like benefit concerts for the unemployed). Bigger post-punk, new wave names like the Clash and Elvis Costello might have gained more attention in the United States for their songs of protest, but in Mrs. Thatcher's Britain, it was the Beat's anthem "Stand Down Margaret" that captured the mood of recession and nuclear anxiety: "I see no joy, I see only sorrow/ I see no chance of your bright new tomorrow/So stand down Margaret, stand down please, stand down Margaret." "There was definitely a sense of apocalypse," Mr. Wakeling said. "It was like, ooh, you better have a dance, we might not be here next Saturday."
He added: "I fear I have far more to thank Mrs. Thatcher for than I ever could have blamed her for. Every time she opened her mouth, I knew where I stood. Once everybody fully understands what George W.'s saying, I'm sure a lot of people will find they're diametrically opposed to that, too."
After the demise of the Beat (the causes: "The rhythm section going off the boil with each other; us touring too much; me being an egomaniac with perfectionist and self-destructive tendencies. So I was told") and, later, of General Public, Mr. Wakeling came to California to make a solo album. It was backed, minimally, by the ill-fated IRS Records, and quickly disappeared.
As a young man, he says, he had considered going to work for Greenpeace or becoming a Buddhist monk before opting for rock stardom. With his musical career having temporarily slowed, he followed his convictions and spent five years working, often full-time, in Greenpeace's Los Angeles office, organizing benefits, coaching celebrity spokesmen and producing "Alternative NRG," an album recorded with solar power.
Now he's back on the road and in the studio, working with Rick Torres, the mastermind of the Los Angeles techno-lounge group Supreme Beings of Leisure, who is also playing guitar for Mr. Wakeling on his current tour. Mr. Wakeling has an idea for combining studio tracks with samples from his own live shows, "to try and combine the hormones and the adrenaline of the gig with the metronomic precision that's required for the radio now." Mr. Wakeling said he did not want to make music that sounded like England in the early 80's, any more than the Beat wanted to make music that sounded like Jamaica in the early 60's. "It's got to sound like early 21st century Los Angeles," he said. "I don't really want to be the English Beat. I'm using this Beat release to try and reinvigorate interest in my wonderful self."
He has other reasons for putting some distance between himself and his musical past. "I think I'm a bit more soul-grooved than reggae-grooved at the moment," he said. "But I think in some ways that's a reaction of disappointment at the tawdry area that much of dance-hall reggae has taken. I don't quite understand loads of men with highly coiffured braids running around the stage denigrating homosexuals, which seems like a big shock to me after the likes of Bob Marley, who used reggae as a very conscious and uplifting medium."
Whatever form his work takes, it will be worth hearing if it still expresses the vulnerability and knowledge of human weakness of a song like "I Confess," with its moaning opening lines: "Just out of spite/ I confess I've ruined three lives/ Don't sleep so tight/ 'Cause I did not care till I found out that one of them was mine."
"It seems to me that that's where people actually connect," he said. "Not by being really strong and showing off your best side. You can sing in a song about something embarrassingly personal but find a way to put it so it rings those universal bells. That way I think it draws folk together, or closer. That's my notion."

PERSON: HALE, MIKE; WAKELING, DAVE

LENGTH: 1000 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
If Fans Stay Away, So Does Music

BYLINE:  By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

 BODY:
FROM here it's like watching a tennis match. Every two years, the premier American early-music festival and exhibition takes place in Boston, where the 2001 outing ends today. Every other year, it moves to Berkeley, Calif. New York, meanwhile, leads an impoverished early-musical life, with little of the music itself and few quality performers like those who have elsewhere carried the aesthetic of period instruments and performance practice to later repertories and broader audiences.
 Things were looking up a few years ago. In 1996, the Gotham Early Music Foundation began importing top performers from around the world: most prominently, the Tallis Scholars, a superb English chorus. And in 1999, the New York Collegium put native talent to work under the aegis of the Dutch harpsichordist and conductor Gustav Leonhardt, a dean of the international early-music movement. 
 Now Gotham has scrapped its ambitious plans for next season and is folding its tent. The New York Collegium has evidently weathered administrative disarray, but to judge from at least one prominent recent performance, in Jonathan Miller's production of Bach's "St. Matthew Passion" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the group is hard put to sustain even the modest promise of its first seasons.
Gotham was the work of two men: Douglas K. Dunn, a lawyer, who selected the performers and planned the programs, and Gordon L. Beals, a foreign-exchange trader, who (though in his own words, "not a wealthy man") provided the financial backing. They entered the field with eyes open. "I very carefully did a lot of budgeting," Mr. Dunn said at the time, "and I was rather appalled at the numbers." The annual budget grew from an initial $200,000 for 7 concerts to $500,000 for 12. Another season would have required additional commitments of $250,000.
"We had a straightforward financial problem," Mr. Dunn said recently, "and if you can't make that work, all the early-music expertise in the world won't help."
With Gotham's demise, the importation of talent reverts largely to two institutions: on a small scale, Music Before 1800, judiciously directed by Louise Basbas as it enters its 27th season at Corpus Christi Church on the Upper West Side of Manhattan; and on a large scale, Lincoln Center, where Jane Moss, the vice president for programming, has applied ever more inventiveness and imagination to the Great Performers series and even to the once moribund Mostly Mozart Festival. Ms. Moss's successes, of course, may have contributed to Gotham's problems.
The New York Collegium, a Baroque choir and orchestra, was founded on the shifting sands of ambition. Michael S. Feldman, its first president, seemed eager to get past the inevitable growing pains and take up Classical and even Romantic music, as if hellbent on following an earlier New York period-instrument group, the short-lived, unlamented Classical Band, lemminglike, into oblivion. Before resigning a year ago, Mr. Feldman announced the replacement of Mr. Leonhardt, never more than a figurehead, with two new music directors: Christophe Rousset, a French harpsichordist, and Fabio Biondi, an Italian violinist. But Mr. Rousset did not appear during the last season, and neither performer is scheduled for the group's five programs next season.
"They are not accessible to us in the way we want," said Dorothea Endicott, who was formerly the Collegium's board president and became its executive director last December. Ms. Endicott is working with an advisory board of five musicians. She hopes to name a new, hands-on music director, she said, a major European figure she would not identify, within 60 days. In an attempt to manage an annual budget of almost $1 million now that a founding grant of $2 million has been used up, Ms. Endicott is restructuring the board and scaling down ambitions in both repertory and performance.
"One priority is to put down roots in New York," she said. "That comes before touring, before making recordings. And we have to define a niche in the Baroque."
Ms. Endicott, who just relocated from Boston, has no ready explanation for the hobbled state of early music in New York, why the city lags behind Boston, let alone major centers like London, Amsterdam, Paris and Cologne. Others have advanced various reasons: a wealth of competition and distractions in other areas of music and the arts; the lack of a magnetic leader, like, say, John Eliot Gardiner in London or William Christie (an American) in Paris; a paucity of appropriate concert settings, or at least of those economically feasible in terms of cost and potential revenue.
"The lack of venues is just an excuse," said Mr. Dunn, who rented numerous halls and churches for Gotham. "And the lack of leadership doesn't apply unless you're trying to set up a performing organization, which we weren't doing. It is a truism but perhaps true that New York is not an early-music town. The audience is of good quality but not large."
New York's days in the vanguard of the field -- in the 1950's and 60's, under the pioneering leadership of Noah Greenberg -- seem a distant memory. Or they would, if so many homegrown performances didn't have a scrappy, amateurish quality redolent of that time.
In New York as elsewhere, the early-music movement has to some extent fallen victim to its success. For a time, when it had the weight of the major record labels behind it, it managed to stake an exclusive claim on repertory up to the Baroque and beyond plausible enough to scare away conventional performers, including symphony orchestras, with their incredible shrinking repertories. So, as a small, specialized audience developed, mainstream listeners tended to lose touch with Handel and Bach, even Haydn and Mozart.
Not even the strictest authenticists ever advocated period-size audiences for early music, and it's a sure bet that such paltry numbers will never sustain a major venture in Gotham. The pity is that so few New Yorkers will ever know what glories they missed.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
In a Kaleidoscope of Remembering and Forgetting

BYLINE:  By HILARIE M. SHEETS; Hilarie M. Sheets is a contributing editor to Artnews magazine.

 BODY:
PROJECTED on a small medicine chest attached to the wall, a man's face drawn in charcoal emerges to the sound of running water. Soon the face seems to dissolve into the interior of the cabinet, and over the next few minutes strange and elliptical hand-drawn images rapidly appear and disintegrate there as well. A tiny man walking across a ravaged landscape leaves in his wake smudgy traces that morph into jars on the shelves. A bird flapping into the sides of the cabinet transforms into a fish revolving around a globe propped in a field. Phrases like "Doomed Sailor's Chilling Note" flash intermittently. Finally, a man rests his head against a woman's naked torso -- a less clinical form of chest that supplies comfort.
 The images are from "Medicine Chest," the most recent of William Kentridge's 13 animated films, now being shown through Sept. 16, together with more than 60 charcoal drawings from which they were shot, in a retrospective at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Lower Manhattan. Mr. Kentridge, 46, is the first globally acclaimed South African artist of the post-apartheid period, and his art is often viewed through the prism of politics. And yet he roots his work in the local and the specific: for him it's a way of getting at universal truth rather than simply illustrating the recent history of his country. 
 "The films can be understood as a sort of diary or daily newspaper of one's self," Mr. Kentridge said, noting that the cryptic phrases in "Medicine Chest" had been lifted from actual headlines. "The dominant thing going through the head that day may be: how do I resolve this conflict with a friend?" he said. "Secondary might be: there are crowds marching in the streets. Third may be: I'm in the middle of this book, and I hate the way it's going to end." He added: "It's a real mixture of the political and the social and the personal. Insofar as the films track anything, they try to approximate that process."
Born in Johannesburg, where he continues to live with his wife, Anne, and three children, Mr. Kentridge is part of a Jewish family that emigrated to South Africa from Lithuania 100 years ago. His parents and three of his grandparents were prominent lawyers. Particularly because of his father's work -- representing families of victims massacred outside Sharpeville in the early 1960's, for instance -- Mr. Kentridge was exposed to the horrors of apartheid in a way most other white children were not.
Images of bodies being absorbed into the landscape show up in the film "Felix in Exile," as the character of Felix Teitlebaum, a melancholic artist, looks into his drawings and tries to envision this landscape outside the bounds of his room. Made in 1994, after the first general election in South Africa brought quiet to what had been a tumultuously violent period, the film struggles with the fugitive nature of memory, how those that should remain with intensity get diluted and obscured over time. Spanning a series of eight films, Felix and his alter ego, Soho Eckstein, a mining industrialist variously ruthless and tragic, putter about their daily activities under the weight of remembering and forgetting.
"If one comes away from the exhibition somewhat confused about what's happening in South Africa, then that's good," Mr. Kentridge said in an interview at the New Museum. "South Africa was the emblematic political situation of the world in that decade from 1980 to 1990. One of the reasons it's not really of great interest anymore is that the stories are much more complicated. The easy heroes and villains have melted into each other."
Dan Cameron, the senior curator at the New Museum and an organizer of this retrospective, says Mr. Kentridge has never wanted to be understood as speaking for South Africa."I think what people tend to do when they first try to grapple with William's work is treat South Africa as if it only means one thing," he said. "His primary characters are clearly South African, but they are defined almost by the way they try to ignore the extraordinary circumstances of their life and act as if any crisis can be surpassed, which I think is a tendency in many cultures, including our own. To simplify it by exoticizing the experience of South Africa is to avoid what's universally human in his work."
Mr. Kentridge has been well known in South Africa over the last two decades in art and film circles as well as in the theater world. He first worked as an actor after graduating from the University of the Witwatersrand and now conceives and directs productions with the Handspring Puppet Company, which incorporate actors, musicians, puppets and animation. But it wasn't until 1997, when he was included in Documenta X, an art festival in Kassel, Germany, that his art attracted the attention of curators, who quickly disseminated it worldwide. In 1999, he had a solo show here at the Museum of Modern Art and received the Carnegie Medal in Pittsburgh. The current retrospective, which opened in Washington, will bring him the broadest exposure yet as it travels from New York to Chicago, Houston, Los Angeles and Cape Town.
"If 10 years ago someone had said, 'In 10 years time, these are the different places you will have shown, these are the projects you will have done,' I'd have been jumping up and down," Mr. Kentridge said. He had always felt that he was simply dabbling at film, drawing and theater but would at some point get a real profession, he said. A clarifying moment came 10 years ago, when he was told by a friend that at 35 he was now unemployable and should just get on with what he was doing.
"During the 1980's there was the cultural boycott of South Africa, which meant that work got seen very little outside," Mr. Kentridge said. "There was never an expectation that it was going to be seen in a large way. In retrospect that was a blessing. It meant I didn't have to try to catch up or surpass what was being done in America. So when there was an interest in these films, I knew what I was doing. Suddenly having them in exhibitions around the world didn't really change the process of making them."
Drawing is the starting point of all his work. In the late 80's, he began fooling around with a camera used in animation, one that can be advanced one frame at a time. His aim, he said, was to film "the process of a drawing coming into being." That sort of play evolved into full-blown narratives. Now he may make 60 to 100 alterations to a drawing in a day, shooting frames between each change. He says it's in the physical act of walking between the drawing on the wall and the camera that he finds a sense of what can happen next in his stories.
The fact that charcoal leaves a trace when rubbed out gives Mr. Kentridge's sequences an imprint of time. Charcoal also creates an immediate reference to black-and-white cinema, like the epics of Sergei Eisenstein, and German Expressionist art by Max Beckmann or George Grosz. The anachronistic quality in his drawing stems, too, from the objects he chooses. "There's something about a mechanical telephone switchboard, with wires being plugged and unplugged, that's an easier way of drawing what our lives have become with the Internet than a TV monitor," he said. "It's finding places where the world and drawing meet on good terms."
While both Felix and Soho have come to bear some resemblance to him, Mr. Kentridge says that is mainly because he needs someone close at hand to use as a model. But Carolyn Christov-Bakargiev, the senior curator at P.S. 1 in Queens, who commissioned his current installation there -- of silhouetted figures parading on the walls of a staircase like shadows of past students -- says Mr. Kentridge has projected himself into the scene in the portly figure of a man reading an open book.
"It suggests the way he feels ethically responsible for the material he's using, especially if it's a material that implies denunciation," she said. She added that that he had been intrigued by how the metal grating enclosing the stairwell was redolent of imprisonment.
Ms. Christov-Bakarigiev also points out that in the film "Ubu Tells the Truth," inspired by the 1995 governmental hearings into human rights abuses in South Africa, Mr. Kentridge layers a chalk outline of the despotic king over his own form. "I think basically his work is about the negotiation between the private and the public," she said, "exhibiting one's own weaknesses, and finding the Ubu that's in all of us."

HEADLINE: Language Lessons 

 BODY:
To the Editor: On May 6 the Travel section published a letter by Benjamin Rifkin commenting on the article by Francis X. Clines, "An Archipelago Called Russian" (April 8), which described the instruction offered by my school, the Specialized Language Training Center.
 The letter by Mr. 
Rifkin, president-elect of the American Association of Teachers of Slavic and East European Languages, could be construed as questioning my credentials and implying that my school is not "reputable." 
 I graduated from Grozny Pedagogical Institute in Russia in 1964 as a certified teacher of Russian Language and Literature, and I have taught Russian for 36 years at a variety of institutions including the Foreign Service Institute of the United States Department of State and two universities. In 1988 I received the Una Chapman Cox Award for Excellence in Teaching from then-Secretary of State George Shultz.
I have also conducted faculty development seminars for many educational institutions and authored and co-authored several publications in foreign language teaching.
Students from such organizations as the Library of Congress, the Rand Corporation, the Harvard Institute for International Development and the Import-Export Bank have chosen S.L.T.C.; surely these highly educated people were aware that universities teach Russian, yet they sought instruction from us. 

BORIS SHEKHTMAN
President
Specialized Language
Training Center
Rockville, Md.

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Patients Without a Country: Who Pays?

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Jennifer Steinhauer covers health care for The Times. Her column on the economics of health care appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: jestei@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
ANY minute now, the men and women of Congress will hunker down to discuss prescription-drug benefits under Medicare, and the rights that Americans should have if they are enrolled in H.M.O.'s. 
 In the meantime, however, a more complicated insurance problem is brewing, with serious public health implications, and few lawmakers have been willing to take it up: Who should pay for the health insurance of immigrants? 
 A provision of the welfare reform law of 1996 barred immigrants who arrived after that year from receiving Medicaid, the health insurance program for the indigent, during their first five years in the United States.
There may be little political impetus to change that portion of the law, but economic and public health issues have undeniably risen from it. New census figures show that one of every 10 people now living in the United States is foreign-born, the highest level since the 1930's, and cities with declining populations are trying to figure out how to attract some of those immigrants to stem labor shortages. But denying government insurance programs to immigrants at a time when more employers are considering backing away from health benefits in general seems to contradict this municipal bear hug. 
There is ample evidence that immigrants who work are underinsured, compared with the rest of the nation. A new study from the Commonwealth Fund, a health care research foundation, found that among full-time workers in 1999, some 80 percent of whites and 75 percent of blacks in general received health-care coverage from their employers, versus only half of Hispanic immigrants.
The study also found that among the Hispanic population, half of those born outside the United States were uninsured in 1997, versus one-fourth of those born in the country. 
And the issue of who will foot the bill for requisite care for even illegal immigrants can be murky. 
Last year, a 14-year-old illegal immigrant showed up at the door of Kings County Hospital Center, a public hospital in Brooklyn, needing a liver transplant, without which he would have died. The hospital does not perform transplants, so Kings County Hospital started calling medical centers around the city that did. All refused him because he was not insured, according to a complaint filed by New York's public hospital system with the Health Care Finance Administration. When the public hospital agreed to enroll the boy in its own managed care program, which would no doubt suffer a loss on this procedure, doors opened. The insurance kicked in at midnight, and Mount Sinai Hospital took him in at 3 a.m. and performed the transplant.
Kings County could not have turned him away. Under federal law, hospitals are required to stabilize any patient who enters the emergency room. But does "stabilizing" include a liver transplant? And if not, who is supposed to pay for it?
The economic fallout from such questions tends to land on the public hospitals and clinics around the country, which labor under low reimbursement rates for primary care and treat many uninsured patients in their emergency rooms. In turn, these hospitals tend to look to the government for increased help or to close clinics at which they lose money. 
This month, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled that the state had violated the state Constitution by going along with the federal government in denying Medicaid benefits to legal immigrants. But it is likely that other states will still not choose to pay to insure this group.
Offering public health insurance, even at small premiums, to at least those immigrants who pay taxes has some universal benefits. The cost of treating the sickest uninsured eventually comes back to the general population through tax increases passed on as subsidies to hospitals, or through higher insurance premiums.
AND the fact is, whether immigrants import health problems or become sick more often because they lack regular medical care, public health threats can stem from the uninsured in general. Children who lack immunization can spread disease, as was seen last year in a rubella outbreak in the South.
Many uninsured people work in service industries, said Judy Wessler, director of the Commission on the Public's Health System, a health care advocacy organization. "If they do not have access to health care services and have direct contact with lots of people, illnesses can be spread," she said, citing restaurants and other food outlets as obvious examples. 
Barring a prudent change in the welfare law, legislators in search of pork projects could consider a special line item that would insure immigrants. Maybe the Frozen Yogurt Stand Improvement Act?

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
Generation X, Still Undecided

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
NEARLY a decade ago, I wrote an article for a Boston newspaper about "Post-Parchment Depression," the malaise that afflicts young college graduates when they suddenly realize that they are facing the rest of their lives and have no idea what to do next. 
 Those of us who graduated in the late 80's or early 1990's -- we've been affectionately called "slackers" or "Generation X" -- were hit especially hard by P.P.D. The economy was in mourning after the rah-rah 1980's, "downsizing" was the word of the day and career options were limited. Personal computers were still the size of the Mir space station, and the information superhighway was a dirt road that had yet to be paved by fiber optics. With few alternatives, many people fled to graduate school, or to teach English abroad. 
 While it became clear that we would not follow in our parents' footsteps -- no 35-year job, no four-bedroom house in the suburbs before the age of 30 -- we still had to find a way to carve our own niche. It wasn't that we had no drive; we just had nowhere to channel it. 
What I did not know at the time was that P.P.D. was not a passing affliction. Instead, it was a chronic condition like hay fever, rearing its head over and over. Ten years later, many of us are as indecisive and confused about our careers as we were when we set out into the world. 
Through no fault of our own, we ex-slackers have become like Peter Pan, searching for our very own Wendy (or Wendell) and never quite growing up. 
That should not be a great shock, considering role models like Mama Madonna, who is touring the world at 42. As a nation, we are in a perpetual state of "adultescence." Fifty is the new 40 is the new 30 is the new 20.
Still, I believe that Generation X-er's were hit hardest by changes in the economy. Just as we started moving out of our entry-level jobs, technology arrived and threw ice-cold water in the face of our dreams. To compete in the marketplace, we had to acquire a whole new set of skills, and we were overshadowed by a newer, technologically trained crop of young minds, sometimes called Generation Y, that graduated into a booming economy. 
"Just as we got on our feet from the 80's boom and 90's recession, we had the dot-com boom, which drove up the cost of living, which meant we were pushed away from financial security," said John Conway, 31, an intellectual-property lawyer at Cowan, DeBaets, Abraham & Sheppard in Manhattan. "We were stuck in entry-level jobs, and the income didn't increase with the cost of living. Everything is delayed, from home-buying to child-rearing. In the middle of the game, the roles changed, and the bar for success was raised beyond our means once again."
Career and life indecision in Generation X shows itself in many ways. Over the last six years, Arthur Traub, 30, has lived and worked in New York, South Carolina, Washington, D.C., Mexico and Brazil, picking up an M.B.A. degree along the way. He has worked in government, banking, telecommunications and information technology, from start-ups to multinational corporations. A few months ago, he was laid off from a high-paying job at a high-technology company; he is now teaching martial arts while deciding what's next.
Two years ago, Julia Slotnik, now 33, decided to abandon her job as an account executive at a Manhattan advertising firm to work on documentary films. Last week, Steve Reynolds, 38, the former head chef at a five-star resort in Granby, Colo., became a New York stockbroker.
Even some baby boomers are making similar life changes. In November, Amy Abern, 43, left her job as a director of a homeless shelter in Chicago and moved to Falmouth, Mass. She is now a travel writer. "I used to look at my mother at 42 and thought she was so old, but now I'm 43 and I still feel like a kid," said Ms. Abern, who is single. "Why shouldn't I try something new?"
I predict that the younger dot-com set, including the most recent graduates, will be better off in their 30's than Generation X-ers are now. To be sure, other problems await the dot-commers, especially those who left jobs empty-handed. But they probably won't grapple with the same career and life indecision that we do. 
After all, they participated in a cohesive vision; they came of age in an economy that nurtured creativity and provided a forum in which it could flourish. They were even placed in "incubators" where they and their ideas could grow. 
THE other day, I was talking to Maura Moynihan, 43, the daughter of Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the former senator from New York. She has been an actress, comedian, writer and linguist, and just recently started her own fashion line. "Your 40's are the best time of your life," she told me. "That's when you really have it figured out." 
One can only hope.

HEADLINE: As Economy Sours, Divorce Rate Rises 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
IN his 32 years as a divorce lawyer on Long Island, Stephen W. Schlissel of Mineola said he had never interviewed more potential clients than he had in the last three months.
 "You will see a dramatic upturn next year" in divorces on Long Island, Mr. Schlissel predicted, adding that the increase stems from the slowdown in the economy. 
 "In other recessions, the divorce business was superb," he said. "Some of my best years were when the economy starts to go sour." 
That was last true during the late 80's and early 90's, he said, when the Island was mired in a recession.
"To a person, lawyers are seeing 50 percent more potential clients than they did three years ago -- that's how dramatic the increase has been," Mr. Schlissel said.
Interviews with other divorce lawyers, marriage counselors and court officials all support Mr. Schlissel's observations: Long Island, which already has the largest number of contested divorces in the state, is headed for another record year. But Peter A. Sorrento, coordinating matrimonial court clerk for the State of New York, said no figures for 2001 would be available until the end of the year.
Alan L. Finkel, the director of the Divorce Mediation Center of Suffolk, said that last year his office, which is in Commack, handled about 200 cases. Already this year, he said, the number exceeds 160.
Dr. Louis Gallagher, a clinical psychologist and marital therapist in Smithtown, said his practice was also booming.
"I haven't seen it this busy in years," he said. "I have to shoehorn people in. The last two or three years have been absolutely nutty. I'm seeing couples for marital therapy and individuals as a result of marital problems."
The reasons that divorces are increasing as the economy is declining are varied, of course, but sometimes they are tied to occupation. "There are a lot of spouses who think that when their business is valued at its lowest, that is the time to get out of their marriage," Mr. Schlissel said, because alimony and support payments will be lower.
Elena Karabatos, a partner in Mr. Schlissel's firm, Schlissel, Ostrow, Karabatos, Poepplein & Taub, said that some professionals and people who worked in service industries were not as affected by the ups and downs of the economy.
"We tend to see couples seeking divorce when their home is at its peak value and their incomes are strong and stable," she said. "Clearly, when there is ample money to divide, it's easier to walk away from a marriage with some semblance of comfort. The professional person, such as a physician, is not necessarily going to feel the impact of a souring economy in the same way a business owner will. Therefore, this sector of the population continues to seek divorce irrespective of the economy."
Frederick J. Crockett III, the management analyst for the Supreme Court's matrimonial department in Suffolk County, said that last year, Nassau and Suffolk led the state's 62 counties in contested divorce cases. Suffolk had the most, 1,640 cases, followed by Nassau with 1,438. Well behind were New York County with 928 cases and Queens County with 862 cases.
The figures for uncontested divorces last year were 2,595 in Nassau and 2,755 in Suffolk. But New York County has the largest number of uncontested divorce cases in the state by far, usually 13,000 to 14,000 a year. But this year they are projected at 22,000.
Long Island also leads the state in the number of pending contested divorces. Stephen Gassman, a divorce lawyer in Garden City and a former president of the Nassau County Bar Association, said that Nassau and Suffolk "have more than double the number of pending contested matrimonial cases than any other of the 62 counties." In April, there were 1,403 pending cases in Nassau and 1,666 in Suffolk.
The numbers are so large that Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann, the Supreme Court's administrative judge for matrimonial matters, said she had added more judges on the Island. 
"Suffolk now has eight and a half judges, up from seven and a half last year, and Nassau six," up by a half, she said. The half figures represent judges who divide their time between divorces and other cases.
"The next nearest county in the state is New York County with four and a half judges," Justice Silbermann said.
A major reason for the backlog of contested cases on Long Island is the fact that many of the contested divorces involve a lot of money. The median income on the Island is $79,100, and that compounds the problem of trying to divide marital assets, said Justice Anthony Marano, the supervisory judge of the matrimonial parts of Supreme Court in Nassau County.
"It's not just a matter of listening to a few hours of testimony and then rendering a decision," Justice Marano said. "The issues are very sophisticated and complex because of the financials involved, and a case can go on for weeks and require a great deal of patience."
"These are not the kind of cases you can rush to complete," Mr. Marano added. "The parties have the ability to engage very talented attorneys -- the cream of the crop in the state -- who properly make use of all the tools available, which prolongs the litigation."
Mr. Finkel, the mediator, put the legal costs for a contested divorce that involves child custody at $50,000 to $60,000. A typical mediation of four to six one-hour sessions costs $1,500 to $2,500, he said.
Joan D. Atwood, the director of graduate programs in marriage andfamily therapy at Hofstra University, agreed that the standard of living on Long Island had a lot to do with the divorce rate.
"It costs a lot for a divorce, and people here make a lot," she said. "In New York State you need a reason to get a divorce -- there is no no-fault divorce here. And because you need a reason, you have to go through an attorney. Most people don't go to a divorce mediation service."
Dr. Gallagher, the clinical psychologist, said the high cost of living on Long Island made two wage earners a necessity in most families, and that this often contributed to stress in marriages.
"People have conflicts all the time, and one of the biggest is financial," he said. "If you have two wage earners, the strain on paying the bills is greater, and there are career pressures. Whose job is more important in terms of relocation and lifestyle issues? Who makes more? And a long commute can add to the stress, as can sharing day-to-day activities in the house."
For families with children, the stress is even greater because the children often have to be driven several miles to play with their friends.
"Years ago in the city, everything was vertical," Dr. Gallagher said. "There were a lot of people in one place. Here in suburbia, everything is horizontal. So it's not a matter of going to the fourth floor to see a friend, because he now lives four miles away."
The Internet is another factor contributing to divorces, said Ms. Karabatos, the lawyer. 
"What I see from my clients is that they lose intimacy in their marriage over time," she said. "At night, instead of watching television, they go to the computer and enter a chat room. It feels safe, and at first it's innocent. But with the computer they are much more intimate than they would be speaking to someone face-to-face, and conversations become regular over time. Before you know it, their curiosity grows, and they want to meet."
"I've had three separate cases where the issue involved erotic interchanges on the Internet," Ms. Karabatos said. "In one case, the spouse claimed his wife was having an affair, and she insisted it was limited to the Internet," but he didn't believe her.
"What makes this scary," she added, "is that they went to the chat room not to have an affair but just to have a conversation, add spice to their lives, spruce up the day."

HEADLINE: Seeing Another Age On Separate Stages 

BYLINE:  By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
SUDDENLY, fleetingly, in Fairfield County, a theater fanatic's crazy dream has leaped into real time. Two esoteric plays, each charting another age, another world, are happening in professional productions on two separate stages here.
 One, "Princess Turandot," has grandly opened the season in a perennial playhouse rooted in legend. The other, "Diana of Dobson's," is a long shot by a start-up company in a makeshift space. 
 Time-honored as the Westport Country Playhouse is, a 1762 fable, best known as a Puccini opera, now reimagined as a flamboyant cartoon in a fusion of styles, is not a summer theater's stock fare. But, as if in celebration of new artistic life for the 71-year-old theater, "Princess Turandot" is the first of five productions, classic and contemporary, under the new artistic director, Joanne Woodward.
As it happens, both productions come to Connecticut from Manhattan. For the Westport, the Blue Light Theater Company's "Turandot," closed off-Broadway since Dec. 30, has been reassembled. In Fairfield, the move from the Mint Theater was direct, and more than that, the practical representation of the new company's philosophy.
Miles Marek of Bridgeport, the producing director, and Stephen Stout of Southport, the artistic director, mean to import "funky, out-of-the-way material," in the words of Carole Schweid, the marketing director, for audiences who may not know where to find it in Manhattan.
Cost cutting for theatergoers -- a trip to New York, parking, all that -- is as much a part of the new group's mission as adventure and risk. And for once, Connecticut is the destination, not the tryout place or the tour stopover.
"But we don't need obtuse mission statements," Mr. Marek said the day after last Saturday's opening of "Diana of Dobson's," a 1908 play about the sordid trap of sweatshops (exploitation of women ), the big chance of the great escape ( money ) and real happiness ( love ). "The play was prescient and scandalous in its day," Mr. Stout said.
"Diana" may sound like a tract, but it's a romance, wittily written by Cicely Hamilton. Performances are at the Wien Experimental Theater at Fairfield University's Quick Center through next Sunday. (For ticket information, call (203) 254-4010).
"We're shoppers for plays," Mr. Stout added, emphasizing that social significance is not what the new company is about. It is the rarefied showcase experience and "a little of everything" that the two men want to bring to Fairfield.
For the showcase is in a New York class by itself. Under a showcase code, Actors Equity allows members to perform in plays for no more than 21 performances in spaces that hold less than 100 seats. And here's the kicker: no pay for the actors, only a small -- very small -- travel allowance. But once a showcase production is moved, say, to Connecticut, it must operate under one of many so-called small professional theater contracts. Actors must be paid a minimum wage and theater capacities can be larger. And an audience's frame of reference is expanded. "When I go to New York, showcases do the kind of stuff I'd want to see," Mr. Marek said.
The economic benefits for the performer are obvious. Don't forget pension and health insurance. "The actors come out here, get a paycheck, a whole new appreciative audience and a few weeks in the country," Mr. Marek said."
The "showcase production world," as Mr. Marek put it, are to be found anywhere in Manhattan. Mr. Marek estimated that there are about 600such shoestring productions a year in New York or in the suburbs. A certain number are reviewed. Otherwise, it's pot luck. "If you live in New York, you might stumble on one," Mr. Marek said, "but not in Connecticut."
For its first season, the company's limit is three shows. That's all the availability of the university's rented space (capacity: 120) allows. "Our goal is to find our own theater in Fairfield," Mr. Marek said, and he has his eye on one. "We hope to nestle in the downtown business district, Mr. Marek said.
In the meantime, "Concertina's Rainbow," a new play by Glyn O'Malley, is to have a three-week run in September. It was produced last month by the Cherry Lane Alternative, a mentor project in Greenwich Village.
"We're finding a way to build a bridge between the experimentation and vitality going on in New York and our resources in Connecticut," Mr. Marek said. "We're setting it all up in our own backyard and finding out if we can raise audiences and their theater consciousness in Fairfield."
"Five years ago, this wouldn't have been possible in Fairfield. Now we know this town will respond to helping us continue," Mr. Stout added. About a new home for a new company, he said, "I'm concerned. But I'm not worried."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
For Him the Toll Smells

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: POINT PLEASANT 

 BODY:
THE question was: When did the revolution actually begin? Raymond Neveil thought for a long moment.
 The question seems relevant as New Jersey observes the 225th anniversary of the American Revolution. But in this case, the issue does not concern a levy on tea, but tolls on the Garden State Parkway. 
 And the authority isn't King George III but the New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates and maintains the 173-mile toll road. The highway with the seemingly endless collection of barricades demanding 35 cents (actually, there 11 toll barriers, and of the 91 exits 19 have toll booths) has led to the emergence of Citizens Against Tolls, a group formed more than a year ago that has succeeded in helping to force the issue into the gubernatorial race. 
"It was in October 1999, in the United Methodist Church in Manasquan," Mr. Neveil of Brielle, founder and president of the group, recalled.
Mr. Neveil (pronounced NEE-vil), a 77-year-old retired manager for the New Jersey Bell in New Jersey, AT&T in New York and a trustee of the church, said he and about eight other trustees had been gathered in the red-brick church to discuss business.
But afterward, the subject of parkway tolls somehow came up, Mr. Neveil recalled. "Someone complained about the tolls," he said, "and so I said, 'Well instead of just talking, let's do something about it.' "
Since then, under Mr. Neveil's leadership, the group has lobbied hard, met with legislators, gubernatorial candidates and the acting governor. It has also issued a financial report on phasing out the tolls, and has staged events to raise awareness of the subject -- as if New Jerseyans' awareness had to be raised.
Next Saturday, as the Battle of Monmouth is being re-enacted in Freehold, Citizens Against Tolls will lead a caravan of cars along the parkway in Monmouth and Ocean Counties protesting the tolls. 
"We had a big rally in Belmar last summer," said Mr. Neveil, as he sat with his wife, Olga, on a recent day in the Shore Rehabilitation Institute after several hours of therapy for hip replacement surgery. "We had gotten some nice contributions by the way, so we hired a plane to fly a banner advertising our group. Parkway officials heard about it and they hired a plane to advertise E-ZPass."
So far, the group has attracted about 600 members, gathered more than 18,000 signatures, set up a post office box -- Post Office Box 497, Manasquan, N.J. 08736 -- and had close to 30,000 hits on its Web site, www.endtolls.com., Mr. Neveil said.
After the October 1999 church meeting, Mr. Neveil wrote a letter to The Asbury Park Press elaborating on the group's goals. Although a meeting in December drew only about 25 people, the January meeting, which featured a speaker from NoMoreTolls.org, a Washington-based group, attracted 80 people.
Among those who read about Citizens Against Tolls was John Millett, a 36-year-old Millstone resident.
"Ray impressed the heck out of me because he's just a class-act guy," said Mr. Millett, the organization's secretary."
Mr. Millett was also impressed that Mr. Neveil, a railroad buff and something of a self-taught transportation expert, had been collecting information about the parkway from newspapers and magazines since the 1980's and assembled a report documenting the waste he perceived.
Mr. Neveil said that before forming Citizens Against Tolls, he had been writing to legislators and newspapers about phasing out the tolls.
Before retiring in 1983, he traveled the parkway for much of his 38 years with Bell in New York and New Jersey and as a consultant to Bell Labs for 4 years and accumulated a list of grievances: traffic jams, pollution, waste of fuel; executives making up to $140,000 a year and getting use of a car; the cost of employing 350 toll takers; a 13-cent cost to collect the 35-cent toll (the authority insists the cost is 8 cents).
Dennis Ingoglia, a spokesman for the parkway, said that he and Mr. Neveil had never met, though they had exchanged many letters.
"He seems like an intelligent person," Mr. Ingoglia said.
But, he added, the Legislature created the highway agency in 1952 to collect tolls for the operation and maintenance of the parkway, and only state officials could change it.
Another group, the New Jersey Alliance for Action, which has studied the financial implications of eliminating the toll, thinks the idea is as bad as a set of square tires. Donald Scarry, an economist who was hired by the alliance to look at the bottom line, put it like this: The state's three million households would have to pay $75 to $100 a year in taxes to make up for a loss in revenue of $120 million to $200 million needed to maintain and operate the toll road.
Citizens Against Tolls might have remained obscure had it not caught the attention of a high-profile ally. Mayor Bret D.Schundler of Jersey City, who is currently seeking the Republican nomination for governor, met with the group last at the Princess Maria diner in Wall Township that since has become its unofficial headquarters.
Mr. Schundler, in a telephone interview, said that he also had been interested in ending the tolls, and while putting together his campaign heard about the effort.
"So, I said to my staff, 'You know, we could save some time to see what these guys came up with,' " Mr. Shundler recalled. "We found ourselves to be kindred spirits."
Indeed, Mr. Schundler was the featured speaker at the group's meeting last July, and has attended several meetings and rallies since then, including one in Waretown last March at which he signed a pledge to eliminate tolls.
In the world of political realities, the question was then raised: Is Citizens Against Tolls just a front for the Schundler candidacy.
"No, no, no," said Mr. Neveil. "Our goal is to get rid of tolls no matter who's elected."
He added: "We're not endorsing anyone, as such. We support Schundler but we support any candidate that will get rid of tolls."
To that end, Mr. Neveil and others have met with the staff of Mayor James McGreevey of Woodbridge, the Democratic candidate for governor, and last week Mr. Millett met with the staff of former Representative Bob Franks, Mr. Schundler's opponent for the Republican nomination. But the candidates have yet to say if they endorse the group's aims.
Members of the organization have also met with the Assembly Transportation Committee and the staff of Acting Governor Donald DiFrancesco, though for now they have failed to win their support.
While not endorsing the elimination of tolls, Mr. DiFrancesco has called for a toll-free Labor Day on the parkway and directed the Department of Transportation to draft a plan to remove the parkway's 11 toll plazas by 2011. That would leave 19 exits where tolls would be collected. He tried to have the tolls waived for Memorial Day, but found that the wheels of government move slower than an old Plymouth on the parkway on a sunny Saturday in August.
Mr. Neveil was not impressed. He saw the plan to eliminate the barriers as a stalling tactic that gained the governor much-needed favorable publicity and the toll-free day as a way of pushing any controversial decisions off until after the November election.
The Neveils have traveled extensively in this country as well as Europe and the Far East, and Mr. Neivel said of his wife, "She wants me to get back to being retired so we can start doing some traveling again."
But Mrs. Neveil didn't seem to be in any particular hurry for her husband to quit the revolution just yet.
"He's put a lot of heart and soul into it," she said. "He's gone so far with it that it would be awful if it just petered out."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property; 
Web Services Take Measure Of Markets

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
A YEAR ago, some real estate executives thought they knew how the rapidly developing Internet technology was going to transform their industry. Real estate was going to be standardized so it could be traded like stocks, bonds or commodities. The vision was that a Nasdaq-like market would develop that would bring efficiency to a highly fragmented market.
 The crystal balls were clouded. Almost no progress has been made in transforming real estate into something that trades like winter wheat, and some ambitious undertakings have failed in the process. 
 But companies, particularly those whose focus is on disseminating information, have succeeded despite the wreckage in the dot-com sector. Executives of the surviving concerns now talk in terms of making incremental progress -- and actually making a profit -- rather than deploying huge amounts of capital to become dominant immediately. 
Each of the surviving companies has a slightly different approach to the information it provides and the way it gets customers to pay for services. Talk of disintermediation -- that is, doing deals directly between landlord and tenant without the assistance of a broker -- has almost ceased. Instead, the focus of current approaches is to use the power of Internet technology to help ease the inherently complex business of real estate transactions.
"You have to look at the value proposition of the broker," said Andrew C. Florance, the chairman of CoStar Group, the largest of the information services companies, which is headquartered in Bethesda, Md. "The tenant moves once or twice in a career, while the broker is in the market every day and knows all the pitfalls. The tenant is not going to wander into that big, hairy jungle alone."
Nevertheless, brokerage and management companies are working to use the Internet to speed up the pace of transactions. Project Octane, a high powered consortium that includes the New York-based Insignia/ESG along with CB Richard Ellis, Trammel Crow and Jones Lang LaSalle, last week announced the formation of Octane Ventures, which it describes as "a collaborative online transaction services platform."
"Right now, if you want to lease 25,000 square feet of commercial space, it takes a year between when you start looking for space and when you conclude the deal," said Joseph L. Fitzpatrick, the executive vice president of Project Octane. Octane Ventures, he said, will work with an existing online company, workplaceIQ, to reduce the time to complete a transaction by making information available electronically. Octane Ventures is buying a 24 percent stake in workplaceIQ for $10 million. 
Some of the companies that have established interactive Web sites have deep roots in the real estate information business. "Our Web site is a logical extension of our books," said Yale Robbins, the chief executive of the company bearing his name, which has been publishing magazine-format guides to real estate markets, titled Office Buildings, for more than 20 years.
But while the books provide data on locations, floor sizes and building services, the information is static, changing only with annual editions of the books. The Web site, MrOfficespace.com, is dynamic, with the listings changing as existing space is leased and new space comes onto the market. The site went into active operation last fall.
Although the system has a high-tech feel, the data behind it is collected the old fashioned way, with researchers calling building owners and managers and asking about space that has been added or removed from the market. "We actively canvass building owners about space," Mr. Robbins said. "We check with them every 30 days."
Brokers are the main consumers of these information services, and some say the wide availability of the data gives brokers and smaller companies the ability to compete with much larger ones.
"Historically, big companies like Cushman & Wakefield and Insignia managed so much property that they had early access to information about what spaces were coming to market," said Marcus Rayner, a principal at Cresa Partners, a brokerage in New York that represents tenants. "The development of third-party information services helped level the playing field by giving smaller brokers in the city information that only the big companies had previously."
Cushman & Wakefield and Insignia, the two largest commercial brokerages in the city, have divergent views on the value of collecting data internally. Thomas Falus, who is president of Cushman & Wakefield's new ventures group, said the company decided last year to sell its database to a company formerly known as RELocate, and later as RealtyIQ, because the growing availability of third-party information made it unnecessary for it to continue to collect figures internally. 
"As commercially available data became good enough to use, we decided we did not need to be in that business," Mr. Falus said. "We got out of that business because others were getting into it. And it allowed us to redeploy our capital into higher-value-added applications."
BUT officials of Insignia/ESG said there is value in keeping track of its core market, New York, as a reality check on third-party services. "In New York we believe in home-grown information," said Joseph R. Harbert, the chief operating office of Insignia's New York metropolitan area.
"We have a staff of 25 people in the region to double check" the information obtained from commercial information providers, he said, adding that the company's brokers are responsible for sharing the information they obtain with the research staff. In general, industry executives say, brokers are more likely to obtain the fuller information than researchers, because the broker carries the potential of a deal with his inquiries, something researchers do not have to offer.
Property managers find the information services useful as well. "I use the information as a competitive cross check," said Fred C. Posniak, a vice president of W&M Properties, the operating arm of a large real estate investment company. "It helps us determine what rent to ask, the amount of free rent to offer and the amount of tenant improvement. It is another useful tool."
Although W&M has its own Web site listing the available space in its portfolio, it also provides information to nationally established services like CoStar so that brokers unfamiliar with W&M can see what is available in its buildings.
Each of the information services has its own approach to getting paid, and there appears to be a consensus among the companies that advertising alone is not sufficient to support such an operation. CoStar's clients must pay to subscribe to gain access to its services, which include listings of available property, financial information and information for preparing studies of comparable transactions.
Company officials said a solo broker buying the basic property availability service would pay about $300 a month for a single market. For a national company with multiple offices across the country, the charge would come to several million dollars a year, they said.
Henry Robbins, executive vice president of Yale Robbins, said the basic listings in MrOfficespace.com are free to property owners and managers. But enhancements, like multiple pictures of the interior and exterior of the property, video tours and floor plans carry a fee. The company also leverages its data and adds to revenue by maintaining Web sites for brokerage companies and a business publication, Crain's New York Business. 
"Other people make you pay for information," Yale Robbins said. "We will remain a free portal and make our living on the enhancements." 
Free is not a popular word at a two-year old competitor, Cityfeet.com. Although it initially made listings available free as a way of getting known, the company now charges $59 a month apiece to show available property, and the co-founders say the revenue is essential to economic health.
"You have to make money to stay in business," said Matthew Shulman, one of the founders and chief financial officer of the company. He said this focus on income, careful control of expenses and a restrained approach to growth are reasons the company is still in operation while other once-sexier dot-coms have fallen by the wayside.
Cityfeet, at its core, is a marketing service rather than a research tool like CoStar, said Guy Shanon, the chief executive. Although the company has many of the classic earmarks of a dot-com, with young people working at desks in a single open space, Mr. Shanon said the company had recently started using job titles to give itself a more mainstream business approach.
The key event for Cityfeet came this February when it went from free listing to the monthly charge. As of January it had about 3,000 listings. After the charge was imposed, about 55 percent of the listings remained. This conversion rate is considered good in Internet circles, Mr. Shanon said.
SINCE a Cityfeet listing is the electronic equivalent of a newspaper classified ad, the company is trying to arrange affiliations with newspapers in the markets where it operates.
In New York, Cityfeet has an association with New York Times Digital, a unit of The New York Times Company. Cityfeet maintains the commercial real estate listing part of the Times Web site and duplicates those listings on its own Web site. Mr. Shanon said advertisers who called The Times to place listings in the newspaper were asked if they wanted to have their offerings carried on the Web sites for an additional fee. 
Mr. Shanon said he plans a similar arrangement with The Boston Globe and Boston.com, which are also Times Company properties. Similar affiliations will be sought with newspapers in other cities, he said.
"Newspapers are the most credible in real estate advertising, and they bring us exposure," Mr. Shanon said.
Unlike companies that are going after large corporate accounts, Mr. Shulman said, Cityfeet is focusing on smaller spaces and companies. "Our site is designed for the one-off guy who has a space or two available," Mr. Shulman said. "He can pay for the listing with a credit card while he is online."
Mr. Shulman said the company is currently profitable in New York and is approaching profitability in other cities. He said previous experience with the Internet convinced the founders that while customers are willing to get information online, they are much more reluctant to do business that way.
"It takes a long time to change people's behavior," he said. That is why the company did not attempt the grow-fast strategy that was the downfall of other dot-coms. "Most businesses are built slowly," he said. "It is very rare to grow fast and then cash out."
Andrew Florance of CoStar said his information service is to real estate what Bloomberg News is to securities markets. Both combine historical data with analysis and breaking news to support people making market decisions. Mr. Florance said CoStar employs about 900 people, mostly in research.
Mr. Florance, who has been developing CoStar since the mid-1980's, said commercial real estate lends itself to rigorous financial analysis more than residential transactions do. "Residential is more emotionally driven, but commercial is information-based," he said.
Costar, he said, offers a portfolio of products that include financial analysis and data about comparable transactions in addition to the listing of space for lease and sale. He said eight of those products have revenue of more than $1 million annually and three have revenues of more than $10 million.
CoStar, a publicly traded company, raised $23 million in an initial public offering in 1998 and $100 million more in a subsequent offering in 1999. The company has incurred losses of as much as $50 million a year, but Mr. Florance attributes that to the capital expenditures needed to establish a nationwide network of offices to collect and analyze data.
In the New York area, the company has about 50 people keeping track of about one billion square feet of space, according to Stephen B. Allegro, the northeast regional director, including 3,817 buildings in Manhattan.
Operating the network is a lot less expensive that setting it up, Mr. Florance said, and he predicts that shrinking costs will allow the company to start posting profits by the fourth quarter of this year. He said the company should have about $70 million in revenues this year.
Many companies have tried to get into the real estate information services business, and the shakeout in the last year or so has been severe. According to Mr. Florance, there were about 400 companies in this line of business last year; currently, the number is down to about 150, he said.
One notable casualty was RealtyIQ, which was founded in New York in 1991 by Bruce Weissberg as RE/Locate. Real estate executives said the company succeeded as a lower cost alternative to CoStar.
In 1999 Frontline Capital Group, an affiliate of the Reckson real estate investment trust, invested in RE/Locate and transformed it into RealtyIQ. The company attempted to establish a national network similar to CoStar's, based on the database purchased from Cushman & Wakefield.
But the effort collapsed when it was unable to lure enough customers and could not obtain additional financing, according to real estate executives. In April, the database containing details of more than 225,000 office and industrial properties was purchased by Octane Ventures. Thus, the data collected by Cushman & Wakefield ended up in the possession of an entity partly owned by its New York archrival, Insignia/ESG.
Another highly touted information and transactions services start-up, Zethus Inc., never even got under way, despite being backed by the Wall Street investment bank Goldman Sachs Group and signing Cushman & Wakefield as a customer.
"Zethus ran out of money -- it is as simple as that," said Mr. Falus of the Cushman & Wakefield new ventures group. "The bubble burst and the capital markets said no. It's a shame." 
An information services company oriented toward investors rather than brokers that has been operating quietly for the last two decades is Reis Inc. Lloyd Lynford, the president of Reis, said the company has begun an Internet version of its service, Reis SE, standing for Subscriber Edition, to provide investors and decision makers at institutions with online information on current and projected rents, vacancies, expenses and landlord concessions
WE support decision makers with real market information," Mr. Lynford said. "In addition to asking rent, we report on free rent periods, tenant improvement and signing rent." He said Reis is a subscription-based company, that sells information services as well as individual reports.
Its experience with Zethus notwithstanding, Mr. Falus said Cushman & Wakefield would continue to participate in new economy ventures, the current round more specialized than Zethus. C.&W. has purchased a 25 percent interest in e PropertyTax. Mr. Falus said that validating the accuracy of property taxes is "a miserable area" for property managers and that this company could help in this function.
Cushman & Wakefield has also purchased 50 percent of the Business Integration Group of Tempe, Ariz., which is known as BIG-e Real Estate. Mr. Falus said the company intends to automate five major back office functions, including lease administration, space administration, preventive maintenance, work-flow management and construction management and project tracking.
Mr. Falus said Cushman & Wakefield expects to decrease the percentage of its ownership stake in these companies as they become successful. And he said the company was still looking for other opportunities to ease what he terms the "pain points" in the real estate business.
"We do not have the ability to do the technology ourselves," he said. "All we can do is find the best of the breed and make investments."
