HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
From Dead Bank To Red Bank

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: RED BANK 

 BODY:
It was the mid 1980's, and downtown stores were being forced out of business by the invasion of sprawling new malls, the population was slipping and the commercial and residential tax base was eroding.
 Red Bank was known as Dead Bank. 
 "The attitude of government was not cooperative toward the business community, and the results were evident," said Edward J. McKenna Jr., a Democrat who was elected mayor in 1990 promising to turn the shopping district around after more than a decade of Republican rule.
Indeed, since the creation of a special improvement district downtown 10 years ago, store vacancies have plummeted to about 1 percent from 35 percent; trendy shops and restaurants have opened; an old movie house has been converted into a performing arts center named after its native son, Count Basie; storefronts have dressed themselves in new facades; and more than a score of special events like the recent three-day jazz, blues and food festival called Riverfest have attracted tens of thousands of visitors.
While there is also a growing number of antique stores, any number of brokerage houses are also situated here. 
Bruce Springsteen, who lives in nearby Rumson, thinks nothing of making an impromptu midnight visit to Jack's Music Store to see how his new CD is selling. The independent film maker Kevin Smith has an office and a comic book store and has even shot some scenes here of films like "Chasing Amy" and "Dogma."
People can dine at any of 80 restaurants and then drift over to a women's boutique like Coco Pari, which is still open at ll on Saturday night.
Yet despite the newfound prosperity in this 1.7 square mile town on the Navesink River -- a mixture of blue- and white-collar families -- sentiment appears to be growing that there has been too much economic development downtown -- bringing with it increased traffic and parking problems -- and not enough being done for other parts of town.
Just how much dissatisfaction there actually is is hard to say in this town -- about 25 percent black and 6 percent Hispanic -- but the only Republican to win a seat on the council in recent years, Jennifer Beck, a 34-year-old public relations woman in Trenton, ran on the slogan "For the whole town, not just the downtown." 
Moreover, she raised enough public concern over a proposal by the administration to build a 570-space parking garage at a cost of $8.4 million that the Democratically controlled council voted it down in April. Some see the defeat, despite Red Bank's past successes, as a sea change in public attitude over how the town has grown and where it is going.
"I don't think there is anyone of us who would say the revival of Red Bank hasn't been positive," Ms. Beck said. "I think the people of Red Bank are very proud of seeing the downtown doing so well."
But with that acknowledgement comes some concern "that the pendulum may have gone too far and that we need to refocus our energy and resources on our neighborhoods."
For his part, Mayor McKenna, a 51-year-old lawyer, said the downtown revitalization benefited the whole town of 11,800 by raising property values and stabilizing the tax base. "We made a conscious effort to sit down and make our town user-friendly for the business community with the goal of protecting our residential districts," he said.
In the beginning, Mr. McKenna and his Democratic colleagues held public meetings and talked about the creation of a special improvement district. In 1991, the district came into existence with the creation of the Red Bank RiverCenter, an alliance of the business community and local government consisting of an executive director and a 30-member board to oversee the revitalization. At first, commercial property owners agreed to pay 28 cents on every $100 of assessed valuation for improvements in the district. That is now up to 36 cents for property owners on Broad Street and 31 cents for the rest of the district.
The McKenna administration also cut loose members of the planning and zoning boards who did not agree with their vision to speed up the approval process for potential new businesses.
"The McKenna administration was a new, charismatic, high-energy movement," said Tracy Challenger, who stepped down as executive director of RiverCenter last fall, after five years. "And it was really a sweeping change."
Aside from promoting Red Bank's reputation inside and outside of town, Ms. Challenger is given credit for starting Streetscape, a project that included widening the sidewalks, laying bricks, putting up benches and installing period lighting in keeping with the late-1890's look of Broad Street, the main shopping thoroughfare.
Streetscape also encouraged the renovation of about 60 buildings that had been neglected for years, she said.
"I'd have to say the revitalization helped, compared to where it was before all the revitalization started, absolutely," said David Prown, the 41-year-old third generation owner of Prown's, a variety store dating to 1925. "Eighty-nine to '93 were just horrid years."
Nicole Caivano, the third-generation owner of Mustillo's, a bridal shop dating to 1942, said that the company had built a steady client base over the years, but that the town's revival expanded it.
"A lot of people come in and say, 'Oh, we had dinner at the Bistro and we noticed the dress in your window,' " said Ms. Caivano. "So I think the restaurants are very good for business."
After scouting locations for about a year with her husband, Anthony, Kimberly Lindau opened the women's store Coco Pari. 
"It's been phenomenal," Mr. Lindau said one recent afternoon as he stood near the entrance to the store, which opened about a year ago. "I have friends that have stores in South Beach, SoHo, Boston, California and I've never seen a location like this. It's virtually 12 months a year."
He said a friend in the Hamptons was paying three times the rent, but business was dead after 5 P.M. and in the off-season. "She pays $38,000 a year," he added. "She could have rented a store here for like maybe $7,500."
Initially, the improvement district was supposed to include the commercial areas on the West Side of town, but a lawsuit by a property owner in the neighborhood -- which is largely residential -- squelched that. Officials decided to limit the district to downtown and eventually include other areas -- something that has not yet happened.
But now, said Mary Mann, who succeeded Ms. Challenger as executive director of RiverCenter last November, resentment had been growing as residents saw how the downtown had benefited. 
"Many assume the borough has been pouring money into the downtown, but they don't realize that RiverCenter is privately funded," said Ms. Mann. "Therefore they think all the events, marketing, promotion bricks and mortar, including Streetscape, benches and facade improvements are funded by the borough when in fact they are funded by RiverCenter."
Streetscape, for instance, was a $1.8 million project, of which RiverCenter paid $1.3 millon out of assessments of the improvement district, Ms. Challenger said, allowing the government to use its resources for such public improvements as Riverside Gardens, a park with a circular lawn surrounded by elevated gardens leading to the river.
In her few months on the job, Ms. Mann has been working to open lines of communication with other parts of town and dispel the notion that downtown merchants were receiving preferential treatment. She recently met the West Side Community Group, a homeowners' organization, and also made it a point for RiverCenter to create events and promotions that were borough-wide.
"I do see my role as showing the benefits of the special improvement district to the whole town and using the special improvement district as a way to unite the whole town," Ms. Mann said.
Danny Murphy, the owner of Danny's Steak House on the West Side who is president of the Arts and Antiques District, another nonprofit group, praised Ms. Mann's efforts. A member of the RiverCenter board for nine years, he quit about a year ago because he felt the organization was not showing enough interest in the West Side.
"Since Mary came on board, a lot of that is past history," said Mr. Murphy.
As for the parking situation, Mayor McKenna said that despite the recent successes, he did not see the increased traffic as a bad thing.
"If we didn't have the traffic, we wouldn't have the people," he said, "which means we wouldn't have the business."

HEADLINE: One Setback Can Send Arts Group to Brink 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA KUEHL 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
THE closing of the American Stage Company was not the only disturbing news to hit New Jersey's arts community recently.
 Strapped for cash, the Playwrights Theater of New Jersey in Madison scrubbed performances of the winning plays in its statewide young playwrights contest. Peters Valley Craftsmen, a craft education center in Layton, begged for emergency aid to avoid bankruptcy. At the American Repertory Ballet in New Brunswick, subscriptions were down; at the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival in Madison, the deficit was up. 
 Don't blame the economy, arts executives said. Overambitious programming, new leadership and even the vigor of the marketplace not so long ago were to blame.
On a deeper level, they said, inadequate financing caused many of the problems. But that is a persistent threat whatever the Dow Jones does.
Arts nonprofits generally rely on government grants and private aid for a substantial portion of their budgets. So in good times and bad they must hang their fate on the fitful generosity of strangers: "Anyone who would care to donate money," Ken Pierson, the executive director of Peters Valley, said hopefully, "we're more than happy to take it."
In such a volatile environment, a single setback -- a grant that falls through or a snowstorm on a show date -- can upset the balance.
Overambition caused the near-fatal fall of the craft center, which was more than $200,000 in debt, board members said. State and foundation contributions were rising, in recognition of the center's programming, even as expenses dwarfed income.
At the American Repertory Ballet, a transition in leadership led to rocky times, said Oceola Bragg, the managing director. Graham Lustig, the artistic director appointed in mid-1999, has mounted works that won critical acclaim but left some former subscribers cold, she said. The company's subscription package also changed, which irritated others.
This winter, when a snowstorm forced the cancellation of two performances of "The Nutcracker," Ms. Bragg said, "we lost $40,000, easily."
Like Peters Valley, the ballet company turned to the state arts council. Last month the council announced a pilot program to help groups qualify for emergency aid to regain their stride. The craft center, the ballet and the Cape May Jazz Festival, which has had periodic budget imbalances, will be the first to benefit.
Meanwhile, at the Shakespeare festival, the deficit rose to about $150,000 from about $50,000, said Bonnie J. Monte, the artistic director. Out of a $2.4 million budget, that's small, but it is a reminder of a tough year in which many staff members left, she said.
"It all comes back to funding," she said. "I can't compete with the salaries in the profit world." With the vacancies, tasks essential for successful fund-raising didn't get done.
When donations fell short at the Playwrights Theater, the artistic director, John Pietrowski, had to make a choice: cut a program or suspend making payments against a deficit.
The ethos used to be, "Hey, we're artists, and the arts are always in trouble financially," so deficits are no big deal, he said. "That isn't true anymore." He chose to sacrifice the young playwrights showcase to live another day.
"Sometimes if you're not keeping track of your finances very well, and if you're not willing to kind of look at the long term," he said, "you can run yourself out of business."

HEADLINE: Waiting To Go On 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA KUEHL 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
WHEN the American Stage Company in Teaneck, spiraling into debt, canceled the second half of its season in March, arts executives across New Jersey double-checked their books and counted their blessings.
 "It's like, 'There but for the grace of God . . . ,' " said Laura Ekstrand, the artistic director of the Dreamcatcher Repertory Theater in Bloomfield. "When something like that happens, it rattles people." 
 The crisis recalled the arts community's distress last fall after the collapse of the Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick. In each case, public and private grants and donations could not keep pace with a respected troupe's artistic ambitions. It's a bitter reversal of fortune feared by many New Jersey artists, who must compete in a crowded and talent-rich field for limited money. 
To help others avoid that fate, arts supporters have been lobbying lawmakers here for $5 million more for the New Jersey State Council on the Arts to distribute to the state's theaters, performance halls, dance companies, orchestras and art museums.
But as the Legislature prepares to vote later this month on the budget for the 2002 fiscal year, the precarious economy and the sobering news that state revenues may fall short of projections by about $1 billion appear to have undermined the campaign.
"I don't want to give a false sense of hope," said Assemblyman Leonard Lance, the chairman of the General Assembly's Budget Committee. "We are going to have to tighten our belts to some extent, and I'm not sure there can be an increase in various programs."
Ann Marie Miller, the executive director of ArtPride, countered gamely, "There's always hope." Her group works to raise appreciation and support for the arts. "We can't just freeze at the point where we are right now," she warned.
This fiscal year the state budgeted $21.9 million to the arts council and specific arts groups. The proposed budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1 dips to $20.7 million, or less than one-tenth of 1 percent of the state's overall budget of more than $23 billion.
Meanwhile, demand for state support this year was the highest ever, with more than 200 arts groups seeking $32.7 million. According to arts council figures, about 165 split less than $19.5 million, and $4.1 million of that went to three heavyweights: the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra and New Jersey Performing Arts Center, both in Newark, and the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.
Arts executives describe the competition for a share of that appropriation, and for corporate and foundation money, as brutal and draining. Mark Roxey, co-founder of the Roxey Ballet Company in Lambertville, which received no state support this year, said the struggle took an emotional and physical toll. Without adequate financing, he said, "you have to question how long you can sustain that quality and that level of work."
Across the state, the stress is starting to show. Usually arts executives vent about perceived injustices in one-on-one conversations: rural groups complain about the favored status of urban ones, while small or struggling groups bemoan operating in the shadows of large, established ones. But a recent falling-out between some South Jersey groups and the arts council has been uncharacteristically noisy and public.
At issue is whether the council has shortchanged the south of some $2 million, in violation of four-year-old budget language intended to redress what some in the south say is the historic underfinancing of cultural development there. Council members deny the accusation and Attorney General John J. Farmer Jr. has backed them; a Senate committee, whose chairman is from South Jersey, devoted an afternoon to airing the grievance. South Jersey lawmakers have vowed to tighten the language to make sure that 25 percent of the arts council's grants end up in the south.
"I've always taken the position there is no North Jersey, there is no South Jersey, there is no East or West," said Leonard M. Fisher, the chairman of the arts council. "We are all one family." When he conveys that in speeches, some people applaud; others glower.
For those hoping to heal the family's dysfunction, the benchmark year is 1989, when the arts appropriation topped $23 million -- almost 0.2 percent of the state's $11.9 billion budget. But in 1991, a recession led lawmakers to cut the arts budget to $11.7 million. As the economy recovered, the arts appropriation grew, but it has never regained its 1989 level. Making matters worse, Ms. Miller said, the current allocation is equivalent to less than $16 million in 1989 dollars.
Looked at another way, if the arts appropriation once again accounted for the same percentage of the state budget as it did in 1989, the arts community would share $46 million in 2002.
In New Jersey, groups can ask the state for up to 20 percent of their annual operating budgets. On average, North Jersey grant recipients must settle for about 8 percent, while recipients in South Jersey receive about 16 percent to help compensate for the lack of corporate support there, said Barbara Russo, executive director of the arts council.
For this fiscal year, NJPAC asked for $2 million in operating support -- about 9 percent of its projected operating budget -- and got $1.5 million, even as the arts council's grant panel lauded NJPAC's programming as "high quality, diverse and challenging." The New Jersey Symphony asked for $2.6 million -- 20 percent of its budget -- and got less than $1.6 million. Paper Mill requested $2 million and got slightly more than $1 million -- less than 6 percent of its budget.
Still, for struggling groups that would rejoice to receive an extra $10,000 or $20,000 -- or anything at all -- such numbers provoke envy, as does this fact of life: groups that draw large audiences and hefty state support also siphon big donations from individuals and corporations.
For example, the Prudential Insurance Company of America has given NJPAC about $14.7 million since 1995, including lines of credit, a Prudential spokeswoman said. And this year, more than a dozen individuals gave $10,000 or more to Paper Mill.
Arts nonprofits generally count on receiving 40 percent or more of their budgets from corporate and individual donations and government aid. Nationwide, donations are more likely to flow to religion, education and health and human services organizations than to the arts, according to Giving USA 2001, an annual report on philanthropy. In New Jersey, arts executives complain that many corporations are reluctant to give.
"This is a state that is one of the richest -- you think I'm going to say in money, it is -- but it's one of the most culturally rich states in the nation," said Bonnie J. Monte, the artistic director of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival. "And that brings the state a huge amount of economic advantages. And not just economic advantages, it makes the state very special. And I wish that people paid a little bit more attention to that."
Two of the state's biggest corporate donors, Prudential and Johnson & Johnson, increased their grants to the arts this fiscal year, officials said. "We recognize the value the arts play in making a healthy community," said Michael Bzdak, the director of corporate contributions at Johnson & Johnson in New Brunswick. And Prudential, celebrating 125 years in Newark, gave almost $9 million to the arts through the Prudential Foundation, a spokeswoman said.
But some corporations have other charitable priorities, said Barbara Rambo, the executive director of the Council of New Jersey Grantmakers. "It's tough when you're focusing on the arts," she said; businesses tend to give to organizations "which mesh nicely with their business mission."
Among foundations, the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation in Morristown has given $44.5 million to arts groups and programs since 1976. That begins to explain why, when "Dodge" is uttered, some arts executives practically genuflect.
Apart from the money, they praise Dodge for its approach to growth. The foundation sponsors workshops that teach nonprofits how to reshape their management, to reap the most from their assets and to weather inevitable transitions and crises, said Alexandra Christy, the Dodge senior program officer.
"The buzzword in the foundation world is, quote-unquote, 'capacity-building,' " she said. "In many ways, of course, organizations need cash. In other ways they need help making their internal organization strong so their capacity to spend that cash is honed and smart."
THE budget cuts of 1991 permanently changed the state's arts landscape.
"A lot of arts organizations were destabilized," said Mr. Fisher, the arts council chairman. "Some of them are still getting back on their feet." And some folded. In a 1999 report to the council, the management of the Tony-winning Crossroads Theater pegged the start of its downward slide to the cuts. Across the state, few were spared.
The cuts forced the New Jersey Ballet Company in Livingston into "survival mode": staff layoffs, a shorter season, a pay freeze and other economies, said Carolyn Clark, the company's founder and director.
"We are beginning to come out of it," Ms. Clark said. But like Crossroads, the company never returned to the level of state aid it once received.
"We feel very sad," Ms. Clark said, "no longer angry or bitter, just sad, because so much more could have been done in New Jersey."
In the mid-1990's, the state arts budget began to climb back, mirroring a nationwide trend. "When the economy began to recover, our budgets recovered as well," said Kimber Craine, the spokesman for the National Assembly of State Arts Agencies in Washington. But in 1996 the arts community absorbed another blow after Congress, reacting to controversial artwork, slashed the budget for the National Endowment for the Arts by almost 40 percent. Grants to New Jersey dropped to $860,400 from $3 million, a decrease of more than 70 percent. The grants have since inched up, to about $1.1 million this year.
"What we went through in the 90's was horrifying," said Laura Aden, the executive director of the New Jersey Theater Alliance. "It was really a very difficult time for the arts both on the state level and nationally. But we've survived, and in some ways we're stronger."
Arts groups have become "more sophisticated," Ms. Miller of ArtPride said, "in terms of understanding what they need to do to survive and to grow. Certainly, 5 or 10 years ago people weren't thinking about building endowments or cash reserves."
Now, on a per capita basis, New Jersey ranks sixth among the states in the amount its Legislature earmarks for its state arts agency, according to the arts agencies assembly. Yet many of the state's arts organizations remain financially unstable.
In response, last July the Legislature approved a cultural trust fund to help arts and history groups build endowments, make capital improvements and otherwise beef up their finances. Under the trust, the state may allot up to $100 million over 10 years as a match for up to $100 million in private donations.
So far, the state's contribution to the fund has been just $1 million, to match a $1 million donation from the Dodge Foundation. No interest can flow from the trust until it reaches $20 million.
An endowment or cash reserve could have written a second act for American Stage. Founded in 1986, the company earned a reputation for developing shows that moved to the New York stage and beyond, like "Forever Plaid" and "I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change."
In announcing the halt to the season, Amie Gartenberg, the president of American Stage's board of trustees, spoke of a "dramatic drop" in the stock market that caused potential donors to retrench. But documents on file with the arts council and an interview with Matthew Parent, the former artistic director, gave a fuller picture. The season started with a deficit of almost $79,000; the board shut down when it was clear that number would probably double by season's end, Mr. Parent said.
The Dodge Foundation dropped its support, although it warned the theater a year in advance. Another foundation bowed out, too, Mr. Parent said, and the grant from the state arts council decreased slightly, even as the council's grant review panel questioned whether the theater could meet its financial goals.
The company adopted an expanded season of more diverse plays this year to address the complaints of donors, Mr. Parent said. The arts council's reviewers had termed the theater's programming "unimpressive and unambitious."
"It's a Catch-22," he said. " 'Be better, and we'll give you more money.' We started making plans to be better, and then the cuts came."
The Dodge Foundation once asked grant recipients for their version of a "more livable" world, said David Grant, the executive director. One response, he said: arts spending should equal defense spending. "I'd be happy," he added, "to equal pro sports spending."
The reality is that the sum of what the state, the N.E.A., Dodge and Prudential were able to bestow on New Jersey arts groups and artists this year would bankroll a single, medium-size Hollywood movie.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
Has DiFrancesco Learned From Whitman's Mistakes?

BYLINE:  By David M. Halbfinger; David M. Halbfinger is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
The portrait of Christie Whitman hung in the State House recently is utterly lifelike in more than one respect. It shows her desk as spotless.
 On her way out the door Mrs. Whitman did a magical job of making nettlesome problems like a faltering economy and stalled talks over a Newark arena seem to disappear. But her budget and arena plans turned out to be worth as much as the paper they were printed on. 
 When Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco took over, the tasks overflowing his in box -- Mrs. Whitman's unfinished business, plus the Senate presidency and a career-climaxing campaign for governor -- seemed enough to bury him in an avalanche. Twelve weeks later, his load lightened when he took himself out of the governor's race and said he would leave politics altogether.
But the last seven weeks have not been clear sailing for Mr. DiFrancesco, who has gotten into an unfamiliar bind, and in the eyes of some fellow Republicans, made some of the same mistakes for which Mrs. Whitman was famous.
Boiled down to a few words, Mr. DiFrancesco's dilemma is this: personal legacy, or party loyalty?
His Republican Party is in its worst shape in a decade, with Democrats growing cockier every day over their chances of recapturing both houses of the Legislature. His handpicked replacement in the governor's race, Bob Franks, is facing an increasingly threatening primary challenge from Mayor Bret D. Schundler of Jersey City. And Mayor James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge awaits in the fall with a record-breaking campaign war chest.
Yet Mr. DiFrancesco has repeatedly antagonized, irritated and even endangered fellow Republicans who have much to lose in November.
He did so on May 21, by unexpectedly posting a June 7 Senate vote on the controversial proposal for a constitutional amendment requiring parental notification for minors seeking abortions. Anti-abortion groups wanted the bill voted on before the June 26 primary in the hopes that they could squeeze supporters of abortion rights like John O. Bennett, the majority leader, and Diane Allen of Burlington County who face credible primary challenges from abortion opponents.
But Mr. Bennett, after all, is next in line to be Senate president as long as he and the Republican majority are still around next year.
Mr. DiFrancesco later relented, delaying the vote until June 28. But a message had been conveyed.
He did so on May 24 by announcing a $150 million bailout of Camden, a Democratic stronghold seen by Republicans as a constantly flushing toilet bowl for state money, without gaining support from legislators in his party. The proposal died a quiet death after local officials decried it as a takeover and Republicans in Trenton choked on the price tag.
"The problem was no communication," said a Republican legislative aide. "He didn't share these ideas with his colleagues before they were pitched" -- a problem, several people here pointed out, that Mr. DiFrancesco often pointed to as a flaw of the Whitman administration.
He did so again on June 6 by announcing the Newark arena proposal without first gaining the support of people like Paul DiGaetano, the assemblyman from Bergen County, home of the Meadowlands, who is next in line to become speaker,again, if the Republican majority is around in the fall.
Another thing that has been vexing some of Mr. DiFrancesco's colleagues is his longstanding practice of reviewing the board list -- the agenda for each Senate session -- and deleting items at his discretion. Mr. Bennett has complained since Mr. DiFrancesco became acting governor that final approval of the board list should fall to him, officials say.
"A lot of senators view it this way," said one legislative aide. "They have been nothing but completely loyal to Don DiFrancesco for 10 years, they made him the longest serving Senate president in history, and now when they are running and he's not, they have problems getting a bill that might appropriate $50,000 onto a board list.
"Furthermore, they see his legacy being shaped on issues that pertain to traditionally Democratic areas," the aide continued.
But Tom Wilson, Mr. DiFrancesco's spokesman, called such complaints unfair.
"His focus has broadened, but that's not to the detriment of anyone else," he said. "This is a person who has served as their Senate president since 1992 and has always given them the full weight and benefit of his time and interest in their success, and he still does that. The difference is that he also wears the hat of governor now."
When he took office amid much talk of cooperation with fellow lawmakers, one might have imagined Mr. DiFrancesco's future portrait would have pictured senators standing behind him. But it seems that like Mrs. Whitman, he is finding the governor's office a lonely place.

Wendy Chen, Alvin Wong

 BODY:
Wendy Chen, a daughter of Nancy Yu-ping Lin of Fresh Meadows, Queens, was married yesterday to Alvin Wong, the son of Maria and David Wong of Astoria, Queens. The Rev. 
Bill H. C. Lee, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Swan Club in Roslyn Harbor, N.Y.
 The bride and bridegroom, who graduated from Cornell, met as freshmen at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan.

His mother is a pension plan specialist in Brooklyn for the Internal Revenue Service. His father retired as a manager for the Golden World Enterprise Corporation, a manufacturer of women's clothing that was in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Hotel Stocks Confront A Travel Slump

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
TRADITIONALLY, the leisure traveler is the first to postpone or curtail plans when the economy sags. But this year, the business traveler, a much bigger spender, has inflicted the most damage on the nation's hoteliers.
 Revenue per available room slid 2.6 percent in April from the previous month, and the decline was probably even bigger in May. That is in sharp contrast to the 2000 boom, in which that revenue measure soared as much as 8.2 percent in June. 
 Cruise lines are suffering as well. The problems have sent Wall Street analysts scrambling to further pare their estimates of travel industry profits.
One of them was Jason N. Ader, a senior managing director and travel and leisure analyst at Bear Stearns, who discussed the industry's woes on Thursday. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. The hotel business looks as if it has fallen off a cliff. What happened?

A. It is the worst in 10 years. Business consumption has been weak in all areas of the economy, and the lodging industry is feeling the impact with its usual 6- to 12-month lag to national economic trends. It was strong until February, that's when we started to see evidence of the downturn. And it's gotten progressively worse, particularly in gateway cities like New York, San Francisco and Boston, which were the strongest areas just last year.

Q. You cut earnings estimates for the industry again last week. Is there any end in sight?

A. It looks like it's going to be a tough summer for business travel, though leisure remains relatively stable. The question is: When will we see evidence of the economy recovering because of declining interest rates and a tax cut? We don't think that will occur in the lodging industry until sometime in 2002. Investors need to brace themselves for results likely to be quite negative throughout the summer. The key figures to watch as leading indicators of a possible recovery are airline traffic and retail sales.

Q. Yet the stocks haven't been pummeled despite such a grim climate. Why not?

A. The stocks have held up despite the deteriorating trends because the supply growth remains very much under control. That's the silver lining. Since the hotel industry is not overbuilt -- the room-supply growth coming out of a slowdown is the lowest in 50 years -- the recovery will likely happen quickly. That has kept investor interest in the industry relatively high.
In the worst-case recession scenario, the earnings risk to lodging companies is not nearly as bad as what we see with the biggest technology companies, which have seen 50 percent-plus declines. That's just not going to happen in lodging.

Q. Are the priciest quarters suffering the most?

A. Yes. People are taking few trips, but also those that have to take trips are being much more frugal. Those customers enjoying Ritz-Carlton or Four Seasons have traded down to Hilton, Marriott, Sheraton and Westin.

Q. So there are some beneficiaries in this pretty severe downturn?

A. I wouldn't say that. There's just certain price categories that are feeling the impact a bit less.

Q. What sort of bargains will consumers be seeing?

A. I think this summer will be a great time for consumers. Las Vegas, cruises and hotels in major cities will be offered at prices better than we've seen in the last few years.

Q. Are there any hotel stocks you are recommending now?

A. Our advice to investors over the next two or three quarters is to be cautious. We have no buy recommendations. Longer term, we're optimistic about prospects for Starwood, which stands to benefit as business travel recovers. If you own Marriott, which mostly franchises and manages rather than owns hotels, you are in a more defensive position.

Q. You mentioned cruises as bargains. Does this reflect the slumping economy, too, or is it mainly a matter of too much capacity coming on line for baby-boom retirement?

A. The problem the cruise industry is really facing, exacerbated by slowing economic conditions, is that there's far too much capacity. And it's going to get worse, not better. Five years from now we're going to have 55 percent more ship berths than currently, putting great pressure on prices and margins and also eroding return on capital. That makes that business less attractive coming out of a slowdown than lodging.
Investors can make a lot more money holding a stock like Starwood than a stock like Carnival, which is clearly the best name in the cruise business on the strength of their market position and balance sheet. But Starwood isn't faced with massive growth in supply.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jason N. Ader

HEADLINE: Talking Union 

BYLINE:  By ADAM FIFIELD 

 BODY:
HANDS clasped behind his back, a copy of El Diario tucked under his arm, Manuel Escobar stood on a crumbling, weed-tufted sidewalk in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in April, staring across the street at a sprawling green building. Through the dark, yawning entrance, payloaders and backhoes could be dimly seen, lurching and digging amid 15-foot-high dunes of garbage as though searching for prey. Every so often, a seagull fluttered out of a swirl of paper scraps, shrieking.
 This is Varick I, a waste transfer station and recycling center on Varick Avenue operated by Waste Management, the nation's largest trash company. Inside are 100 workers who haul, sort and bale tons of the city's garbage every day. 
 Squinting in the sun, a few beads of sweat standing on his tanned brow, Mr. Escobar, 36, glanced furtively toward a security booth. The guard, who watched him carefully, had called the police on previous occasions when Mr. Escobar, a labor organizer, had crossed the street onto company property. 
Just after 2 p.m., the end of the day's first shift, a few rumpled figures emerged from the building into the blinding sun. 
"Buenos dias!" shouted Mr. Escobar, shooting a hand into the air. Heads down, the men ignored him and plodded determinedly away. Others soon followed, though Mr. Escobar waved to all. 
Finally, one acknowledged him with a nod, and as if tugged by a magnet, the organizer strode swiftly across the street. Grinning, he gripped the man's hand and pumped vigorously. The man, in his mid-20's and paunchy, smiled, looking around nervously. They walked together down the street, Mr. Escobar's hand planted on the man's shoulder, talking and nodding. At the corner, Mr. Escobar fished a 3-by-5-inch union pledge card out of his pocket. The man took it reluctantly, like a child who accepts something he knows he shouldn't from a stranger. 
Mr. Escobar is the senior field representative for the Waste Material, Recycling and General Industrial Laborers Local 108, Laborers' International Union of North America, A.F.L.-C.I.O., which represents 1,600 workers at 66 garbage transfer and recycling centers in and around the city. More plainly, he is the lead foot soldier for one of the city's most dynamic unions.
Labor unions in the United States have long been in decline, dropping from 35 percent membership of the work force in the 50's to 13.5 percent, or 16.3 million workers, last year. To be a labor organizer "is a lot more difficult now," said Joshua Freeman, a history professor and labor expert at Queens College.
But labor organizers, persistent by profession, push on, choosing to look at the bright spots. For some unionists at least, one such development is "living wage" legislation, which seeks to raise the income of some low-wage workers, including those whom Mr. Escobar woos. The City Council may vote on such a bill this summer. More good news is the record of scrappy Local 108, which has won all but one of the 16 elections in which it has participated since it was formed in 1998 by combining three other union locals.
With a neat mustache, a crop of graying curls and a contagious laugh, Mr. Escobar, a 5-foot-4-inch native of Honduras, sets his sights on workers who are among the city's lowest paid. Many earn just the federal minimum of $5.15 an hour, others perhaps $1 or $2 more. Along with the four other organizers for Local 108, he handles duties like seeking out new members, monitoring plant conditions and negotiating issues like suspensions and back pay.
Mr. Escobar does it with style. He is known among his colleagues as El Suave for his ability to melt hostile situations with warmth and charm. One afternoon, when an organizer from a rival union spit coffee all over him, he paused, licked his shirt, then replied: "Hey, you didn't put enough sugar in it!" 
Working out of the black 2000 Mercury Mountaineer that the union provides, Mr. Escobar wears many hats: counselor, negotiator, social worker. As the rules for and patterns of welfare and immigration change, the job of labor organizing has evolved. He schedules doctors' appointments for members, runs immigrant orientation forums and even deals with the police if members are robbed. 
Mr. Escobar, who was once a garbage truck driver for a waste transfer station in Brooklyn, says he is moved by a sense of social justice and a desire to see workers prosper. He knows that his salary, about $55,000 a year, puts a gulf between himself and his members.
"I don't want to be the only one who has three weeks' vacation so I can go back and visit my country," he said. "I don't want to be the only one who can buy my son nice things." 
He is strident on occasion. "What I don't like is going to the Labor Board to defend the workers against the biggest liars in the world," he said. He confessed that he once bent procedural rules in his quest to organize workers.
Others have qualms about unionizing in the garbage industry. Steven Changaris, northeast regional director of the National Solid Waste Management Association, a trade group, said union-negotiated provisions on, for example, overtime pay, can limit a company's flexibility. 
"One of the things that may be laid down from the management perspective is, 'Don't tie my hands with the union protocol,' " he said. There are governmentally imposed price caps on what his member companies can charge, he pointed out. If those limits are not raised but union contracts push wages up, waste companies may be caught in a squeeze. 
There is also the tarnished past of the Mason Tenders District Council, the parent union of Local 108 and five other locals. The council, which is the laborers' union in the city, has reincarnated itself under the eyes of federal monitors and the leadership of a new business manager, Anthony Silveri. But things were different in the early 90's.
"This particular district council was extremely corrupt," said Jeffrey Schaffler, a former senior racketeering investigator for the United States Department of Labor. "But it has made extraordinary strides. It's been cleaned up for all practical purposes." 
In this reborn union, Mr. Escobar is a man with a mission. "The guy has a passion to do this work," said Mike Hellstrom, the Local 108 business manager and an outspoken labor leader. "He has it in his blood."
MR. ESCOBAR'S work focuses largely on people at the lowest level of the waste industry, those who stand at waist-high conveyor belts and sift through moving trash. These are the pickers and sorters, who segregate the recyclables from the nonrecyclables, which could be anything from soiled diapers to old food to used hypodermic needles.
Some get skin rashes from handling the garbage or slice their fingers open on jagged pieces of metal in the debris. On the odd occasion, something ghastly comes down the conveyor belt, like the severed human head that showed up two years ago at Varick I.
At most companies with which Local 108 does not have contracts, salaries for pickers and sorters range from $5.15 an hour, the national minimum wage, to around $6.50. Most of these laborers are immigrants from Latin America, many are illegal immigrants, and many work as much overtime as they can to send money to relatives back home. In neighborhoods like Bushwick, Brooklyn, and Mott Haven, the Bronx, their families live doubled or tripled up with other families in tiny apartments partitioned with plywood.
One April afternoon, Mr. Escobar paid a visit to a picker and sorter, a neat, soft-spoken man of 22 who lives with five other people in a cramped two-bedroom apartment in Woodside, Queens. The man had signed a Local 108 pledge card several weeks ago, and Mr. Escobar wanted to see whether he was still willing to join. 
Giving his name only as Ralph -- he is an illegal immigrant -- he said he made $5.40 an hour, working from 10 p.m. to 10 a.m. six days a week at a Brooklyn transfer station. He said he started working four months ago, and sends money to his parents in Ecuador every week. 
All he can afford is rent and food, Ralph said. "We don't even have a chance to go to school and learn some English," he said. During his four months in America, he had never eaten in a restaurant. 
Mr. Escobar said that illegal immigrants, who are about 60 percent of his workers, often say that they are forced to work weekend shifts and are threatened with firings if they talk to union representatives. But if these illegal immigrants are most in need of unions, organizing them is still hard.
"Many of them aren't sure of their rights, and they're easily intimidated," said Anne Pillsbury, executive director of the Central American Legal Assistance Project in Williamsburg. "Most of these people come from countries where there is no rule of law. Some of them come from countries where union organizers are killed."
Still, Local 108 has had 15 victories in 16 union campaigns, many at plants with unions that, Local 108 contended, were weak. At its shops, Local 108 has negotiated pay raises as high as 50 percent for pickers and sorters, its officials say. These workers now average $8.25 to $9 an hour. Employer contributions for medical insurance rose at some shops from $108 per month per worker to $385. Workers also got more sick days, more vacation days and bigger pensions, and safety issues were addressed.
Most satisfying, say Mr. Escobar and his fellow organizers, is what members can do with the extra dollars in their pockets: buy a car so they don't have to walk or bicycle to work, or move out of their cramped, shared apartments. 
"I became more comfortable after my salary increase," said Luis, an illegal immigrant who works at a Brooklyn transfer station and whose pay rose $4 an hour after he joined Local 108. "I could buy better things for my son."
But Jeff Berkowitz, general manager of the Hunts Point Recycling Corporation in the Bronx, sees increased wages as potentially fatal to smaller companies like his.
"We don't have the financial wherewithal to increase wages where the unions want it," said Mr. Berkowitz, whose plant is now in contract talks with Local 108. If he must pay pickers and sorters $8 or $9 an hour, as Local 108 wants, he said, "we'll go out of business." 
MR. ESCOBAR knows how arduous the minimum-wage life can be, especially when part of the slim paycheck is sent off to relatives abroad. He arrived in New York in 1985, and his first job, at a plastics factory, paid $3.88 an hour. Still, he sent money home, usually around $200 a month, he said. His grandparents, who live in a small village, have bought nice clothes and a washing machine, and his grandfather was able to afford a prostate operation.
But Mr. Escobar also knows he is luckier than many of the people he is trying to organize. His mother, a housekeeper in New York for many years, was a legal American resident when she sponsored him for entry in 1985. Then 20, he joined her in her small apartment in Flushing, Queens. Because of her sponsorship, he was able to get an alien registration card, something many immigrant workers do not have. 
In November 1999, 14 years and eight jobs later, Mr. Escobar became an American citizen. He still lives with his mother. She and Mr. Escobar's stepfather occupy a section of a split-level, cream-colored clapboard house that Mr. Escobar owns on a tidy, quiet street in Elmhurst, Queens. Living in the other part of the house are Mr. Escobar, his wife, Blanca, and their 2-year-old son, Emmanuel. He felt he had attained the American dream when he bought the house. 
"I used to watch all these people barbecuing in their backyards, enjoying the sunshine," he said. "And I said, 'Someday, I will have that.' "
Mr. Escobar's backyard is a bumpy swath of asphalt. There is no grass. But there are a few plastic chairs, and there is plenty of space for a barbecue grill. 
Mr. Escobar's union career, which gave him the key to his middle-class life, began with a display of organizing prowess.
In summer 1998, he was driving a garbage truck for a small waste transfer station in Brooklyn that, he said, did not pay overtime or provide health benefits. The company was unionized, but in his six months working there, he said, he had never met a union representative.
When an organizer from Local 958, a predecessor to Local 108, showed up handing out pledge cards one morning, Mr. Escobar signed immediately and started recruiting fellow workers. During breaks, he spoke about what the local could do for workers, as they stood eating amid the mounds of garbage. There was no lunchroom.
In one afternoon, he collected 25 signed pledge cards. He admits that he violated the policy of not soliciting for unions during working hours. "I knew it was illegal to do that during company time," he said, "but I was so mad at the other union."
As it turned out, the election was invalidated for reasons unrelated to Local 958. But Mr. Hellstrom, who was then the local's business manager, was so impressed by Mr. Escobar's verve for organizing that he hired him.
Later that year, the rookie organizer was put to the test in a campaign at a transfer station in New Jersey. Standing outside the site one afternoon, Mr. Escobar noticed a group of 15 or so workers carpooling in a large Ford van. He followed the van to Jersey City, noting each spot at which workers got out.
The next morning, he drove to one of the spots and joined a handful of workers waiting for their ride. When the van came, he got on board, immediately told everybody who he was and made his pitch. 
He expected the van to stop outside the plant gates, where he would be able to hop out without difficulty. Instead, Mr. Escobar said, the van hurtled past the gates onto company property. As the workers filed out, the gates closed. 
Then, he said, he ran around the back and began to scale a 20-foot-high chain link fence. Halfway up, he noticed a security camera mounted on the fence, only a few feet away. He scrambled to the top and gingerly eased himself over. 
But it was worth it. Local 108 won the election. "Those brothers had nothing," Mr. Escobar said. "Now, they have everything."
The poverty of many of Mr. Escobar's constituents is hard to deny. In April, when he visited Mr. Berkowitz's plant in the Bronx, he was thronged by workers asking about progress in the contract talks.
One picker and sorter, witha bristly gray beard, a yellow hard hat and old jeans that had a greasy glaze, said he made $5.15 an hour and sent $100 to $150 to his family in Honduras every few weeks. He said he also has a wife and three children to support in the Bronx.
"I can't survive on this salary," he said. "I can't buy nothing for myself. Sometimes I must pick up things in the garbage to survive." He pointed to his feet, which were clad in one ragged Nike sneaker and one oil-stained work boot. They were different sizes, and the boot slipped a little with each step. He had found the mismatched pair while doing his job, he explained, rooting through debris on the conveyor belt. 
A few weeks later, Local 108 negotiated an across-the-board 50-cent raise for all workers at the Hunts Point plant. 
It was just temporary relief, until a complete contract was signed. But the spring brought more good news. Largely thanks to Mr. Escobar, Local 108 had gathered enough pledge cards at three Waste Management plants in Brooklyn to take part in a union election. 
Mr. Escobar was happy about this second small victory as he drove through Brooklyn one morning, passing through a beige-and-red canyon of factories. Spotting the one where he used to work, he said, "No matter what God puts in my hands, I must remember where I came from."

GRAPHIC:  In recent years, 60 cities and counties, including Chicago, Cleveland, Detroit and San Francisco, have enacted "living wage" laws. These measures raise the minimum wage for people, like Manuel Escobar's constituents in the waste industry, who work for companies or nonprofit groups that get contracts or tax breaks from those governments. Most of these laws raise the minimum wage to $8 to $12 an hour, substantially more than the federal minimum of $5.15. Now may be New York City's turn. This summer, the City Council may consider a bill that would raise the minimum to $10 an hour with benefits and $11.50 without benefits. If it does not pass or if the mayor vetoes it, the bill's backers plan to make it a campaign issue in the fall. Supporters say the high cost of living in this city makes the bill especially important. A study released last September by the Statewide Emergency Network for Social and Economic Security, an Albany coalition of labor and social service groups, found that a single adult living in Brooklyn in 2000 had to earn at least $8.65 an hour to meet basic needs. A Brooklyn parent with one child needed at least $16.79 an hour. Unlike some public-sector union leaders that oppose the bill for its $60 million subsidy to affected companies, Mr. Escobar and Mike Hellstrom, the Local 108 business manager, support it. Still, Mr. Hellstrom said, nothing can replace "good old-fashioned organizing." (pg. 8) Photos: Manuel Escobar chatting with recycling workers in Hunts Point, the Bronx. "I don't want to be the only one who can buy my son nice things," he said. (Fred R. A native of Honduras, he is known as El Suave for his diplomatic skills. (Photographs by Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)(pg. 8) Chart: "LIVING WAGE: COUNCIL MAY WEIGH RISE IN MINIMUM PAY" In recent years, 60 cities and counties, including Chicago, Cleveland, Detroit and San Francisco, have enacted "living wage" laws. These measures raise the minimum wage for people, like Manuel Escobar's constituents in the waste industry, who work for companies or nonprofit groups that get contracts or tax breaks from those governments. Most of these laws raise the minimum wage to $8 to $12 an hour, substantially more than the federal minimum of $5.15. Now may be New York City's turn. This summer, the City Council may consider a bill that would raise the minimum to $10 an hour with benefits and $11.50 without benefits. If it does not pass or if the mayor vetoes it, the bill's backers plan to make it a campaign issue in the fall. Supporters say the high cost of living in this city makes the bill especially important. A study released last September by the Statewide Emergency Network for Social and Economic Security, an Albany coalition of labor and social service groups, found that a single adult living in Brooklyn in 2000 had to earn at least $8.65 an hour to meet basic needs. A Brooklyn parent with one child needed at least $16.79 an hour. Unlike some public-sector union leaders that oppose the bill for its $60 million subsidy to affected companies, Mr. Escobar and Mike Hellstrom, the Local 108 business manager, support it. Still, Mr. Hellstrom said, nothing can replace "good old-fashioned organizing." (pg. 8)

HEADLINE: CITY LORE; 
Another Obituary on Ladies' Mile

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
MARY G. CLOSE was a woman of substance. A woman who more often than not wore a thick string of pearls. A woman who set two forks for dinner on weekdays, and took a single-malt scotch at sundown until her 94th year.
 A teacher from Brooklyn who lived in an apartment on West 71st Street for nearly 40 years, Ms. Close, who was this reporter's great-aunt, was the image of early-20th-century American elegance. Ms. Close had a kind of frugal grace that was fed in no small part by the offerings of B. Altman, Lord & Taylor and Stern's back in the days when those stores still offered cachet, brown paper packages and in-store pianists. 
 But the last Stern's will soon close its doors. Federated Department Stores, which acquired Stern's in 1988 and also owns the Macy's and Bloomingdale's chains, announced in February that it would convert or close all 24 Stern's locations in New York and New Jersey.
According to Jean Coggan, a spokeswoman for Federated, the conversion of 17 Stern's stores into Macy's was completed last month. Two Stern's outlets will reopen as Bloomingdale's in 2002, and the going-out-of-business sales at the remaining locations, which are to be closed, will wind down in August.
For more than a century, Stern's has played a unique role among New York department stores. It evolved from a magnet for class-conscious German immigrants early in the century to a destination for the aspiring middle class after World War II. Its demise tracked that of the elegant retail world that Ms. Close knew so well.
Stern's sat in a top tier of the city's department stores. Like B. Altman's, it never quite rivaled Lord & Taylor or Bonwit Teller, but it clearly had more clout than Wanamaker's.
Four sons of an impoverished German Jewish immigrant founded Stern's in 1867. Buoyed by their initial success, the Stern brothers led the retail migration to Ladies' Mile in 1878 with the opening of a seven-story building on 23rd Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. It was the largest department store in New York until 1910.
"When the customer entered the store, he was welcomed personally by one of the Stern brothers, all of whom wore gray-striped trousers and cutaway tailcoats," said Larry Stone, who began at Stern's in 1948 as a trainee and retired in 1993 as chief executive. "Pageboys escorted the customer to the department in which they wished to shop, and purchases were sent out in elegant horse-drawn carriages and delivered by liveried footmen."
In 1913, the store moved to 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue. "At that point they catered to lots and lots of show business people because of being so close to Broadway," Mr. Stone said. "The store on 42nd Street literally had a carriage entrance, and while Madame shopped either her chauffeur or the driver of her horse-drawn carriage waited for her."
According to James Shenton, professor emeritus of history at Columbia University, Stern's was a socially significant institution for the hundreds of thousands of German Jews who immigrated to New York in the late 19th century.
Stern's was sort of like an upper-class establishment which catered to the interests and needs of the most influential group of Jews in New York, the German Jews," he said. "They were becoming part of the establishment and began to distance themselves from the incoming Eastern European Jews."
"To be a customer at Stern's was a mark of identity," Professor Shenton said. 
Stern's attracted another kind of customer as well. Amid the Vienna fancy goods, bric-a-brac, cloaks and costumes, smoking jackets, porcelain dolls and Alexandre kid gloves were more modest items for customers whose desire outpaced their means. Stern's fed the aspirations of these less wealthy shoppers, too.
Louis Stern, one of the founding brothers, was aware of the social stratification reinforced by the dual marketing approaches of stores like his. In an article in a trade magazine in 1901, he said he was troubled by the "undemocratic and un-American" implications of the new "bargain basements" in department stores. 
But in 1951 Allied Stores acquired Stern's, and a new era began. In the competitive postwar retail landscape, Stern's began marketing itself to the masses.
"We became clearly the moderate-priced department store," Mr. Stone said. "These were customers who did not want to go to discount stores, and they didn't want to go to higher-priced department stores because they couldn't afford to."
Stern's thrived in this middle-market niche for decades. Besides the moderate prices, the store ran marketing campaigns that included in-store appearances by celebrities like Bob Hope and Richard Chamberlain. In the mid-60's, it had a fashion-forward Carnaby Street Shop.
But, ultimately, Stern's lost out to big box stores and to the fact that, during the 80's recession, customers of all incomes became bargain hunters. "The fineness identified with department stores became obsolete," said Wendy Liebmann, president of WSL Strategic Retail, a consulting firm. "Shopping at Kmart for your clothes somewhere along the line became acceptable."
Now, Stern's is almost gone, a situation that was unimaginable in the world of Mary G. Close. "When you walked into Stern's," Professor Shenton said, "my recollection of it was you had this wildly implausible feeling that everything was there forever."

HEADLINE: Life With Father Isn't What It Used to Be; 
Nuclear Dad: Last of My Kind

BYLINE:  By JOE QUEENAN 

 BODY:
AS the new census returns came in recently, many Americans were shocked and disappointed to learn that nuclear families -- man, woman, assorted progeny living under a single roof -- now make up less than one-quarter of the households in the United States. Well, not me. Viewing marriage as a sort of emotional endurance test, and parenthood as a brutally demanding, financially ruinous, yet emotionally fulfilling decathlon, I am proud of the fact that my wife, my 17-year-old daughter, my 14-year-old son and myself have been able to stay the course and remain "nuclear" in the truest sense of the word. Even though I strongly suspect that they all secretly hate me.
 In truth, the motives for my euphoria are not of the highest pedigree. Basically, I was overjoyed at the trends confirmed by the 2000 census figures, because this is the first time in my life that I can honestly lay claim to membership in an imperiled minority. Ethnically generic, economically standard-issue, culturally nondescript, I had spent most of my obvious, suburban adult life as a member of a class that was almost laughably stereotypical. Now, for the first time, I find myself on the very threshold of the exotic. 
 Demographically marooned by my fellow Americans, I, like the whooping crane, find myself claiming membership in a class that is not only endangered, but in some sense also irrelevant. It is like being the last of the Mohicans, or the next-to-last of the Picts or the penultimate Jute. No two ways about it: It is exhilarating.
In no way, shape or form am I suggesting that membership in a nuclear family demonstrates moral superiority to those who, through choice or circumstances, have opted for other familial configurations. Far from it. In many cases, nuclear families have retained their monadic status simply because their children refuse to leave or because the children are not strong enough to force one or more parents to clear out. When conservative social critics champion governmental policies that will strengthen the family unit, they too often forget that many, perhaps most, such households are best described as inadvertently nuclear, situationally nuclear or even dysfunctionally nuclear.
For example, in households where one or more of the parents actively despise their children, or where the children loathe one or both parents, or where everybody dislikes a grandparent who stubbornly refuses to check into an assisted-care facility, one witnesses a dynamic best described as the King Lear syndrome. These are families that, though nuclear in composition, are fundamentally miserable. In households where mutual antipathy runs rampant, one comes face to face with a social unit best listed under the rubric the thermonuclear family.
Speaking from experience, it is fair to say that my family has not yet achieved thermonuclear status. Nor is it likely to do so in the future. Yet because my children are clearly anxious to get their hands on my money and have always been a bit tight with a buck, it is not hard to envision a time after their college years when they may come back to live under my roof in an arrangement best described as the postnuclear family. 
This is not something I am looking forward to, having always frowned on couples who continually take their grown children back in as lodgers, thus practicing serial empty nesting. It is my firm belief that once a nuclear family has ceased to be nuclear, no good can come from regressive nuclearity. Put in layman's terms, once there are no Bradys, there can no longer be a bunch.
One phenomenon that has not been sufficiently examined is phantom nuclear families. These are households where the husband and wife maintain a desperate illusion of nuclearity out of fear of social repercussions. 
As nuclear families dwindle in number -- down to 23.5 percent of all households in 2000, from 25.6 percent in 1990 -- their status as a mysterious and even exotic demographic group will grow, not unlike Arctic-based Huguenots. I for one would be willing to pay my children large cash emoluments long into their young adult years in exchange for their silence regarding the true social organization of our family. I am also willing to have my mother move into my house if it will help engender an illusion, however nebulous, that ours is truly a nuclear family. No two ways about it: I am a dyed-in-the-wool-nuclear-family kind of guy.
All this said, it is only fair to confess that the nuclear family is not something that I ever aspired to as a young man, nor is it even something that I am especially good at. Like macrame or retail haberdashery, it is something that I merely drifted into. I do not claim to be a better nuclear parent than the next guy, nor do I believe that one must be a nuclear parent in order to succeed as a nurturer. I can only say that for the first time in my life I can look at myself in the mirror and see the gleaming reflection of a dying breed. It's great to feel special.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
Forget About Efficient Markets. Let the Sun Shine In.

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IF you still believe in efficient markets, consider this: City by city, according to a new study, stock markets rise more often on days when the sun shines in the morning than when skies are overcast. And, the study concludes, the New York Stock Exchange is among the most weather-influenced markets in the world.
 These findings are devastating for people who advocate the efficient-market hypothesis, at least in its strongest form. The hypothesis holds that the market so efficiently assimilates all new information as it sets stock prices that no one can outperform it consistently. But if something as obviously irrelevant as the weather can change market performance, such efficiency cannot exist. 
 The study, "Good Day Sunshine: Stock Returns and the Weather," by two finance professors, David Hirshleifer of Ohio State University and Tyler Shumway of the University of Michigan, is available at
www.cob.ohio-state.edu/fin/dice/papers/ 2001/2001-3.pdf.
For example, on a day when Paris is sunny and Brussels is cloudy, French investors tend to interpret that day's news more optimistically than Belgian investors -- even though the two exchanges trade many of the same companies and are affected by the same economic developments.
The professors arrived at their conclusions by studying 26 stock exchanges worldwide between 1982 and 1997. They found that sunshine's positive effect is not confined to one country, or to a few emerging markets. In fact, they found it in virtually every market they studied. Furthermore, American investors will be humbled to learn that, notwithstanding their self-image as technologically sophisticated, the Big Board is among a cluster of stock exchanges that are most influenced by the weather. Others in that group are markets in Brussels, Paris, Vienna and Helsinki, Finland.
All of this may be fascinating, but how can the study make you a better investor? Its greatest lesson is not how to day-trade the world's stock markets according to the weather -- though if you were so inclined, the key would be to have low transaction costs, like those that apply to stock index futures. In that event, according to the professors' calculations, you might make money by going long in markets whose cities start the day in sunshine and going short in markets whose cities are under clouds.
More important, the study shows that our moods can have powerful effects on our interpretation of economic developments. When the sun is shining, the study concludes, people tend to put a more optimistic spin on the day's news developments. The process is subtle; indeed, most of us are unaware of how our moods contaminate our objectivity. But if the weather can change our opinion about a stock, imagine the impact of our other daily mood swings.
The main point, of course, is that objectivity is rare among investors. We may think that we are being objective as we assess an earnings report, for example, but we most likely are not.
To have any chance of beating the market, we need to be ruthlessly objective. Although we have conclusive evidence that the market is not completely efficient, it would be a mistake to conclude that it is totally inefficient, and thus easy to beat. To the contrary, despite frequent anomalies, financial markets remain predominantly efficient and difficult, though not impossible, to beat.
To immunize yourself from your moods, use a mechanical investment strategy that dictates how to react in all possible circumstances -- eliminating the need to make judgments in the face of new developments. And try to be disciplined enough to stick with the strategy, even in the face of inevitable emotional pulls to second-guess it.
If you follow this advice, I predict that your long-term performance will be more than enough to cheer you on even the cloudiest of days.

ANNUALIZED PERFORMANCE 1982-97 Sunny days: +25%Cloudy days: +9% (Source: David Hirschleifer, Ohio State University and Tyler Shumway, University of Michigan)

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS; 
In Small-Town America, A Big Media Market

BYLINE:  By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Davenport Institute for Public Policy at Pepperdine University. His column on the Main Street economy appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: BATAVIA, Ohio 

 BODY:
MOST media moguls have built their empires on metropolitan dreams. Daniel Hammond is aiming to make it big by reaching the nearly 40 million Americans -- like those in this town of 3,000 east of Cincinnati -- who are served by small-town newspapers.
 With a downtown sprinkled with late 19th- and early 20th-century buildings and mom-and-pop shops, Batavia is typical of the small-town targets of Mr. Hammond's start-up weekly magazine, American Profile. The magazine, 14 months old, already appears in 630 small-town newspapers, with a combined circulation of three million; it is a folksy insert similar in appearance to USA Weekend or Parade but distinctive in the small-town thrust of its content. 
 "It's an untapped market," said Mr. Hammond, 41, who was a marketing executive for the First Data Corporation in Atlanta before starting the Publishing Group of America, the privately held parent of American Profile, in Franklin, Tenn. "There's over $300 billion, a quarter of the disposable income in the country," available in small towns, he said. 
In the advertising business, small cities and towns are often called "C" or "D" markets. They are rated behind both the large "A" markets, which include the top 25 metropolitan areas like New York and Los Angeles, and the second-tier, "B" cities with populations of more than 80,000. 
Although the populations are small -- C markets are 20,000 to 80,000, D markets less than 20,000 -- their combined total is about 25 percent of the American population.
For years, demographers and advertisers widely assumed that C and D markets were losing population, yet recent census data reveals a strong pickup in many of them across the country. In fact, as more companies relocate to rural areas and as early retirees from the baby-boom generation move in, such markets are undergoing considerable change.
"These are not all a bunch of uneducated hayseeds anymore," said Mr. Hammond, contradicting the image held by some people living in big cities.
Most of these cities and towns have their own newspapers, often family owned and operated, and Mr. Hammond said he believes that these publications, unlike their metropolitan-area counterparts, are often read cover to cover. "It's the only place to find out who the homecoming queen is," said Mr. Hammond, a native of Noblesville, Ind., a town of 8,000 people northeast of Indianapolis.
Until American Profile came along, most small-town newspapers, like The Clermont Sun of Batavia, lacked a weekly supplement. With a circulation of only 3,100, the newspaper was considered too small for Parade and USA Today, which concentrate on papers with circulations of more than 100,000.
Even so, William C. Latham, 68, the paper's publisher, said he believes that those national publications do not fit the tastes and preferences of his readers anyway.
Michael Kurtz, 30, the editor of The Sun, agreed. "People here are tired of the glitz, the bad news and the crime," Mr. Kurtz said from the paper's offices on Main Street. "People here want to read about how a family man rebuilt a house. That's what they can get in American Profile."
These sentiments, and the notion of an underserved market, gave Mr. Hammond the idea for American Profile nearly a decade ago. The early research into the C and D markets was financed by a second mortgage that he took in 1991 on his house in the Nashville suburbs. By early 2000, he had raised a total of $3.5 million in capital from Megunticook Management, a venture capital firm based in Boston that specializes in the media business.
Heberden Ryan, a partner at Megunticook, said the magazine had already exceeded its own business plan by reaching a circulation of more than one million in its first year. That success opened the door to an additional $23 million investment in March from Quadrangle Group L.L.C., a New York firm that specializes in media properties.
American Profile, which has a staff of 57 in Tennessee, reaches more than three million people in its five regional editions. Mr. Hammond expects circulation to increase to 4.5 million readers next year.
Yet he sees that number as a fraction of the nearly 40 million people in his target audience. If he can capture a large portion of these readers, the Publishing Group of America could eventually become the publisher of one of the nation's largest-circulation magazines and expand into properties in cable television, specialty magazines and the Internet.
"They told Wal-Mart 40 years ago, you could not build a powerful company based in towns with less than 50,000 people," he said. 
Like Wal-Mart back then, American Profile has gained little initial notice in an industry that is concentrated in big cities. Dr. Samir Husni, a journalism professor at the University of Mississippi and an expert on magazines, traced that in part to the decidedly "light" nature of its content. 
Mr. Hammond acknowledged that the magazine consciously avoided "controversy," including articles on topics like crime, politics and even fundamentalist Christianity, a major force in rural America. Recent covers of the magazine have included headlines like "Home for Good: The Lure of Hometown America and Why It Beckons Us," and "Unsung Fathers: 5 Families Tell What Makes a Dad Special."
"Not every journalist would accept this," said Mr. Husni, who runs a magazine consulting firm. "This is a cheap shot to some people, but this works because it serves customers in good old small-town America." 
Mr. Husni has been so impressed with the magazine's marketing strategy that last year he rated American Profile, along with "O," Oprah Winfrey's magazine, as "launch of the year" among 874 new magazines.
ADVERTISERS also appear to be impressed. Advertising revenue, barely $3 million in 2000, is on track to pass $20 million this year, Mr. Hammond said. American Profile's advertising base now includes brand names like Kimberly-Clark, Colgate, Kraft and Coty fragrances. The magazine has also attracted ad dollars from major media names like NBC and Mercury Records.
Marla Goldstein, senior director for media planning, advertising and promotion at NBC, said she saw American Profile as a way to reach small-town viewers who usually do not receive weekly supplements like USA Weekend and Parade in their local newspapers. In general, small-town residents tend to watch more television, particularly network television, than their big-city counterparts, she said.
"This gives us a way to reach out to people we haven't really been able to reach in print before," she said from her office in Burbank, Calif. "We want people to learn about our shows in a format where there's no worry about an inappropriate article next to our ad."
Mr. Hammond said his success with advertisers and publishers was rooted in his ability to capture the sensibility of small-town newspaper readers. As a native of a small town himself, he said he believes that he has a natural feel for what they like. And most of his editorial and marketing employees, he said, also have small-town backgrounds.
"The critical thing is we can't fake it," Mr. Hammond said. "If we are perceived as people in New York or Los Angeles doing the hometown shtick we'd wither on the vine. But this is a natural for me."
