HEADLINE: Orbitz Takes Off, in the Spotlight 

BYLINE:  By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
INTERNET companies have earned their share of criticism in the last few years, whether through hubris or incompetence. But arguably no dot-com has been subject to as much scrutiny before its debut as Orbitz, the new online travel agency owned by five of the nation's biggest airlines. 
 Consumer groups have decried it as anticompetitive, a sentiment echoed (not surprisingly) by the company's rivals, most notably Expedia and Travelocity. 
 "I really believe Orbitz will become a platform for collusion," Mark Silbergeld, co-director of the Consumers Union's Washington office, said after Orbitz's first week of operation. "All the major competitors in an already highly concentrated industry now have a platform from which to agree how to market their tickets." 
Orbitz executives respond that since all the fares are made public on the site, price collusion would be easily spotted. Furthermore, they say, the federal Department of Transportation reviewed such anticompetitive concerns before clearing Orbitz in early April. (An investigation by the Justice Department is ongoing.)
Regardless, now that the Web site (www.orbitz.com) has finally rolled out, the first reviews are rolling in. Although the site still has much to prove, it appears to be equal to, or even slightly better than, its chief competitors when it comes to low fares, site design and customer service. 
"Orbitz has come roaring out of the gate," said Henry Harteveldt, an analyst with Forrester Research, an Internet consulting firm. "They have one of the broadest arrays, if not the broadest array, of low fares. And their real secret sauce is in their customer service." 
In the short term, Orbitz -- owned by American, Continental, Delta, Northwest and United -- should provide consumers with a welcome experience, especially on Wednesdays. That's the day airlines typically release last-minute low-price Web fares. Unlike other online agencies, Orbitz has agreements with 35 airlines requiring them to share any publicly available fare.
So consumers can spare themselves a trip to the various airline sites by logging on to Orbitz to search for last-minute getaways. On the Wednesday after the site's June 4 debut, for instance, I found a $227 round-trip T.W.A. fare for nonstop flights between J.F.K. in New York and San Francisco, taking off on Saturday morning and returning on Monday evening.
Searching the same dates on Expedia, the lowest fare from a known carrier was $296 -- also from T.W.A. Expedia also offered a $246 Bargain Fare, but it would not tell consumers precisely when or with whom they would be traveling until they bought the ticket. On Travelocity, a $463 flight on National Airlines was the lowest comparable fare shown.
Orbitz seemed to produce good results on other days, too. On a Tuesday, for instance, I researched three trips, all from La Guardia to San Francisco. For one, I replicated a last-minute business trip, departing the next day and returning two days later. The others involved weeklong excursions, with one beginning a month from my booking date and the second 60 days from booking.
For the business trip, Expedia and Travelocity matched Orbitz's lowest fare of $665 from American Trans Air (from La Guardia). But Orbitz let me easily modify my flight search to include other airports within a 100-mile radius -- a great feature for places like New York and the San Francisco area, which both have multiple airports. Within 30 seconds, Orbitz returned a $610 nonstop on Jet Blue from J.F.K. to Oakland. Neither Travelocity nor Expedia offered the chance to modify my search this way. (On Expedia, you must choose a specific airport, and on Travelocity a city.) 
For the hypothetical vacation 30 days later, Orbitz, Expedia and Travelocity again matched one another with $352 round trips with one stop. But again, when I widened my search, Orbitz beat them: $287 nonstop on T.W.A. from Kennedy to San Francisco -- at least $50 less than Travelocity and Expedia. 
For the trip 60 days later, Orbitz returned a $238 T.W.A. round trip with one stop. Expedia found one for $315 from American Trans Air with one stop, and Travelocity turned up one from US Airways with one stop for $304.50. 
As enticing as it may be to extrapolate these results, Mr. Harteveldt, of Forrester, cautioned against declaring anyone the winner in a lowest-fare contest. Because the airlines' computer software changes fares thousands of times each day based on how full a flight is, there's no such thing as the lowest price, he said. 
Orbitz is an attractive, mostly easy-to-use site, with air fare results in a readable grid showing the lowest- to highest-priced airlines from left to right. Below the grid are each flight's details, including travel time. 
Perhaps because Orbitz is owned by airlines, the air fare category is more refined than the other functions. The rental car category is fairly useful, giving a simple menu of car preferences, then displaying prices in an easy-to-swallow graphic. 
But the hotel function on Orbitz leaves much room for improvement. Consumers cannot select a price range or grade of hotel -- only brands -- which would be fine if the results were displayed in order of cost. Instead, they fall seemingly random, without the kind of graphics that make the airline and car searches painless. You must click on a hotel listing to find its rates, and worse, the site sometimes displays hotels that are not available on the nights selected. 
On Expedia, by contrast, the least-expensive, best-rated hotels were displayed first and users can modify searches based on the quality of the hotel (from one to five stars). Travelocity displays the least expensive hotels first, along with icons showing various amenities, but unlike Expedia, it does not give easily-digested ratings. Instead users must click to the descriptions and hope they provide enough information for a decision.
Despite some opening-week technical problems, including a brief shutdown for an upgrade, customer service is an area where Orbitz said it hopes to make headway against its competitors. And at first glance, some of its initiatives are indeed different from those of Travelocity and Expedia. 
While the latter two sites offer e-mail alerts about airline delays or cancellations, and Travelocity will page you with updates on gate changes and flight delays, Orbitz says it goes further. For instance, instead of relying solely on information from the airlines, Orbitz says it employs former air traffic controllers who scan data from the Federal Aviation Administration, air traffic control systems and weather services to determine whether customers can expect delays.
The company will send updates to customers beginning three hours before departure -- notably, via the phone, cell phone, wireless handheld computer or e-mail. Or if they prefer, Orbitz will set up a free personal voice-mail box to hear updates or create a list of people to keep informed. 
It is perhaps a tall order to expect Orbitz to maintain a stellar record in its quest to ferret out flight problems before they bring grief to customers. It appears an even taller order when one recalls that the industry that spawned Orbitz is hardly famous for customer service. But Orbitz has pledged to differentiate itself on these grounds, and industry observers -- and consumers -- will likely hold the company to it.

HEADLINE: THE RIGHT THING; 
A Blame Game Hurts Both Ford and Firestone

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY L. SEGLIN; Jeffrey L. Seglin teaches at Emerson College in Boston and is the author of "The Good, the Bad, and Your Business" (John Wiley & Sons). His column on business ethics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: righthng@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
EARLY on the morning of May 21, senior Ford Motor executives met with Bridgestone/Firestone officials at Firestone's headquarters in Nashville. Since the recall of 6.5 million Firestone tires on Ford Explorers in August, after tire blowouts and vehicle rollovers, Ford had been analyzing the safety of the roughly 13 million Wilderness AT tires, made by Firestone, that were still in use on Explorers and Ford trucks. "We wanted to get into a discussion at that time" about tire safety, said Ken Zino, a Ford spokesman.
 Instead, John T. Lampe, the chief executive of Firestone, handed over a letter severing his company's 95-year-old link to Ford. The next day, Ford announced that it would replace those 13 million Firestone tires. "We did not have confidence in the tire," Mr. Zino said. 
 Firestone read Ford's motives differently. "Ford steadfastly refused to look at the vehicle," said Jill Bratina, a Firestone spokeswoman. "We told them our concerns, asked them again to please look at the vehicle. They said no."
Sorting out the purpose of all this public blaming isn't easy. In a recent survey of 130 of its members, the Council of Public Relations Firms found that 85 percent believed that Ford and Firestone could have avoided the damage to their credibility and consumer confidence if they had worked together rather than attacking each other publicly.
And from a legal standpoint -- lawsuits are among each company's worries -- the pointing of fingers at the supplier and then back at the manufacturer can be a mistake. 
"It's counterintuitive," said John D. Winter, a product liability lawyer with Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler in Manhattan. When several defendants are involved in cases dealing with accusations of product liability, he added, "it's usually a 'united we stand, divided we fall' approach."
After blaming a product's supplier, a manufacturer will have to convince a jury that it stopped using the product as soon as it found problems. 
From the public airing that Ford and Firestone have given their brawl, it would be too simple to conclude that blaming is always bad. Peter A. French, director of the Lincoln Center for Applied Ethics at Arizona State University and author of "The Virtues of Vengeance" (University Press of Kansas), calls it "an act of moral courage."
"The easier thing to do is to say, 'Oh well, you know these things happen, too bad, live with it,' " he added. "The more difficult thing is to say, 'No these things happen because people did something inappropriate -- something morally wrong, something wrong, period.' And they need to be called to task for that. They need to take the responsibility and act appropriately."
Indeed, in the Ford-Firestone fight, both companies have staked moral motives for their actions. "People will know that we took a moral and ethical stand," Mr. Lampe said after the breakup. In response, Ford offered its own, more succinct, moral thrust. "These are our customers and we will protect them," Mr. Zino said.
But when each company vigorously fixes blame on the other, and when each cites a higher ground, it becomes nearly impossible to decide whose claims to give more credence. Even in appearing to take some responsibility, each player casts more doubt on the other than it does on itself. "We have taken responsibility for the tires that had the problems last year," Ms. Bratina said. "For the past 10 months they have been trying to divert attention from their vehicle onto on our tires. We hoped that Ford would take responsibility for their part of this."
At Ford, Mr. Zino had his own take. "Our customers are tired of us squabbling with a supplier," he said. "We sold them the vehicle. We will replace these tires."
THE real ethical lesson here is not that blaming is bad or good. Instead, the lesson is found in what happens when companies fail to work together to solve a problem after the marriage of their products. In the letter to Jacques Nasser, Ford's chief executive, in which he ended the relationship, Mr. Lampe wrote, "Business relationships, like personal ones, are built upon trust and mutual respect."
Ms. Bratina elaborated, "At this point in time, that trust has been damaged to a point that we can't continue working together."
When responsibility for a problem is not shared by companies, trust is lost not only between them, but also with their customers. After all, why should customers trust the statements of either company on safety issues when each has made it abundantly clear that it cannot even trust the other?

HEADLINE: Spain and Argentina Find Themselves in Tangle Over Airline 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, June 16 

 BODY:
Few countries in the world have closer relationships than Argentina has with its motherland, Spain. 
 But that did not stop the sparks from flying between Buenos Aires and Madrid this week as a Spanish holding company that controls Aerolineas Argentinas threatened to ground the long struggling airline once and for all. 
 Employees of Aerolineas Argentinas obstructed passengers trying to take Iberia flights at the Buenos Aires international airport in retaliation, even rolling an aircraft across a runway and clashing with the police. Scores of Iberia passengers, including a woman carrying 7-month-old twins, were forced to hike a mile to get around one blockade. 
Members of Argentina's Congress took to the stump in nationalist outrage, charging that Spain had stripped the formerly state-owned Argentine airline of its assets in a throwback to colonial days. And a union confederation began organizing a boycott of Spanish companies. 
The anger grew so fierce that senior Spanish officials publicly called for calm. Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar said he regretted that "there are people stirring anti-Spanish sentiment." Mr. Aznar reminded Argentines that Spain "has contributed in a very sympathetic way" to Argentina's well-being over the last decade as Spanish companies invested more than $30 billion in the economy. 
But as the deep recession in Argentina approaches its fourth year, popular resentment over a decade of economic policies that have failed to expand the middle class has enveloped Spain in a backlash. 
When Carlos Saul Menem, Argentina's president at the time, sold off most of the state's enterprises in the 1990's, Spanish companies bought the flagship airline, banks, oil company and telephone company. Now many of the former Argentine officials involved in those deals are facing allegations that they took kickbacks, while the Spanish owners are blamed for the bad service and high prices of their new Argentine operations. 
Aerolineas Argentinas, a majority share of which was bought by Iberia in 1990 before the Spanish airline was itself privatized, is widely criticized here and around South America for its high fares and indifferent service. 
Critics note that the airline owned 29 aircraft and had no debt a decade ago; now it leases almost its entire fleet and loses an estimated $1 million a day. While the airline had the advantage of highly subsidized fuel pumped by the state oil company before the two companies were privatized, passengers look back at those days with nostalgia.
Aerolineas Argentinas, which still paints its aircraft in the powder blue and white colors of the Argentine flag, became a nationalist cause after the Spanish holding company, Sepi, suspended routes to New York, Miami, Los Angeles, Auckland, Sydney, Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro on June 7. Spanish executives demanded that Aerolineas Argentinas's seven unions agree to a rescue plan that included wage cuts between 6 and 20 percent. Two of the unions have refused to go along; in response Sepi said it could be forced to end payments on the airline's $930 million debt. Nearly 7,000 jobs are at stake at a time when 15 percent of the Argentine work force is unemployed.
In a television interview, the Spanish foreign minister, Josep Pique, criticized the Argentine unions for asking investors "to keep plowing in money indefinitely" while they refused to adapt to new market conditions. He said he hoped the struggle between the unions and the holding company would not "end up clouding relations between the two countries." 
The Argentine government dispatched its infrastructure minister, Carlos Bastos, to Madrid to find a way to keep the airline running long enough to find another buyer, to save jobs and sustain the vital tourism industry. Argentine officials spoke optimistically about the outcome of Mr. Bastos's trip, and there were signs that Lan Chile, the profitable Chilean airline, might consider snapping up much if not all of the operations of Aerolineas Argentinas. 
But Pedro Ferreras, the leader of Sepi, said his company might have to file for protection from creditors, to avoid bankruptcy on the Aerolineas Argentinas debt as early as next Thursday, which means that the airline could face a hard landing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Aerolineas Argentinas's planes sitting at an airport near Buenos Aires; lack of agreement on wage cuts has threatened the airline's existence. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Egypt on Trial 

BYLINE:  By Mary Anne Weaver; Mary Anne Weaver is author of "A Portrait of Egypt: A Journey Through the World of Militant Islam." She is an Alicia Patterson fellow for 2001.

 BODY:
LATE ONE EVENING LAST SUMMER, Saad Eddin Ibrahim, a prominent Egyptian-American civil rights advocate and one of the Arab world's leading social scientists, was working in his study - a spacious one, on a quiet, tree-lined street in the suburb of Maadi, one of Cairo's most fashionable neighborhoods. The room was bursting with books, stacks of papers, family photographs and half-finished cups of tea. On that particular evening, the 61-year-old professor of sociology was alone in the house: his American-born wife, Barbara, was out of town; his son, Amir, was out with friends; and his daughter, Randa, was at her own home with her husband and Saad Eddin's second, recently born grandchild. It seemed unusually quiet, the professor thought to himself. Evening prayers had recently ended at the adjacent Victory College mosque, and the worshipers had left. With their departure, all noise, all sounds, seemed to have come to an end. 
 A partly bald and bearded man of medium height and build, and an outspoken proponent of his views, he ensconced himself on the sofa and began to read. He may have fallen asleep, or simply been deep in thought; he can't quite recall. Whichever it was, he gradually became aware of a persistent drumlike pounding on his front door. Sleepily, he made his way down to the entrance foyer, opened the door and was abruptly jolted completely awake. A dozen armed guards from State Security Investigation, or S.S.I., stormed into the house, as 40 or so others cordoned it off. Some raided his study and eventually carted off scores of boxes of files and books, his computer - and the family safe. Others surrounded him. "Come with us," one of them said. "Come with us. You're under arrest." 
 "I looked out of the door," Saad Eddin said a few weeks ago, as we sat in the open-air cafe of my Cairo hotel one late April afternoon. "It was like the siege of Stalingrad. Armored cars surrounded the house. Guards were posted everywhere. Why had so many people come to arrest one harmless intellectual? Why didn't they just make a phone call? I would have come."
It was a little before midnight when Saad Eddin Ibrahim was bundled into an armored car and driven about three miles, high above Cairo, into the Mokattam Hills to the Ibn Khaldun Center for Development Studies. Established by Saad Eddin 12 years before - and named for the great medieval Islamic scholar - the center had emerged as a leading exponent of democratic reform and intellectual freedom in the Arab world.
As the armored car continued to climb the sinuous mountain road, Saad Eddin glanced out of the window. "I could see the whole motorcade," he said. "There were at least 10 cars ahead of me and another 10 behind: bright lights in the darkness. There are so many layers, so many conflicting images, in all of this, and it was that night that I first saw the contrast, the physical part - two starkly different images, one romantic, one harsh. Caravans in the desert, I thought, as I looked at the twinkling lights, or the carts of death, during the French Revolution, taking their victims to the guillotine."
It was June 30, the last day of the fiscal year, and Nadia Abdel Nour, the financial manager of the Ibn Khaldun Center, had worked late that night supervising the closing of the books. A genteel, attractive woman of 50 or so, with luminous dark eyes, she is a Sudanese refugee and the sole support of her large refugee family. At around 8 p.m., as she waited at a nearby bus stop, her neatly ordered world began to fall apart.
"They grabbed me from behind, blindfolded me, threw a bag over my head," she later said. She had no idea who they were. She was terrified. "I thought I was being kidnapped!" she said with a shudder. 
"When we arrived at Ibn Khaldun, I found her there," Saad Eddin said. "She was outside the center. She was sobbing and shaking. She was still blindfolded. She had no idea where she was, or why."
As Saad Eddin and Nadia Abdel Nour watched in bewilderment, dozens of S.S.I. officers began tearing the Ibn Khaldun Center apart. Others surrounded the building, blocking all access roads. Still others took up positions around it, their automatic assault weapons drawn. Many of their faces were partly concealed by visored helmets, and it was impossible to know who they were.
All across Cairo that evening, lawyers and economists, students and social workers were arrested and taken off to high-security prisons. By the following week, 28 officials and employees of the Ibn Khaldun Center, along with representatives of the League of Egyptian Women Voters, had been swept up. Most remained in prison for two months. During that time, not one of them - not even Saad Eddin Ibrahim - was charged. They were held under Egypt's draconian emergency laws, which President Hosni Mubarak has renewed every three years for the 20 years of his presidency.
It was nearly dawn when Saad Eddin Ibrahim and his 20-car security escort were ushered through the gates of S.S.I. headquarters -- where he was held through the following night. For 14 hours, Saad Eddin was interrogated about his work, his public lectures and his dozen or so books. Interrogators came and went from the windowless spartan room. Some were from the office of the public prosecutor, others from S.S.I. After that ordeal, he was transferred to the high-security section of the Tora prison complex in South Cairo, one of the country's most dreaded detention sites. He would spend six weeks there before being released on bail. 
"My first interrogation ended at about 8 o'clock that night," Saad Eddin said. "It was just twilight when I arrived at Tora Mazra'at. An elderly, white-haired police corporal was sitting at a desk. He peered at me over his half-glasses: 'Dr. Saad Eddin Ibrahim?' 
"I thought he was reading a newspaper, but it was too early for that, and then he said: 'I'm Ali Hamdan. I was a private here 20 years ago, when you came to do research. It was a long time ago.' He paused for a moment and then he asked, 'What has happened to the world?'
"I saw the human face of Egypt that night in this old man," Saad Eddin said. "Previously, I had seen the brutal face of the state. There have been so many faces of Egypt in all of this, so many threads. There I stood in handcuffs, and I had to comfort this old man."
Ali Hamdan composed himself and began leafing through a dusty, frayed ledger book. "I'm sorry, Dr. Ibrahim," he finally said. "We are simply full. We've got a full house, after the arrest of the followers of Sheikha Manal." (The Sheikha, a Cairo housewife, had recently been accused of heresy.) The old man continued going up and down his list: Gama'a al-Islamiya, al-Jihad, the Muslim Brotherhood. It was a veritable who's who of Egypt's Islamist groups.
After a good deal of telephoning - it was the weekend, and no one was picking up - Ali Hamdan finally found someone, who found someone else, who agreed that, since according to the prosecutor's order, Saad Eddin was to be kept in solitary confinement, he should be dispatched to the prison's hospital ward. It was empty, and on that Saturday night in Cairo, everything else was full.
I HAD SEEN Saad Eddin Ibrahim in many personas over the years: as my professor of sociology at the American University of Cairo in the late 1970's; as a friend; as a consultant to the United Nations and the World Bank; as an irascible interlocutor, who favored silk ascots and ties, pounding his fist on a lectern at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York or, with equal skill, puncturing the arguments of a trembling government official on television screens across the Arab world. And yet, it was not until a sunny morning in the late days of April this year, with his trial under way, that I had ever imagined seeing him sitting inside a cage.
In fact, it was the same cage - or perhaps a similar one - in the same High Security Court where the Islamist assassins of the previous Egyptian president, Anwar Sadat, had been tried and sent to their executioners some 20 years before. The symbolism was not lost on any of us sitting in the court. It was that assassination that had led a young Hosni Mubarak, freshly installed as president and brandishing his emergency laws, to establish not only these High Security Courts - against which there is no appeal - but also Emergency Courts and Special Military Courts. All of these have been decried over the years by human rights groups as contrary to all precepts of international law.
In the 1990's, the courts played a crucial role in Mubarak's successful campaign to crush a rebellion by Islamic militants. Thousands of Islamists, alleged Islamists and would-be Islamists were summarily arrested under emergency law and paraded in and out of these courts and their cages, and they continue to be. Even today, between 15,000 and 16,000 Islamists -- not all of them militants -- remain in prison. Many have never been charged or tried. Under Mubarak's emergency laws, his regime is not even obligated to release their names. 
As long as the courts were employed -- ostensibly at least -- against Islamic militants, the West was more than happy to look the other way. But with the arrest and trial of Saad Eddin, Egypt's increasingly powerful security services seemed to have widened their brief, dangerously. For this was the first time, at least that anyone could recall, that a liberal was being tried by one of Mubarak's extraordinary courts. And he was not only a liberal but also the West's favorite Arab intellectual and his country's most prominent human rights and democracy advocate, arguing passionately for an opening to democracy, civil rights and the rights of Egypt's Christian Copts, a minority suffering frequent discrimination. And he had even served occasionally as an adviser to the Egyptian president himself. 
THE ABSURDITY OF THE cage in which Saad Eddin Ibrahim now sat -- a giant metal one along a wall of the room, with planks of wood haphazardly criss-crossing its top, in which the defendants were locked while the court was in session -- was, in a sense, a metaphor for his trial. There he was forced to defend his innocence against a sweeping indictment that neither he nor his lawyers were fully able to comprehend. (It appeared to be contrary to at least two Egyptian laws and legal precedent.) 
For months on end, he listened in pained silence to accusers he did not know, and who had never read his books, but who charged nevertheless that he had "tarnished" Egypt's image abroad. He looked on in disbelief as he was accosted with charges of financial impropriety that were based exclusively on the testimony of one of his associates, who later recanted everything he said and ultimately sat with Saad Eddin inside the metal cage, as a co-defendant.
When the state finally presented its case, it charged Saad Eddin not only with defaming Egypt but also with accepting money from abroad without government approval, embezzling donated funds and conspiring to bribe officials from government-controlled television and radio. (Ultimately, everyone would be acquitted of the bribery charge, after those named as the would-be recipients testified that not only did they not know Saad Eddin but also that most of them didn't even work for state radio or television.)
The defamation count stemmed from the professor's writings and lectures on clashes between Egypt's majority Muslims and the Copts and on his findings of voting irregularities in 88 constituencies during parliamentary elections in 1995. (It is worth noting that eight days after Saad Eddin's arrest, the Supreme Constitutional Court declared the entire Parliament invalid because of electoral irregularities, and that other writers had published reports on discrimination against the Copts without being brought before Mubarak's courts.) 
The charge of accepting money from abroad without the government's permission was rooted in a $250,000 grant from the European Commission to, in part, produce a documentary film on voter registration and education and on the importance of participating in last autumn's poll. That charge was in turn grounded in a 1992 military decree that had been hastily promulgated to prevent Islamist organizations from providing assistance to victims of a devastating Cairo earthquake. 
The issue of the constitutionality of that law is now pending before the courts. But it hardly seemed germane to Saad Eddin's trial, since the law applied only to nongovernmental organizations and charitable groups, not to a research center, like Ibn Khaldun, that had long been registered (and paid taxes) as a civil company.
The final charge, of embezzling funds, seemed particularly silly, since the European Union had insisted all along that the money - which, like all such grants, had been subjected to routine audit - had been properly spent.
If the charges against Saad Eddin seemed flimsy and politically contrived, the unseemly haste with which his judges arrived at their verdict was even more remarkable. There was little pretense of deliberation by the three dark-suited men in a case that involved thousands of pages of documentation and would normally have commanded weeks, if not months, of consideration.
On May 21, 90 minutes after the defense completed its summation and before the defense team had even finished turning over its evidence, the court found Saad Eddin guilty on three of the four charges. He was sentenced to seven years at hard labor, despite his age and his health, which had been deteriorating for some time. Nadia Abdel Nour received two years and was sent to a women's criminal prison. 
The other 26 defendants, in what became known as the Ibn Khaldun trial, were given prison sentences of one to five years. (Twenty of these were suspended.) Barring a presidential reprieve or an appeal on procedural grounds, Saad Eddin and his jailed colleagues have limited legal recourse; there is no appealing the substance of a decision delivered by a High Security Court.
Within hours of the verdict, there were shouts of protest from around the world: from human rights organizations - including Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch, Freedom House and International PEN - the European Union and the United Nations. In meeting after meeting, foreign diplomats have protested to the Egyptian President. 
In the United States, the verdict was condemned by the State Department and by the editorial boards of major newspapers, which raised the issue of Egypt's $2 billion annual stipend from Washington. In Congress, Representative Tom Lantos, a Democrat from California and the co-chairman of the Congressional Human Rights Caucus, circulated a petition in early June calling for President Mubarak to "overturn this miscarriage of justice." 
As the professor was led out of the courtroom and returned to Tora prison late that Monday afternoon, it remained unclear precisely why the trial had even taken place. Those of us who attended it -- journalists and foreign diplomats, human rights monitors, intellectuals, lawyers, family and friends -- had received scant edification from the indictment (which had been cobbled together hastily less than two months before the trial began), from the state prosecutors or from Hosni Mubarak's opaque High Security bench. 
"The reason that Saad Eddin is in that courtroom has nothing to do with what's on the charge sheet," one Western diplomat remarked to me during the trial. "If the purpose of this exercise is to discredit Saad, Mubarak has achieved his ultimate objective: a chastened Saad Eddin Ibrahim in a demoralized civil society." 
It was clear that Saad Eddin had crossed a "red line," but what was it? And what had so provoked the 73-year-old Mubarak that he would risk international censure and opprobrium to teach a lesson to one influential but essentially powerless intellectual? Although it is apparent that the professor's trial was meant to serve as a warning to others, it is less clear who the president's real targets were and why he was seemingly so determined to make a point.
A FORMER COMMANDER OF THE EGYPTIAN AIR Force, Hosni Mubarak is now the longest serving president in his country's history, having presented himself to the voters for six-year terms an unprecedented four times. In these referendums -- in which no opposition candidates are permitted to stand and voters have the choice of voting yes or no -- he has garnered, on average, 96 percent of the vote.
When he assumed office, the day after Sadat's assassination, in 1981, Mubarak spoke of limited presidential terms, of opening Egypt to democracy, of his own need for outside help and advice and of the imperative to reform the country's stagnant economy - nearly 70 percent of which was dominated by bloated and inefficient public sector industries. 
Mindful of Egypt's status as the second leading recipient of United States aid, after Israel, Mubarak reaffirmed his country's commitment to the 1979 peace treaty with Israel and set to work behind the scenes as a mediator in the continuing quest for Middle East peace. Later, he more than anyone else gave legitimacy to the United States-led coalition in the Persian Gulf war. 
Over the years, however, and partly in response to the threat posed by Islamic militants, he began to rescind the limited freedoms he had initially doled out. More recently, vital foreign investment has fallen sharply while the breakdown in the peace process has raised the uncomfortable issue of Egypt's close ties to the country that is Israel's largest and most vocal supporter. In response, his critics say, Mubarak has gravitated more to his security and intelligence services, and grown increasingly out of touch, surrounding himself with sycophants and old military friends. 
Whether the president will utimately release Saad Eddin from prison, no one can say. Clearly, though, the Saad Eddin affair is entering a new phase. It is now, in a sense, Hosni Mubarak and his army-backed regime that are on trial, in western capitals and in the court of international public opinion. Yet, even though Washington is working quietly behind the scenes, it is hardly likely to sacrifice its second most important strategic partner in the Middle East to rescue one prominent intellectual from injustice. But the case does shine an uncomfortable spotlight not only on the heavy-handed tactics of a close ally but also, ultimately, on the Mubarak regime's drift from its early promises of democracy and economic reform to a status-quo autocracy concerned mostly with maintaining its grip on power. 
The lavish infusion of American aid - which at nearly $50 billion since 1979 follows only tourism as Egypt's leading source of foreign exchange - was meant to buy political stability and, perhaps, at least a token of democracy in a sea of repressive regimes. Yet now, an Egyptian-American intellectual whose greatest crime seemed to be his passionate defense of democracy and civil rights, is languishing in one of Egypt's most notorious high-security prisons.
The Saad Eddin Ibrahim I've known over the years is bright and sarcastic, funny and clear, clever and vastly intelligent - a man with powerful friends and powerful enemies whose critics were not amused by what they considered to be his occasional intellectual arrogance. He could be demanding, of his students and his fellow intellectuals. On a trip I made to Egypt in 1998 to research my book, he had insisted that I read a short story called "The Complaints of the Peasant." Peering at me across his cluttered desk at the Ibn Khaldun Center, he told me, somewhat dismissively, I thought, since I had lived in Cairo for three years, "You will never understand Egypt otherwise." It was typical of Saad Eddin. The story had been published, so to speak, on papyrus, in hieroglyphics, some 4,000 years before.
One afternoon while the trial was still in progress, I went with Saad Eddin and some others for a late lunch at a villa in a new development in the midst of the desert. Before arriving in Cairo, I hadn't seen him since 1999, and he had aged visibly, considerably more than two years. His left hand was unsteady, and he walked with a limp. He suffers from a nervous-system disorder, which is still not fully diagnosed. It affects his balance, and he has progressive numbness in his right hand - his writing hand.
As we sped along the highway, I tried to recall all the conflicting opinions I had heard about him. That he is too ambitious, too impulsive, too complex. Or, conversely, that he is a genuinely brilliant social scientist with a message that must be heard. "His power is in his personality as much as in his pen," one of his closest friends said. "He is either the bravest or the most foolish man I've ever met."
Saad Eddin Ibrahim is as quixotic as his country is sometimes anomalous and always complex. He is part Egyptian fellaheen, or son of the soil, an intellectual aristocrat born into a poor farming family. And he is a product of America in the 60's, with a well-stocked mind full of political literature, socialism and Marxism, Black Power and marches against the Vietnam War. He is also part Egyptian establishment, a tenured professor at the American University of Cairo and, until recently, a familiar figure in the corridors of power. A controversial figure who moved with calm assurance through the worlds of militants and mullahs, he was equally at home with Western scholars, Islamic assassins and Egypt's first family.
The American University of Cairo is a rarefied place, catering to the children of Egypt's political and business elite. And it was there, in the late 1970's, that Saad Eddin was first introduced to the Mubarak family. Suzanne, the wife of Mubarak, then vice president, was a student of his (as were the couple's two sons in later years). It was during that period as well that Saad Eddin became the first Egyptian academic to do in-depth research on the country's militant Islamist groups. (He became convinced that the best way to deal with the radicals was to marginalize them by legalizing more moderate groups, like the Muslim Brotherhood, and bringing them into the political arena). In 198l, when Mubarak became president, Suzanne Mubarak called on two of her former professors as advisers. One was Saad. "His relationship with the first lady was always close," one of Mubarak's advisers said. "But he became too bold with the president. He actually told him that it was time to open the country up: to hold elections, bring in democracy." He thought for a moment, and then he said, "That was the end of Saad." 
The story is often told about a meeting that Mubarak held with a group of intellectuals more than five years ago. When the president arrived late, Saad Eddin - to the astonishment of everyone in the room - demanded to know why he had been kept waiting. 
When we reached our lunching spot, a sprawling villa owned by an immensely wealthy businessman in what is called New Cairo, we dispersed into various rooms or onto the terrace, which overhung an enormous swimming pool. The villa, and the development of which it was a part, rose from the barrenness of the surrounding desert almost like a sphinx.
As we sat on the terrace, I asked Saad Eddin what he remembered most about the investigation leading to his trial, which prosecutors appeared to be making up as they went along. He reflected a moment, tilting his face as he rested his chin on his hand. Then he smiled: "The totally chaotic nature of it. It went on for over six weeks. Things were dropped in and dropped out. Altogether, there were 30 charges, 26 of which came and went. Each time we rebutted them, they went back to the Ibn Khaldun Center and tore it upside down. Then they came back with new charges, and it started all over again."
He thought for a moment and said angrily: "What was not chaotic was the simultaneous, highly orchestrated campaign against me in the government press. We've compiled four volumes, four volumes of 300 pages each - that's 1,200 pages of slander against me. They have accused me of everything except doing drugs or being a homosexual. The government used all of its organs of destruction against me." He fell silent for a moment and then shook his head as though all of this must be happening to someone other than him.
"There are so many layers, so many dimensions in all of this," he continued, as the sun began to set over the desert. "How many Egyptian intellectuals feel angry, but impotent? They are torn between expressing themselves openly and being vulnerable to the state." It was the only time I heard bitterness in his voice, for several of his fellow intellectuals had forsaken him since his trial began.
IT IS HARD TO IMAGINE SAAD EDDIN IBRAHIM in Mansura, the center of Egypt's cotton trade, where he was born in 1938. Set in the heart of the lush Nile Delta, it was once, under British rule, an elegant city of villas and gardens. It is now a distinctly provincial town, a chaotic mix of pungent bazaar, cement factories and cement public parks. I had passed through it many times over the years and on its outskirts had watched water buffalo raise the Nile's precious water by turning a crude wooden lift, as they have done for thousands of years. Blindered, they moved in endless circles, as though in a trance. 
Saad Eddin's father, Muhammad, managed the family farm and was often called upon to arbitrate village disputes. His mother, Gowhara, though not educated herself, was fiercely determined that her children, including her daughters, go to school - and they did. The road Saad Eddin traveled out of Mansura, in 1956, to Cairo University, was the same road that had been traveled a decade earlier by Hosni Mubarak, then a young air force recruit from a not-so-distant dusty village.
In 1962, at the age of 23, Saad Eddin arrived in the United States on an Egyptian government scholarship. He remained for 13 years - receiving his master's from the University of California at Los Angeles, his Ph.D. from the University of Washington and his American citizenship. Teaching was, and is, a passion of his, and he taught political sociology at U.C.L.A. and Washington, and also at a joint campus of Purdue University and DePauw. 
It was at DePauw, at a Black Power meeting, that he met his future wife, Barbara. Their courtship consisted, to a large extent, of traveling to antiwar rallies and teach-ins across the Midwest. (Barbara Ibrahim is now the regional director for the New York-based Population Council in West Asia and North Africa.)
Never a private or timid man about his views, Saad Eddin, during his American years, was a student activist, a bit of a Fabian socialist and a passionate follower of Egypt's mercurial leader Gamal Abdel Nasser. But he was devastated when Nasser led his country to humiliating defeat by Israel in the June 1967 Six-Day War. And he had been bewildered and angry the previous year, when Nasser had placed him on a political black list for critical remarks issued by the North American branch of the Arab Students' Association, which Saad Eddin headed. 
Not only did Nasser strip the young Saad Eddin of his Egyptian passport and government-sponsored scholarship, but he also sequestered the family's scant property. (It was only in 1974 that Nasser's successor, Sadat, restored Saad Eddin's passport and personally invited him to return home.)
The intervening years have done little, if anything, to dull his stinging critiques, and his critics have multiplied. If his views on democracy and human rights have outraged Hosni Mubarak's sclerotic regime, his advocacy of an end to discrimination against the Copts has not only angered the government but also vastly irritated the country's Islamic militants. And his calls for a genuine normalization of relations between Egypt and Israel - after more than 20 years of a decidedly cold peace - had produced furious protests from many among Egypt's intellectual elite. They, like Hosni Mubarak himself, have steadfastly refused all invitations over the years to visit the Jewish state (with the lone exception of Yitzhak Rabin's funeral, which Mubarak attended). 
"Saad has always been incomprehensible to so many people here," I was told by Ambassador Hussein Amin, a fellow intellectual and close friend of Saad Eddin's. "Some of it, of course, is professional jealousy. He has been such a success, materially and otherwise. Whenever there's a seminar in Europe or the States, he's consulted on whom to invite. He's altogether a wonderful man. But many intellectuals are wary, suspicious of him. They simply cannot comprehend why he says what he says."
A month or so before his arrest, Saad Eddin had participated in two seminars that addressed a particularly horrific slaughter in the Upper Egyptian village of el Kusheh on New Year's Eve last year in which 21 Copts were killed, execution-style, by Muslim villagers. Immediately thereafter, he began receiving death threats. They may have - but probably did not - come from Islamic militants. On three previous occasions, in 1992, 1994 and early 1999, when the country's intellectuals found themselves trapped in a no man's land between the Islamic militants and the government, Saad Eddin was offered security protection by the state. But he had turned the offers down. 
"Now, I had actually been threatened," he told me one afternoon during a break in the trial. "So, I went off to see the head of State Security. Now I wanted protection, but they turned me down." The American University of Cairo later provided him with a guard.
"I think I sensed that afternoon that something was amiss," Saad Eddin went on. "During six weeks in prison, you have time to evaluate all your past sins, and I kept asking myself: What did I do? What did I say to the head of State Security that afternoon? He had mentioned my research on the elections and the Copts, and then he remarked, 'Why do you persist?' I replied, 'If a social scientist doesn't investigate the problems of his society, what good is he?' 
"The chief of security thought about this for a moment, and then he said: 'We will not protect you until you get off these hot topics. We don't want to appear to be associated with your views."'
"Fine," I replied. "I'd rather be killed than silenced. One month later, they tried to kill me, metaphorically."
Three weeks after our meeting, the High Security Court handed down its verdict. "This is politically motivated, and the sentence is politically dictated," Saad Eddin Ibrahim told The Associated Press on his cellular phone as he was being led out of the court by a dozen or so armed guards. "It is a struggle, and it will go on. I do not regret anything I stood for."
Yet as Saad Eddin was returned to jail, there were still more questions than answers in Cairo, not unlike the weeks in April when I was there. Two of the four charges against him concerned foreign financing - curious, I thought, in a country that survives on foreign aid. But as one European Union diplomat remarked to me: "This trial is about political intimidation, not about fraud. If the regime thought that fraud was involved, they should have sent tax inspectors to the Ibn Khaldun Center, not S.S.I. thugs. The line that Saad Eddin crossed has never been defined." 
Why Saad Eddin? Many close observers think the precipitant event was his appearance last June on the Rome-based satellite station, Orbit. It was a live broadcast of the funeral of the Syrian president, Hafez al-Assad. Saad Eddin was the main commentator, describing the events and responding to viwers who called in with questions or observations. The coverage was scheduled for 3 hours, but it lasted 12, during which Saad Eddin had to continue talking. This "is always bad for Saad," according to one of his friends. "He doesn't mean to be provocative. He just opens his mouth and he is."
In time, the discussion turned to the elevation to the presidency of Assad's son, Bashar, and the Arab world's bizarre system of Republican dynasties. "Yes," Saad Eddin told the audience, "it has happened in Syria, and most likely it will happen in Iraq, in Yemen, in Libya." 
"But what about Egypt?" a caller asked.
The professor replied that Egypt was not applicable, because Mubarak himself had publicly denied that he was grooming his younger son, Gamal, as his heir - a denial that few Egyptians believed. 
"But even though Mubarak denied it, it could still happen, couldn't it?" the caller persisted. 
"The guy was really getting on my nerves," Saad Eddin said later. "I thought to myself, He never quits."
And thus, the professor scripted a scenario in which members of the ruling National Democratic Party would march to the Presidential Palace and demand that Mubarak anoint his son. The President would resist and resist, but ultimately he would concede to public pressure.
When Mubarak saw the tape, he was furious. Seventeen days later, his security apparatus stormed into Saad Eddin Ibrahim's home. 
"I don't doubt that the Orbit commentary was the last straw," one Western ambassador said to me. "There are three power centers in Egypt which had it in for Saad: the intelligence service, which disdained his reporting on the Copts; the ruling party, which was outraged by his documentation of electoral fraud; and the information people, who simply loathed everything he did. But Saad had a lot of powerful friends. Ministers and former ministers were on his board. Mrs. Mubarak was a friend. And as long as those friends remained there for him, and he stayed within certain bounds, the three power centers couldn't touch him. But in a country like this, talking about the president's family simply is not done. And I also think the family felt a personal element of betrayal."
The question of Mubarak's successor is a particularly delicate one, all the more so as it has remained unanswered for 20 years. The president's problem has always been whether to appoint a civilian or a military man. In recent years, the question has become even more pronounced, as old-style totalitarian leaders in the Arab world have given way to a new generation of Western-educated technocrats -- who are also their sons. But for Egypt's military establishment, which has grown accustomed, over five decades, to its role as the country's final arbiter of power, the idea of a dynastic succession is untenable.
It was a matter of some import, then, when a year or so ago, Mubarak began grooming his 37-year-old son, Gamal, an investment banker who had lived in London and who had frequently done business in the United States. Gamal was given a senior post in the ruling National Democratic Party, began accompanying the president abroad and started to attend cabinet meetings. The country's powerful businessmen, the only new element on Egypt's otherwise dormant political scene, were Gamal's most influential constituency. 
The Orbit commentary was not the first time that Saad Eddin had tackled the issue of Republican dynasties. He had written a sarcastic article about them earlier for Al-Majala, a Saudi magazine. But few of those who mattered in Mubarak's world read Al-Majala, yet everyone watched Orbit TV - including the leaders of the Middle East, who had marched solemnly with the president to Assad's burial ground, and, even more important, the leaders of Egypt's 300,000-man army.
BY JUNE 21, Justice Muhammad Shalabi, who presided over Saad Eddin Ibrahim's trial, must justify, in writing, why he and his two colleagues on the bench arrived at the verdict they did. The defense lawyers then have 60 days to file an appeal, which they certainly will do, to the Court of Cassation, the country's highest court. But the appeal can be made only on procedural grounds. On the basis of one of his military decrees, however, Mubarak may override a decision of a High Security Court by granting an amnesty.
I couldn't help wondering how Mubarak was reacting to the growing furor caused by the verdict in Saad Eddin's trial. For the Egyptian president is a man of more than average vanity who, over the years, has reacted negatively to criticism. His temper is also legendary. During the weeks that Saad Eddin was being held in prison without charge, Mubarak had spurted out to a string of foreign ambassadors who had come to protest: Why is everyone so concerned about this stupid man?
The answer, of course, is that the arrest and trial forced Western governments - and Washington in particular - to acknowledge certain realities about Egypt that they had long and conveniently overlooked. The trials in which defense lawyers have limited, if any, access to prosecutorial documents. The arrests at gunpoint in the middle of the night. The indefinite imprisonments without charge (or sometimes even trial). The almost total absence of legal niceties like search warrants or indictments. All of this had been happening in Mubarak's Egypt for nearly 20 years. Yet now, with the world watching, it had happened to his country's most prominent intellectual, and an American citizen on top of that. 
This is not to say that Mubarak's regime does not tolerate any dissent. Egypt's normal system of justice continues to function. And it is difficult to imagine what could have been more embarrassing to Mubarak and his regime than when the Supreme Constitutional Court ruled that Egypt's entire rubber-stamp parliament was illegal, because of electoral irregularities. 
Mubarak's apparent insensitivity to international opinion can be attributed in part to the circumstances he faced in the months leading up to Saad Eddin's arrest. His privatization process, once a proud symbol of Egypt's commitment to economic reform and modernization, had been largely on hold for two years, upsetting the country's newly emergent, and powerful, business community. The economy had suffered a sudden and serious slump. 
His security forces, concerned about the income inequalities that were expanding along with reform, were preaching caution. Their major concern was to avoid a repeat of 1977 and 1986, when tens of thousands of angry rioters took to the streets and presented Mubarak (and Anwar Sadat before him) with the greatest challenges of their presidencies.
But social tensions were increasing nevertheless. With foreign investment falling and employment stagnating, there have been unpublicized strikes, and peasants are selling their cattle and abandoning their land. And despite the best efforts of the regime to prevent Islamists from voting in last autumn's parliamentary poll, the Muslim Brotherhood -- whose candidates stood as independents, since the party remained banned -- had emerged as the second largest bloc in Parliament. 
Over the years, Mubarak's primary value to the United States has been his role behind the scenes, as an important moderating force in the quest for Middle East peace. Yet as the Clinton administration, in its final months, was frantically trying to forge a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians, for three weeks, both during and after the most critical phase of the Camp David peace talks, Mubarak was simply left out.
The summer and the fall of last year were not an auspicious time for Mubarak and his regime. And it was not a time in which the Egyptian president, or his security and intelligence establishment, wanted the added irritant of dealing with a person like Saad Eddin.
During the weeks I spent in Cairo in April, there were huge anti-American demonstrations on Egyptian campuses nearly every day as the violence between Israelis and Palestinians reached an intensity that had not been seen for years. And every evening, government-controlled television screens were full of images of Palestinian women and children being killed. 
It was not a time to be seen as being associated with the United States. And Saad Eddin's public image had not been helped when, a month or so before the Palestinian al-Aqsa intifada took hold, Egypt's public prosecutor first leaked to the press that Saad Eddin had been accused of spying for the United States.
The transparently baseless accusation was drawn exclusively from a lecture he had given at a seminar, also attended by a number of Egyptian government officials (including a handful of retired generals), at the U.S. National Defense University in 1994. The accusation was never translated into a formal charge, but it may remain on the books; no one knows except Mubarak and his intelligence service. Saad Eddin's legal team has been pressing for an answer, but even the state prosecutor has told them that he simply does not know if the charge still stands. 
The only insights that anyone has are from comments by Mubarak himself, who in a Newsweek interview in March, while Saad Eddin's trial was under way, said: "You are making a big fuss about this man. Some people consider him as a traitor. ... There was a very serious accusation against him. I told the attorney general, put it aside, because this would make a big story and very high punishment."
Saad Eddin's fate rests, for the moment, in Mubarak's hands, yet in some sense, Mubarak's fate also rests in Saad's, in the court of public opinion abroad. And it was in that court, almost certainly on the day of the funeral of Hafez al-Assad, that the contest between the professor and the president had been joined - a contest with a present and a past, and one that is highly personal for both men.
The last evening I saw Saad Eddin Ibrahim, the khamsin wind had begun, swallowing Cairo in clouds of sand and dust that rolled over the city from the deserts to the south. A hazy patina obscured all outlines and shapes, and nothing was what it appeared to be.
"Have you gotten everything you need?" he asked.
I told him I still was curious about one thing: why did he think his trial had taken place?
He didn't answer immediately, and then he said: "As I told you before, there are so many threads interwoven in all of this: the state versus civil society; the internal versus the external; the personal versus the personal. As much as I try to understand, I may be more enlightened, but still, questions remain. When I was in prison, I could see the state as in an X-ray, not beautified but stripped down. And I saw how fragile the heart of the state is." 
He paused for a moment, and then he said: "In a pyramid, which we perfected 4,000 years ago, when even one stone is removed, the structure faces the danger of collapse. So it is not so much that Saad Eddin Ibrahim is a threat per se, but rather, he is an example that could be emulated, one stone at a time." 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Laws devised to punish Islamists were used against the liberal intellectual Saad Eddin, left, and his associate Nadia Abdel Nour.; " Why Is everyone so concerned about this stupid man?" President Mubarak has repeatedly asked.; Under Mubarak's draconian emergency laws, Islamists like these being released from Tora prison can be held without being charged and without their names being released. (Norbert Schiller)

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 6-17-01: DOCUMENT; 
The Study of O.

 BODY:
 This past semester, the history department at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign offered a new undergraduate course: "Oprah Winfrey, the Tycoon," developed and taught by Prof. Juliet E.K. Walker. According to Walker's description, the purpose of the interdisciplinary course was "to critically examine and analyze Winfrey's activities in the building of her entertainment empire within the context of the impact of a multiplicity of societal, cultural and economic factors in the post-modern information age propelled by a new technology in the New Economy of Global Capitalism." Fourteen students completed the class. Herewith, a sampling of their term papers, the first forays into the nascent field of Oprah Studies.

"Body Image," by Lauren Gassman
Oprah's fluctuating weight is analogous to the history of women's weight and body image in America, where women have changed drastically over almost every decade. . . . The history of women's body image has been a roller coaster of weight fluctuations and different images of the ideal body. Oprah Winfrey epitomizes the struggle of most women in that every woman is striving to be what society calls "normal." . . . Through Oprah's yo-yo diets, weight fluctuations and weight-loss shows, one thing is for certain: the idea of body normality weighs heavily with Oprah and many other women throughout the world.

"Oprah Winfrey: A Symbol for African-American Philanthropy," by Katharine Dahl-Kearney.
Many celebrities use philanthropy as a way to gain even more publicity and get more fans. However, most of Winfrey's philanthropy is private, and the only times she goes public is when she wants to draw attention to the cause. Philanthropy and self-help are important concepts in the African-American culture and have been around for a long time. . . . During the 18th and 19th centuries, blacks raised money for education, churches, troubled women and children and the general uplift of the African-American culture. These are exactly the same causes Winfrey champions today. Although she was 200 years after the organization of the first African-American Philanthropic society, she still continues many of the same initiatives.

"Image: Is It Everything?" by Aricka Flowers
The extremes of people's thoughts on who Oprah is span from comments by critics indicating that she is the master of the con, along with Phil Donahue, to describing her in terms of the black mammy stereotype: nearly 200 pounds of Mississippi-bred black womanhood, brassy, earthy, street smart and soulful. Seeing that there is such a disparity between the two aforementioned critics' commentaries on Ms. Winfrey, there needs to be some closer analysis of why. . . . It will become apparent that Winfrey's image to most people is the same. The discrepancy comes from their own views and even biases of what exactly the image means or does.

"A Case of: Cristina Saralegui & Oprah Winfrey," by Rolando Argumedo Jr.
Oprah Winfrey is a media giant. She has her hands all over television, the publishing industry and the Internet. But, Oprah does remember where her people have been. . . . With the power and celebrity she possesses, Oprah is free to take on all challenges and new enterprises. The only person who could possibly stop Oprah -- is Oprah Winfrey. This won't happen for a while.

HEADLINE: State Wants New Station, But Where to Build It? 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
THE nine miles of tracks between the Milford and New Haven railroad stations is the longest stretch without a stop along the Metro-North line in Connecticut. Just check the schedule. It is three or four minutes between most stops in the state, but the trip between Milford and New Haven is 15 minutes, climbing to 18 minutes on some trains.
 It is a commuting no man's land that forces people who travel from the towns in between, Orange and West Haven, to make their way to Milford or New Haven to board a train, meaning many have a long commute even before their rail trip begins. 
 For years the State Department of Transportation has considered building a new station somewhere along that corridor. And for years Orange officials have said it should be built there because of the presence of the Bayer Corporation, a major employer, in their town. West Haven officials have said, no, their city is best because of all the people who would use the station to get to work. 
The issue may soon be settled. Later this month, the State Department of Transportation is expected to receive the results of a six-month study that will recommend where to build the $25 million to $30 million station. Although new stations have been built along branches of the New Haven line, a new location hasn't been added in the state on the main line since the route was built about 100 years ago. And while the agency is used to towns on the branch lines telling it to put the new stations somewhere else, this is the first time municipalities have actually fought to get one.
"Frankly, the battle between West Haven and Orange is unique, completely unprecedented," said Harry Harris, the chief of the state agency's public transportation bureau. "Nothing like it -- the fight between a town and city over a proposed train station -- has ever happened before."
For nearly a decade West Haven town officials dreamed the station would be built in their shoreline city of 54,000 that borders New Haven because they believed it would help spur revitalization and development in an economically depressed urban center. They also said it would provide desperately needed transportation for the estimated thousands of people who live within walking distance of the proposed station. The city once had a station, but the transportation department said it was closed in 1929.
For a variety of reasons, including some community opposition and lack of state funds, several proposals in the mid-1990's for a new station were dropped.
Two years ago, Orange, an affluent community of 12,000, came up with a proposal to build the station in that town instead. That station would be built at the doorstep of Bayer, the pharmaceutical company, which is the top single employer and taxpayer in both communities.
Ann Sousa, a senior administrative assistant at Bayer, who commutes more than 30 miles each way from Clinton, wants the station in Orange. She said she is among a group of about 25 Bayer employees who take the train to New Haven and then are taken to work by a company shuttle bus, which takes the workers back to the station after work.
"Every morning and afternoon there's the pressure that you have to catch one of the three shuttle buses or you are going to be stranded at the station in the morning or at work in the late afternoon," said Ms. Sousa. She said she has driven to work, but the commute on Interstate 95 is even more time-consuming.
The same is true for Juliette Carmody, who is an elementary school teacher in Bridgeport and lives on Church Street just a few blocks from the proposed station in West Haven. She now drives to Bridgeport and said what should be a simple 20-minute commute is more often a "nightmarish one to two hours" I-95. She said she has considered taking the train from Milford and New Haven, but that by the time she drove to either one and parked, it would take her even longer.
"We desperately need the station," she said. "We've been hearing about it and waiting 30 years for it and now I can't believe Orange can just come in and take it away from us. I've been driving to work for years, and every year I pray harder and harder for a train station so I don't have to face that awful turnpike drive anymore."
The attempt by Orange to land the station has outraged West Haven leaders and spurred a grass-roots effort to bring the station there, culminating in a 7,500-signature petition drive this year led by Michael Mercuriano, a lifelong resident and local real estate appraiser and broker.
"This would be a mass transit project and the masses are in West Haven where the station would benefit far more people than it would in Orange," said Mr. Mercuriano, who served on the city's Redevelopment Commission for 11 years. "The need is here where you will find the needy, not in Orange where a station would amount to nothing more than corporate welfare for Bayer Corporation."
West Haven Mayor Richard Borer Jr. said "both towns have our strengths and weaknesses," but said more people would be affected if the station were located in his town.
"There's no question in my mind that more people would be helped by a train station here in our city than in Orange," he said. "We envision businesses actually springing up around the station site -- coffee shops, salons, restaurants that will create new jobs. And in West Haven there are people who live near the station who would be able to use it."
In a survey of people who live and work in West Haven that the city conducted in April and May, 90.2 percent of the 1,100 people responding indicated they would likely use a West Haven train station, and 8.5 percent said they would use the station six or more times per week. The survey also found that about 9 percent said they currently take the train in New Haven or Milford.
Orange hasn't conducted a survey. But Mitchell Goldblatt, the town's first selectman, insisted that a station in his town would be the far better site for the region because it would be more accessible, easier and faster to build, and would help get more cars off I-95, which is one of the state's main goals in planning a new station. 
"The Orange site is nearly midway between the New Haven and Milford stations," Mr. Goldblatt said, "and is directly off Marsh Hill Road, which is currently undergoing a major state reconstruction that includes road widening and exit and entrance ramp expansion that will be completed long before construction on the station would even start."
He pointed out that there are 26 properties near the West Haven site, off Saw Mill Road between Railroad Avenue and Hood Terrace, that would have to be obtained or condemned to make way for the station, but in Orange there are only about a half dozen.
West Haven leaders said most of the properties in their city are owned by two or three individuals and aren't homes as they are in Orange.
The two final proposals were selected last year from among about a dozen by the South Central Regional Council of Governments that represents 15 towns and cities in the New Haven region. 
Judy Gott, the executive director of the council, said it would support either location.
Both sites are within 2 1/2 miles of each other, are each within a short distance of Interstate 95 and both would offer more than 1,000 parking spaces.
The West Haven site, off Exit 42 of I-95 in the old Savin Rock industrial area off Saw Mill Road, would actually have more parking with plans for 1,500 spaces compared with about 1,000 in Orange. The Marsh Hill Road Orange site, off I-95 Exit 41, would include a 500-car parking garage.
Making it even tougher to decide which site is better, both plans also include offers by owners of properties at the two sites to finance part or all of the projects and then leasing the property back to the state.
In West Haven, Martin DeGrand, a principal of DeGrand Trucking who owns property near the proposed site, has offered to finance the entire project and then lease it back to the state. In Orange, DiChello Distributors Inc., which owns the land where the station would be built, has offered to build the parking garage and then lease it to the state.
But while the Orange plan is being mostly pushed by politicians and government leaders, on the West Haven side Mr. Mercuriano, 54, has mounted an aggressive grass-roots campaign that includes the petition and support from the local Veterans Hospital, the city's Chamber of Commerce, the Center for Disability Rights and Notre Dame High School. 
The Bayer Corporation late last year said it supported the Orange location, although Laura Malis, a spokeswoman for the company, said it did not know how many employees who drive to work would use either station. The main entrance to Bayer, which employs 2,000 at a 113-acre campus that straddles the border of Orange and West Haven, is in Orange.
Support for Orange also comes from State Rep. Raymond Collins, a Democract who represents both communities. He introduced a bill in the General Assembly earlier this year to allocate funding to prepare plans for an Orange station.
"If we take emotion out of the equation, the ideal site is clearly in Orange," Mr. Collins said. "The Orange site is at the junction of not only Orange and West Haven, but also the city of Milford, which has terrible overcrowded conditions at its downtown station, and the Orange site would draw Milford commuters, too."
Mr. Harris, of the transportation department, said that the consultant's report will go a long way in determining where the station would be built, noting that adding a new stop would add three or four minutes to the commute to or from New Haven.
The report on the sites is being prepared by Frederick R. Harris, a consulting firm in Stamford. Mr. Harris (no relation to the Frederick R. Harris firm) said short of finding a fatal flaw at either site, he will look for factors in the consultant's report such as cost and environmental comparisons, traffic volume, estimated user volume and which site would require more roadwork. 
He said that once a location is chosen, his agency would request the money from the Legislature.. He said once the money is approved, it could take four or five years to complete the station.
Mr. Goldblatt, the Orange first selectman, is confident, but knows the decision of where to put the station could go either way.
"It's all going to come down to the state's priorities -- if the top priority is to find the best location for the region then there's no question it would be in Orange," he said. "But if it's to help an urban center by providing a train station, then of course we don't stand a chance."

Top, passengers get off a train in New Haven, the station many West Haven and Orange commuters must use instead. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)(pg. 1)
