HEADLINE: The Coming Of Tiger 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

DATELINE: HARRISON 

 BODY:
WHEN the news hit the driving range at the Westchester Country Club that Tiger Woods had officially committed to playing this week's Buick Classic here, Mark DiBuno took out a yardage finder and zeroed in on the stately homes nearby.
 DiBuno, who runs the range, pronounced them about 350 yards away, safely out of reach of club members. But a decent drive by Woods could well take out a bay window. 
 "I'm going to have to find a special spot for him way in the back," he said, half-joking.
But there was no joke about the news: Tiger was coming. And suddenly a 34-year-old tournament that has never sold out is bracing for the biggest crowds in its history. 
"The day Tiger Woods says he's playing in your tournament, it lifts virtually every aspect of your revenue stream, from TV to concession, merchandise sales and attendance income," said Dean Bonham, a sports marketing analyst based in Denver.
"It creates utter chaos," he added, "but I can assure you it is chaos people running the event are happy to deal with. It gives instant credibility and profitability, and the carry-over affects next year and the years beyond, even if Tiger doesn't show up again."
For months, Woods and Buick had said only that the Buick Classic was on Woods's schedule. And tournament officials worried that, especially with the U.S. Open the week before the Buick Classic, Woods would again skip the Classic, in order to recover.
But on June 7, Buick announced that Woods had committed to play, and the tournament basically changed from a local tour stop into a national event. Tournament workers scrambled into overdrive to brace for the crowds.
The usual number of shuttle buses from parking lots and train stations has been doubled to 40, and 10,000 parking spaces have been secured at lots at Purchase College and local corporate parks. The tournament has hired extra security guards, the nine concession tents have been enlarged and additional bleachers have been installed.
Peter Mele, the tournament director, said he had been planning for two different events, one with Woods and one without him. Early mention that Woods would play, he said, "allowed us to put a Tiger plan in place."
Mele said that more tournament marshals would be added to Woods's playing group to deal with crowds.
"His presence puts more pressure on our people working out on the course," he said. "It's just such an impact, and there are just that many more spectators to deal with, that it makes it more critical they do their job well."
Now officials are faced with the problem of ticket sales, something akin to word getting out about Springsteen playing the local prom. Tickets have sold briskly since speculation about Woods began. Typically, tickets have always been available at the gate. But this year, officials say, it is likely that every round will sell out.
Woods's appearance in a tournament can double its attendance. While some other tournaments routinely get 50,000 to 60,000 spectators, the Classic has usually dealt with crowds of less than 20,000. In a smaller market, the Greater Hartford Open has drawn 100,000 on weekends.
Ticketmaster outlets are handling the sales, and for the first time, there is the prospect of tickets being scalped. Mele said he would limit sales to 35,000 tickets a day, the maximum the course can handle.
"We want to make sure fans have a good experience," he said. "If we go and add another 5,000 tickets and tell people tickets are still available at the gate, we could have 10,000 people show up, and everyone would have a miserable experience. We just don't have the parking."
General admission tickets are $30 a day, but there are other options, including the $60 ticket to gain admittance to the club's patio for lunch. The $150 ticket provides admittance to the Champions Club, a large air-conditioned hospitality tent in the center of the course with panoramic views.
But much of the golf course, built in 1922, offers only casual viewing at best. It cannot accommodate the large crowds seen by more modern courses built for stadium golf.
Still, tournament officials are trying to devise strategies to handle larger crowds, creating new viewing and walking areas and adding more bleachers, including 500 new seats behind the 17th green, Mele said.
It is hard to overstate what Woods's appearance means to the Buick Classic, Westchester's most prominent sporting event. Golf industry experts say his presence alone will lift the event to a status it has never attained, increasing national visibility and even giving the area an economic boost.
"We've never seen anything like this here," said Brandon Steiner, chairman of Steiner Sports, a New Rochelle-based marketing company. "Westchester has no sporting events like this. You may get, what, 3,000 people at Yonkers Raceway? But this will fill every hotel and restaurant. There are cars being rented and private jets landing at the airport. It's hard to estimate, but this could be a $25 million boost in the economy.
"This is huge publicity for Westchester," he added. "Tiger is the critical difference for being a first-class golf tournament. If you don't have him, you're simply not in the big leagues. People are going to come from all over because it's once in a lifetime. Imagine you had the opportunity to see Babe Ruth play."
Since it was born as the Westchester Classic in 1967, won by Jack Nicklaus, the tournament has grown every year. However, it has never fully capitalized on its proximity to New York City, where interest in golf takes a back seat to celebrity cachet. 
But Woods, arguably one of the world's most famous athletes, has the celebrity to draw non-golf fans and could raise the tournament's status.
Certainly, the New York connection is being seized upon by marketing officials this year, with Woods scheduled to play in a foursome with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in a charity pro-am on Wednesday. Proceeds from the tournament will go to New York United Hospital Medical Center in Port Chester and other charities.
The buzz about Tiger extends beyond the golf course. Nearby homeowners are making a cottage industry of selling parking space in their yards and renting out their houses for the week for upwards of $20,000.
Hotels are booked, and the county airport is preparing for the roughly 20 top players flying in by private jet, said Steve Ferguson, the airport's operations manager.
Even the golf course itself is being shored up, for golfers and spectators alike.
The course has always been one of the toughest on the tour, and according to Joe Alonzi, the course's longtime superintendent, it will play even tougher this year because of significant changes.
"The players are going to see a different golf course," he said. His staff of 42 workers has been expanded to 65 to prepare for the tournament.
Most of the sand traps, 57 to be exact, were rebuilt this spring, some were reconfigured, and some were deepened up to seven feet, with new drainage and new sand. The tee areas on holes 6 and 13 were moved back about 30 yards to add length.
The rough has been grown about eight inches high, and the greens are as hard and fast as they have ever been. They are cut three times a day and rolled smooth every morning. And instead of using sprinklers, workers are now hand-watering the greens.
The improvements demanded five acres of new sod, installed around the greens and bunkers, but also in gallery areas, to prepare for the crowds.
"We're going to have the largest crowds ever here, and the walking areas are tight," Alonzi said. "We may have to close the gates, and to me that's a good thing, because if you sell an unlimited amount of tickets, this course is just not equipped to handle that."
The news about Woods had Steve Mahady, operations manager for the tournament, speeding around in a golf cart, fielding calls on his walkie-talkie and cell phone.
"Of course we're bracing for Tiger; it takes the event to a different level," said Mahady, one of the four P.G.A. Tour employees who work on this event year-round. "With or without Tiger, it's a lot of details to handle. They just become much larger details if he comes.
"You can see we have limited real estate here," he said. "I mean, this is New York. Also with parking. If this were Kansas City, you could have people park 20 miles away and that's 20 minutes. In New York that can mean three hours."
Mahady zoomed by the 18th green, where workers were assembling a large metal scaffolding for the luxury sky boxes. The 19 corporate boxes each have air conditioning and bar and food accommodations for about 30 people. The ones overlooking the 18th green cost $40,000 for the week, and the ones on holes 16 and 17 cost $30,000, including food and drink.
One of seven air-conditioned toilet trailers being used this week had arrived at the course and Mahady was directing it into the corporate hospitality area. The area looks like a futuristic village with its dozen cone-top tents, which are rented by companies that include Buick and ABC.
In the middle of the course is the Spectator Village, where fans can visit interactive exhibits by ESPN, Bloomberg and others.
Lisa Harap, who oversees hundreds of volunteers preparing for the tournament, said that when new volunteers arrive the first thing they are told is how to deal with the most common phone call.
"It's every call," she said. "They all ask, 'Is Tiger coming?' People say they're coming solely because of him."
One volunteer, Jamie Willis, said that once it was announced that Woods was playing, the tournament was flooded with volunteers.
"Every Tom, Dick and Harry wants to volunteer now, and every coach of every golf program wants free tickets," said Willis, who for seven years has commuted by train from Manhattan to work the tournament.
The day before the 1997 event began, Ernie Els, who won the Classic in 1996 and 1997, called Woods "the future of golf."
And since then, Woods has rewritten golf history, winning its four major tournaments in succession, something no golfer has done except Bobby Jones in 1930. And Woods is shooting for his fifth straight major this weekend, the U.S. Open.
In his sixth year on the P.G.A. Tour, Woods, 25, has won 28 tournaments. Last year, he won nine tournaments and set a record for the lowest seasonal scoring average, 67.79.
Still, his history at the Buick Classic has been less than spectacular. He missed the cut as an 18-year-old amateur in 1994. And in 1997, after winning the Masters in his first full season as a pro, he tied for 43rd at the Buick Classic.
The other 155 golfers playing in the Classic this week range from local club pros to some of the world's top players, including Els, Vijay Singh, Sergio Garcia, Corey Pavin, Steve Elkington, Ben Crenshaw and Nick Faldo.
But the spotlight is clearly on Woods.
"If he wins the U.S. Open the week before this, you won't be able to get a ticket," predicted John Kennedy, director of golf at the Westchester Country Club. Even fans who do get tickets, he added, may not see much of Woods anyway.
"This is a traditional golf course, not one designed for a huge crowd," he said. "If you have 25,000 total spectators and 10,000 of them are following Tiger, you have to get out four, five, six holes ahead just to see him go by. Unless you come early enough to see him warm up on the range, you could wind up seeing maybe two shots during his round."
He predicted success for Woods at Westchester. The course has narrow fairways and small fast greens, and a long hitter like Woods can afford to hit irons off the tee for accuracy. The two long par 5's here, the 9th and 18th holes, will be more difficult than ever, even for Woods, since new bunkers were added around the green to make it harder to hit in two shots. 
Woods needs the $630,000 first-place prize money about as much as he needs the Buick S.U.V. given to the winner.
Since turning pro in September 1996, he has become the P.G.A. Tour's all-time leading money winner with more than $24 million. He won a record $9.2 million in prize money last year.
But his prize money pales in comparison with the $370.4 million he has landed in endorsement contracts. He negotiated two five-year, $100 million contracts, one with Nike and another with Disney, the richest endorsement contracts in sports history.
Given his wealth and success, there has been much speculation about why Woods decided to play in the Buick Classic this year. 
Traditionally, the tournament falls before the U.S. Open, a week in which Woods likes to prepare rather than compete. That's not the case this year, however, making the event more attractive. 
But on the golf courses of Westchester, many wondered whether Woods was feeling pressure from Buick, which signed him to a five-year, $25 million contract in 1999. Since then Woods only played in two of the four Buick-sponsored tournaments last year.
But Tony Derhake, executive director of Buick Golf, denied this.
"There was no arm-twisting," he said. "He has no commitment to play in any of our tournaments."
Derhake did say that, of Buick's four tournaments, the Classic is in the company's largest and most important market, and that Woods's presence would give the tournament its highest visibility ever.
"Oh, big time," he said. "He'll give it the largest lift it's ever gotten. He can double the attendance, the concession and the press coverage. This will definitely sell more Buicks."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Of Politics, Free Markets, And Tending To Society

BYLINE:  By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
WHEN President Bush rejected the pleas late last month of Gov. Gray Davis of California to impose price caps on Western electricity rates, the president used the language of Economics 101 to argue that price controls would be a dangerous interference with the free market. "Price caps do nothing to reduce demand," Mr. Bush said, "and they do nothing to increase supply."
 But when confronted only a few days later with an equally blatant demand to cast aside the workings of the market -- in a case involving imported steel -- Mr. Bush went the other way. He abandoned his free-trade argument and threw his support behind quotas against foreign steel makers. 
 Hypocritical? Perhaps. But also perfectly understandable.
And for economists who insist on the sanctity of the market above everything else, there are lessons in both moves.
For one thing, in a democracy politics trumps economics just about every time. By moving against so-called dumping, the sale of imported steel in the United States at low prices, President Bush was playing to two steel-making states, West Virginia and Pennsylvania, that are crucial to his re-election plans.
And by rejecting Governor Davis's demands for price controls, the president was making it equally clear that he already considers California to be lost to the Democrats. (If the Bush administration agrees this week to limit Western electricity prices in response to pressure from lawmakers, that only reinforces the importance of political influence over economic reasoning.)
Steven E. Landsburg, an economist at the University of Rochester, was understandably cheered by Mr. Bush's opposition to price caps and even more angered by his move to limit steel imports. In The Wall Street Journal, he wrote:
"Free trade is not only about the right of American consumers to buy at the cheapest possible price; it's also about the right of foreign producers to earn a living. Steelworkers in West Virginia struggle hard to make ends meet. So do steelworkers in South Korea. To protect one at the expense of the other, solely because of where they happened to be born, is a moral outrage."
But for all the eloquence of that view, it will not carry market advocates very far. It is not some evil character flaw to care more about the welfare of people nearby than about that of those far away -- it's human nature. And it is morally -- and economically -- defensible.
Even though they create wealth and promote overall efficiency, markets do, after all, leave plenty of losers. Steelworkers in Pennsylvania genuinely suffer when they lose their jobs to Korean mills that can provide less expensive steel to the benefit of American consumers. Similarly, the profits of energy producers enjoying the advantages of tight electricity markets, whether or not they are gaming the system, come directly out of the pockets of California energy users and taxpayers.
These negative effects cannot be dismissed out of hand. A society that ignores the consequences of economic disruption on those among its citizens who come out at the short end of the stick is not only heartless, it also undermines its own cohesion and adaptability. Indeed, the more efficiently the machinery of the market has operated in recent years, the more those who see themselves as its victims have tried to throw sand in the gears.
Francis Fukuyama, in a book called "Trust: The Social Virtues and the Creation of Prosperity" (Free Press, 1996), argued that neoclassical economics, for all its virtues, ignores the role of "social capital," such intangibles as "reciprocity, moral obligation, duty toward community and trust," in maintaining the prosperity of post-industrial societies.
"American liberals need to understand that they cannot take organic cohesion of American society for granted," Mr. Fukuyama wrote. "American conservatives, for their part, have to understand that before they cut back the role of the state in society, they should have some idea about how to regenerate civil society and find alternative ways of taking care of its weaker members."
At the same time, the case for relying primarily on market mechanisms to deal with issues like California's energy woes and the decline of the American steel industry remains strong. The political tendency to drag things out often only adds to the costs and creates more suffering than getting the pain out of the way quickly. But in promoting such approaches, economists need to take the losses into account and support substantial compensation for those who suffer the consequences.
"Those who pay attention to community," Mr. Fukuyama concluded, "may indeed become the most efficient of all."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
The Planners Pounce on the Tax Cut

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH KELLEHER 

 BODY:
EVEN before President Bush signed the tax-cut law on June 7, financial services companies began deluging investors with advice on how they should change their planning.
 Congress passed the bill on Saturday, May 26, during the Memorial Day weekend. By the next Tuesday, Merrill Lynch was running full-page advertisements in major newspapers under the headline "How the New Tax Plan Affects Your Future Depends on What You Do Right Now." Fidelity Investments was right on Merrill's heels, and a host of others have followed. 
 The barrage of appeals may cause some confusion among investors. The most obvious difficulty, said Joseph Healy, a vice president of the T. Rowe Price Group in Baltimore, is that the advice may be premature. "You can't really act on it," he said. Many important provisions of the new law will take effect months or years from now.
There is another fundamental problem: once they do take effect, the changes may be so short-lived that it may not make sense to act on them. All the provisions of the tax act expire on Jan. 1, 2011. "The entire act is subject to this sunset provision," said Lori Noffsinger, manager for financial planning at First Union Securities in Richmond, Va.
Nonetheless, marketers are scrambling to create advertising campaigns, direct-mail brochures and brown-bag seminars to educate people about the tax changes, even though many clients will be inclined to do nothing this year.
"We're spending our dollars today to win the trust and confidence of our prospects," said David Acey, First Union's marketing director. 
Many money managers are convinced that the tax act is a watershed event in terms of the business it will generate in coming months. 
By comparison, the creation of Roth I.R.A.'s in 1997 was "minuscule," said Charles Gabriel, a senior vice president at Prudential Securities in Washington. Advertising will pick up over the summer, Mr. Gabriel said, timed to coincide with rebate checks, the one tangible part of the tax law for most people this year. 
The "Hamptons Effect" -- the tendency of Wall Street to take a summer break -- may not hold, at least not for marketers, said Tom Joyce, a spokesman for American Express Financial Advisors in Minneapolis. Slowness "might hit the market in terms of volume," Mr. Joyce said, "but not in terms of advertising."
The act creates a 10 percent tax bracket for the first $6,000 earned by singles and $12,000 by married couples. The lower bracket will apply to taxes paid on 2000 returns and will mean a few hundred dollars for many taxpayers. "Rather than spending your refund, you may want to put it to work for you," A. G. Edwards said in a mailing to clients.
MOST aspects of the law are more difficult to explain than the rebate. Income tax relief, for example, includes a child tax credit that increases in steps beginning next year, going to $1,000 from $500 a child by 2010. The top tax bracket decreases in steps, to 35 percent from 39.6 percent by 2006, and marriage penalty relief arrives in 2005.
Like those credits and cuts, the changes to savings vehicles will be phased in gradually. Bob Horton, integrated-marketing director at Merrill Lynch in Plainsboro, N.J., defended aggressive advertising. For the next decade, he said, "you have to plan to plan."
One focus for Merrill Lynch is the changes in the estate tax. The amount of money exempt from the tax will go up in four steps between now and 2009, while the rate goes down in six steps. In 2010, the estate tax will be eliminated -- until everything reverts to today's rules on Jan. 1, 2011. 
"Almost anybody who has a will needs to have it rewritten with a different set of distribution rules applying for each year between now and 2011," said Ken Kies, chairman of the federal tax policy group of PricewaterhouseCoopers in Washington. Mr. Kies said people considering insurance to pay estate taxes would have trouble deciding how much, if any, to buy.
Despite such thorny issues, Merrill Lynch this week started a second advertising campaign tied specifically to estate-tax changes.
Other advertisements will focus on education and retirement accounts.
The Education I.R.A., which allows money to be withdrawn tax-free to pay for a child's school expenses, will have a higher limit on contributions -- $2,000 next year, up from $500 -- and will be open to higher-income participants. Couples with an adjusted gross income of $190,000, up from $150,000, will be eligible to make a maximum contribution.
In addition, money may be withdrawn tax-free for elementary and secondary school expenses -- including tutoring, uniforms, extended day care and computer equipment -- as well as for college.
Qualified State Tuition Plans, or Section 529 plans, are becoming more attractive. Beginning in 2002 money can be withdrawn free of federal tax. Those withdrawals, however, are limited to expenses for higher education. Contribution limits vary by state but are usually much higher than those for the Education I.R.A. Planned advertisements will focus on generous grandparents.
JOHN SEARING, vice president for planning at the L. Warner Companies, a financial planner in Timonium, Md., is focusing on changes in retirement savings vehicles. Warner will use direct mail to explain that under the new tax law, contributions to both Roth and traditional I.R.A.'s will eventually rise to $5,000 a year from $2,000. (A Roth allows tax-free withdrawals after age 59 1/2, while traditional I.R.A.'s defer taxes until withdrawal after age 59 1/2.)
Todd Cleary of T. Rowe Price's financial planning services unit emphasized that investors who are at least 50 years old will be able to make additional "catch-up contributions" to both types of I.R.A.'s of $500 a year through 2005 and $1,000 a year starting in 2006. In addition, annual contribution limits to 401(k) plans, a savings vehicle offered by many employers, will go up to $15,000 in 2006, from $10,500, and then increase for inflation. The sunset provision may motivate higher contributions by those who want to beef up their accounts before the rules change again, he said.
Still, the uncertainties surrounding the law could turn off clients, Mr. Cleary said. "Retirement planning is such long-term stuff," he said. "Sometimes, if it's too complex, people throw up their hands." 
This complexity presents a marketing challenge. "It's not like trying to say, 'You can get a laptop in a new blue color,' " Mr. Joyce of American Express lamented. 
Despite some marketers' breathless tones, Mr. Kies of PricewaterhouseCoopers said, most investors can safely defer action. He said it would be wise to see if the president and Congress agree next year to extend the tax changes through 2011.
"If annual extensions mount, we're closer to being able to count on the tax law's opponents saying, 'Hell with it; let's make it permanent,' " Mr. Kies said. That might help investors plan more effectively.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Europe Builds Itself Up At Bush's Expense

BYLINE:  By GREGG EASTERBROOK 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THOUSANDS of protesters chanted against President Bush during his stops in Spain, Belgium and Sweden last week, some baring their rear ends; European leaders spoke condescendingly of America's president; the European press depicted him as a cowboy hayseed. In other words, from the European perspective, the Bush visit could not have gone better.
 As the European Union struggles to expand, to "harmonize" its thousands of overlapping rules, to manage its uncountable internecine jealousies and to formulate a new understanding of what it means to be European, there is one thing all Europeans seem to agree on. It is faux horror about the United States. 
 For all their pretenses of being dismayed by Mr. Bush, if European Union leaders were to describe their dream American president for this moment in time, they might well specify someone exactly like Mr. Bush -- seemingly, at least to European eyes, unsophisticated, swaggering and brash, all the qualities the European Union can unite on in dreading the United States. 
"The European Union has a hormone problem," says Jeffrey Gedmin, a Europe scholar who runs the New Atlantic Initiative at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington. "They are developing a sense that whatever diminishes the stature of the United States is of benefit to Europe." 
During Mr. Bush's visit, President Jacques Chirac of France, Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder of Germany and Prime Minister Wim Kok of the Netherlands all criticized his positions on global warming and missile defense, breaking the taboo that heads of state do not air disagreements during state visits. The Council of Europe, roughly analogous to the Organization of American States, was so underwhelmed that the American president was in its jurisdiction that by midweek the front page of its Web site had no mention of his presence. Instead, the major news was, "Parliamentary Assembly to Observe Elections in Bulgaria." 
Such slights against the leader of the best friend Europe has ever had were intended to inflate the European Union's collective ego. For great issues have recently made the European Union fractious: proposed expansion from 15 to 27 member nations (basically all the former Eastern Europeans states want in, and Ireland just voted no to that); whether Turkey should become part of Europe (if it qualifies for the European Union, Turkey would receive huge subsidies); whether there should be a European meta-government that supersedes national capitals. And with the demise of the Soviet Union, Europe now has no enemy to unite its competing states.
In such a context, Europe might find it useful to have a common antagonist. Enter Mr. Bush.
The Bush administration's rejection of the Kyoto global warming treaty, supposedly bad news, actually could not have been scripted better. European Union leaders got to repeatedly denounce Mr. Bush for saying the United States will not ratify Kyoto -- though no European Union nation has ratified it, either. After the 1992 "Earth Summit" in Rio, when Mr. Bush's father declared that the United States would not accept mandatory greenhouse-gas reductions, he was lambasted by European leaders, who vowed prompt, decisive action to impose restrictions on their own. They did nothing.
Last week, after deriding the Bush position on Kyoto, the European Union again vowed prompt greenhouse action, promising to ratify Kyoto on its own. Yet no European nation other than Denmark has any serious greenhouse-reduction strategy even in the planning stages, while a stand-alone European Union ratification of Kyoto is a million-to-one shot. From the Europeans' standpoint, the ideal outcome was for the Kyoto treaty to collapse but for Washington to take the blame. Now Europe gets to act outraged, while being spared the hard work and cost of actual reform.
Indeed, despite European protestations, American ecological standards are far more strict than European rules, and have been for 20 years or more. "Europe is now the world leader on environmental issues," the Swedish environment minister, Kjell Larsson, said as Mr. Bush arrived in his nation. But Paris today has worse smog than Houston; water quality, especially of rivers, is lower in Europe than in the United States; acid rain reduction has been more rapid in the United States than in Europe; European Union nations like Greece, Italy and Portugal still discharge huge volumes of untreated municipal waste water, a practice all but banned in America. In addition, the European Union did not act against leaded gasoline till more than a decade after the United States; the forested percentage of the United States is higher than the forested percentage of most European countries, while America has fewer threatened species than Europe; and many other environmental indicators favor the United States.
It is true that Europe is more energy-efficient than America. And moreover, as Bjorn Lomborg, a professor at the University of Aarhus in Denmark, demonstrates in the forthcoming book "The Skeptical Environmentalist," smog is declining and water quality improving everywhere in the West, Europe and America alike. But the idea that Europe is ahead on environmental matters is a convenient fiction of European politics. 
TRYING to build up Europe by acting outraged against America has become the European national sport on many fronts. One is anger about globalization by American companies, though European firms are themselves active globalizers. 
European diplomats harp on America's refusal to agree to a global treaty banning land mines. (The Pentagon maintains that its defense of the North-South Korean border rules out a land-mine ban.) Land-mine reduction is an important goal, but pales on the arms agenda compared with reduction of nuclear warheads -- something that, inconveniently, Washington is pursuing.
On no subject is Europe's internal need to feel superior to the United States more clear than capital punishment. Outlawing capital punishment is now a condition of European Union membership, and European commentators like to suggest there is a huge values gap between Europe and America. Always skipped is that 12 American states ban the death penalty, while polls show public pro-and-con views regarding capital punishment are nearly identical in the United States and the European Union. When the French politician Jack Lang was campaigning for mayor of Paris, he ostentatiously traveled to Texas to meet with a death-row prisoner; he was lauded in France. (Imagine if a candidate for mayor of Dallas traveled to Paris to meet with poor North African immigrants to discuss French racism.) Something besides moral opposition to the death penalty underlies this European obsession.
That something may extend to a realignment of American-European relations. Speaking in France before Mr. Bush's visit, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said the European allies now perceive a need to check American strength. Using the balance-of-power calculations that are the mainstay of traditional European diplomacy, Europe worries that America is too strong, and wants to bring it down a notch.
Mr. Gedmin of the American Enterprise Institute thinks the day may not be far off when Europe sides with Russia or even China against America on some key issue. A possible preview: When Mr. Bush first decided to review North Korea policy, the European Union sent a delegation to Pyongyang to confuse the situation. 
It seems certain there's more Euro-static coming, because for the moment, many European leaders believe that making small of America is in their interest.

HEADLINE: June 10-16; 
Talk That's Not Cheap

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY

 BODY:
He may not have Air Force One at his disposal anymore, but former President Bill Clinton has still been traveling the world with a vengeance, mixing highly paid speaking engagements with do-good events.
 He flies commercial, with an occasional chartered flight thrown in, but he is no regular passenger. 
He always sits in first class, aides say, and he spends the flights signing cocktail napkins or tickets for fellow passengers and visiting the cockpit. He has tarmac privileges at many airports, allowing him to avoid the terminals. But sometimes he joins the crowds. He was spotted at an Au Bon Pain at Logan International Airport in Boston, waiting in line for a chicken sandwich. 
 Aides say he has hit 17 or so countries since leaving office. There was an economics forum in Hong Kong, a vacation to the Dominican Republic, a festival in Britain's Hay-on-Wye, and stops in Canada, Nigeria, Austria, Sweden, Poland, Spain, Ireland and South Africa.
Of course, he charges for some appearances. After all, he still has many legal bills to settle. And most of his speaking invitations come from abroad. Industry officials say he brings in a hefty $150,000 a speech plus travel and other expenses. For some talks, like one for the World Congress on Information Technology, set for February in Australia, he charges more. An Australian newspaper put his fee at $264,000, but Mr. Clinton's aides said that figure was too high -- by a bit. 
Today, he heads to Palo Alto for the graduation of his daughter, Chelsea, from Stanford. There will be no speaking -- he's just going as a proud father. MARC LACEY

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT IN EUROPE: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Bush and Putin Look Each Other in the Eye

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, June 16 

 BODY:
Whatever happens now, for good or for ill, a new era in America's relations with Russia began today.
 Seldom have two leaders so strikingly overcome the limited expectations about their first meeting as George W. Bush and Vladimir V. Putin did today, putting their new friendship on a high plane of newfound trust and instructing their defense chiefs, both hard-liners, and their foreign secretaries, to find a common approach for a new framework for international security. 
 Whether this constructive new beginning -- made with surprising buoyancy and personal engagement -- will succeed as the genuine partnership that Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin described here this afternoon will depend on how they follow through on the collaborative venture that they outlined only in broad strokes. 
It includes joint work to study security threats, cooperative energy projects and new studies on how American corporations might find investment opportunities in the struggling Russian economy. It also includes American support for Russia's entry into the World Trade Organization.
"This was a very good meeting," Mr. Bush said standing alongside the Russian president. "He is an honest, straightforward man who loves his country," he added, and he called Mr. Putin a "remarkable" leader whom Americans can trust. 
Mr. Putin confirmed the American president's assessment and said the meeting had proved that "reality was a lot bigger than expectations." He asserted that an important cold war milestone had been passed with Mr. Bush's declaration that Russia is no longer America's enemy.
The two men had come to look each other in the eye, and Mr. Bush said he did just that to take the measure of Mr. Putin's soul. They both appeared to like what they saw, even as they laid out the agenda of their extensive disagreements on missile defenses, the expansion of NATO onto the territory of the former Soviet Union and Russia's growing arms trade with Iran. 
And today's reversal of tone in American-Russian relations may reflect how much each leader needed the positive outcome. Mr. Bush needed to prove to Europe and to the Senate that he was not engaged in recklessness as he pursued a new security concept that includes missile defenses. And Mr. Putin needed to know that the new Bush administration was not looking for a confrontation because Mr. Putin has his hands full at home trying to pull Russia beyond the wreckage of the Soviet era.
For more than two hours, Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin discussed a world rapidly transforming itself from the world of their fathers and despite the surprisingly positive outcome of today's meeting, it cannot be separated from the extraordinary week of diplomatic activity that preceded it. 
In his first major diplomatic foray abroad, Mr. Bush discovered this week that Europe was becoming its own powerhouse of economic and security interests that, while similar to those of the United States, are by no means identical on issues as diverse as climate change and urgent European calls for NATO to step into the fray in Macedonia.
And though Mr. Bush may have succeeded in fostering what he termed a "new receptivity" to his proposal for missile defenses among some European leaders this week, Germany and France stood as formidable skeptics, each concerned that Mr. Bush's plan would trigger a new arms race by not taking into account Russia's and China's concerns. 
As if to sharpen that point, Mr. Putin made his entrance here after flying from China, where he and President Jiang Zemin and the leaders of four Central Asian republics signed the founding charter of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, not quite an alliance, but a potent new expression of Asian interests.
Indeed, despite the warming with Mr. Bush, Mr. Putin seems to be fostering a new era of triangular diplomacy, positioning Russia to be an ally of China and of Europe as a hedge against American unilateralism, a concern he mentioned today. His tactic put Mr. Bush on the defensive, and Mr. Bush this week was at pains to assert that America is not about to go it alone in international affairs, but was trying instead to galvanize support for a new international security concept. The concept remains largely undefined except that missile defenses are a prominent centerpiece. 
With all the disagreement, however, what seemed most important was that the two presidents -- neither of whom has been in office very long, one a former Soviet K.G.B. officer, the other a scion of American wealth and political dynasty -- had finally met in the shadow of the Alps, near the fragile epicenter of European instability in the Balkans.
Mr. Putin had been seeking this meeting since almost the day after Mr. Bush's inauguration, but Mr. Bush's advisers delayed it for months, saying they were formulating a new policy toward Russia, one that now seems to be taking shape.
The two leaders now move on, to see each other again in July and October at the summit meeting of leading industrial nations in Genoa and of Asian and Pacific leaders in Shanghai, and they accepted invitations to visit not just each other's capitals but each other's homes.
Between now and then, both must return to domestic political challenges. Mr. Bush faces the Senate, now led by Democrats, many of whom are as skeptical as some European leaders about the consequences of abandoning the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty and how to pay for missile defenses even if they turn out to be feasible.
And Mr. Putin returns to Moscow, where he must prove that he is the democratic leader he advertises himself to be, one who wants to take Russia into Europe, a goal that will be difficult to reach as long as the partisan war in Chechnya continues without negotiation. 
Mr. Putin's yearold government also stands at a critical juncture of reform, with sweeping proposals to build a new judicial system, institute jury trials and privatize land ownership this year, an issue still so contentious in post-Soviet Russia that a fistfight broke out Friday among lawmakers. And though Mr. Putin this week reaffirmed his commitment to a free press and to building civil society, his administration has been dogged by incidents of pressure and intimidation that have called that commitment into question.
"This is a unique opportunity," said Aleksei Arbatov, an influential member of the Russian Parliament watching events from Moscow. "There are a lot of problems and mutual suspicions between our countries, and the main issue for both leaders is to decide whether they want to resolve these issues cooperatively, or to deal with those problems without dealing with each other."
"The fact that the United States is the only remaining superpower in the world," he continued, "means that it has to use this opportunity to demonstrate that it is a well-meaning state trying to establish the rule of the game for international relations on the basis of cooperation and not on force."

HEADLINE: Chelsea Clinton, Still a Closed Book 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif., June 15 

 BODY:
She may be the ultimate anomaly of the multimedia age, a household face whose voice has so seldom been heard that she could be a silent movie star. She was not yet 13 when she first slipped onto the national stage in her parents' shadow, and at 21, having traveled the world at her parents' side, she is barely better known.
 On Sunday, when she becomes one of this year's crop of 1,600 graduates of Stanford University, Chelsea Victoria Clinton will pass an irretrievable milestone of adulthood in a nation that watched her grow up in wordless pantomime. 
 "We've come a long way from when she turned 16 and radio stations called and offered to give her a car," said Neel Lattimore, a former press spokesman for Hillary Rodham Clinton who was often charged with helping enforce the Clintons' fiercely protective no-press zone around their only child.
In her four years here, university officials have tried hard not to mention her name, let alone issue any information about her, but on the brink of graduation, some facts are known. 
Ms. Clinton has earned a bachelor's degree in history, with highest honors, and wrote her 150-page senior thesis on the Northern Ireland peace process. It includes interviews with a certain former American president to whom the paper formally refers in the third person. And like her father, Bill Clinton, before her, she is headed to Oxford University in the fall, to pursue a master's degree in a course of study that is not yet set but will apparently involve international relations and economics.
"She did an absolutely prodigious amount of work," said her admiring thesis adviser, Prof. Jack Rakove, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of "Original Meanings: Politics and Ideas in the Making of the Constitution," who taught a course on Thomas Jefferson that Ms. Clinton took last year. Professor Rakove said he was doubly impressed because Ms. Clinton took the fall semester off to enjoy her family's last months in the White House and settled on a topic only in the winter.
"As you might expect," Professor Rakove said, "she's really well informed. If you talk books with her, you can be blown away by how much she knows."
The Clintons have put Chelsea at their side in times of joy, on election nights, at conventions, in campaigns and on state visits, and in times of trouble, most notably in the painful walk to the presidential helicopter after Mr. Clinton confessed infidelity in the Monica Lewinsky scandal. But with a handful of exceptions, most strikingly in impromptu comments in Tanzania when she told a group of young women of a "hopelessness and cynicism" that had a hold on some American youths, Chelsea has been seen and not heard, and there is no sign that her graduation will change that.
Through family spokesmen, Ms. Clinton declined to be interviewed for this article and turned down other requests, including an offer to pose for the cover of Vanity Fair in circumstances of her choosing. Her mother, Senator Clinton, did not respond to repeated interview requests left with her press secretary.
But Bill Clinton, delighted at the prospect of a Father's Day graduation, agreed to respond to written questions from The New York Times, and recalled a flood of memories of the birth, first day of school, dance and piano recitals and an early science project on Jupiter of the daughter who, he said, "has her mother's character and her father's energy."
"Perhaps even more than when Chelsea finished high school," Mr. Clinton wrote, "I think Hillary and I are graduating too, to a new phase in our relationship with Chelsea. We are excited about it, grateful that she still wants to spend time with us, and sure I'll be learning a lot more as we tag along in her life."
The Clintons are doing their best to blend in with other families here this weekend, along with Mrs. Clinton's mother, Dorothy Rodham, and Dick Kelley, the widower of Mr. Clinton's mother, Virginia, though it is safe to say that the parents of most other graduates are not bunking at the home of Steve Jobs, co-founder and chairman of Apple Computer. Former White House staff members, led by the president's personal aide, Kris Engskov, are here to help handle logistics and the one formal photo opportunity planned for the press on Sunday, to be sandwiched between the universitywide graduation at Stanford Stadium and the private departmental ceremony at which Ms. Clinton, like other students, will actually receive her diploma.
"We're going to parties and dinners with her friends and their families, attending her graduation events and whatever else she wants to do," Mr. Clinton said.
There were no visible signs that Ms. Clinton's graduation loomed as anything out of the ordinary on this high-powered campus, where Justice Stephen G. Breyer of the United States Supreme Court, a onetime Stanford parent, was spotted casually strolling today.
"She's just a totally normal student," said Gretchen DeVries, 21, a junior from Poughkeepsie, N.Y., who is majoring in materials science engineering. "Everyone here has accomplishments. She really doesn't make a larger contribution than anybody else."
Ms. DeVries's friend Naomi Chin, 20, also a junior engineering major, from Washington, D.C., added: "Off campus, that's all people want to know about, is Chelsea. But here she blends in. The Secret Service agents dress like other students and walk 40 feet behind her, and if you didn't know to look for them, you wouldn't know they were there."
Ms. Clinton has endured the occasional tabloid report that she was spotted dancing in this or that nightclub, but managed to avoid any public scrapes with authority akin to the recent charges against Jenna and Barbara Bush, the current president's twin daughters, for alcohol violations in Texas. 
One Clinton family friend expressed unease about the inevitable comparisons. "This just tends to put her even more on a pedestal," the friend said, "and she's great, but if you're on a pedestal, there's only one direction to go."
Mr. Clinton declined to comment on the Bush case but said, "By and large, the press and people generally have given Chelsea the space to grow up without undue intrusion, and I'm grateful for that." He added: "It isn't easy to grow up in the spotlight, especially when children are first exposed to it. I think the more limited the public focus on children, the better."
Carl Sferrazza Anthony, a historian who studies presidential families, noted that the world could only guess at Ms. Clinton's deepest feelings.
"We're speculating a lot on how she survived," Mr. Anthony said. "I think there has to have been some psychic damage that occurs. When you're a bright young person interested in the world around you, and you're hearing what people are saying about your dad, it's going to affect you."
But Mr. Anthony, who has met Ms. Clinton on several occasions over the years, suggested that she may someday have a tale to tell.
"I once said to her, 'You really should think about at least writing a memoir, if not for publication, at least leaving a record of a diary, some notes, your observations of the historical figures that you've met,' " he recalled. "And she sort of smiled and said, 'Well, you know, maybe.' "

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT IN EUROPE; 
Two Leaders Talk About a 'Productive' Exchange

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the statements and answers yesterday by President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia after their meeting, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. Mr. Putin's statements were made through an interpreter.

President Bush
 President Putin and I have just concluded two hours of straightforward and productive meetings. We had a good discussion of our views of Russian-American relations and of the changing world at the beginnings of this new century. Our countries have common interests and we share great responsibilities. 
 My meeting with President Putin today is an important step in building a constructive, respectful relationship with Russia, a relationship that has the potential to benefit not only our two countries, but also the world. Russia is an important country with vast potential. When Russia and the United States work together in a constructive way, we can make the world a safer and more prosperous place. 
I enjoyed the opportunity to meet President Putin in person for the first time. I am convinced that he and I can build a relationship of mutual respect and candor. And I'm convinced that it's important for the world that we do so. More than a decade after the cold war ended, it is time to move beyond suspicion and toward straight talk, toward mutually assured -- beyond mutually assured destruction and toward mutually earned respect. As we work together to address the world as it is, not as it used to be, it is important that we not only talk differently; we also must act differently. We have great opportunities to cooperate on economic, commercial, regional and security issues. President Putin and I have agreed to launch an extensive dialogue about a wide range of issues that we can constructively address together. . . I invited President Putin to Washington this fall. He accepted. He invited me to Russia, and I accepted. And I look forward to the visit. We also agreed to continue our cooperation and work toward common solutions on important regional issues, from the Balkans to Nagorno-Karabakh to Afghanistan. And we discussed our common interests in developing the energy resources of the Caspian basin in a way that benefits all the countries of the region. . . .

President Putin
 . . . I think that we found a good basis to start building on our cooperation, counting on a pragmatic relationship between Russia and the United States. We compared our approaches in key areas, and once again we established our common ground. I want to return now to what the president said very unclear , that Russia and the United States are not enemies. They do not threaten each other. And they could be fully good allies. And taking into account the fact that the United States and the Russian federation as no one else, as no other country in the world, have accumulated huge amounts of nuclear weapons, weapons of mass destruction, we bear a special responsibility for maintaining common peace and security in the world, for building a new architecture of security in the world. 
The president and I have agreed that we're going to tell our ministers of defense, secretaries of defense, foreign ministers, to continue in this vein, to continue this discussion, without any pauses. Of course, we discussed the very difficult regional issues -- the Near East and Afghanistan and the Balkans. 
I have to say that this discussion showed that the differences in our approaches in very fundamental areas are much less than that which unites us. The differences in our positions, the positions of the two countries, really are not of a fundamental nature, a global nature, something which cannot be solved -- not at all. I think that it would be very incorrect for us to start forcing on issues and arguments and not take into account the very fundamental main concepts and issues in our relationships, which are the basis and the whole foundation of the relationship between the Russian federation and the United States of America. 
The president and I are united in saying that the economic ties between our two countries do not correspond to the potential of our two countries. The government of the Russian federation, the businessmen of both countries and the U.S. administration, of course, can do a lot more to support the effectiveness of our economic ties. And the president expressed that we need an additional impulse from our businessmen, and we will do everything possible to receive a very high-level business delegation of the United States to Russia. . . .

Questions and Answers

Q. President Putin, President Bush has said that he's going to go forward with his missile defense plans, basically with or without your blessing. Are you unyielding in your opposition to his missile defense plan? Is there anything you can do to stop it? And to President Bush, did President Putin ease your concern at all about the spread of nuclear technologies by Russia? And is this a man that Americans can trust?

MR. PUTIN -- Now, as far as the issue of anti-missile defense, the official position of the Russian government is known. . . .
Based upon today's dialogue, I've come to the conclusion and the impression that we might have a very constructive development here in this arena. At least the president of the United States has listened carefully. He listens to our arguments very carefully. But I think the specialists, as I have said before, have to sit down, have contact to identify the overall platform that we're going to work from and try to find a way together to solve these problems. Now, as far as the issues of proliferation and nonproliferation, I have to say that in our opinion this is a topic that's very, very closely tied to the ABM Treaty, because many other things are hooked onto this same string. . . .

MR. BUSH -- . . . I appreciated the opportunity to be able to talk about a new relationship. And we will continue these dialogues. The basis for my discussion began with this simple premise, that Russia and the United States must establish a new relationship beyond that of the old cold war mentality. The cold war said loud and clear that we were opponents and that we bring the peace through the ability for each of us to destroy each other. Friends don't destroy each other. People who cooperate do not have a basis of peace on destruction.
Our nations are confronted with new threats in the 21st century. Terror in the hands of what we call rogue nations is a threat. I expressed my concern, and so did the president, very openly, about nations on his borders and nations that can't stand America's freedoms developing the capacity to hold each of us hostage. And he agreed. I brought up concerns about Iran. And I'm hesitant to put words in the president's mouth, but he said he's concerned as well. And I think that accurately categorizes your position. And we'll work together to stop the spread of weapons of mass destruction. And I believe, as we go down the road, that we'll be able to develop a constructive relationship as to how to use our technologies and research and willingness to keep the peace in a way that makes the world more peaceful.

Q. -- Could you tell us anything about what you talked about the expansion of NATO?

MR. BUSH -- I said I thought that was a wise thing for NATO to expand, so long as nations met their obligations. . . .
MR. PUTIN -- I'm going to lay it out for you. . . .
Look, you understand that we're not -- our attitude toward NATO is not one towards an enemy organization. Of course not. And I'm grateful to the president of the United States that finally, from the territory of the United States, these words were heard. This is very important for us. We value this. When the president of a great power says that he wants to see Russia as a partner, and maybe even as an ally, this is worth so much to us. But if that's the case, then, look, we ask ourselves a question. Look, this is a military organization. Yes, it's military. They don't want us there. They don't want us there. It's moving towards our border. Yes, it's moving towards our border. Why? So this is what's -- this is the foundation of all our concern, not just to bring it in or not bring it in or accept NATO or not accept NATO.

HEADLINE: G.E. Calls Its $45 Billion Bid For Honeywell All but Dead 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN with ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

DATELINE: PARIS, June 16 

 BODY:
Jeffrey R. Immelt, president of the General Electric Company, pronounced its proposed $45 billion takeover of Honeywell International all but dead today, but said that G.E. would wait to receive a final judgment from the European Commission next month.
 Antitrust regulators at the commission are concerned that the combined companies would have too much power in the market for aviation products like jet engines and navigation equipment. They had asked G.E. to spin off its lucrative aircraft leasing division and sell off Honeywell divisions worth billions of dollars. But G.E. refused, submitting its final offer to regulators last week. 
 "We are very far apart as we sit here today," Mr. Immelt told reporters at the biannual air show here, "and fundamentally we are planning our future without Honeywell."
Mario Monti, the European competition commissioner, has tried to engage G.E. in further talks in the hope of reaching a compromise. On Friday, the European Commission invited G.E. to modify its proposal, even though the deadline for new concessions had passed late Thursday.
Today, Mr. Immelt said G.E. would no longer negotiate. Asked if the deal could still be pulled like a rabbit out of a hat, he replied, "I don't know what the rabbit would look like."
Should the deal fall apart, as now appears likely, it would be the first big American merger to be blocked solely by European regulators. This prospect has raised fears of retaliation and rising trade frictions between the United States and Europe.
But looking to the future, Mr. Immelt, who will succeed John F. Welch Jr. as chief executive and chairman later this year, took pains not to antagonize the commission. He noted that G.E. has a long-term commitment to Europe, where it generated $25 billion of its $130 billion in revenues last year and employs 85,000 people. He said the company was likely to make future acquisitions that also would come before the regulators in Brussels.
"The commission has been constructive," he said. "They've been open. We have no fight to pick with the commission."
On Thursday, Mr. Welch consulted with Andrew Card, the White House chief of staff, raising speculation that G.E. would use its considerable political influence to pressure Brussels into backing down. President Bush said he had discussed the case on his European trip. 
But today, Mr. Immelt dismissed the idea of pursuing this political course. "We are so far apart that this is not a place where we would use political pressure," he said.
In the wake of Mr. Immelt's comments, attention will turn to what will become of Honeywell. United Technologies, which was negotiating to buy Honeywell before being outbid by G.E. last fall, is already considering another attempt, according to executives close to United Technologies. However, Honeywell is bound by contract not to negotiate with others until the commission rules.
Asked why G.E. did not simply withdraw its offer, Mr. Immelt said Honeywell was deeply involved in the talks and had agreed with G.E.'s strategy. "We are being respectful of the process," he said.
G.E., however, cannot withdraw its acquisition proposal without Honeywell's explicit permission, which, according to an executive close to G.E., Honeywell has not given. 
Despite his praise of the commission, Mr. Immelt expressed plenty of dismay about its conclusions. Stopping short of saying that its motivations were political, he did say that they were "not economic."
He said the deal had passed muster with a dozen different antitrust regulators, including in the United States and Canada. But he pointed out that European regulators pay closer attention to the effect a proposed deal has on competitors, while their counterparts in Washington focus on the impact on customers.
He strongly denied that G.E. uses its size and market power to compel customers to buy more of its related products, a practice known as bundling and a major concern of European regulators. "The first time any of us ever heard of bundling was Nov. 1," Mr. Immelt said, referring to the week after the deal was announced.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 6-17-01: On Language; 
The Politics Of

BYLINE:  By William Safire

 BODY:
Think of Ronald Reagan, and his phrases evil empire and there you go again and make my day come to mind, along with the derogations star wars and morning in America. 
 Think of George Bush the elder, and you have a thousand points of light and line in the sand and kinder and gentler nation, with his voodoo economics and read my lips, no new taxes tossed back at him. 
 Think of Bill Clinton, and - what? In his ascent to power, the vividly Carvillian it's the economy, stupid was indelibly associated with Clinton; in his descent, it was the relentlessly replayed sentence accompanied by his wagging finger. 
This department seeks memorable Clintonisms from friend and foe, but will begin today with a linguistic sleeper. A phrase coined by candidate Clinton in his campaign for the Democratic nomination has been gaining strength as the years flash by. 
His chief rival at the time, Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts, ran a TV spot claiming to be honest, truthful and unpolished -- no Bill Clinton, that's for sure." Asked in an Illinois cheesecake emporium in March 1992 about this and other charges about his character, Clinton replied: "I think that the American people can spot somebody that's on their side. . . . They're tired of the politics of personal destruction."
As president in 1994, Clinton lashed out at Republicans in Congress for blocking his proposals, charging them with "the politics of personal destruction and of legislative obstruction." This caused a Georgia member of the House minority, Representative Newt Gingrich, to call his attack "not the politics of personal destruction; it's the politics of self-destruction." After the G.O.P. upset that year, establishing itself as the majority in the House, Clinton slammed back with: "My job is not to stand in the way and be an obstructionist force. My job is not to practice the politics of personal destruction." 
He continued to use the phrase as an attacking defense, culminating in a short Rose Garden speech after impeachment in 1998: "We must stop the politics of personal destruction. We must get rid of the poisonous venom of excessive partisanship, obsessive animosity and uncontrolled anger." Nit-pickers who winced at the redundancy of "poisonous venom" were impressed with Clinton's alliteration in his peroration to "rise above the rancor." 
The phrase outlived the Clinton presidency. Last month, The Washington Post played on it in a headline above a column by George Will about the likely resistance to George W. Bush's proposals by a Senate controlled by Democrats: "The Politics of Personal Obstruction." When a phrase is familiar enough to take such wordplay, that is evidence that it is becoming fixed in the lexicon.
In coining phrases, the politics of has long been found useful. In his 1860 "Leaves of Grass," Walt Whitman sang of "the politics of Nature"; Upton Sinclair in 1918 excoriated the "politics of hypocrisy"; Aldous Huxley titled a 1963 book "The Politics of Ecology"; and Yippies in 1968 lolled back to enjoy with Timothy Leary "the politics of ecstasy."
In the politics of politics, Arthur Schlesinger Jr. led the way, beginning in 1949 with "The Politics of Freedom," followed by his "Politics of Upheaval" in 1957 and, five years later, "The Politics of Hope." This deeply impressed Vice President Hubert Humphrey, who in 1968 -- not an especially upbeat time in war-torn America -- was optimistic enough to hail "the politics of happiness, the politics of purpose and the politics of joy." 
Mr. Clinton, now practicing the politics of personal reconstruction, will undoubtedly be glad to learn of the studious interest in his phrasemaking. Send in those favorite Clinton locutions or persnickety characterizations to onlanguage@nytimes.com or to On Language, The New York Times Washington Bureau, 1627 I Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20006. 

Enchiladaville
 The governor of California, Gray Davis, after meeting with President Bush about the energy shortage causing rolling blackouts in the Golden State, said, "The big enchilada, the thing that really matters, above all else, is temporary price relief."
The governor is wandering in a no man's land between a whole enchilada and the big enchilada. A whole enchilada means "the entirety of a thing," its synonyms "the whole ball of wax," "whole nine yards," "whole schmear" and the etymologically mysterious "whole shebang." After Jimmy Carter won the presidency in 1976, the former California governor Ronald Reagan said that Democrats, long the majority party in Congress, could no longer claim that divided government impeded progress. "The Democrats cannot fuzz up the issue by blaming the White House," he said. "They've got the whole enchilada now."
The big enchilada is not a situation but a person. It is "the boss, the person of undoubted authority and influence, the one on top," and from a law officer's point of view, "the main target." In a taped Watergate conversation in 1973, Bob Haldeman says of John Mitchell, the former attorney general, "He is as high up as they've got." John Ehrlichman concurs, "He's the big enchilada." Queried about the coinage of this variant, Ehrlichman wrote me from jail a few years later: "I coined the phrase. I've cooked my own enchiladas for years. My California upbringing. Could have said 'big fish' or 'top dog' or 'big cheese,' I guess."
Governor Davis has been using big enchilada to mean, as he defines it himself, "the thing that really matters above all else" -- the ne plus ultra, the "acme, ultimate" or "most profound degree." In my view it confuses two distinct slang terms.
An enchilada is a tortilla into which is rolled a mixture of meat or beans and seasoned with a sauce made of chili, a hot red pepper (the chil in enchilada). The entire thing can be eaten by a person of great influence in the dark.
