HEADLINE: Oil Pipeline to Turkey Backed by Chief of BP 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, June 20 

 BODY:
Sir John Browne, the chief executive of the BP Group, said today that the Baku-Ceyhan oil pipeline from Azerbaijan to a port on Turkey's southeastern Mediterranean coast would be built and operating by the end of 2004, the strongest public backing the project has yet received.
 Sir John said a detailed engineering study that began last month was not a further evaluation of the pipeline's economic viability, but a determination of what sort of line could be built within the project's budget, which he said was about $3 billion. 
 "You know where you've got to aim on price, and now we are thinking about what can be built for this amount," Sir John said in an interview. "We are proceeding with this project. It's commercial. It's environmentally sound." 
The much-debated pipeline was backed by the Clinton administration and adopted by the Bush administration as a way to diversify the transportation routes for the vast amounts of oil that have been discovered in the Caspian Sea region, and avoid having to transport all of it through Russia or Iran. But skeptics have said the route is too expensive and can never be built.
Last month, BP and seven other oil companies involved in the project approved spending $150 million on a detailed study of the route of the pipeline and engineering requirements. The study is expected to take about a year, with construction starting in mid-2002.
Sir John said oil fields being developed around Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, contain five billion barrels of high-quality crude oil, enough by itself to make economic sense out of the pipeline, which will pass through Georgia on its way to Turkey. And talks are under way to use the line to carry oil shipped down the Caspian Sea from the Tengiz and Kashagan fields in Kazakhstan, though that remains an uncertain prospect.
Initial estimates put the cost of the Baku-Ceyhan line at $2.4 billion, but Sir John confirmed that the design study completed last month came up with a price tag of about $3 billion. The project remains economically viable at the higher figure, he said. Other oil companies are expected to join the pipeline consortium soon.
BP has discovered a huge amount of natural gas in the Shah Deniz field in Azerbaijan, and it plans to build a gas pipeline that will parallel the oil line for most of its route to bring that gas to market in Turkey.
BP and Turkish government officials have also pushed the Baku-Ceyhan pipeline as an alternative to increasing the amount of oil-tanker traffic passing through the Bosporus, the 18-mile strait that divides this city of 12 million people.
Turkish maritime officials and environmental organizations are concerned that the already crowded waterway will become more dangerous later this year, when an increasing number of tankers are expected to come down from the Black Sea carrying oil originating in the Tengiz fields in Kazakhstan.
Sir John and other BP executives took a cruise on the Bosporus today, taking along representatives of several environmental organizations to highlight what the chief executive said was the company's commitment to be as environmentally friendly as possible.
The Shah Deniz gas field in Azerbaijan promises to be almost as important as the oil reserves in the development of Caspian-basin energy. Worldwide demand for gas is growing rapidly, especially for use as a relatively clean fuel for generating electricity.
A study by Cambridge Energy Research Associates, released here today, predicted that demand for liquefied natural gas would triple in the next 20 years, and that the gas would become a more important factor in world markets.
The report, released as part of an international energy conference sponsored by the American research company, said the liquefied gas market would expand because prices were falling, environmental concerns were making gas more attractive and the global energy market was expanding and becoming more competitive.
Most gas today is delivered through pipelines to specific markets. But liquefied gas is generally transported by ship on special tankers, offering greater flexibility to shift supplies between markets and reducing development costs, the report said.
Turkey, which imports about 98 percent of its energy, could become an important transit point for gas in coming years, if supplies from a nearly completed Russian pipeline, the planned BP pipeline and other projects end up giving the country a surplus of gas.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sir John Browne said the pipeline could be open by the end of 2004. (Adrian Wyld/Canadian Press)

HEADLINE: More Cold Water on Japanese Hopes 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 20 

 BODY:
Hopes that economic growth will soon revive in Japan are receding, with new statistics showing the nation's trade surplus contracting sharply and the government poised to conclude that the country will fall far short of its previous 1.7 percent growth forecast for the year. 
 A panel led by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has produced a draft report saying that growth will remain at a low level through 2002, in part because of deepening deflationary pressures caused by efforts to clean up the huge volume of nonperforming loans plaguing the banking system. 
The conclusions, expected to be formally released after the panel meets on Thursday, were reported by Bloomberg News and other news agencies today. 
 The trade figures for May, the 11th straight month in which Japan's surplus has deteriorated, showed slumping exports of technology goods while imports of energy rose.
Weak demand in Japan's main markets, the United States and Asian countries, was reflected in the export figures, the government said. The surplus shrank to 287.8 billion yen ($2.3 billion), seasonally adjusted, down more than half from April and nearly seven-eighths from May 2000.

HEADLINE: Less Baseball Is More 

BYLINE:  By Rick Burton; Rick Burton is director of the James H. Warsaw Sports Marketing Center at the University of Oregon's Lundquist College of Business.

DATELINE: EUGENE, Ore. 

 BODY:
Why is the concept of cutting a few teams from Major League Baseball viewed as threatening and radical? That was the big question hanging over last week's owners' meeting. While he made no firm statement on the subject, Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner, reiterated that contraction of baseball is a viable option.
 It is doubtful that Selig will act anytime soon; the threat of lawsuits, the potential challenge to the league's sacred antitrust exemption and the possibility of negative news coverage are too daunting. But baseball has gotten fat and, like many companies, needs to take decisive action at some point. Protecting weak teams or dysfunctional franchises is bad for business. Cutting two teams and their combined 162 games might actually improve the business for everyone -- owners, players, networks and fans. 
 At the heart of baseball's economic problem is disparity in payrolls. Teams like the Boston Red Sox, the Los Angeles Dodgers and the New York Yankees, with player payrolls of as much as $110 million a season, have an unfair advantage over teams like the Montreal Expos, the Oakland Athletics and the Minnesota Twins, with payrolls less than $35 million. While there can be exceptions, pitting poorer teams against richer ones generally makes for games that are not very competitive and therefore not interesting enough to attract large numbers of fans. 
Purists suggest that failing teams are simply poorly run and that if they moved to other, more baseball-friendly cities, they might attract bigger audiences. But if the teams aren't competitive, that interest would be temporary. And to be competitive in player salaries, a baseball owner needs not only ticket sales but a local television market that can bring in revenue. There are no major untapped television markets that can generate enough money to justify the purchase price of a team and the enormous costs of building a new stadium.
Even in Portland, Ore., with the Oregon State Legislature willing to consider providing $150 million in subsidies to lure a team, the math simply doesn't work. To make a failing relocated team competitive, a new owner in Portland would have to raise at least $150 million to pay part of the stadium costs, in addition to the purchase price for the team (at least $100 million) plus $25 million to $50 million a year in player salaries. With just 81 home games in a 40,000-seat stadium -- in a city with no historic connection to the team and a small media market -- the prognosis is gloomy.
At best, moving weak teams will create temporary fans. Without salary caps or real revenue sharing like that in the National Football League, small-market teams will have a never-ending struggle. Contraction may be the only cure for a sport where lack of parity is making failure on the field and at the gate all too likely.

HEADLINE: Forecast Index Rises the Most Since Late '99 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20 

 BODY:
A crucial forecasting gauge for the economy had its biggest increase in almost a year and a half in May, but economic growth will continue to be slow for the next few months, a private research firm said today.
 The Conference Board said its index of leading economic indicators rose 0.5 percent in May -- the biggest gain since an identical 0.5 percent rise in December 1999 -- after rising 0.1 percent in April. 
It was also the third increase for the index in the last six months. 
 Wall Street economists had expected a rise of 0.2 percent.
"Latest readings suggest the U.S. economy may be poised for some recovery," said Ken Goldstein, a Conference Board economist.
"Continued, though modest, strength in services and some limited recovery in manufacturing is a combination likely to deliver limited job, income and gross domestic product growth over the next few months, barring any sudden economic shock," he added.
The Conference Board, based in New York, said the coincident index, a barometer of current economic trends, was unchanged in May after a 0.1 percent drop in April.
The lagging index, which measures past trends in the economy, fell 0.2 percent in May after a 0.1 percent decrease the previous month.
"Taken together, the three composite indexes and their components suggest that the period of slow growth in the U.S. economy will continue in the next few months," the board said.
Fred Breimyer, senior vice president with the State Street Corporation in Boston, called the report a "dichotomy."
"I'm not sure that the data are reliable because the elements that are most positive are financial," he said. "The ones I treat as the best guides are the ones that relate to real production, real demand."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Technology Issues Rise; Market's Direction Seems Unclear

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
A late rally in technology issues led the stock market higher yesterday, a choppy session in which investors pondered conflicting signals about the prospects for corporate earnings.
 Analysts said no strong single factor seemed to be driving overall market activity, as the Dow Jones industrials rose more than 100 points in early trading, then reversed course and bounced in and out of negative territory before closing higher. 
 "A lot of people believe that you 'sell them in May, and stay away,' " said Ned Collins, head trader at Daiwa Securities America, "particularly this year because of all the question marks that are in the air. A lot of people are wondering when and where the earnings are going to come from. We have a lot of churning to go through, a lot of backing and filling." 
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 50.66 points, or 0.48 percent, to close at 10,647.33. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 10.56 points, or 0.87 percent, to 1,223.14. 
The Nasdaq composite, a technology stock gauge, rose 38.58 points, or 1.94 percent, to 2,031.24, with market breadth narrowly positive.
Investors' nervousness about earnings was reinforced after Tellabs, a telecommunications equipment maker, joined the growing list of companies warning of disappointing financial results, as it cut its sales forecast by more than a third and said it would only break even in the quarter. Shares of Tellabs plunged $5.16, to $16.04.
Analysts said some investors' hopes for a turnaround were buoyed after Gerald M. Levin, chief executive of AOL Time Warner, told Reuters that the company's advertising revenue was stabilizing and that it was likely to meet its 2001 financial forecast. AOL gained $2.96, to $52.80. 
"This isn't good news in the classic good news sense," said Michelle R. Clayman, chief investment officer at New Amsterdam Partners. "But it seems to imply that the rate of decline is either slowing or has stopped."
Bear Stearns provided a hopeful sign after it reported second-quarter operating earnings that exceeded Wall Street estimates. Its shares rose $1.77, to $55.13.
General Electric helped lead the Dow and the S.& P. 500 higher, gaining $1.90, to $50.77, after the European Commission was said to have drafted a recommendation that G.E.'s bid for Honeywell International not be approved. G.E.'s rise offset a drop in Honeywell shares, which fell $1.46, to $37.04.
Tobacco stocks rose as investors reacted to a move by the Justice Department to try to settle a multibillion-dollar civil suit filed against the industry in 1999 under the Clinton administration. The suit contends that the tobacco companies withheld information about the dangers of smoking. Shares of Philip Morris rose $1.90, to $46.50; R. J. Reynolds climbed $2.48, to $54.81; and the American depository receipts of British American Tobacco were up 48 cents, to $15.58. --------------------

Fed Chief Buoys Treasuries
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said higher labor costs were not accelerating inflation, suggesting that the central bank had leeway to cut interest rates further.
Ken Anderson of Evergreen Asset Management in White Plains said, "There's a lot more wood to chop to make sure the economy doesn't sink," adding that the Fed had "room to lower rates by 50 basis points next week, and again in August."
The 10-year Treasury note rose 7/32 yesterday, to a price of 98 15/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.20 percent from 5.23 percent on Tuesday. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 12/32 , to 95 30/32 . Its yield fell to 5.66 percent from 5.69 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Alternative-Fuel Program Fails to Reach Its Goals
A report by the Bush administration recommends continuing federal incentives for ethanol-fueled vehicles. But it does so despite finding that the program has failed to live up to both of its goals: reducing gasoline consumption and increasing the use of alternative fuels.
 By building dual-fuel vehicles, automakers receive credits that allow them to lower the average gas mileage of all other vehicles in their fleets. That has allowed them to sell more gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles. Page A1. 

Chairman of Disney Studios to Quit
Peter Schneider, the chairman of Walt Disney Studios, announced unexpectedly that he would leave the company to set up a new Broadway production company. The move comes less than a month after the hugely hyped premiere of Disney's "Pearl Harbor," which has failed to be the summer-dominating hit that some had predicted. C3.

I.R.S. Guide Focuses on Consultants
The Internal Revenue Service is teaching its auditors how to focus on tax cheating by self-styled business consultants and by corporations that use former employees as consultants to avoid withholding taxes. C5.

Technology Rally Helps Lift Stocks
A late rally in technology issues led the stock market higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 38.58 points, or 1.9 percent, to 2,031.24. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 50.66 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,647.33. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 10.56 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,223.14. C7.

U.S. Holds Lead in Supercomputers
The twice-annual ranking of the world's fastest 500 computers, being issued today, shows that the United States still has a significant lead in building powerful supercomputers. But the list is also an indication that, increasingly, the world of supercomputing is no longer at the cutting edge of computing technology. C4.

Union Members Protest at Verizon
Union protesters rallied at Verizon's headquarters, contending the company was violating a contract in which it agreed not to fight organizing drives at nonunion subsidiaries. C4.

Bear Stearns Surpasses Estimates
Bear Stearns, one of Wall Street's leading firms, said that its second-quarter net income rose 43 percent, surpassing expectations, as a strong bond market helped limit the damage from its investment banking and stock trading. Revenue rose to $1.37 billion from $1.32 billion despite the weak market. Shares of Bear Stearns rose $1.77, to $55.13. C5.

Coke to Help Fight AIDS in Africa
Coca-Cola, Africa's biggest employer if affiliates are counted, says it will use its resources to combat AIDS on the continent. A8.

Leading Indicators Climb 0.5%
The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators rose 0.5 percent in May after rising 0.1 percent in April. C3.

Auto Insurers May Leave New Jersey
Companies insuring almost a third of New Jersey's drivers are considering withdrawing from the state, escalating the battle over auto insurance that continues to be one of the most charged issues in the state. B1.

One Less Problem in Productivity
New research from economists suggests that one potential problem with statistics on productivity -- the measurement of hours worked -- is less of a problem than previously thought. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: Niagara Falls and Buffalo Proposed as Casino Sites 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 20 

 BODY:
The Pataki administration and the Seneca Indian Nation have struck a deal to build two Las Vegas-style casinos in Buffalo and Niagara Falls, and possibly a third elsewhere in western New York, the governor said in a surprise announcement late this afternoon.
 The casino plan requires legislative approval under a recent state court ruling. Tonight, the two men who control the State Legislature said that they had not seen any of the details of the proposal, but neither voiced any opposition to the concept. Even the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, who has traditionally opposed gambling, seemed flexible on the notion of a casino in western New York. His spokesman, John McArdle, called him a "realist." 
 The deal would give the Seneca Nation control of the Niagara Falls Convention Center, a 153,000-square-foot building that is in dire need of an uplift, for $1 a year. If the deal goes forward, the casino could open as soon as next spring.
A site has not yet been selected for the Buffalo casino, but there have been discussions about renovating a portion of a downtown office building. The deal announced today would also allow the Indians to open a third casino in the future on existing reservation land, which stretches across three counties in western New York.
The proposed casinos could provide a boost to an economically depressed area, and create competition for the first time for the two privately operated casinos on the Canadian side of the Niagara River. Gov. George E. Pataki today seized on that fact to rally support for his proposal. "They have had a casino that has generated the jobs and the revenue and has attracted private investment," he said at a late-afternoon news conference in Niagara Falls, with his back to the skyline of Niagara Falls, Ontario. "There is no reason why on our side of the falls, we can't surpass that and have more investment than they had on the other side."
Mr. Pataki's aides told reporters about the news conference shortly before he headed to Niagara Falls. Several lawmakers said the announcement caught them by surprise.
"I'm shocked that this agreement has been negotiated in secrecy," said Assemblyman Sam Hoyt, a Democrat from Buffalo who opposes the proposed casino. He does not accept the economic-boon argument, and warns about the social ills gambling can bring.
"It catches me off guard. It catches most of my colleagues off guard," Mr. Hoyt said of the announcement. I'm shocked that there will be no public input whatsoever on such a volatile issue."
The agreement, which must also be approved in a referendum among the Seneca Nation and obtain federal approval, would be valid for 14 years, with a seven-year renewal option. The governor's office did not respond to calls tonight requesting details of the proposal. But Sheldon Silver, the Assembly leader, said the governor had told him the casinos would yield roughly $115 million a year for the state, 20 percent of which would go to local governments.
The casino deal comes against the backdrop of an ongoing land-claim dispute between the state and the Seneca Indian Nation. The Indians have sought to gain control of some additional territory, including Grand Island, a town of 19,000 between Buffalo and Niagara Falls. The land claims have yet to be settled.
"This has been a long and difficult process for both parties," the Seneca Nation president, Cyrus M. Schindler, said at the news conference. "This agreement should be a tremendous economic boost for the Seneca Nation and the entire region of western New York."
Governor Pataki has long favored the development of Indian casinos to revive economically depressed areas. In the past, he had contended that his administration could unilaterally allow gambling by Indian tribes; he signed a pact with the St. Regis Mohawk Indians to build a $500 million casino in the Catskills. Two months ago, though, the governor was overruled by a State Supreme Court justice, who declared that Mr. Pataki had violated the New York State Constitution by signing gambling compacts before securing legislative approval.
On this deal, though, securing such approval does not seem to face huge hurdles.
Mr. Bruno, the Senate majority leader has lately come around to the idea of a casino in western New York. Tonight, his spokesman, Mr. McArdle, said Mr. Bruno understands that a casino could bring "a huge boost" to the economically depressed downtowns of Niagara Falls and Buffalo. "He's recognized that that area in particular has not done as well as other areas in the state," Mr. McArdle said.
Meanwhile, Mr. Silver, the Assembly speaker, who has generally endorsed Indian casino as an economic-development tool, said tonight that he supports the concept, but has yet to see the details of the governor's plan. "I have been supportive in the past of casinos in Niagara Falls and the city of Buffalo," he said.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Britain: Interest Rates 

BYLINE:  By Alan Cowell (NYT) 

 BODY:
 British interest rates are likely to remain steady or rise after the Bank of England's monetary policy committee voted 8-to-1 to keep the benchmark rate at 5.25 percent this month. After three rate cuts earlier in the year, largely in response to the economic downturn in the United States, minutes from the bank's monthly meetings on June 5 and 6 said that the United States slowdown had so far been less severe than expected and that a further cut in British rates would heighten inflationary pressures. Since the bank's deliberations, data have shown British wages, prices, home-buying and consumer demand are all rising.
 Alan Cowell (NYT)

HEADLINE: Ethanol Plan Fails to Reduce Use of Gasoline 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER with DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 20 

 BODY:
A report prepared for Congress by the Bush administration recommends continuing federal incentives for ethanol-fueled vehicles. But it does so despite finding that the program has failed to live up to either of its goals: reducing gasoline consumption and substantially increasing the use of alternative fuels.
 Virtually no vehicles built to run on either ethanol or gasoline are actually using ethanol, partly because fewer than 1 in 1,000 of the nation's service stations sell it, according to the report. Yet by manufacturing the dual-fuel vehicles, automakers receive credits that allow them to lower the average gas mileage of the rest of their fleets. This has allowed them to sell more gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles. 
 Consequently, the report says, American gasoline consumption increased by 473 million gallons last year, or 0.3 percent. The extra gas consumption will rise steeply in the coming years, as more vehicles are produced under the law, the report warns. 
Because burning gasoline produces large quantities of carbon dioxide, a gas linked to global warming, the 1988 law promoting ethanol use actually increased American emissions of global-warming gases by 1.46 million metric tons last year, the report says. This meant that the rule accounted for about a tenth of the increased output of such gases by American vehicles, which have become the fastest-growing source of global-warming gases.
Rather than halt the program, the report recommends that more be done to increase the amount of ethanol actually burned by the dual-fuel vehicles, although it offers few specifics on how to accomplish this.
The Transportation Department declined to comment on the report, saying that it was still in draft form. A transportation official said that the text of the report had already been approved by the Office of Management and Budget. But some wording in the report might be changed before Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta sends it to Congress, the official said.
Mr. Mineta is traveling in Europe this week on business, so any action will not come until next week at the earliest, the official added.
The Transportation Department was supposed to report to Congress by September 2000, on the effectiveness of the law, which was intended to reduce American dependence on imported oil and encourage the use of alternative fuels like ethanol, a type of alcohol commonly made from corn. Caught between lobbying by corn farmers and automakers who favor the law and environmentalists who oppose it, the Clinton administration did not meet the deadline and left the issue to the Bush administration. A person critical of the ethanol law provided a copy of the report to The New York Times.
The Bush administration's conclusion represents the second big victory this month for the ethanol lobby, a powerful group of interests ranging from the National Corn Growers Association to ethanol distillers like Archer Daniels Midland. The administration decided last week to deny California's request for a waiver of regulations requiring that ethanol be used to produce clean-burning gasoline instead of other additives that are less expensive.
The ethanol program has bipartisan backing among corn state officials. Marlys Popma, the executive director of the Republican Party of Iowa, said that supporting the broader use of ethanol was crucial to the electoral success of any presidential candidate seeking votes in the state's caucus every four years, the first of each presidential campaign. "Ethanol is just hugely important in Iowa because it drives up the cost of corn," she said.
And according to the state's Democratic governor, Tom Vilsack, ethanol "is a lifeline, and it is a real ray of hope to family farmers that creates not only economic opportunity but preserves a way of life that's important to preserve."
Environmentalists are less kind to ethanol, and particularly the current incentive program for automakers. "The Bush administration is proposing to extend at one fell swoop a loophole that increases our oil addiction, costs consumers billions of dollars a year, manipulates the farmers and increases global warming pollution," said Daniel Becker, the energy policy director of the Sierra Club.
Mr. Becker argued that the ethanol program was costly for consumers. The report projects that continuing the program will increase gasoline consumption by nine billion gallons from 2005 to 2008. At $1.70 a gallon, a typical price now, that works out to $15.3 billion, or nearly $4 billion a year, in extra gasoline costs, Mr. Becker said.
The report also noted that few consumers even know when they have bought a vehicle with the $200 sensor for burning ethanol, for which the automakers do not charge extra.
General Motors, Ford Motor and the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler have made 1.2 million dual-fuel vehicles, almost all of which are designed to burn either ethanol or gasoline. These include most Chrysler minivans and some Chevrolet S-10 pickups, Ford Taurus sedans and Ford Windstar minivans.
This has allowed the automakers to reduce the average fuel economy of all vehicles they sell by five-tenths to nine-tenths of a mile per gallon. Foreign automakers have not made use of the law with the exception of Isuzu, which has begun selling some dual-fuel Isuzu Hombre pickup trucks made for it by General Motors, which owns 49 percent of Isuzu.
The administration's conclusions come just after President Bush faced heavy criticism in Europe for not doing enough on global warming.
Last month, Mr. Bush said he would wait for a fuel-economy report in July by the National Academy of Sciences before deciding what to do about the gas mileage of automobiles. But Vice President Dick Cheney has endorsed the expanded use of ethanol.
Fuel economy has become increasingly controversial in Washington. The House Appropriations Committee approved a transportation bill today that for the first time in six years does not include a prohibition on any toughening of fuel-economy standards for sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks.
The Republican majority in Congress had included such a provision since 1995 to prevent the Clinton administration from tightening these standards. But auto industry lobbyists said earlier this year that they did not need such a provision again this year because they trusted the Bush administration not to make any changes that would be technologically difficult to meet.
The recommendations of the ethanol report will form the basis for a formal issuance of regulations by the Transportation Department later this year, after public comment is solicited.
"Based on the results of this analysis, our preliminary conclusion is that continuation of the program should consider other actions that could improve the program and its chances of success," the report says. Without new regulations, the federal incentives would expire with the 2004 model year.
All gasoline-powered vehicles can run on a mixture of 10 percent ethanol and 90 percent gasoline, and this mixture is commonly sold in the Midwest. The dual-fuel vehicles are designed to run on nearly pure ethanol, which is 85 percent ethanol and 15 percent gasoline, and often marketed as E85. The administration report said only 101 of the 176,000 service stations in the United States sell nearly pure ethanol.
Most of these service stations are in the Midwest; there is not a single one on the West Coast and there are only two on the East Coast, one in Virginia and one in South Carolina, according to the National Ethanol Vehicle Coalition, which is backed by corn growers. Oil companies dislike ethanol because it cannot be transported in most pipelines, requiring use of costlier rail cars or tanker trucks.
"I'd be the first to admit that 99.5 percent of E85 vehicles don't use E85," said Phil Lampert, the coalition's executive director "We've offered to set up stations, and we'll pay 100 percent of the cost to install E85 pumps, and they refuse."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ethanol is not widely available except in the Midwest, where it has been championed by politicians and lobbyists for corn farmers and processors. By doing so, they are allowed to meet lower fuel-economy standards for the rest of the vehicles they sell. But the dual-fuel vehicles almost always burn gasoline because little ethanol is available. So instead of lowering gasoline consumption, the dual-fuel vehicle policy has been helping to drive gasoline consumption up. HEADLINE: Major Insurers May Pull Out Of New Jersey 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON with JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 20 

 BODY:
Companies insuring almost a third of New Jersey's drivers are considering withdrawing from the state, escalating the battle over auto insurance, which continues to be one of the most charged issues in a state with the highest premiums in the country.
 American International Insurance Company of New Jersey, a subsidiary of the giant American International Group, said today that it had filed documents requesting approval to close shop in New Jersey, where the company insures about 4 percent of the 4.8 million vehicles in the state. 
 The news of the company's request came a week after the State Farm Indemnity Company, New Jersey's largest insurer of drivers, said that it planned to withdraw from the auto insurance business in the state, where it insures 17 percent of the market. 
Meanwhile, the Liberty Mutual Group, with 11 percent of the state's business, said through a spokesman today that it, too, was looking toward the exits. 
"It is nearly impossible for an insurance company to make money in New Jersey," said Glenn Greenberg, a Liberty Mutual spokesman, "and no company, understandably, wants to continue in a market where a financial loss is guaranteed. We are considering all our options."
The companies maintained that they were hampered by regulatory issues, inadequate rates and the slow pace of progress on cost-saving measures enacted in 1998.
State officials were quick to point out that all three insurers have applications for hefty price increases pending before state regulators. A spokesman for the State Department of Banking and Insurance suggested that the companies were more interested in getting rate increases than in leaving the state. 
"We find it somewhat puzzling that such an announcement has been made while substantial rate increase requests are pending," said Peter Hartt, the spokesman. "I don't want to characterize their motivations and I don't want to characterize their strategy, not at this stage, anyway. But it is clear that at several times over the past few decades when significant reforms have been enacted, companies have threatened to withdraw and ended up staying."
In fact, American International told its employees in a June 15 memorandum that it could change its mind, "should circumstances change." And Mr. Greenberg of Liberty Mutual said his company's primary focus was not on leaving but "on getting a rate increase."
Both sides acknowledged that it would take years to disengage a company from its insurance business in the state, and that drivers would not face the prospect of finding new coverage anytime soon. But if the companies make good on their plans to leave, insurance analysts said, the reduced competition among the remaining insurers could mean higher costs to drivers.
In the meantime, the ferment is certain to make the issue an explosive one in a year in which the governor's office is up for grabs. 
New Jersey passed a major auto insurance law change in 1998 that was intended to reduce insurers' costs by reducing fraud and ending medical price gouging, among other things. The new law also forced all insurers to adopt across-the-board price cuts of 15 percent, cuts that many insurers are now trying to offset with requested price increases.
New Jersey's Republican governor and legislative majorities have treated the 1998 insurance overhaul as a major advance for the state's burdened drivers, while Democrats insist that they should get credit for forcing the issue.
Rae Hutton, a spokeswoman for Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, said, "State Farm and A.I.G. are worried about their bottom lines, but our bottom line is the money motorists have to pay for insurance, and we think it should be lower."
Like Mr. Hartt at the Department of Banking and Insurance, Ms. Hutton maintained that auto insurers had often threatened to leave New Jersey but then reversed themselves.
A spokesman for James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor, said it was the Republicans' fault. "This is further evidence that the Trenton administration has completely failed to make any meaningful reforms of the auto insurance system," said Richard McGrath, Mr. McGreevey's campaign manager. "Jim McGreevey has a series of reforms he believes will most importantly reduce rates for motorists but would also make New Jersey a more attractive market than it is to auto insurers."
Like Mr. McGreevey, the insurers maintain that the state has not carried through all of the changes in the 1998 act, leaving the companies enmeshed in regulations and a slow-moving bureaucracy, and unable to recoup the 15 percent mandatory rate cuts through savings.
"We've got a problem here," said John Tiene, president of the Insurance Council of New Jersey, an industry trade group. "If you don't have enough money coming in to pay the claims going out, you can't operate. Rates are a part of the discussion. But the broader issue is the ability to operate efficiently. In New Jersey, the state manages everything from premium rates to claims handling to how much profits companies can earn."
Mr. Tiene said the state's insurers appealed to Governor DiFrancesco last week after State Farm announced that it was withdrawing. "He's got to ensure that companies have the appropriate rates to conduct business," Mr. Tiene said.
Mr. Hartt of the state insurance department maintained today that the most important elements of the insurance overhaul, those aimed at reducing insurers' costs, were in place. 
"The fact is that every single cost-containment provision of the act has been implemented," Mr. Hartt said. He said changes that the insurers wanted, like updating the geographic regions that help determine insurance rates, were under way and were not part of the bill, for example.
But Mr. Tiene said political rather than economic considerations were shaping the process.
"No one wants to be the one to allow an insurance company to increase their rates," he said. "So the insurance department delays as long as possible. Then they deny the request for an increase and you have to go to an administrative court. The process can take years."

BYLINE:  By Tara Bahrampour (NYT) 

 BODY:

HEADLINE: Big Contract To Embraer From Brazil 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 20 

 BODY:
Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica, or Embraer, said today that it had won a contract to provide as many as 100 large regional jets to the Brazilian airline TAM Lineas Aereas.
 Embraer announced the deal, worth $750 million to $3 billion, at the Paris Air Show, which continues through the end of the week. Deliveries of the planes are to begin in 2004. 
 In a bid to repeat the success of its line of smaller 35- and 50-seat regional jets, Embraer invested about $1 billion over the last two years to develop the 70-seat ERJ-170 and the 98- to 108-seat ERJ-190. But the economic slowdown in the United States, where a majority of regional air travel occurs, had led analysts to suggest that the larger planes might be hard to sell.
They also worried that sales would be hurt by contractual restrictions that prevent many American pilots from flying larger jets.
Since announcing the new line of planes at the 1999 Paris Air Show, Embraer has sold only 30 ERJ-190's and 90 ERJ-170's, with a large portion ordered by CrossAir of Switzerland at that year's show. Embraer has since issued options for 205 more of the planes.
While the United States market might be limited at least for now, said Rodrigo Pereira, an analyst for Banco Pactual, an investment bank based in Rio de Janeiro, "there is a big market in Europe, hich will make up for some of the lack of demand in the U.S."
Indeed, Embraer's main competitor, Bombardier of Canada, which has also developed a series of larger regional planes in the last few years, announced this week that it had sold 50 of its 70- and 86-seat jets to the German leasing company Deutsche Structured Finance, a unit of DePfa Bank A.G., for $1.5 billion.
And another competitor in the regional jet market, the Fairchild Dornier Corporation, owned by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice and Allianz Capital Partners, sold eight of its new 70-seat aircraft this week to CSA Czech airlines for $230 million.
Embraer recently opened an office in China to make headway into what is expected to be the next big airline market.
At the 1999 air show, Embraer beat all expectations, selling or optioning 281 smaller jets for more than $6 billion. Since then, the company has increased its order log to $11 billion in firm commitments and another $12.7 billion in options, based on figures from the end of the first quarter.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Wieden Executive Leaving Agency

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA WINTERS LAURO 

 BODY:
Matthew Seiler, managing director at the New York office of Wieden & Kennedy, is leaving after only 13 months. A former top Wieden & Kennedy executive was named to replace him. 
 Wieden & Kennedy, based in Portland, Ore., said yesterday that Mr. Seiler was resigning, effective immediately, because of what were termed "philosophical differences." 
 In a telephone interview, Mr. Seiler said, "There are so many very exciting things going on in the world right now, economically and technologically speaking, and to me they signal taking this agency to a different place" from one where "Wieden & Kennedy Portland is comfortable."
Mr. Seiler, 39, joined the New York office in May 2000 from the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, where he had been executive vice president and director for strategic services.
Buz Sawyer, 47, will succeed Mr. Seiler, effective in mid-July. Mr. Sawyer worked at the Wieden & Kennedy Portland office from 1990 to 1992, then helped open an office in Amsterdam, where he became managing director.
He left in 1998 to become president at the San Francisco office of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Lowe Lintas closed the office in May after account losses there.

HEADLINE: Segarra Is Re-elected President Of the City Board of Education 

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
Ninfa Segarra was re-elected to a yearlong term as president of the New York City Board of Education yesterday, giving Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani continuing control of the board in his final months in office.
 Ms. Segarra is one of the mayor's two representatives on the board and certainly the most vocal. Her election underscored what had been a nakedly political struggle for control of the board, in which, even by her own account, racial and mayoral politics played as much if not more of a role than educational issues. 
 Reading a statement after her election by a 4-to-3 majority, Ms. Segarra invoked Mr. Giuliani's agenda: private management of public schools, radical cuts in central administration and the sale of the board's newly refurbished headquarters in Brooklyn. 
In later comments, she also stressed her status as the first Hispanic woman to head the board, and said that she and the board's only black member, Irving S. Hamer Jr., who cast the decisive vote in her favor, would bring special sensitivities to issues that affect black and Hispanic schoolchildren, even if they do not always agree on policy.
"For a Latina born and raised on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, and now raising two kids of my own within our public school system, I can truly say that it has been the adventure of a lifetime to serve on this board for the past 11 years," Ms. Segarra said in her statement.
She took pains to make flattering mention (twice) of Dr. Hamer, the Manhattan member, who stunned everyone in April by casting the swing vote for Ms. Segarra to become interim president. She filled out the unexpired term of William C. Thompson Jr., who resigned to run for city comptroller.
Dr. Hamer said after yesterday's vote that his reasons for supporting Ms. Segarra were the same as they were two months ago. Yet he acknowledged that one of the reasons he gave then -- the possibility that a mayoral ally would secure more city money for public schools -- had not materialized. Aides to Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy have complained that the mayor's budget will cut spending for schools by more than $200 million after inflation.
Ms. Segarra's pointed mention of having children in the public schools contrasts with Mr. Levy's enrolling his two children in private school. 
She criticized the chancellor for not having more blacks or Latinos in high-ranking positions in his administration. When pressed, she said the administration of Mr. Levy's predecessor, Rudy Crew, was also lacking in members of racial minorities, but she added that at least Dr. Crew himself was black. According to board officials, Mr. Levy has appointed 14 members of minorities, who make up 46.9 percent of his 32 senior managers. Dr. Crew appointed 24 minority-group senior managers out of his 58 appointments, or 41.4 percent.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Tries To Head Off Skittishness Among Lenders 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that more businesses have had trouble repaying bank loans as the economy has slowed, but he urged lenders not to overreact by cutting off credit to healthy borrowers.
 Speaking to the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan also said he saw few signs of accelerating inflation, despite the rise in the costs of energy and labor. His comments suggested that the Fed would not be constrained by concerns about rising prices when it meets next week to consider cutting interest rates for the sixth time this year. 
 Analysts are all but certain the Fed will reduce rates when it meets on Tuesday and Wednesday, but how big the rate cut will be is unclear. The initial betting on Wall Street was a quarter of a percentage point in the central bank's federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks. 
Because each rate cut this year was half a point, a quarter-point reduction would signal that the Fed thinks it does not need to ease monetary policy much more to reinvigorate the faltering economy.
But with recent data showing a sharper deceleration in industrial production than anticipated -- and with inflation apparently under control -- growing numbers of economists are predicting a rate cut of half a percentage point. A poll today by the Reuters news agency of primary dealers in government securities found that 17 expected a quarter-point cut, down from 19 in a similar poll last week, while 8 expected a half-point cut, up from 6 last week.
Most of Mr. Greenspan's appearance before the committee was devoted to assessing the state of the banking system, which he said had entered the economic slowdown in good shape. 
But he said a number of industries were under intensifying financial pressure because of the weaker economy, including retailers, manufacturers, health care providers, telecommunications companies and utility companies in California. He said banking regulators would be watching closely to see if credit problems grew worse, a development that could slow any economic rebound.
Many indicators "suggest that bank asset quality is deteriorating and that supervisors, therefore, need to be more sensitive to problems at individual banks, both currently and in the months ahead," Mr. Greenspan said. "Some of the credits that were made in earlier periods of optimism -- especially syndicated loans -- are now under pressure and scrutiny."
Banks are in generally strong financial condition, he said, and have improved their ability to judge credit risk.
Still, he said, the financial system remains prone to a cycle in which overoptimism among loan officers gives way to credit problems and then a period in which even healthy borrowers have trouble getting the financing they need.
"Such policies are demonstrably not in the best interests of banks' shareholders or the economy," he said. "They lead to an unnecessary degree of cyclical volatility in earnings and, as such, to a reduced long-term capitalized value of the bank. More importantly, such policies contribute to increased economic instability."
Mr. Greenspan referred to the economy only in passing during his prepared testimony. But he touched on the state of the economy in response to several questions.
The Fed chairman said he thought the decline in the growth rate of productivity in the first quarter would not be repeated in the second quarter. Much of Mr. Greenspan's upbeat view about the economy's long-term prospects hinges on his belief that the trend in productivity growth has been driven higher by advances in technology and heavy capital spending by businesses.
He said he was not worried that the federal budget surplus would give way to deficits because of the $1.35 trillion tax cut signed into law this month by President Bush.
Asked whether rising unemployment was hurting consumer confidence and spending, Mr. Greenspan said that confidence had slipped somewhat as layoffs had increased, but that consumers continued to spend at relatively robust rates.
"We've had a significant pickup in initial claims on insured unemployment, which is the broadest measure that we've got on layoffs," Mr. Greenspan said. That is certainly affecting consumer confidence, he said. "But we have not yet seen any real serious deterioration in the actions that people take."
Asked whether he saw signs of inflation, Mr. Greenspan replied, "It's very difficult to see anything short term."
As output has slowed, he said, the labor costs associated with each unit of production have increased, a common phenomenon in a weakening economy because employers adjust their production levels more quickly than they lay off workers. 
"But we've seen no evidence that those costs are being passed through into final prices in any material way," Mr. Greenspan said.
Similarly, he said, companies are absorbing higher energy costs rather than increasing prices for consumers. Core inflation, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, has been "relatively stable," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan Greenspan told a Senate committee that he saw few signs that inflation was accelerating. (Susana Raab for The New York Times)(pg. C6)

HEADLINE: States Expecting to Lose Billions From Repeal of U.S. Estate Tax 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 20 

 BODY:
Even as they deal with declining revenue growth from a softening economy, states are scrambling to plan for the potential loss of $50 billion to $100 billion over 10 years from the repeal of the federal estate tax enacted last month.
 The loss in revenue would come because states for 75 years have tied their own estate and inheritance taxes to the federal estate tax. The elimination of the federal levy would have the effect of ending various state death taxes unless governors and legislators take the unpopular step of creating new taxes on estates and inheritances. 
 In all, the loss of the estate tax is expected to cost states about 1.5 percent of their tax collections, says the Federation of Tax Administrators, a nonpartisan group based in Washington. But the states' complaints about the repeal of the estate tax, as enacted by Congress and President Bush, are not limited to the amount of revenue they expect to lose. 
Governors, legislators and budget officials are also chafing under a Congressional timetable that calls for the states to lose their tax revenues by 2005 while stretching the repeal of the federal estate tax more gradually over 10 years. Because the state taxes are based on a complicated formula that involves a credit against federal tax liability, the federal government will end up pocketing the money that otherwise would have gone to the states from 2006 through 2011.
The National Governors' Association calculates that windfall at $36.5 billion over the six years. If it reaches that level, Congress will have succeeded in forcing the states to subsidize a fourth of the $138 billion, 10-year cost of repealing the federal estate tax.
Even Republican state leaders who strongly support the repeal are perturbed by what they see as inequitable treatment. And they have not been soothed by the fact that the repeal was part of a package championed by a Republican president and enacted by a Congress that had Republican majorities in both houses at the time.
Last week, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida wrote legislative leaders in his state to warn them about anticipated revenue shortfalls, including the expected loss of $210 million from the estate tax in the 2002-03 fiscal year.
"While I support the eventual repeal of the estate tax," Mr. Bush, the president's brother, wrote, "shifting the burden merely allows Washington to spend more, while requiring us to spend less."
Estate tax revenues are hard to predict because tax officials cannot know who will die in a given year and how much they will leave. The National Governors' Association estimates the cost of the repeal to the states at "upwards of $65 billion," although the group also uses a range of $50 billion to $100 billion.
Similarly, the impact of the estate tax repeal on state revenues varies widely by state, depending on the wealth of a state's residents and the structure of its tax system.
California, for instance, would probably lose the most in actual dollars, with an estimated loss of $356 million when the estate tax begins to phase out next year and a loss of nearly $1 billion if it is fully eliminated. Because California's budget is so immense, the largest in the nation, those losses would account for only about 1.2 percent of the state's total revenues.
The impact on New York, New Jersey and Connecticut would be far greater, with each state losing 2.5 percent to 2.8 percent of total revenues. 
New Hampshire, which has no income tax on wages and no sales tax, would be the hardest hit. The anticipated loss there, while only $25 million when the tax is fully eliminated, would account for about 4.6 percent of all revenues.
"Anytime you lose revenue that accounts for 4 percent of the general fund budget, it's difficult to make up," said Gov. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, a Democrat. "Nobody ever likes to raise taxes. And particularly when you're eliminating a whole area of taxes, it makes it hard."
Unless the economy turns around quickly, the estate tax repeal will force many states that are already facing budget cuts to make further reductions in spending on schools, roads, prisons and social services. Some are likely to dip heavily into rainy-day funds that governors and legislators have built up during the recent economic expansion.
"Tax increases, in all honesty, seem to be off the table," said Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the governors' association. "So states will probably just take the hit and try to hold down spending."
State leaders are only now beginning to understand the full effect of the federal estate tax repeal on their budgets. And many are unhappy on several counts.
First, they say, the timing is unfortunate because states are already facing increasing pressure to reduce budgets because of declines in expected revenues from taxes on income and sales. Eleven states, many of them in the South, have already made midyear cuts totaling $1.6 billion in their 2001 spending plans because of revenue shortfalls and higher-than-anticipated demands for Medicaid services, according to a survey released today by the National Governors' Association and the National Association of State Budget Officers. More states are expected to do so by the end of the year.
The study found that while state revenues are still growing, they are rising at a slower rate than in recent years. Governors proposed general fund spending increases of 8.2 percent in the 2001 fiscal year, but only 3.6 percent for the 2002 fiscal year, the groups reported.
Second, many state officials are furious that the Congressional conference committee that negotiated the tax cut last month adopted a Senate plan that would effectively eliminate state death taxes faster than it would end the federal estate tax.
The measure caught many governors by surprise, and Mr. Bush supported a House plan that would have phased out the state and federal taxes simultaneously. But the Senate language prevailed in the conference committee, and Mr. Bush approved it as part of a $1.35 trillion tax cut package.
Frank Shafroth, the director of state-federal relations for the governors' association, said governors were agitated that decisions with such a significant impact on their budgets were made with little input from the states.
"This was a decision made without any consultation whatsoever or any consideration of the consequences," Mr. Shafroth said. "In some ways, I'm hearing more grumbling from Republicans than Democrats. Remember, at the time this happened, the White House, Senate and House were controlled by Republicans, and I think they thought this would bring an era of greater federalism rather than less federalism."
Senator Bob Graham of Florida, a Democrat and former governor, said that Congress's treatment of the states might set a dangerous precedent, particularly in dealing with coming debates like the taxation of sales on the Internet.
"It's going to have an adverse effect on the state-federal relationship on fiscal policy," Senator Graham said, "with states feeling they are very distinctly the redheaded third cousin at the family picnic."
About 2 percent of all estates -- those larger than $675,000 this year -- are subject to federal estate taxes. Since 1926, the federal government has allowed taxpayers to claim a dollar-for-dollar credit against their federal estate tax liability for the amount of death taxes they pay to their states. The credit is limited based on the size of the estate and a set of graduated rates that rise with the estate's taxable value.
At the moment, 38 states and the District of Columbia provide that their only state death taxes are so-called pick-up taxes that equal the credit allowed by the federal code -- thus giving the state a portion of the revenue without increasing the total tax paid by the estate. Two other states, Louisiana and Connecticut, recently passed laws to adopt pick-up taxes starting in 2004 and 2005, respectively.
The remaining 10 states have separate estate or inheritance taxes, but also use the state death tax credit to help calculate a taxpayer's liability in some instances. Those states would still lose money because of the repeal, but probably not as much as states with the pick-up tax.

HEADLINE: Disturbing Numbers for Mr. Bush 

 BODY:
During last year's presidential campaign, George W. Bush made much of his willingness to listen to the American people. But the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows a White House increasingly and alarmingly out of touch with what Americans are thinking. One result is a downturn in Mr. Bush's overall approval ratings at precisely the moment that they might be expected to rise. There is also disenchantment with Mr. Bush on specific policy matters, particularly involving economic fairness and the environment. 
 Though it is historically true that political honeymoons tend to fade as presidencies mature, Mr. Bush and his chief political adviser, Karl Rove, cannot be happy with what they see. Mr. Bush already has one big legislative achievement under his belt, the tax cut, and he is just coming off his first foreign tour, a trip to Europe that began raggedly but ended fairly smoothly, and was treated as a triumph by the White House. Yet the president's approval rating has dropped in the last month and now hovers uncertainly at 53 percent. 
 As to taxes, Mr. Bush will be disheartened to find that half the respondents think the tax cut will do little to help the economy, while two-thirds say the money could have been better spent on Social Security and Medicare. On foreign policy, less than half approve the way Mr. Bush is handling international matters, while more than half are uneasy about his capacity to deal with a global crisis.
The verdict on Mr. Bush's handling of social issues and domestic policy must be equally disturbing to a president who began his campaign by promising to "reconnect" his party to the disadvantaged and who often stressed his kinship with "those that struggle to get into the middle class." It is not merely that the public wants the president to move more vigorously on specific matters like patients' rights and prescription drug coverage. More broadly, Mr. Bush is increasingly perceived as both the servant and captive of moneyed interests. Fifty-seven percent said the administration's policies favored the rich, only 8 percent said they favored the middle class, only 2 percent said the poor. Nearly two-thirds also said that Mr. Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney were too closely wedded to the oil and gas industry.
Given the recent prominence of energy and environmental issues, the poll asked more than the usual number of questions on these matters. By a huge margin, Mr. Bush was seen as favoring energy production over environmental protection -- and by margins nearly as large, the public said that Mr. Bush had it exactly backward. They greatly favored energy conservation over energy production, and said they would happily protect the environment even if it meant paying more for electricity and gas. 
No less interesting was the revelation that despite a huge White House public relations blitz, the public, by a nearly 2-to-1 margin, doubts whether an energy crisis even exists. Such skepticism on a matter of fundamental concern to the administration suggests a credibility problem that may go well beyond the energy question.

HEADLINE: A Delicate Nuclear Balance 

BYLINE:  By Anatol Lieven; Anatol Lieven is a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

DATELINE: COPENHAGEN 

 BODY:
At his press conference in Moscow after he met with President Bush in Slovenia, President Vladimir Putin of Russia indicated his interest in a compromise on amending the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty to allow an American missile defense. But he also indicated, forcefully, that this must be a genuine compromise, taking Russian concerns into account, or Russia would retaliate with a major expansion of its nuclear arsenal. This tough stance was inevitable. From the Russian point of view, it is an effort at balance.
 The American plans carry an obvious long-term threat to Russia's own nuclear deterrent; from the viewpoint of Russian security, adding warheads to counter an American missile shield would be a logical course. More immediately, the plans put Russia in a complex situation -- especially, as President Putin hinted, with regard to China. 
 Russian and other opponents of antimissile programs have good reason to hope that defense systems will go on failing in tests, eventually burying the whole plan in domestic opposition and ridicule. The Democratic ascendancy in the Senate has increased Russian hopes in this regard. This is one good reason for Russia not to rush into an agreement.
Another reason is that Russia has no interest in getting ahead of Europe on this issue. As President Bush's talks with European leaders indicated, the latter remain profoundly skeptical of missile defense.
Russia has no interest in encouraging European leaders to abandon their skepticism. Russian hard-liners believe Russia passed up a golden opportunity to split the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over how to conduct the Kosovo war. Hostility to the United States in the Russian establishment remains strong and is fueled by the imminent prospect of NATO's expanding to include the Baltic states. Under such pressure at home, the Russian government is certainly not going to give free help to Mr. Bush in bridging a gap between America and Europe that American policies created.
If Russia is to cooperate with the United States on missile defense, it will only do so at a price. The first part of the Russian price relates to money and technology. The Russian security establishment was appalled at the shattering of Russia's high technology sector by Western-backed economic reforms in the 1990's, and by the supplanting of Russia on international markets. In return for agreeing to amend the ABM treaty, Moscow is likely to want both access to American technology and major American purchases of its own products.
Even more important, however, is the question of how, and to what extent, the ABM treaty is amended. Moscow wants a very tightly defined amendment that would allow limited protection against a few missiles from "rogue states" but would explicitly exclude future development toward a fuller shield.
This stance is dictated not only by Russia's interests, but also, as Mr. Putin stated, by those of China. Even a full-scale development of national missile defense would take decades to threaten Russia's massive deterrent -- leaving aside whether Russia, as Mr. Putin indicated, would begin adding warheads in response to unilateral American action. However, the effectiveness of China's small arsenal could be compromised very much sooner. And Russia cannot afford to make a deal with the United States at Beijing's expense.
In part, this is because Moscow needs China to counter American global influence. But even if that were not so, Russia could still not risk angering China on a vital matter, not with a long common border and a huge and growing disproportion in population and non-nuclear military might. So American negotiators must recognize that their Russian opposite numbers will, to some extent, represent Chinese interests.
Should the United States be prepared to negotiate with Russia on these terms? A public debate on this question is necessary; and for that to occur the Bush administration must decide what it really wants from missile defense and tell the public of its decision. Whether because of coyness, uncertainty, caution or some other factor, the administration's intentions on this major policy issue remain rather mysterious. If the aim is a limited shield against rogue states, then a compromise with Russia (and perhaps even China) should be possible. If the hope is to create an expandable system leading to the militarization of space, then neither Russian, nor indeed European, acceptance is likely to be forthcoming.

HEADLINE: Pakistan's Military Ruler Declares Himself President 

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, June 20 

 BODY:
Twenty months after toppling Pakistan's civilian government and assuming unbridled power under the misleadingly modest title of chief executive, and less than a month before flying to India for a crucial summit meeting, Gen. Pervez Musharraf today followed the pattern of three of Pakistan's military rulers over the last 50 years and appointed himself president and formal head of state.
 After a brief, understated swearing-in ceremony in Islamabad, the Pakistan capital, General Musharraf renewed assurances that he will return the country and its 140 million people to civilian rule after elections in October 2002. 
 That date was set by Pakistan's Supreme Court when it endorsed the bloodless military takeover of October 1999 but stipulated a three-year deadline for restoring democracy.
In assuming the presidency while remaining army chief of staff and chief executive, the 57-year-old general said he planned "no change in the intention" to follow the court's demand for elections, which he described as "very clear." 
Still, by pushing aside the departing civilian president, Rafiq Tara, and giving notice of his dismissal in a terse, one-sentence announcement that was read on Pakistan's state-controlled television at breakfast time, General Musharraf appeared to be setting the stage for a form of "guided democracy" that would leave him with final authority once an elected government was installed.
In Washington, the spokesman for the State Department, Richard A. Boucher, said General Musharraf's action "severely undermines Pakistan's constitutional order and casts Pakistan as a country ruled by decree rather than by democratic process."
Pakistan's presidency has traditionally carried a five-year term, and the general has already hinted that he intends to retain overall authority beyond next year.
But the timing of his move, three weeks before he is to arrive in New Delhi for a three-day summit meeting with Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, appears to reflect diplomatic objectives too. 
The meeting from July 14 to 16, billed as the most important of its kind in years, has stirred fresh hopes of a breakthrough in the half-century of enmity and war, punctuated by sputtering attempts at reconciliation, that followed the 1947 partition of British-ruled India into India, with a Hindu majority, and Pakistan, with a population that is overwhelmingly Muslim.
By taking the presidency before the summit meeting, General Musharraf appears intent on muting questions about his legitimacy, and longer-term future, as a negotiating partner on Kashmir and other knotty issues. India had registered misgivings by proposing ceremonial arrangements that seem to fall short of a full head-of-state welcome for the Pakistani leader.
In remarks televised in Pakistan, General Musharraf presented his assumption of the presidency much as he did his original seizure of power: as the act of a reluctant patriot, motivated by a desire to rid Pakistan of corruption and economic mismanagement that left the country teetering on the edge of an economic morass.
He described taking the presidency as a "personal embarrassment" but said it was "absolutely necessary" in Pakistan's national interest to enable him to carry forward reforms that he has deemed essential if Pakistan is to have a sustainable democracy.
For the swearing-in, General Musharraf shed his usual military khaki for the high-buttoned sherwani black coat that is the traditional formal wear for the subcontinent's statesmen. 
His tone was unobtrusive, although the steel behind his move was underlined by the presence, prominent among the guests, of Pakistan's other top military leaders. 
"I personally, in all sincerity, in all honesty, think that I have a role to play in this nation," he said, "and I sincerely think that I have a job to do here. And therefore I cannot, and I will not, let this nation down."
Mr. Tarar, the ousted president, was a figurehead appointed by the deposed civilian government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif. By taking the last top post not already in his grasp, General Musharraf stripped away, as some of his Pakistanis opponents see it, the last facade of constitutional rule. 
The impression was compounded by another move today, the formal dissolution of Parliament and of the legislatures in the country's four provinces. Since Parliament and all of the legislatures had been suspended since the 1999 coup, that had little practical effect.
To provide legal cover for today's moves, General Musharraf depended on a provisional constitutional order, previously approved by the Supreme Court, that gave him power to reorganize the country's institutions. But he also relied on a quiescent political situation within Pakistan. 
Overt challenges to his rule have been limited, as they were after today's announcement, when there were scattered arrests of supporters of opposition political parties, and some recent opinion polls have suggested that he is supported by a majority, or something close to it, among Pakistanis. 
Crucially, given that he leads a country with more than $35 billion of foreign debt, General Musharraf has also been accepted -- or not strongly opposed -- by Pakistan's traditional allies, including the United States, and by key international organizations like the International Monetary Fund.
Those points were pressed today by the general's chief spokesman, Maj. Gen. Rashid Qureishi, who rejected suggestions from a BBC interviewer that the Pakistani ruler was a dictator, saying that Pakistanis, and people outside Pakistan concerned for the country's well-being, recognized in General Musharraf a man "who has the best interests of the people at heart" and an austerity program that can end the downward economic spiral.
"For the first time in 14 or 15 years," General Qureishi said, referring to the last time that Pakistan had a military ruler, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, who died in an air crash in 1988, "the whole world has recognized that Pakistan has taken great strides towards becoming an economically viable country."
The restrained reaction today within Pakistan reflected, in part, the sense that General Musharraf was already all-powerful. But after living under military rulers for 26 of their 53 years as a nation, Pakistanis have grown leery of generals who promise a return to democracy, then adopt endless stratagems to delay it. 
That was the case with General Zia, who held power for nine years until his death, and Gen. Mohammmad Ayub Khan, who ruled for 11 years in the 1950's and 60's. The other military ruler who became president, Gen. Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, stepped down after only two years in 1971 after losing a civil war in East Pakistan that led to the creation of Bangladesh.
Imran Khan, a former cricket hero who leads the Movement for Justice, a reformist political party, said he understood that General Musharraf felt the need for the presidency's stature before his India trip, and added that in any case his hold on the presidency would depend on his getting an elected Parliament to endorse him. 
But Mr. Khan added, "What we don't want is to get into next year and suddenly find that the elections have been postponed."
Spokesmen for Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif, who alternated as prime minister through the 1990's until both were deposed and charged in corruption scandals, were more vehement. 
"It looks to me as though we're going back to the days of Zia ul-Haq," said Yusuf Talpur, a spokesman for Ms. Bhutto, who lives in self-imposed exile in London. 
Mr. Sharif's son, Hasan Nawaz Sharif, said his father, freed from a lengthy jail term for corruption by General Musharraf last year in a deal that sent him into exile in Saudi Arabia, was "very sad and very disappointed" by the day's events, but added that Pakistani military rulers had all seen their grand plans for the country voided by one catastrophe or another.
One of Pakistan's most influential journalists, Najam Sethi, editor of the weekly Friday Times, said General Musharraf was taking advantage of the weak opposition to his rule. 
"He's neutralized India; he's neutralized the United States; he's neutralized Europe," Mr. Sethi said. "People are learning to live with him." 
In any case, there was no groundswell of opposition that might have stopped him. "The people of Pakistan are still alienated by and large from the political process," Mr. Sethi said, "and to that extent General Musharraf seems to have a clear ride."
