HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Court Reverses Ruling On a U.P.S. Tax Shelter
A federal appeals court reversed a 1999 ruling that United Parcel Service engaged in sham transactions to avoid hundreds of millions of dollars in corporate income taxes.
 The decision was the second in a week by a federal appeals court rejecting government efforts to tear down corporate tax shelters. Together, tax experts say, the rulings articulate a doctrine giving companies broad freedom to shelter income from taxes. Page A1. 

Liberty Media in German Cable Deal
To further expand its holdings overseas, Liberty Media, controlled by John C. Malone, is acquiring cable TV systems with 10 million subscribers from Deutsche Telekom for about $4.7 billion. Liberty and Deutsche Telekom did not disclose the precise terms of the deal, which the companies said were still being negotiated. Analysts were generally enthusiastic about the deal, but investors were less optimistic. Shares of Liberty Media fell 46 cents, or 2.8 percent, to $16.19. C2.

Offers Received for Magazines
Emap, the British publishing company, received formal bids -- the largest slightly more than $550 million -- for its United States magazine business, which includes titles like Motor Trend, Hot Rod and Teen. C2.

Stocks Rise on Hopes for a Rate Cut
Stocks rose modestly as investors pinned their hopes on another interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 68.10 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,715.43. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 13.90 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,237.04. The Nasdaq composite index added 27.52 points, or 1.4 percent, to 2,058.76. C6.

Bid System Could Be Used for AIDS
The price of drugs for tuberculosis fell by more than one-third when the World Health Organization set up a system for buying them in bulk and asked drug companies to compete to offer the best price. The reductions are significant because the system could serve as a model for buying AIDS drugs for Africa and other developing countries. C4.

New Drugs Expected for Psoriasis
New drugs made using biotechnology will soon offer what could be the first safe, long-term treatments for psoriasis, doctors at a conference devoted to the disease said. C4.

Trade Deficit Narrowed in April
The trade deficit narrowed in April as imports of business equipment, consumer goods and other items fell more than exports, government figures showed. The trade gap in goods and services decreased to $32.2 billion from a revised $33.1 billion in March, the Commerce Department said. The deficit had narrowed to $28.6 billion in February, the smallest gap since January 2000. C6.

Insurer Cuts a Deal With Opponents
Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, which has been seeking permission from New York State to convert to a for-profit company, has made a giant leap toward that goal by striking a deal with the main opponents of the plan. A1.

Flaws Seen in Hot Lines for Recalls
A consumer advocacy group said that 18 percent of the 595 hot lines set up for recalled children's products since 1990 no longer functioned properly. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said it would begin forcing companies that recall products to maintain consumer phone lines indefinitely. C6.

Morgan Stanley Profit Falls 36%
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said that its profit fell 36 percent in the second quarter of its fiscal year as a slump in stocks slowed underwriting, mergers and equity trading. Nevertheless, the earnings beat estimates. C6.

Nuanced Fight Over Euro in Britain
A nuanced conflict is taking place in Britain between the government and businesses leaders that could stall the nation's adoption of the euro. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: Franks Proposes an Overhaul of New Jersey's Property Taxes 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 21 

 BODY:
Tackling the nettlesome issue of high property taxes for the first time in his campaign for governor, Bob Franks today proposed freezing tax assessments for as long as people own their homes, a change that could revolutionize the way municipalities and school districts finance operations.
 Mr. Franks, the former representative who is running for the Republican nomination, also proposed to hold increases in property tax rates to the rate of inflation. Both measures would require an amendment to the State Constitution. 
 Mr. Franks's plan came with four days left until the Republican primary, at a time when Bret D. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City, has opened up a wide lead among likely voters, according to the most recent poll. Mr. Schundler has made lower property taxes a priority in the campaign. Mr. Franks said he had planned to unveil his property tax plan shortly after the primary.
"For too long, New Jersey homeowners have been at the mercy of local governments who order re-evaluations just to raise more tax revenue," Mr. Franks said. Under his plan, homes would be assessed at the purchase price, and never again. Now, state law requires reassessments at least once every 10 years.
The plan raises a number of questions, not least whether it would penalize new arrivals in a community by taxing them on the market value of their property, subsidizing lifelong residents whose assessments had not kept up with market value.
Mr. Schundler said tonight that Mr. Franks's plan would penalize people for moving: "What is the rationale for that, if people want to get their child into a better school system, or to move to a better neighborhood, or closer to a job, or if a senior wants to move to a smaller house?"
Mr. Franks announced his tax plan even as the Election Law Enforcement Commission, meeting in Trenton, was handing Mr. Schundler a victory in a long-running campaign-finance dispute. It concerned $885,000 in advertisements that featured Mr. Schundler prominently last year, but were paid for by a scholarship fund he controls, not by his campaign. Mr. Franks argued that that amount should be deducted from Mr. Schundler's $5.9 million spending cap in the primary.
The commission accepted Mr. Schundler's reasoning that the ads should not count toward the cap because they ran before Jan. 1, the start of the primary campaign cycle. Mr. Schundler's aides called on Mr. Franks to stop running commercials that attack Mr. Schundler for "taking money from needy children" through the scholarship fund ads.
A lawyer for Mr. Franks, William E. Baroni Jr., said the commission's decision "blows a hole" in the state's decades-old public finance system.
"What has now been created is a world where a candidate for governor can open an allegedly charitable organization, spend a million dollars on television commercials on the eve of the start of the campaign, and say that has nothing to do with his gubernatorial campaign," he said.
Meanwhile, the Schundler campaign said supporters were reporting so-called push polls, in which people ostensibly polling voters asked questions aimed at influencing opinions. 
Deborah Wirths, a Republican committeewoman in Sussex County, said she was called at 5 p.m. Wednesday by a woman who asked her whom she would vote for on Tuesday; she said Mr. Schundler. Mrs. Wirths said the woman then asked: "If the race were tomorrow and you found out Schundler believed that people should be able to walk on the street with concealed guns, and that women who were victims of incest and rape were not allowed to have abortions, would you still vote for Schundler knowing these things?"
"That's when I said, 'Who's paying for this poll?' " Mrs. Wirths said. "She said, 'We're not allowed to know that information.' "
Charlie Smith, the Franks campaign manager, "categorically" denied "any involvement in any type of poll such as that." But, he added, "that message is similar to one that we believe as a campaign many voters deserve to know about Bret Schundler."

HEADLINE: Emap of Britain Draws Bids In Sale of U.S. Magazines 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Emap, the British publishing company, received formal bids -- the largest slightly more than $550 million -- for its United States magazine business yesterday, including titles like Motor Trend and Teen, executives close to the auction said.
 The bidders included American Media, which publishes The National Enquirer; Primedia, which publishes Seventeen and New York magazine; AOL Time Warner; and the Texas Pacific Group, an investment firm with holdings ranging from J. Crew to Oxford Health Plans, the executives said. 
 Emap paid $1.5 billion for the magazines in 1998, with its purchase of Petersen Publishing. The magazine titles have struggled amid the economy's downturn and the subsequent advertising slump. 
Petersen Publishing was founded by Robert E. Petersen, who started Hot Rod in 1947. In the United States, Emap now publishes dozens of Petersen's enthusiast titles, including Skin Diver, Guns & Ammo and Snowboarder. FHM, a ribald men's magazine started by Emap after the purchase, is not included in the sale. 
In the last decade, Petersen has changed hands several times. In 1996, it was sold for $450 million to a group headed by D. Claeys Bahrenburg, with backing from Willis Stein & Partners L.P., a private equity fund based in Chicago. 
Over the next two years, James J. Dunning Jr., the chief executive, developed dozens of new enthusiast magazines -- niche titles as specific as Blue Corvette Magazine and Red Corvette Magazine -- and attracted advertisers by developing crossplatform advertising. 
Executives who have seen financial figures for the auction said that Emap had put a $600 million price tag on the properties but might settle for $550 million. 
One executive who quit the bidding said he did so because he believed the asking price was too high and ought to be closer to $450 million.
Executives at American Media said that the company's chief executive, David Pecker, is intensely negotiating with Emap. Mr. Pecker has been trying to lure high-end advertisers to his tabloid properties, but has been unsuccessful so far. If American Media were to purchase Petersen, Mr. Pecker could try to lure its mainstream advertisers into American Media's tabloids. 
Time Inc. executives said that AOL-Time Warner expects the unit to expand. The Emap properties, they said, could fit neatly with Time's purchase last year of Times Mirror Magazines, a publisher of sports and enthusiast magazines. 
Primedia has bid on the properties in the past, losing out in the 1996 bidding, when the company was known as K-III Communications. Primedia is controlled by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.
Gruner & Jahr, a division of Bertelsmann, and Hachette Filipacchi, passed on bidding after expressing initial interest, according to executives close to the companies.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Chelsea Is on the March Northward

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
A 12-story mixed-income rental building is nearing completion at the northeast corner of West 30th Street and Ninth Avenue, continuing the northward push of housing in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood.
 Chelsea Place, at 363 West 30th Street, is in the area long dominated by giant postal facilities: the General Post Office between Eighth and Ninth Avenues and 31st and 33rd Streets and the mail-sorting complex between Ninth and 10th Avenues from 28th to 30th Streets. Madison Square Garden is a block away and the open rail yards are nearby. 
 The new structure, a nondoorman building, includes 77 studio-to-two-bedroom apartments, including penthouses, of 450 to 1,200 square feet. Some penthouses have fireplaces, terraces or skylights. Twenty percent of the units are set aside for residents making less than 50 percent of the median annual income in New York City. The remaining 80 percent of the apartments are being leased at market rates of $1,675 to $4,600 a month. 
Those rents are somewhat less than those for apartments at the crop of new high-rise rentals, totaling about 1,000 units, in and around the neighborhood, according to the developer, the Zucker Organization of Manhattan.
"They are under the market, but not undercutting the market," said Robert A. Scaglion, director of business development at CitiHabitats, a Manhattan brokerage firm. "They are in a location that is slightly off the beaten path and are not offering a doorman, so they are priced accordingly."
Typical monthly rents at new buildings in Chelsea, he said, range from $2,000 for a studio to $4,800 for a two-bedroom (down 10 percent from last year). "It is a strong but price-sensitive market," he said. "Landlords who adjust to today's market will do well and those who hold out for higher rents will continue to hold out."
Laurie Zucker, vice chairwoman of the Zucker Organization, said, "The economy is cooling, so we wanted to rent up quickly and not hold out for the last dollar." She added that her company would rather wait for the rents to increase over time and use the less expensive rents today.
Since leasing began at the end of May, contracts have been signed for 39 of the 60 market-rate apartments, including all six studios, said Nina F. Falk, an associate broker at Cantor & Pecorella of Manhattan, the project manager. She said the units were being rented by single people and couples from the area, 25 to 35 years old on average, who want a newer or larger apartment. But, she added, "everyone came here for the rent."
The subsidized units will be rented for $517 to $665 a month to people earning $20,700 to $29,550 a year, depending on the size of the apartment and the family. Applications for those units are no longer being accepted.
Ms. Zucker said her company was able to keep rents lower for the market-rate units in part because the $3.2 million cost to acquire the Chelsea Place site was reasonable.
The developers were attracted to the site because "West 30th Street is a beautiful residential block in an emerging neighborhood," Ms. Zucker said.
Developers are expanding the boundaries of Chelsea northward by turning what used to be manufacturing districts along Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas into housing sites. The change was spurred by rezonings along the avenues to permit residential development.
By developing Chelsea Place as an "80-20" project and keeping 20 percent of the units affordable to people with limited incomes, the Zucker Organization received $17.7 million in tax-exempt bond financing from the New York State Housing Finance Agency.
The building is clad in red brick and limestone and features "big windows, which gives it the bold, gutsy look of a downtown loft," said Stephen B. Jacobs, who designed Chelsea Place and heads the Manhattan architectural firm bearing his name.
Amenities include an exercise room with an adjacent laundry, a rooftop deck, a third-floor terrace and a 15-car underground parking garage. Ms. Zucker said initial occupancy was expected to begin in mid-August.

HEADLINE: Budget Leaders Reach Pact, Keeping Rebates 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT HANLEY

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 21 

 BODY:
Legislative budget leaders said today that they had reached agreement on a new spending plan for New Jersey that preserves two election-year property-tax rebates without increasing other taxes or fees.
 Although the state faces revenue shortfalls, leaders said the proposed budget for fiscal 2002 had been balanced, as required by the State Constitution, through spending cuts and the rollover of unspent money in the current budget. 
 But they would not state the size of the plan or give details about the trims made to the $23.2 billion budget that Christie Whitman proposed in January before she resigned as governor to become head of the Environmental Protection Agency. 
"Everybody's going to be a little unhappy," said Senator Robert E. Littell, chairman of the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee. "But there's no irreparable harm done to anyone."
Under the State Constitution, the Legislature has to enact the budget by July 1. The document was being printed today and was expected to be introduced before midnight, officials said. Committee hearings on it are scheduled for Monday.
Unlike budget preparations during the economic boom of the late 1990's, negotiations on the budget for the fiscal year starting on July 1 have been overshadowed by squabbling over projected shortfalls in the state's tax revenue.
The state treasurer, Peter R. Lawrance, contends that proceeds from sales, corporate, income and other taxes are $948 million below expectation for the rest of this budget year and for fiscal 2002. On the other hand, the Office of Legislative Services, a nonpartisan branch of the Legislature that, among other things, analyzes state finances, puts the revenue shortfall at $1.6 billion.
The new budget was fashioned with Mr. Lawrance's income estimates, said Senator Littell and Assemblyman Leonard Lance, head of the Assembly Budget Committee.
The two legislators, both Republicans, said that the budget did not tamper with increases in the two rebate programs recently announced by Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco.
Under one, the N.J. Saver Rebate, Mr. DiFrancesco on Tuesday increased the average annual payment to homeowners to $500, up from an average of $240 last year. The increase will cost the state $607 million, up from $337 million last year, Mr. Lawrance has said. Under the other program, the Homestead Rebate, Mr. DiFrancesco and G.O.P. legislative leaders favor an increase to $750 from $500 the maximum payments for disabled and elderly homeowners who earn less than $100,000 a year. Mr. Lawrance has said the $118 million cost of this increase was in his department's budget for fiscal 2002.
The N.J. Saver rebate checks are to be mailed in early September, about two months before voters choose a new State Legislature. Republicans are expected to face a stiff challenge to their decadelong control. Some Democrats have criticized the increased rebates as G.O.P. election-year gimmickry.
Mr. Lance noted today that Democratic legislators had wholeheartedly endorsed the rebates in the past.
"I hope those who have voted for them will vote for the budget," he said.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL; 
McNabb Won't Run From Demands

BYLINE:  By THOMAS GEORGE

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA 

 BODY:
The spotlight radiates on Donovan McNabb, and it is hot. With the Eagles' final minicamp recently behind them, and with their training camp debut set for July 27, McNabb has been shuttling between interviews, photo shoots and fund-raisers, mindful to keep football at the forefront.
 For McNabb, 24, a third-year quarterback in the N.F.L. around whom the Eagles franchise is being built, a player with a 14-10 record as a starter who generated a head-turning playoff showing last season, fulfilling his demands is tricky business. 
 So, McNabb's teammates warn against bombarding him with sticky subjects. Tread lightly, they say, when asking him about being booed by Eagles fans at the draft in 1999. Do not talk about the black quarterback issue or even hint about his running abilities as a quarterback. Avoid discussing the pressure he might feel to produce more now rather than later. 
But as McNabb settled in to talk at the Eagles' complex, it was as if he were in the pocket peering right and left, ready to strike. The spotlight may be hot, but for that moment, at least, he brought extinguishers.
"I don't concentrate too much on what everybody is thinking, and when did that change?" he offered, even before the subject could be broached. "When I got booed at the draft, I looked over at my mom and she started to cry. I looked at my dad and he was upset. My brother was mad. Me? Of course I took it personally. Now, I look at it as every opportunity I have to step on the field is a chance to show what I can do."
Like the scrambling, darting, daring quarterback he is, he followed that comment with this one:
"I get tired of hearing about the mobility of black quarterbacks in the N.F.L. Hey, what about black quarterbacks being players who have done well in college, have been drafted and bring their knack of reading defenses, decision making and leadership to the game? I just don't hear that part."
O.K., McNabb was rolling now, so how about the pressure? Could he handle this spotlight? The heat?
"I know I'm a third-year player, but why can't it all happen now?" he asked.
It's all a bit much -- being regarded as one of pro football's best quarterbacks, being asked to nix the Giants jinx, to win a championship, right now, in the coming season.
Just what will McNabb do?
Just the thought makes every Eagle ecstatic and eager.
Because McNabb, who was booed on national television by some Eagles fans on draft day because they wanted Ricky Williams instead, is now among the most prominent sports figures in Philadelphia. Sixers guard Allen Iverson may have just completed a tantalizing bid for a basketball championship, and the Phillies may have made baseball fun here once again, but McNabb is the city's most adored sports star.
Last year, in only his second pro season, he took an average group of offensive personnel and led the Eagles to startling heights. Philadelphia finished with an 11-5 regular-season record and upset the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in a playoff game. McNabb, passing and running, accounted for 74.6 percent of his team's total net yards last season. He finished second behind St. Louis Rams running back Marshall Faulk for league most valuable player honors. Over all, in his two seasons, he has thrown 29 touchdown passes compared with 20 interceptions.
This season there is great anticipation.
"They were not expected to do what they did last year, but they won as a team without a lot of big names," said receiver James Thrash, a free agent the Eagles signed from the Washington Redskins. "Why wouldn't I want to come here and be a part of this with Donovan? He is one of those rare players who is exciting to watch even if you are playing against him."
McNabb's father, Sam, who still lives in Chicago, McNabb's hometown, knows his son.
"There is nothing that Donovan starts that he does not feel he is capable of finishing as the very best," he said. "I see a natural process of evolution with him where he has been blessed to have both of his parents and that helped him build a foundation. Now he is taking that foundation and building a pretty nice house. Everyone was unsure about him as a football player last year. This year the expectations are so much greater. Donovan has to be ready to answer some questions. Donovan has to be ready to pass some tests."
McNabb's draft-day disaster cannot be overstated, because it is the backdrop from which he works. He said he knew there was a problem well before the draft because a former college teammate from Syracuse who lived in Philadelphia had warned him that the entire city seemed to want the Eagles to draft Williams, the Texas running back, with the No. 2 pick.
"People think it all started when the pick was announced," McNabb said, "but even before the draft started, when we were in the green room and the players that were there were being announced, I was booed. Yeah, I noticed that. And then when the pick came and there was more booing, how can you ever be prepared for that?"
Especially on a day like that, his father said.
"Everything for a young man in a high draft position builds up to that point and it becomes the biggest day of his life," Sam McNabb said. "He had never heard that kind of thing before. We had never heard it. His mother, it took her a long time to get to this point where she can talk about it now without crying and getting emotional. People tried to explain it by saying, 'It wasn't meant against you, it was because they didn't take Ricky Williams.' Well, that's like being in a drive-by shooting and saying the bullet was not meant for you, sorry it hit you.
"It was a rude awakening for Donovan. It taught him about big business. And it is something to build off of in terms of keeping grounded, in understanding that going from hero to zero doesn't take a whole bunch."
McNabb's 1999 contract was said to be a seven-year, $54 million deal with a $11.3 million signing bonus. But those around McNabb call him frugal and even tight.
McNabb opts for conservative.
"If I see a shirt for $75, I know I can get that shirt for cheaper than that and I won't buy it," he said. "I check on everything financial with my agent. If I have a family member who needs money, I check into it, really check into it, first. I don't worry about what people think -- it's my money, so it's my business."
He is defiant and direct. And there is little naivete there.
"Well, on that one, he's like me," his father said, chuckling. "I call it being economically wise."
His teammates say that they see no pretentiousness, that he is a teammate's teammate. They say he has the ability to be the funniest guy in the room, the crack comedian, yet also the most serious among them.
"Donovan in a practice or a game runs into some players who are so focused and intense that they are about to have a nervous breakdown," Eagles cornerback Bobby Taylor said. "He can calm 'em down."
McNabb can throw the ball on the run, throw it on the roll, stand firm and split a defense or run through one. The Eagles' owner, Jeffrey Lurie, talks about McNabb's professionalism and dynamism and about how McNabb and Coach Andy Reid form a duo that can create and sustain greatness.
Reid offers caution: "I've been watching quarterbacks in this offense a long time and it takes three years to grasp it and four years to perfect it. After four years you're going to know what this guy is. You could see him one day knowing the offense so well that he can execute it off his back foot, throwing sidearm, improvising, letting more of his ability show. I'm a realist. You have to perform every year in the N.F.L. Time will tell. Donovan does have the work ethic to finish ahead of the curve. When you look at his ability alone, he is competing against history and himself."
McNabb is competing in the same division against a Giants club that has beaten the Eagles in nine straight games, including 20-10 in a playoff game last season. He is finding ways to distance himself from his painful start, finding a way to accept being booed, then being embraced. More is expected, though there is doubt about just how much the Eagles' offense, especially the receiving crew, has been improved.
For McNabb, though, it is hot. Now, he has to keep cool.
"I'm a guy who's got to make an impact," he said. "This year I want to improve on putting a little more air under my passes. This year we have at least two more opportunities to change the way things have gone with the Giants. I'm learning more -- but I've learned a lot."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Donovan McNabb's desire to excel stems from being booed on draft day. (Bradley Clark Bower for The New York Times)(pg. D1); Eagles quarterback Donovan McNabb has thrown for 29 touchdowns and 20 interceptions in two seasons. (Bradley Clark Bower for The New York Times)(pg. D2)

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 32

LENGTH: 4667 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* AFRICAN GALLERIES, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (on long-term view). The museum has one of the oldest and most important collections of African art in the country. Just a few years ago, 250 objects from the permanent collection were installed in revamped first-floor galleries; now two dozen pieces have been added and the space has been redesigned again, this time with multicolored walls, mural-size color photographs, documentary films and ambient sound. Added works expand the definition of African to include both Morocco and ancient Nubia. And the overall selection, from familiar friends to treasures recently acquired, is thrilling. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $4; $2, students and 62+ (Holland Cotter)

* "AFRICAN, OCEANIC AND ANCIENT AMERICAN ART: RECENT ACQUISITIONS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Oct. 28). One of the best new group shows in the city -- stimulating to mind and eye -- is sitting smack in the middle of the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing at the Met, and you've probably never seen the like of much of what's in it. The 70 pieces all came to the Met as gifts or purchases over the last five years. They take many forms, from devotional icons to notebook drawings to Sunday-best hats, and they span centuries and continents, from a tiny Mexican ceramic mask made around the ninth century B.C. to a hummingbird-colored silk mantle woven in Madagascar in 1998. A bottom line to such diversity? Almost everything here was meant to have some contact with the human body: to be worn, carried, caressed. This is art with the velvet ropes down. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

"AZTLAN TODAY: THE CHICANO POSTNATION," Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th Street, (718) 681-6000 (through Sept. 9). Removed in time from the intensely political art of the Chicano civil rights era, almost everything in this show of recent work takes the form of conceptually based photography and video. The tone is low-key; the polish is high. A stance of rooted historical witness has been replaced by ambiguity. Ethnic identity is treated alternately with shrewd comic flair, tender theatricality or autobiographical intimacy. The work is strong; of particular interest is the way it suggests subtle changes in the nature of political art through the 1990's. Hours: Wednesdays noon to 9 p.m.; Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $3; $2, students and 65+ (Cotter)

* JACQUES AND NATASHA GELMAN GALLERIES, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5000 (continuing). These glorious new galleries display 50 French modern works, almost all paintings, drawn from the Gelmans' collection. In addition to the paintings here, the collection includes five sculptures, more than 30 drawings and a major work on paper: a Matisse cutout, the Met's first, which will be shown in a subsequent hanging. The standouts installed here include Matisse's Fauve masterpiece "The Young Sailor II"; a matched set of small, classic Cubist paintings, one by Picasso, one by Braque, both from 1911, arguably the high point of their collaboration; and a fantastically refined, sexually fraught 1929 Dali, "Accommodations of Desires." It is a selection that is not only consistent in its high quality but also, for all the big names and visual firepower, surprisingly personal. It makes the museum a modern art destination in a way that it has never quite been before. Hours and admission: See above (Roberta Smith).

* "EL GRECO: THEMES AND VARIATIONS," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through July 29). This gemlike single-digit exhibition (just seven canvases) outweighs some of the more grandiose shows in New York museums at the moment. It brings together, mostly for the first time, four versions of the artist's tumultuous "Purification of the Temple," which provide a vivid time line of his transcultural development, and three versions of his resonant portrait of St. Jerome as a cardinal, which were all painted toward the end of his life when he skillfully copied -- always with interesting differences -- his works for private patrons. The show makes its small oval gallery reverberate with thoughts about painting: as craft, thought, commodity and lifelong pursuit. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 62+ (Smith).

* WILLIAM KENTRIDGE, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 16). By way of drawings and film animations, Mr. Kentridge addresses in searing images South Africa and its racial problems, along with the longings and frustrations of bourgeois lives played out in the country's deeply dysfunctional setting. The exhibition begins with his jarring "Shadow Procession" (1999), a ragtag parade of silhouetted moving images projected on a big screen, which evokes the displaced and dispossessed who haunt not only South Africa but also the history of the world. At the heart of the show are his drawings and the short animated films he makes of them, in which the process shares importance with the content. Many of the films contrast the lives of two antiheroes, one a crude rapacious businessman, the other a sensitive artist, in compelling medleys of images that touch on the personal and the political. Departing from this format is "Ubu Tells the Truth" (1997), a highly charged satire based on the hearings of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, set up in 1995 to investigate human rights abuses during the apartheid era. It's not often that good art is shaped from such raw angry material, but Mr. Kentridge's powers of invention are equal to the challenge. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students, artists and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

* "MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE CLEVELAND MUSEUM OF ART," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through Aug. 19). From Michelangelo to Louise Bourgeois, from Rembrandt to Franz Kline, this cornucopia of drawings from one of the most important collections in the United States bristles with the work of stellar talents. A standout is a double-sided drawing in red chalk by Michelangelo, probably done around 1510-1511. One side reveals the trouble he had sketching a foot that fits the position of a youthful male nude on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel; the other shows the headless nude itself, a powerful, ingeniously posed figure that emphasizes the sculptor's magnificent grasp of anatomical rendering. A rare compositional drawing by Fra Filippo Lippi, a subtly toned landscape by Claude Lorrain, a scene of battling horses by Gericault, a stately portrait by Ingres, one of Seurat's brilliant black crayon drawings of a French vaudeville scene, and works by Degas and Toulouse-Lautrec are among the highlights. The 20th-century American group is something of a disappointment, but there is enough great stuff to make this a masterpiece of a show. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 65+ (Glueck).

* "UNIFORM: ORDER AND DISORDER," P.S. 1 Center for Contemporary Art, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Sept. 3). Originally shown in Italy, this exhibition traces the changing forms and symbolism of the modern military uniform as it progresses through and is transformed by the larger culture -- alternately respected and violated, examined and absorbed, abbreviated and exaggerated. The perpetrators include artists like Wolfgang Tillmans, Vanessa Beecroft and Maurizio Cattelan; fashion designers like Prada, Versace and Donna Karan; and scores of terrorists, punks and nameless teenagers. Eight well-stocked vitrines present a plethora of supporting material. The exhibition ends with the real thing: a gantlet of the uniforms and head gear -- from fatigues to parade dress -- worn by members of the different Italian military services. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5 (Smith).

Galleries: Uptown

LOCKWOOD DE FOREST, Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through July 27). By no means a name to reckon with in the pantheon of American view makers, de Forest (1850-1932) specialized in unpretentious small sketches meant to convey the feeling of a place rather than dwell on its physical attributes. His work, until recently kept mostly in family hands, was a visual diary of his many wanderings. In contrast to the taste of the time, he regarded his sketches as finished works, focusing, even in exotic locations like Egypt, India, Syria, Greece and Mexico, on village life, stretches of dunes, desert rocks, tree-lined shores and distant mountains bathed in fog. For those who like their countrysides relaxed and uninvasive, this show will appeal (Glueck).

LAURA DE SANTILLANA, Barry Friedman, 32 East 67th Street, (212) 794-8950 (through June 29). Blowing glass is a natural for Ms. de Santillana, as her grandfather Paolo Venini founded a glassworks in Murano, Italy, noted for its hospitality to artists. Later it was headed by her and her father. Her abstract sculptures, in tabletop size, have simple, squarish tablet shapes. But they glow with subtle oppositions of brilliant versus muted tones, translucency versus opacity, materiality versus evanescence. Their energy also derives from the tensions they set up between painting and sculpture. Infused with the light values of glass, these painterly sculptures at their best can be dazzling (Glueck).

JOHN DUFF, Knoedler, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through June 29). Mr. Duff displays his enduring involvement with industrial materials, geometric form and philosophical conceptions of order. Sculptures from the late 1960's and 70's that are on view here include elegant distorted cylinders or double-ended boat shapes made of rough fiberglass (Ken Johnson).

KEITH HARING, Skarstedt, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 79th Street, (212) 737-2060 (through June 30). Promiscuously generous an artist as he was, Haring was also very uneven. This exhibition of just four medium-large canvases from the early 1980's shows him at his best. Two in particular suggest the vision of a modern Bosch. Densely populated by manically interactive demons, monsters and little men, they combine graphic ingenuity, mythic narrative and erotic polymorphism to exhilarating effect (Johnson).

ALEX KATZ, Adam Baumgold, 74 East 79th Street, (212) 861-7338 (through July 13). Though famous mainly for his large, elegantly flattened and simplified pictures of beautiful, well-to-do people, Mr. Katz also has a lovely touch on a small scale. This modest but rewarding show of mostly small pictures of women, plus some funky little collages from the 1950's, shows to advantage his delicate brushwork, perfect compositional sense and controlled eroticism (Johnson).

MAX KUEHNE, "Artist and Craftsman," Hollis Taggart, 48 East 73rd Street, (212) 628-4000 (through July 13). A student of Robert Henri, Kuehne (1880-1968) was a competent painter, but his most distinctive contribution was his production of well-made richly decorative furniture, picture frames and wood carvings. Under influences ranging from Japanese to Art Nouveau, he incised outlines of flora and fauna into gessoed surfaces and added colored glazes and burnished metal leaf. The most engaging pieces here are a pair of smoothly carved, elegantly humorous silver giraffes (Johnson).

* "POP ART: THE JOHN AND KIMIKO POWERS COLLECTION," Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through June 30). With his Japanese-born wife, Kimiko, John Powers (1916-1999), a former president of the Prentice-Hall publishing company, gathered a big-bang collection of Pop Art by the movement's stars. The 26 objects shown here, including works by Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Claes Oldenburg, Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol and James Rosenquist, are mostly from the 1960's, and they bring a whole era back into vivid focus. Among the signature works are Warhol's serial extravaganza, "200 Soup Cans" (1962); Mr. Rauschenberg's "Broadcast" (1959), a combine painting with a working radio attached; and Mr. Oldenburg's soft "Drum Set" (1967), a bodylike sendup of a professional drummer's instruments in vinyl and canvas that droops on a platform in a metaphor for its own spent energy. Collectors' collectors, the Powerses made the pursuit into an art of their own (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

* VIJA CELMINS, McKee, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 688-5951 (through June 29). Ms. Celmins just keeps making the same old thing: paintings that are at once rigorously formal and expansively illusory, quietly transcendental and materially sumptuous. This spare, beautifully installed exhibition features eight easel-size paintings: six of starry night skies and two of blurrily luminous spider webs. In the print room, crisp wood engravings of rippling ocean surfaces look like 19th-century illustrations for "Moby-Dick" (Johnson).

RALSTON CRAWFORD, "Phantom Forms," Laurence Miller Gallery, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-3930 (through June 29). This hard-edge painter often used his camera to record subjects taken up in paintings, but more often his photographs stood on their own. This small show of a dozen or so is a sampling from thousands produced by the artist over the years. His focus in most of the pictures is the play between light and shadow (Glueck)

CONRAD MARCA-RELLI, "Canvas Collages," Washburn, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through June 29). Marca-Relli ran with the Abstract Expressionists in the 1950's, but while his collage-based work always had a bold, rough-hewn immediacy, he was driven more by interest in structure than gesture. His compact, puzzle-like compositions of canvas, paper, mattress ticking and other materials from the 1960's hark back to the glory days of Cubism (Johnson).

ANDREA MODICA/ VICTOR SCHRAGER, Edwynn Houk, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 750-7070 (through June 30). A series of close-up antique-looking photographs of 100-year-old human skulls, exhumed from a mass grave on the grounds of a Colorado mental hospital, is a radical departure for Ms. Modica but lacks the intense humanistic poetry of her justly celebrated "Treadwell" series. Mr. Schra ger's quasi-antique photographic still lifes of flowers and old books suggest an Emersonian wedding of nature and culture (Johnson).

JEFF WEISS, "The Big Boys Are Coming," Laurence Miller, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-3930 (through June 29). Mr. Weiss's large digitally processed, surrealistic photoworks combine appropriated images into crazily disjunctive, apocalyptic landscapes. In one, a woman decapitates a kayaker, while in the distance oil towers belch smoke and fire and a space shuttle takes off. Up close, the pictures have the bland sheen of magazine illustrations; one wonders what these boyish visions might look like if they had been made in some more individualized way (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

PHILIP AKKERMAN, Gorney Bravin & Lee, 534 West 26th Street, (212) 352-8372 (through June 30). Mr. Akkerman, a 40-year-old Dutch artist, has painted self-portraits, and only self-portraits, at the rate of one a day, since the mid-1980's. Within this Conceptual framework, he invokes the entire history of portraiture, displays a terrific color sense (especially where skin is concerned), makes good use of his extensive hat collection, and subjects his somber face to an impressive range of physical and formal distortions. (In the project gallery, unusually personal photographic works by Julie Bamber and Catherine Opie are exhibited, their common theme being the artists' fathers.) (Smith).

RICHMOND BURTON, Cheim & Read, 521 West 23rd Street, (212) 242-7727 (through June 30). Mr. Burton's new paintings speed up his calligraphic strokes and commas to good effect. His palette of silver and gold mixed with red, turquoise or purple also helps to create the impression of decorative and somewhat Middle Eastern imagery -- graceful Persian texts or Byzantine mosaics -- converted pure molecular energy (Smith).

"CLENCH, CLUTCH, FLINCH," Paul Rodgers, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 414-9810 (through June 30). Organized by the critic Dominique Nahas, this 13-artist show makes little sense thematically, but it offers a number of interesting things, including Julianne Swartz's peep-hole view of a bright interior with mirrored balls and fluttering tinsel; Monica Castillo's video of a woman painting on a man's genitalia; Melvin Way's small, diagrammatic, Outsider-like drawings; an inflated man by Tim Hawkinson; a big, wildly elaborate doodle by Diana Cooper; and a set of calligraphic drawings by Henri Michaux (Johnson).

* STEPHEN DEAN, Henry Urbach Architecture, 526 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 627-0974 (through June 29). One of the most impressive debuts of the season is that of Mr. Dean, a young French-American artist whose obsession with intense, saturated color has taken him to India, where color is intrinsic to daily life. The result is "Pulse," a painterly, almost unbelievably gorgeous video of the annual spring Holi festival, when residents douse one another with colored powders and water until the streets flow with color (Smith).

KEN LUM, Andrea Rosen, 525 West 24th Street, (212) 627-6000 (through June 30). Each of this Vancouver-based artist's new works simulates a cheap plastic store sign that includes moveable letters. The temporary letters for Hanoi Travel read: "Disneyland Packages/ Fun in the Sun/ We remember the People's War." This may signify the triumph of global capitalism over local politics, but on the whole this show does not do justice to Mr. Lum's gift for evocatively condensed story-telling (Johnson).

ANTONIO MURADO, "Icescapes," Lucas Schoormans, 508 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3159 (through June 30). The new paintings of this inventive abstractionist walk a fine line between beauty and decorative elegance. Using wide brushes and mostly shades of beige and gray, Mr. Murado streaks and scumbles broad latitudinal swathes, evoking Abstract Expressionist gesturalism and expansive arctic landscapes that hark back to the icy visions of Caspar David Friedrich. Dark yellow, crackled glazes of varnish add a look of old masterish antiquity (Johnson).

CHUCK NANNEY, Debs & Company, 525 West 26th Street, (212) 642-2070 (though June 30). "Everything I do was done by a feminist artist in the 1970's" is the stance taken by one of the drawings in this show, and it's not far wrong. But Mr. Nanney's crudely stitched together pouches, cardboard pedestals displaying crumpled balls of aluminum foil or bright little pom-poms, have plenty of riffs of their own. Most notable is an overreaching attraction to glamour, attained by the simplest of means. Excess is rarely so economically achieved (Smith).

* SHIRIN NESHAT, Barbara Gladstone Gallery, 515 West 24th Street, (212) 206-9300 (through June 29). Three videos isolate themes or devices that Ms. Neshat previously deployed in combination, to more impressive effect. The strongest video is "Possessed," which gains from its Philip Glass score and touches on the artist's main theme -- the plight of women in traditional Muslim societies. The near pitch-dark "Pulse" creates an aura of poetic ambiguity for the viewer to unravel, while "Passages" has groups of bare-headed men and chador-clad women, in separate groups, in a dramatic setting. United, these qualities succeed; divided, they are far less engaging (Smith).

ROBERT WATTS, "Photography Into Sculpture," Leslie Tonkonow, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-8450 (through June 30). In the late 1950's and 1960's, Watts (1923-88), a player in the Fluxus movement, worked to undo all the usual ways of conceiving art objects, artists and viewers. This show revisits a time when art could still be innocently revolutionary. "Three Clouds," consisting of three cubes, one all white, one with a photographic surface of human skin and the third photographically dissolved into clouds, is a witty dematerialization of Minimalism and, perhaps, an updated Christian Trinity (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* "BETWEEN STREET AND MIRROR: THE DRAWINGS OF JAMES ENSOR," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through July 21). The show's pleasure partly involves serendipity. This feels like the perfect moment for an oddball like Ensor, but maybe any time would feel like the right time for somebody whose work, whether it is appalling or fantastic (and it can be both simultaneously), looks eternally modern. The drawings are from the 1880's and 90's. Some started out as ordinary sketches of household objects to which faces and monsters were added, like Rorschachs of the artist's imagination. They somehow become more luminous and translucent the more densely they are drawn, an extraordinary paradox. On the other hand, when the drawings aren't dense, they can be vaporous like Turners, with an effect akin to looking back on a dream: you can't quite place what you are seeing. But the emotion the images provoke is stronger precisely because of the frustration attached to it. Ensor is one of those artists Americans tend to forget or never really knew properly. A hero in Europe, he is vastly deserving of reappraisal here, and this excellent exhibition is a place to start (Michael Kimmelman).

WILLIAM N. COPLEY, Nolan/Eckman Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 925-6190 (through June 29). A patron of artists and a painter himself, Copley (1919-1996) worked in a witty frou-frou style heavily influenced by decorative patterning a la Vuillard and Matisse. His life, he said, was "a quest for the ridiculous image," and he often found it, giving lighthearted treatment to brothels, prostitutes, priests and policemen. The wacky spirit in this work tickles rather than bites, and like these two indulgences, a little goes a long way (Glueck).

BRAD KAHLHAMER, "Almost American," Deitch Projects, 18 Wooster Street, (212) 343-7300 (through June 30). An American Indian reared by white, middle-class parents, Mr. Kahlhamer makes big paintings in which contradictory worlds converge or collide. Painting Abstract Expressionist-style, he generates spacious, Western frontiers and populates them with scrawled Indians in canoes, bison, flying eagles, stacked audio speakers and his own country-western song lyrics. The paintings are raw and baggy, but the spiritual enterprise as a whole is moving (Johnson).

Other Galleries

* "COTE D'AZUR: ART, MODERNITY AND THE MYTH OF THE FRENCH RIVIERA," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-4818 (through July 14). "A dream space created by artists for the 20th century" is how Kenneth E. Silver, author of the book that spawned this show, describes the French Riviera. And to prove the point, more than 70 works by 40 artists are on view, from Matisse and Picasso to the photographer Jacques-Henri Lartigue and the architect Le Corbusier and including more contemporary talents like Yves Klein and Eric Fischl. Rail access opened up the long-neglected southern coast to commerce and tourism in the 1860's, and the first artists, Renoir and Monet, arrived there in 1883 for a two-week tour. They evidently spread the word, for by the time of World War I the coast had became a mecca for artists whose palettes thrived on the dazzling quality of the light and the clear, fresh colors of the sky, water and vegetation. The Cote d'Azur's heyday is deftly covered, but one caveat: Why clutter this persuasive survey, which really celebrates the coast as a garden of European modernism, with recent and peripheral works by a group of American artists? (Glueck).

WILLIAM POPE.L / DANIEL J. MARTINEZ, the Project, 427 W. 126th Street, Harlem, (212) 662-8610 (through June 30). Solo shows by two outstanding mavericks. Mr. Pope.L's installations of liquor bottles and dolls, recycled Goodwill underwear and prose poems on race are about shifting concepts of inside vs. outside and the insistent invisibility of blackness. Mr. Martinez's self-portrait photographs take a shock-tactic approach to abjection. In one picture, he pulls his viscera out through a slit in his stomach; in another, he leans toward the camera to reveal suture marks circling his head. The pictures are collaborations between Mr. Martinez and the special-effects film makeup artists Bari Dreiband-Burman and Tom Burman (Cotter).

JENNA SPEVACK, "Sticks and Stones and Superstrings," Here Art, 145 Avenue of the America, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 647-0202 (through June 30). In a written statement, Ms. Spevack makes the dubious claim that her tiny drawings of imaginary stones, sticks and lengths of rope in precariously balanced arrangements illustrate advanced scientific theories. But her finely drawn, whimsical pictures have considerable faux-innocent, comic appeal (Johnson).

Last Chance

* "WILLIAM BLAKE," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). A touching and beautiful show if you have a taste for Blake's art, which strives for ecstatic revelation on the level of his famous visions and rises to the heights of his verse, sometimes. From the Age of Aquarius to New Age, he has come to serve as the patron saint of flower children, Jungians, Freudians, occultists, spiritualists, nudists, unpublished authors, animal lovers, socialists and teenagers of the sort who read Hermann Hesse. By turning our attention to his laborious illustrations and watercolors, the exhibition compels us to think about him as a serious and original visual artist, which is to say as a more idiosyncratic and substantial figure than the cliches suggest. He truly believed that the world was ending and that he had been sent to set things right at the last minute. Whatever else he may or may not have been, Blake was the most genuine and uncompromising artist you can think of. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

* "FREESTYLE," Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500 (through Sunday). Spring in New York brings new-talent museum surveys, and this spring, "Freestyle" is the one to catch. The museum's curator, Thelma Golden, working with Christine Y. Kim, has brought together 28 young or youngish black artists from across the country, some of whom are appearing here for the first time. The show is, for the most part, punchy to look at (painting dominates), full of ideas and, with the intriguingly complex notion of a "post-black art" in the air, completely of this American moment. Not to be missed is the spicy magazine-style catalog with essays by some of the best young art curators and critics around. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and 62+ (Cotter)

* EDUARDO SARABIA, I-20 Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 645-1100 (through tomorrow). Animated by walls painted with green vines, this impressive debut roams freely across several mediums, the artist's Mexican roots and the Los Angeles cityscape. The centerpiece is a festival-float cornucopia that has references to sex, violence and the materialistic American dream (Smith).

HEADLINE: Deadlock Over Budget Shows Change In Minnesota 

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, June 21 

 BODY:
Minnesota's reputation as a place that is always Scandinavian clean and orderly is in danger -- at least the part about things always being orderly.
 For the past month, the State Senate, the State House of Representatives and the state's aggressively irrepressible governor, Jesse Ventura, have been at loggerheads over what to include in the $27.3 billion budget for the next two fiscal years. 
 If no agreement is reached by midnight on June 30, the end of the fiscal year, all state-run operations, except those deemed essential, like police and health services, will probably close.
"We're pulling separately in three different directions rather than jointly in just one direction," said Governor Ventura, who summoned legislative leaders to his office this afternoon in an effort to break the impasse. He did not succeed, but aides said he would try again tomorrow. 
Nobody loves a good dust-up more than Mr. Ventura. But the current squabble, he warned on Wednesday, is "headed down the road to disaster if there isn't a solution in the next couple of days."
The issues include taxes, school spending and abortion policy.
Everybody agrees on the need for tax relief, especially the governor, who has made it a centerpiece of his tenure. But what kind?
The governor and the Republican-controlled House want to reduce taxes paid by businesses, while the Democratic-controlled Senate wants to give homeowners a break.
Democrats want to increase school spending. But Republicans want to hold the line, and Mr. Ventura says he could go for some cuts.
Democratic leaders and the governor favor financing family planning and oppose a 24-hour wait for abortions. Republicans oppose putting up state money for family planning and favor a waiting period.
Mr. Ventura is particularly adamant on the abortion issue. He says he will veto budget legislation that includes anti-abortion language.
He has also threatened to veto any temporary spending bill, except one that finances only essential services, if the Legislature, which is in special session, does not pass a budget bill by the deadline.
"Legislators have taken an oath to govern, and I intend to make them stick by that oath," Mr. Ventura said a few days ago.
Why this gridlock and turmoil in a state that natives sometimes refer to good-naturedly as "the land of the bland"? For one thing, Mr. Ventura and the entire Legislature are up for re-election next year. The governor has his agenda, as do members of the House and Senate, and agendas tend to play a bigger political role when an election is just around the corner.
Another factor is the economy.
When drawing up the state's budget two years ago, Senate, House and Ventura administration negotiators took the revenue surplus the state was enjoying because of the booming national economy and divided it three ways, giving the three sides something to spend without interference by the other two.
This year, the economy is weakening and there is not enough surplus to divide, the negotiators say.
But perhaps more than anything else, basic change in Minnesota and Minnesotans is affecting the budget talks. The state is less cohesive and increasingly less Scandinavian and Northern European and more Latino, Asian and African-American. 
Mr. Ventura calls himself an independent and centrist, but at heart he is a reformer and seeks -- unsuccessfully so far -- to shake up Minnesota government by imposing term limits on elected officials and merging the House and Senate into a unicameral Legislature that meets every other year rather than yearly.
"I'll make a deal with the Legislature," he says. "They go unicameral -- a unicameral Legislature wouldn't squabble as much -- and I promise not to run again. Otherwise . . ."
Rural, conservative Republicans dominate the House; urban and suburban liberal Democrats run the Senate.
"The division has been deeper and more pronounced in recent years, and it can make things difficult," said the House speaker, Steve Sviggum, who lives on a farm near Kenyon, south of St. Paul.
Craig Grau, a political scientist at the University of Minnesota in Duluth, argues that change in the state and a "tripartite" government need not add up to governmental gridlock.
"It doesn't have to be that way," he said. "But when you have three different parties -- independent, Democrat and Republican -- with three different agendas -- centrist, left and right -- and you throw in egos and a looming election year, well, what you get is gridlock."

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Are Ambivalent On Pataki's Casino Proposal 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 21 

 BODY:
Senate Republicans overcame division in their ranks over casino gambling late this evening and approved a Pataki administration plan to allow the Seneca Indians to build as many as three Las Vegas-style casinos in western New York complete with the state's first slot machines. 
 The Senate's blessing came just a day after Gov. George E. Pataki unveiled a deal to build casinos in Niagara Falls and Buffalo, and possibly a third elsewhere on Seneca land, and legalize slot machines on Indian casinos in New York; slot machines are now expressly prohibited by the State Constitution. Conservative Republicans who have long opposed casino gambling on ideological grounds softened their stance on this particular proposal, and many of those who expressed reservations earlier in the day closed ranks by sundown. 
 "I had a lot of concerns about it," said Dale M. Volker, a Republican, and the senior member of the western New York delegation, said tonight. "We looked at it, talked to various people about it, decided it was in the best interests of western New York to move ahead on it."
The measure passed 39 to 14. Several Democrats, including two who represent Buffalo and Niagara Falls, voted for it: Byron W. Brown and William T. Stachowski. "We need to keep our dollars in Niagara Falls, America," Mr. Brown said.
Members of the Democrat-controlled Assembly adjourned tonight without voting on the casino proposal; they plan to return Monday. The speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, has expressed cautious support for the plan, but with no more than a skeletal proposal from the administration, he balked at the prospect of handing the governor carte blanche authority to negotiate the details with the American Indian nation. "I have a million questions," he said tonight.
And so, on the official last day of the legislative session, the casino deal became a bargaining chip in the budget negotiations between the governor and the two men who control the Legislature. Mr. Pataki needs the Legislature's approval to go forward with the plan. 
The most contentious issue concerns slot machines. The Pataki administration wants to amend the state penal law to permit slot machines on Indian land across the state. Neither of the two Indian casinos in New York -- one operated by the Oneida Nation near Utica and the other by the St. Regis Mohawks in Hogansburg, near the Montreal border -- has slot machines now. Instead, they have video gambling machines that accept no cash, using a device like a debit card instead.
Today, Senator Frank Padavan, a Queens Republican and an opponent of gambling, harshly criticized the governor. "He's trying to get around this in the writing of this bill," he said. "To me, that is fraught with legal challenges which most certainly will come."
Today, a host of questions remained. Who will develop and operate the casinos? How many slot machines will be permitted? How much money will they generate? And how much of that will go into the coffers of Buffalo and Niagara Falls?
The agreement with the Seneca Nation also provides that the state will get 18 percent of the net proceeds -- that is, after the bettors have been paid but before expenses -- in the first four years of operation. That will rise to 25 percent by the eighth year of operation.
Conservatives and liberals alike have held up casino development as a salve to the economic woes of western New York. A casino, they say, would attract the scores of tourists who visit Niagara Falls every year and cross the border to play the slot machines in the two giant privately operated casinos in Canada.
Likewise, other conservatives and liberals have railed against gambling on moral grounds and assailed casino development as economic boosters.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
In the economic slump, Madison Avenue carries on. Deals, new campaigns and layoffs.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
AMID the pervasive gloom on Madison Avenue, the business of advertising goes on as large accounts change agencies, campaigns are approved and deals are made. But the economic slowdown is still having its effects as additional agencies lay off employees.
 In one of the largest consolidations ever of a media planning and buying account, Royal Philips Electronics named offices of Carat International, part of the Aegis Group, as its worldwide consumer media agency. Philips spends an estimated $600 million annually on advertising for products that include TV sets, electric shavers, picture tubes and lighting. 
 "This appointment brings global benefits for Philips," Mark Kerray, vice president and head of global brand management at Philips in Amsterdam, said in a statement, like "organizational efficiencies and better message management."
The decision came after a four-month review that had been narrowed to three finalists: Carat, which works for Philips in Europe; Initiative Media Worldwide, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies; and MediaVest, part of the Starcom MediaVest Worldwide unit of the Bcom3 Group, which works for Philips in Latin America and North America. Offices of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, owned by Bcom3, share the Philips consumer creative account.
"It's big, big news for us, a validation of our strategy to expand to the U.S. and Asia," David Verklin, chief executive at Carat North America in New York, said in a telephone interview, "because you've got to be a global player to serve global businesses."
The consolidation is "a precursor of the future for the top 40, 50 brands as they hire one or two media service providers to handle their accounts on a worldwide basis," he added, "so they can do global media deals."
Mr. Verklin's reference was to the large ad packages giant marketers are buying across various properties owned by media conglomerates like AOL Time Warner, the News Corporation and Viacom Inc. Such package deals are proving popular as advertisers make plans for the important fall and holiday shopping seasons.
Speaking of the fall, the FedEx Corporation has approved a campaign scheduled to begin then, proposed by its longtime agency, BBDO New York. The campaign will replace ads that BBDO New York introduced only months ago, which carried the theme "This is a job for FedEx."
The approval came after a presentation made by BBDO New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom, that was described by the trade publication Adweek as a "last-ditch" effort by the agency to save the account, with billings estimated at $85 million. Because FedEx executives have been unhappy with the agency's recent work, Adweek reported, if they had not liked the proposed fall campaign, they would have placed the account in review.
"We're looking very forward to moving forward on the campaign," said Carla Richards, a spokeswoman for FedEx in Memphis. She declined to discuss the Adweek report because, she said, she could not comment on internal business matters. BBDO New York, which has worked for FedEx since 1989, referred inquiries to FedEx.
Turning to the deals, two agencies are teaming up for a joint venture.
The Troy, Mich., office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, part of Bcom3, and Martin Advertising in Birmingham, Ala., are forming an agency that will handle the advertising accounts for local dealer associations for two General Motors divisions, Cadillac and Pontiac. Terms were not disclosed.
The joint venture, named the D'Arcy Martin Group, will bring together D'Arcy, the creative agency for the two divisions, with Martin, which has experience creating campaigns for dealer associations and individual dealerships. D'Arcy Martin opens with 50 employees at full-service offices in Troy and Birmingham and at account service offices that are in current D'Arcy offices in five markets: Atlanta, Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles and New York. Media buying will be handled by the New York and Troy offices of LCI, owned by Interpublic. Billings have not been determined.
The joint venture is motivated by a recent policy change at General Motors, which eliminated local dealer associations in 1999 in favor of a more centralized approach but is now reinstating the associations in different form. D'Arcy Martin will be led by executives including David Martin, president, who also continues as president at Martin; D. Stan Fields III, chief operating officer at the D'Arcy Troy office; and Patrick Sherwood, president at D'Arcy North America.
Finally, as for the layoffs, they are being made at three agencies.
Euro RSCG McConnaughy Tatham in Chicago, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, is dismissing 12 employees, or about 5 percent of its staff of 250.
Doug Dome, a spokesman for the agency, confirmed a report of the layoffs in the online edition of the trade publication Advertising Age. He attributed the dismissals primarily to "a general slowdown in spending" by clients as well as the recent loss of the Midas account.
Mullen/LHC in Winston-Salem, N.C., part of the Lowe Group unit of Interpublic, is dismissing about 30 people, or 20 percent of its staff of 150.
Mary Churchill, a spokeswoman for Mullen/LHC, attributed the layoffs to the economic slowdown and the recent loss of two accounts, the Hanes unit of Sara Lee and Thomasville furniture.
And Digitas, an interactive agency in Boston, is laying off 130 employees, leaving 1,600; in April, 65 employees were let go. The latest layoffs come a week after Digitas reduced revenue and income estimates for the second quarter below what management had expected.

HEADLINE: Public Interests; 
You've Got Mail

BYLINE:  By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
Only about a month left until we get our $300 rebate checks from the federal government. Everybody's a winner! I just want to say right here and now that I don't intend to quit my job, although I do hope to buy my parents a new house and perhaps travel.
 The Internal Revenue Service, out of concern that taxpayers might get confused and send the money back, is mailing an explanatory letter in advance. "We are pleased to inform you," it begins, "that the United States Congress passed -- and President George W. Bush signed into law -- the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Act of 2001, which provides long-term tax relief for all Americans who pay income taxes." 
 The plug for President Bush is driving Democrats crazy. Senator Charles Schumer of New York called it "political editorializing" and worried that it would undermine the public's faith in the integrity of the I.R.S. Senator Max Baucus of Montana demanded to know if the 30 million Americans who aren't getting checks would be receiving a letter explaining that President Bush signed into law a tax relief bill that cuts them out.
We have been down this road before, so many times in fact that we could drive it in our sleep. Chief executives at the state and local level have been doing this sort of thing for a couple of decades now. In 1998, when Virginia sent taxpayers a rebate for part of the tax they pay on their cars, Gov. Jim Gilmore enclosed a letter, which his staff said was necessary because someone had to "explain what the checks were for." Critics wondered whether public education absolutely required repeated references to "my historic tax relief plan." 
This is all part of a greater pattern of political marketing that gives you public service ads featuring governors climbing mountains in the name of tourism, and mayors explaining the finer points of recycling. We're lucky that the law limits federal officials' opportunities to follow suit. Otherwise we'd be seeing Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill reminding us to turn in our pennies, and John Ashcroft telling everyone to cross at the corner or else.
The administration of New York's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, offers a number of useful examples of how a chief executive can become a multimedia celebrity on the back of tax cuts and public service announcements. (Actually, there are very few things in life that haven't been covered by the Giuliani era. If you're concerned about whether ferrets make good pets or wondering if it might be interesting to know more about your own mayor's sex life, we have a precedent for you.)
Four years ago, when he was running for re-election, Mr. Giuliani recorded public service ads reminding New Yorkers that they were about to get improved mass transportation services. ("Free transfers. Free ferries. One city, one fare. I'm Rudy Giuliani.") The mayor credited himself with helping commuters to make a smooth transition to the new system, although it's hard to know how ferry riders could have screwed up their new responsibility to not pay any fare. 
Connecticut residents got a tax rebate check in 1999, along with a letter from the governor, John Rowland. "The rebates made it income, which made the money taxable," said Bill Curry, a former state comptroller. "They would have given them more money by just adjusting the tax code, but they wanted the letter so badly they were willing to cut the feds in for a quarter of the deal." Mr. Curry is thinking about seeking the Democratic nomination to run against Mr. Rowland. Another possible candidate, the Senate majority leader, George Jepsen, is currently starring in a privately funded public service ad urging citizens to observe safety in the use of sparklers during fireworks season.
Years ago, New York street sweeper trucks would blare a recording of Mayor Ed Koch warning that cars would be towed if they got in the way, and that was pretty traumatic for all concerned. But generally, this lust for public education runs only in the direction of good news. "I would have no problem with the I.R.S.'s inclusion of Bush's name if it were included on all mailings," wrote Erik Enquist in his newsletter, The Facts. Mr. Enquist wants to see a note informing homeowners that "The I.R.S. and President George W. Bush hereby notify you that a lien has been placed on your home."
