HEADLINE: Townies 

BYLINE:  By A. O. Scott; A. O. Scott is a film critic at The Times.

 BODY:
 EMPIRE FALLS
By Richard Russo.
483 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $25.95.
 IF Richard Russo had wanted an epigraph for his new novel, he might have chosen a few lines from Lou Reed's album "Berlin": "Men of good fortune / often cause empires to fall / While men of poor beginning / often can't do anything at all." Granted, "Empire Falls" is too tangled and populous to be summed up in an aphorism, but it is nonetheless grounded in the New England bedrock of class-bound fatalism.
The man of good fortune, his unhappy courtship and thwarted ambitions chronicled in a prologue, his grim end in an epilogue, is C. B. Whiting, prodigal son of the family whose shirt factory dominates the central Maine mill town that gives the novel its name. While C. B.'s abdication -- he prefers poetry to business and Mexico to Maine -- may not be the direct cause of the town's decline (corporate mergers and the globalization of the labor market would have happened anyway), his mysterious ruin casts its shadow over the lives of his less privileged fellow citizens.
One of these is Miles Roby, the son of an itinerant house painter and a factory clerk, whose tragic flaw is that he has never been prodigal enough. Miles is a nice guy, but his decency is sometimes hard to distinguish from passivity, and it has left him, at 42, stranded in a town he once longed to escape. He can't say no to C. B.'s widow (who rules Empire Falls like the Yankee transplantation of a Tennessee Williams matriarch), can't save his ex-wife from another unhappy marriage, can't rein in his cantankerous father, can't protect the 16-year-old daughter he adores -- can't, in short, do anything at all. He's Russo's hero.
And Russo is mine. Fans of his previous novels -- "Mohawk," "The Risk Pool," "Nobody's Fool" and "Straight Man" -- will be gratified to find the familiar elements in place: a dying Northern industrial town (though in New England this time, rather than upstate New York); a bumptious cast of sharp-tongued women, sarcastic old-timers and characters vain, dumb or venal enough to serve as the butt of everyone else's jokes; a tone of affable, chop-busting comedy darkened by minor chords of heartbreak and frustration.
But the not entirely tongue-in-cheek portentousness of the title suggests that something bigger is at stake, that the carefully observed scenes of provincial life will add up to something panoramic and important and that Russo may at last have joined his fellow Northerners Russell Banks, Frederick Busch and Joyce Carol Oates in trying to rescue the proud, battered regional realist tradition from cuteness, eccentricity and sentimental condescension. The presentation of "Empire Falls" -- its bulk, its title, its solemn cover painting of a red-brick factory against a gray-and-yellow sky -- promises not only local color but sublimity.
The promise is made only half in earnest and only half kept, which is good news. Russo is brave enough to conceive a large ambition, but too smart to overreach. The publisher's blurb announces a saga "shot through with the mysteries of generations and the shattering visitations of the nation at large," but such unwieldy grandiosity (to say nothing of gaseous prose) is mercifully absent from Russo's repertory. Instead, you intuit the scale of the story and its wider implications through the eyes and voices of individuals preoccupied with fairly mundane visitations -- like the comings and goings of Miles's father, Max, a jocular ne'er-do-well with little regard for anyone else's feelings and even less for his own hygiene. "He becomes a public nuisance every now and then when he tires of being a private one," Miles's mother, Grace, once explained.
Miles's own private sufferings -- his still-raw grief over Grace's death, his anger at the circumstances that robbed him of his chance to finish college and leave Empire Falls behind -- occasionally illuminate the transformation of the town's (and the nation's) public life. Miles, whose mother wanted him to go to college out of state "so you won't be able to come home whenever you want to," returned in his senior year to take care of her in her final illness and ended up managing the Empire Grill instead of becoming a college professor. Miles, who has served a few terms on the school board and volunteers to paint his parish church, is both a solid citizen and a representative man. Like most of his neighbors, he has stayed put out of a mixture of loyalty, hard luck and self-defeating stubbornness:
"They stayed, many of them, because staying was easier and less scary than leaving, and because for a while at least they'd be able to draw unemployment benefits. Others remained out of pride. When the realization dawned that they were the victims of corporate greed and global economic forces, they said, O.K., sure, fine, they'd been fools but they would not, by God, be run out of the town their grandparents and parents had grown up in and called home. The fortunate ones were older, their modest houses nearly paid off; close to retirement, they would limp to the finish line, then help their less fortunate sons and daughters as best they could."
In such circumstances, to ask for more amounts nearly to hubris, and the unforgiving moral universe of Empire Falls seems engineered to frustrate even the most tentative pursuits of happiness. Janine, Miles's ex-wife, just wants a little sexual fulfillment after nearly two decades of passionless matrimony, but the price she pays for the occasional orgasm is marriage to a narcissistic cheapskate named Walt Comeau and the alienation of her daughter's affection. Grace, whose blissful dalliance on Martha's Vineyard with an enigmatic sugar daddy named Charlie Mayne dominates Miles's childhood memories, was punished with a middle age of humiliation and servitude. Miles, too adept at compromise for his own good, has learned to make do with a yearly sojourn on the Vineyard as he nurses the hope that his daughter, Tick, will have the kind of future he was cruelly (and partly by his own choice) denied.
Russo knows his characters too well to allow them the luxury of victimhood or to indulge in the grim determinism of some of his peers. His humane sympathy for weakness and self-deception -- a sympathy extended even to the manipulative Mrs. Whiting and her minion, a dimwitted policeman named Jimmy Minty -- does not rule out stern satiric judgment. The people of Empire Falls are not held down simply by fate or by their own bad choices but by the active collaboration of their neighbors and loved ones: the cruel priest who helps break Grace Roby's spirit, the myopic art teacher who tries to break Tick's, and the teenage football star (Jimmy Minty's son Zack) who mocks and torments a lonely misfit named John Voss. One of the old-fashioned pleasures of "Empire Falls" comes from the delicious expectation that the villains will receive their comeuppance and that the good guys will find at least a morsel of the satisfaction they so desperately (and often half-consciously) crave.
Russo's command of his story is unerring, but his manner is so unassuming that his mastery is easy to miss. He satisfies every expectation without lapsing into predictability, and the last section of the book explodes with surprises that also seem, in retrospect, like inevitabilities. As the pace quickens and the disparate threads of the narrative draw tighter, you find yourself torn between the desire to rush ahead and the impulse to slow down.
Empire Falls, situated at a fictitious and unlovely bend of the Knox River, is the kind of place tourists from Boston or New York speed through en route to the mini-Martha's Vineyards of the Maine coast, perhaps stopping for lunch at a place like the Empire Grill and eavesdropping on the taciturn, wisecracking regulars. By the end of this novel, you'll know the town's geography like a native, and its tattered landmarks -- the Empire Grill, the old Whiting shirt factory, the architectural folly C. B. Whiting built across the river -- will be as vivid and as charged with metaphor as Salem's house of seven gables or the mansions of East Egg. You will also have had the good fortune to tour this unremarkable geography in the company of an amiable, witty raconteur who knows all the gossip and the local history as well as some pretty good jokes. Only after you've bought him a beer, shaken his hand and said goodbye will it occur to you that he's also one of the best novelists around.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 39

LENGTH: 3573 words

HEADLINE: Harvard's Hoard 

BYLINE:  By Johanna Berkman; Johanna Berkman, a former Goldman Sachs analyst, has written for Lingua Franca, New York and Worth.

 BODY:
Next Sunday, Lawrence Summers becomes the 27th president of Harvard. But the distance from the Treasury Department to this particular ivory tower is not as great as it once might have been. Summers will have less money to play with than he did in his last job, as treasury secretary, but the endowment of the institution he inherits has climbed in recent months to as much as $19 billion -- a sum greater than the physical assets of McDonald's, the G.D.P. of Ecuador, the net worth of all but 5 of the Forbes 400 or, according to The Boston Globe, the endowment of every nonprofit institution in the world after the Roman Catholic Church. As the head of Harvard, there will be no escaping the burdens of high finance. 
 Or low. Summers's appointment in April was barely a month old before Massachusetts Hall, which houses his new office, was taken over by dozens of students protesting Harvard's failure to provide a "living wage" of $10.25 to all its employees. Over the next 26 days, tents popped up in Harvard Yard, as students, professors and workers slept outside in sympathy. Robert Reich, the former labor secretary, dropped by to show support. Senator Edward Kennedy tried to enter the building to meet with the students, but the police wouldn't allow it. Newspapers across the country ran editorials taking Harvard to task for refusing to spend even the smallest fraction of its endowment to improve the lives of its workers. Drawings of Summers as Marie Antoinette began to go up around Harvard Yard. 
 If the issues of the protest are small for such a rich and enormous institution -- about 400 employees and several hundred contract workers are affected by the university's position, which it has pledged to reconsider -- they call attention to a growing chorus of critics who believe that Harvard is at least squandering an opportunity to rethink its culture, or even its mission, in light of that one stunning number: $19 billion. (The next largest endowment, Yale's, is $10 billion.)
"It's absurd," says Reich, who has taught at Harvard. "There's no reason to raise a giant endowment merely for the sake of having a giant endowment." Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economics professor, is a bit more philosophical: "We all have the sense that this is a remarkable amount of money. The question is, To what purpose will it be put?"
Harvard surely wouldn't lack for recommendations if it wanted them. Frank Newman, the director of the higher education policy program at the Pew Charitable Trusts and the former president of the University of Rhode Island, notes that universities receive favorable tax treatment because society expects them to be "above and beyond corporate citizenship, to take the steps that help make society better." He suggests that Harvard spend more money to mentor minority students or to study such national issues as the health-care system. Sachs says that Harvard should "increase the knowledge capacity" in the developing world; Reich talks about Harvard "replicating itself" both globally and nationally. Todd Plants, who graduated from the college two weeks ago and was the chairman of the Student Affairs Committee last year, argues for more financial aid. (And you can see his point: tuition, room and board for the last four years cost $126,486, which more than a third of this year's 1,602 graduates paid in full.)
But Harvard has been reluctant to think creatively about its increased wealth. Last fall, for example, at a meeting of the Harvard Management Company board, which oversees the investment of the university's endowment, one member posed an intriguing question: Do we want to be fully endowed? At the time, Harvard's endowment was paying out enough income to cover 27 percent of the university's $2 billion operating budget. Would it be worthwhile to try to cover the whole thing? To make the school free to all 18,000 students? To liberate its 2,000 professors from grant writing to concentrate on teaching and research? The question was a nonstarter, says Elizabeth Huidekoper, Harvard's vice president for finance. The conversation "didn't quite go that far."
In January, Princeton (endowment: $8.4 billion) promised to abolish student loans. In April, Cornell (endowment: $3.4 billion) said it would open a medical school campus in the tiny Persian Gulf nation of Qatar. But the three largest nonannual expenditures of the outgoing president Neil Rudenstine's tenure capture Harvard's conservative approach when it comes to innovative spending: the purchase of 29 developed acres up the Charles River in Watertown for $168 million; the purchase of 48 developed acres across the river in Allston for $150 million; and the costs of formally merging with nearby Radcliffe for another $150 million. Ask about satellite campuses or online education, and you'll hear that such steps are too expensive. Ask about covering students' tuition, and you'll learn that paying for your schooling is a virtue. ("There's something good about hunger," one dean says. "It is important for our students to be co-investors in their own education.") Ask whether the recent $120 million operating surplus is a sign that Harvard could think of some new ways to spend its money, and you'll be told that that amount, left over after subtracting operating expenses from the sum total of endowment payouts, tuition, research grants and other income, is not all that significant. ("It's in the noise," Rudenstine says.) Rudenstine dismisses calls for a change in Harvard's spending strategies as the usual campus grumbling or the agitation of uninformed outsiders.
It is true that the situation looks more complicated from the inside. Perhaps because its purpose is to preserve generational equity in perpetuity, the Harvard endowment is often talked about as if it were a single, monolithic entity. In fact, it comprises 9,600 funds donated over the last three centuries. (Harvard's buildings, which the university carries at a depreciated value of $1.7 billion on its balance sheet, as well as its vast art collections and landholdings, are not included.) At most universities, the president controls the endowment. At Harvard, the endowment funds belong to whichever of the 10 schools they were donated. The result, a system known internally as "Every tub on its own bottom," has produced wide disparities in wealth. The richest by far is the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, the university's undergraduate and graduate core; its endowment is $8 billion, greater than that of every other university but Yale, Texas, Stanford and Princeton. Next in size are Harvard's medical ($2.1 billion) and business ($1.3 billion) schools. Two of the poorest are education ($290 million) and design ($250 million).
Despite its decentralized budget pool, Harvard is an incredible fund-raising machine. When the university's governing body, the Harvard Corporation, hired Rudenstine in 1991, it wanted a conciliator who could bring together the independent deans to collaborate on the first university-wide campaign since the 1940's. An unexpected bonus, says Ronald Daniel, Harvard's treasurer, was that the quiet, self-effacing former Princeton provost became a magnet for big donors. Under Rudenstine's watch, Harvard conducted a six-year, $2.1 billion fund-raising campaign -- and exceeded its goal by $500 million. More than 68 percent of this $2.6 billion came from gifts of $1 million or more; there were 498 of these. And while only two gifts were $50 million or more, 90 donors gave gifts of $5 million or more. That Harvard is already so rich, and so much richer than every other school, seems only to enhance rather than to hinder its ability to attract large gifts. "I like to back a good organization," says Thomas H. Lee, the centimillionaire leveraged-buyout fund manager, explaining why he gave such a wealthy school $22 million. "Excellence is expensive."
Harvard cultivates this crowd through an invitation-only organization called the Committee on University Resources, which was founded at the end of the 1960's to encourage those who have been generous to Harvard to give even more. A few years ago, for example, a university official told a COUR member, Albert J. Weatherhead 3rd, the owner of Weatherhead Industries in Cleveland, "You're Harvard's third largest living donor, and you won't rest until you are No. 1." Weatherhead, who has given a total of nearly $50 million to the school, says, "I just love that quote." When Rudenstine took office, there were 200 COUR members; today there are 400.
Typically, COUR's annual spring gathering, which takes place over two days in Cambridge, has a theme. During the last campaign, these included globalization and ethics. This year's event, however, was "really unusual," says William Boardman, Harvard's associate vice president for capital giving. "We didn't have a lot of fund-raising to talk about." Rather than something academic, he chose a theme more central to the lives of committee members, and perhaps the school as well: wealth management.
From his 16th-floor perch inside the Boston Federal Reserve office tower, Jack Meyer, Harvard Management Company's president and C.E.O., oversees a staff of 185 and the investment of the university's billions. Were it not for the sign on the door, you would have no idea that H.M.C. is a university-owned nonprofit rather than an independent, highly sophisticated money-management firm. There is the water view, the beautiful wood paneling and the very for-profit salaries. Last year, H.M.C.'s top five performing portfolio managers earned bonuses totaling more than $50 million. The single biggest payout went to the foreign-equity manager. He got $17 million, more than 48 times as much as Rudenstine's compensation of $352,650.
Once, these bonuses made Meyer, a friendly man who speaks with the fast clip common among those who wield power on Wall Street, a scourge in the Harvard community. "In the early 90's, I received a lot of correspondence that was somewhat less than friendly," he says. Today, after the long bull market, even Jeremy Knowles, the arts and sciences dean, has made peace with Harvard's rewarding those who produce wealth much more generously than those who produce knowledge: "I ask myself, How much would they have made at Goldman Sachs?" (Knowles's salary, like that of every dean but that of the medical school, is less than $300,000. The average salary of a full professor at Harvard is $135,200.) 
Harvard began its metamorphosis into a hedge fund in the mid-70's, when, after a pair of Ford Foundation monographs encouraged universities to invest more aggressively, it set up its own shop. Since Meyer took over in 1990, H.M.C. has employed an aggressive but diversified arbitrage strategy to make a fortune for the university's endowment -- $4.3 billion last year alone, a sum roughly equal to Columbia University's entire endowment. H.M.C. has also spread its investment tentacles into 68 private equity and venture-capital firms and seeds new investment funds too. The first -- there are now four, all run by former employees -- was seeded in 1998, when H.M.C.'s top-performing hedge-fund manager, Jonathon Jacobson, quit to start his own firm shortly after receiving a $10 million bonus. The deal: Meyer gave Jacobson $500 million to manage in exchange for reduced fees. Another dividend: as a free agent at Highfields Capital Management, Jacobson can invest Harvard's money in controversial holdings -- he has invested in casino stocks, for example -- while reducing the risk of a major P.R. blow-up. (H.M.C.'s only in-house prohibition is tobacco investments.) Last year, according to the university's tax returns, H.M.C. paid Highfields $29 million for investment-management services.
Another factor helping the growth of the endowment has been Harvard's conservative payout policy. While the endowment's returns have surpassed the internal target of 6 to 6.5 percent above inflation for the last nine years, the corporation has paid out only 4.2 percent of its endowment on average to the deans for spending, less than the typical university target of 4.5 to 5 percent. The strategy has netted the university additional billions. 
'Harvard's money became a puzzle to me," says the psychologist Carol Gilligan, who will resign from her post as a professor at the School of Education next spring and teach full time at New York University. "Where are the resources of the university going?" she asks. Over at the far wealthier law school (endowment: $930 million), Prof. Alan Dershowitz expresses a similar befuddlement over why he has had such a difficult time getting funds for the public-interest-law program. "Harvard's goal is to die with the most amount of money," he says. "It should not be the goal."
Rudenstine counters with a lament: "Everyone thinks of the $19.1 billion as one pot of money. It's thousands of pots of money that are restricted accounts."
In fact, 87 percent of the Harvard endowment is "restricted" to either a particular school or specific purposes at that school. Still, Harvard's claim that its hands are tied when it comes to spending remains open to question. First, Harvard, rather than wealthy donors, at times creates those restrictions. Take the Weatherhead Center for International Affairs. The Weatherheads had already given Harvard four professorships and wanted to have a global impact; they would have considered an unrestricted gift (so long as it was "mind engaging"). Second, there has been as much as $920 million sitting unrestricted in the university's $3 billion general operating account. Much of that sum was generated in an unusual fashion -- by taking funds the deans set aside for near-term use, investing that money into the endowment and paying the deans a money-market rate of return while keeping the difference for the central administration. "If you want to say it was risky, I can certainly agree with you," Rudenstine says, but "in the end, proof happens in the pudding."
But what is the point? Why run the machinery this way? Lani Guinier, a professor at Harvard Law, thinks she understands Harvard's values. "Money has become the exclusive denominator," she says. "It defines everything: prestige, excellence, competence, commitment to the public good." Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College, sets Harvard in a broader social context. "We've reduced our definition of worth into fame and wealth, and it carries over into the way institutions think about themselves," he says. "An overwhelmingly huge part of what Harvard is about is managing its money. The absurd theory is, Harvard is safe if there's an atomic bomb that destroys all of America -- Harvard will continue. Learning and studying are very simple things, and the values they require are the love of learning and intellectual curiosity. Are they fostered by wealth? I don't think so. Smugness is fostered by wealth."
Even those from institutions that have profited in the same ways Harvard has, if less spectacularly, question Harvard's choices. James Freedman, the president of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, tells me that as a former president of Dartmouth College (endowment: $2.5 billion), he "can't throw stones at others." But within a matter of minutes, he is arguing for a radical revision of Harvard's endowment policies: "You really wonder why Harvard, out of its $19 billion, couldn't take $1 billion and say, 'This is the capital that will fund our scholarships."' John Hennessey, the president of Stanford University (endowment: $8.7 billion), which recently received the largest gift ever made to higher education -- a $400 million matching grant from the Hewlett Foundation -- says it's time for Harvard to re-examine its financial priorities. The issue of whether the endowment is big enough or if its size warrants fundamental changes to the school's mission is one that the next president of Harvard "will have to face," he says.
When I relay some of these comments and suggestions to Rudenstine, he characterizes his first three years at Harvard as a "nightmare" because of the early-90's recession and deficits at the school. "So my first question when anybody says something about what any university should be doing is, Tell me how much you know about running a university." When I reply that some of these critics do (or have) run colleges and universities, he asks: "But do they know anything about Harvard? Harvard is different."
Harvard is indeed different. as Howard Gardner, a professor at the Graduate School of Education, notes: "Harvard is older than the United States, and I think there's a reason for that. It's been very well managed." That management denies Harvard's president the authority to spend the university's money as he sees fit. But Summers will have power all the same. There is, for starters, the unrestricted money in the general operating account; that $920 million alone is more than the entire endowment of Boston University ($913 million) or Georgetown ($745 million). As the fund-raiser in chief, too, Harvard's president can steer donors toward particular projects. 
While there's no indication that Summers plans to shift Harvard's strategy, there are those who believe he has precisely the kind of credentials to effect change if he wants to. In terms of brilliance and force of personality, Summers -- who at 28 was the youngest professor to receive tenure at Harvard in its modern history -- is as well equipped as anyone. And it stands to reason that the Harvard officials who chose him had more in mind than hiring a financial campaign guru. "If you were focused on money and fund-raising, that was probably not where Larry's competitive advantage lay," says his mentor and predecessor at Treasury, Robert Rubin. "He's much more caught up in the question of Harvard's mission."
Not that it would be easy. Should Summers seek to generate greater societal and intellectual returns on his school's money, he would need to persuade the corporation, which sets the endowment payouts, to be more generous. He would probably run into resistance. A remark from Harvard's treasurer, Ronald Daniel, suggests why: "Harvard is still a long way from having 'more than what it needs,"' he says. Even where there is no doubt about the school's financial security, ingrained caution toward spending is a brake. (Harvard was, of course, founded by Puritans.) When faculty members think about the endowment, they tend to share Harvard's conservative spending values. "What the $19 billion ought to allow us to do is be very thoughtful about how we go about making decisions," Gardner says. But mostly it is not a concern. As Henry Louis Gates Jr., who runs Harvard's Afro-American studies department, describes the endowment: "It's like the air we breathe. We take it for granted. It's around you all the time, so you don't think about it."
And were Summers to act, he would first have to contend with the great intramural disparities. The deans of the rich schools are likely to favor the capitalist status quo -- Every tub on its own bottom does make a larger number of people both responsible and accountable," says Knowles, the arts and sciences dean -- while it's hard to imagine the poorer deans entirely ignoring the untapped coffers around them. At the School of Public Health, which lacks a core of wealthy alumni supporters, Barry Bloom, its dean, describes his tub's financial set-up as "a pretty hazardous situation," because 59 percent of his professors' salaries are paid for with grant-sponsored funds. He says it "would be reasonable" if Harvard paid at least half.
Many are skeptical that the money race is over. As Harvey Cox, a Harvard Divinity School professor who has been teaching there since 1965, says: "The idea that the big capital fund-raising drive came to an end when Neil Rudenstine announced whatever colossal amount of money it was, is simply not true. The next day, we were, of course, raising money again." Sachs, the economics professor, acknowledges feeling like a "relentless fund-raising machine," but he expects change soon: "Harvard now has the happy circumstance of being able to move in a new direction." Arthur Levine, the president of Teachers College at Columbia University, likens Summers to Charles Eliot, Harvard's president from 1869 to 1909, who transformed the school into a modern national institution: "The task before him is to take a Harvard that has been the leader in industrial America and make it into the foremost university in an information age, and he has the resources to do it."
So far, this generation's Eliot has spent much of his time on airplanes, traveling around to meet Harvard's biggest donors, which is, depending on how you look at it, either an inauspicious harbinger for his presidency or simply a matter of Realpolitik. Or maybe nobody's business but the school's and that of its citizens and donors. When we spoke this spring, Summers said it was "very premature to be making vision statements." Fair enough. Still, it's hard to lie low when you have $19 billion, especially when it derives in part from favorable tax policies. For now, at least, he describes fund-raising as just a means to an intellectual end. "If the time were ever to come when we were consuming large amounts of resources and not making a commensurate contribution to teaching and knowledge," he says, "that would be a very serious problem, indeed."

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 1415 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Extensive Acreage Is Conserved at Luxury Projects

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
WITH buildable acreages dwindling to a trickle in elite communities from Greenwich to Litchfield, builders are pouncing on leftover parcels from former farms and estates, foreclosed properties and properties in locations out of the fashionable neighborhoods.
 Seemingly immune to a softening market, custom-home builders and large developers alike are using these pockets of land to create elegant, expensive and very private new mini-neighborhoods. 
 While only a few homes are built on such parcels, towns are exacting a price that was initiated decades ago for sprawling subdivisions of hundreds of homes on immense tracts of land. Typically, a minimum of 15 percent of the property must be dedicated in perpetuity to the municipality or a private conservation organization. But depending on environmental concerns, site access and other conditions as much as 70 percent of a single lot can be consigned to conservation. 
In Greenwich's back country, 16.3 acres out of 34.7 acres, or 47 percent of the property, has been set aside in a conservation easement at Old Round Hill Road Estates on Old Mill Road. Homeowners are permitted to walk the area, but nothing will ever be built there, trees cannot be cut down nor can any activity take place that disturbs the natural landscape.
The property was acquired 17 months ago as an approved subdivision from a local family trust. To date, the new owners, a joint venture of the Fieber Group L.L.C. and Alex Kaali-Nagy of New Canaan, are constructing three of an eventual seven custom-designed homes of 10,000 to 14,500 square feet on two to three acres each. Two of them are under contract. Prices start at almost $7.3 million, including a pool and tennis court. 
"Buyers are coming from within Greenwich and from New York," said Shelley Tretter, the development's sales agent from Sotheby's Greenwich office. "They are different from buyers of the 80's -- they are cautious. They want a sound investment, traditional architecture, extraordinary detail, high quality and timeless appeal." 
These are the last palatially sized houses to be built in Greenwich on two- and three-acre lots. Had the subdivision been approved after 1998, the developers would have been subject to new regulations intended to halt the proliferation of McMansions. Only 7,841 square feet would be allowed on two acres and 8,167 square feet on three acres. Moreover, no pool houses, guest houses or other structures would be permitted.
On Deming Road at the northern border of Litchfield, an open house was held this month for a 5,200-square-foot model home on 14.7 acres at Litchfield Hollow. It is priced at $825,000, reduced from $865,000. The property was acquired in foreclosure four years ago by the developer, Richard E. Mute, head of American Building Systems Inc. of Bristol. Two years were spent in obtaining approvals from town boards and another 18 months in construction. 
FIVE additional lots are available within the total 52.2 acres. Prices will be governed by the houses, all of which will be built by Mr. Mute. Buyers may bring in their own designs, subject to his approval. They must be in a similar country colonial style.
Prices in both communities, at the high end of their markets, seem to fly in the face of a climate in which job losses and lapsed mortgage payments are increasing. "We have a shortage of inventory in Litchfield," said David Luzi, whose local brokerage handles Litchfield Hollow, "and we are still getting multiple offers."
Edward Deak, professor of economics at Fairfield University, said: "There is enough income and wealth in greater New York and lower Fairfield -- and even among the landed gentry and weekenders in Litchfield -- to absorb million dollar properties. Athletes, old and new Wall Streeters with enormous incomes but possibly short earning capacities appreciate the tax advantages and the eminent salability of the real estate."
Subdivisions like these, he added, where the builder has taken the opportunity to provide a very private neighborhood of homes that complement each other on the same economic level, sited so that the children can play together, "enhances their value," he said. "It makes all of them worth that much more." 
Two lots of 4 acres and 4.7 acres at Litchfield Hollow are exempt, but a conservation easement applies to the model house and remaining three lots of 6 to 14 acres. Twenty-three acres will be conserved by consigning 25, 50, 50 and 70 percent of those lots to conservation, depending on the topography of the lots, with the model house at the maximum. The house sits on about four landscaped acres of the 14.7-acre lot. Beyond the back lawn the easement begins in a forest where nothing may be built, stored or dumped, trees may not be cut down and the property may not be subdivided. 
With the exception of one house at Old Round Hill Estates in Greenwich that fronts on Round Hill Road, driveways in both developments are off one private road ending in a cul-de-sac. In Greenwich the road will be paved in Belgian block, which looks like refined cobblestone, with granite curbings. In Litchfield it is unpaved rustic gravel-over-dirt with no curbings.
Imposing stone walls and a gate will mark the entry into the Greenwich development and each individual driveway will be gated; in Litchfield there are low stone walls but no gates. Within each development's overarching style -- English Georgian in Greenwich; New England colonial in Litchfield -- every home will be distinctive. 
At the Litchfield Hollow location, houses may be set back as little as 50 feet from the road and 45 feet from the side lot lines. If they were built in more populated areas, like the in-town historic district, 121-foot and 199-foot setbacks for front and side yards would be required and the number of lots would have been reduced. 
Originally, Mr. Mute applied for 14 lots, but wound up with only six after the town's Planning and Zoning and Inland Wetlands Commissions cut back on his usable land. To provide access to the property, he was required to build a road and a small bridge with wooden railings over the narrow Bantam River. His request to build a box culvert through which the river could run at a fraction of the cost of a bridge, was denied by the town as too urban and a threat to fish and wildlife. 
The 10-room model house has a massive see-through stone fireplace open to the living room and cathedral-ceilinged library; four additional fireplaces; crown moldings; cherry, oak and marble floors; custom kitchen and bathroom cabinetry; a 21- by 24-foot widow's walk accessible through a hatch; three-car garage; playroom; family room; wrap-around bluestone terraces; stainless steel gas barbecue and sink on the back terrace; a hot air heating and humidifying system; unfinished cast concrete wine cellar; and extensive landscaping. 
The developers at Old Round Hill Estates in Greenwich offer stone, brick and clapboard exteriors; pillared front entries; custom architectural detail; paneled libraries; a home theater; home office; two playrooms; up to seven bedrooms and 10 full and half-baths; four- or five-car garages; separate formal and family dining rooms; mud rooms; custom kitchen cabinetry; and mature plantings.
AT least two more subdivisions are on the market in Litchfield, where lots are for sale without houses. High Mark on Chestnut Hill Road has three out of five lots of 2.5 to 13 acres available at $120,000 to $225,000. The remaining two are under contract. 
Falcon's Flight on Butternut Road, which opened two years ago, is larger -- 17 lots on a former farm. "We sold some lots to builders and others to individuals who are building their own homes," said Allan Temkin, an associate of the developer, Falcon's Flight Farms L.L.C. Two lots of five acres each are available at $179,000 per lot. Both have stone wall entrances and split rail fencing. 
Bruce Wernert, owner of a 3.3-acre parcel on Valley Road in Greenwich, has renovated the property's 2,500-square-foot Normandy-style house for sale at $1.3 million and a three-quarter-acre lot is under contract for $475,000. The buyer will build his own house.
Mr. Wernert is donating the remaining two lots to the Greenwich Land Trust. "It makes sense to do this," he said. "You get a tax deduction for a charitable donation at full appraisal value, and you don't have to deal with issues about whether or where you can build. A lot of people are doing it. If you don't need the land, no one wants to pay taxes on it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Luzi, left, broker, and Richard E. Mute, developer, on widow's walk of Litchfield Hollow model home. (Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 1240 words

HEADLINE: FILM; 
In Taiwan, an Anti-Modern Poet Of Modern Anomie

BYLINE:  By LESLIE CAMHI; Leslie Camhi writes from New York about film, art and books.

DATELINE: CANNES, France 

 BODY:
DAYS before the start of the new millennium, as an endless rain falls over a high-rise Taipei neighborhood, a woman's wallpaper is peeling and her walls are inundated. A plumber looking for leaks leaves a hole in the floor of the apartment above her, where a man lives alone. For him, the hole is an object of idle curiosity and a place to spill bodily excretions; for her it's a possible source of contagion. The radio has broadcast warnings of a strange virus causing people to crawl like bugs and seek refuge in dark, humid corners. He drinks, she cleans; each dines alone on instant noodles and tries to stave off the growing sense of panic and isolation. Sometimes, the woman dreams of escape: elaborately coiffed and dressed in gorgeous plumes and sequins, she croons show tunes from a 1960's Hong Kong musical, infusing them with manic joie de vivre. 
 "When making a film, I never think of the plot first, but rather I think in terms of concept or revelation," said Tsai Ming-liang, the director of "The Hole" (1996), speaking Mandarin through an interpreter at a beachside restaurant here last month. His latest work, "What Time Is It There?" had just had its premiere at the Cannes International Film Festival. "If you can't get into my films metaphorically," he added, "you'll miss them altogether." In "The Hole," the orifice shared by two disconnected people in a ruined world becomes an umbilical cord uniting them, and, finally, their last hope for communication. 
 The tenderly absurdist and deeply humanist vision of this 43-year-old director is the focus of a retrospective beginning Friday at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, which will include all but the last of his five features. Following the series, his 1996 film, "The River," opens commercially on July 27. Though few New Yorkers know Taipei well, many will recognize the universe Mr. Tsai's characters inhabit: an urban environment in constant mutation, whose lawless growth and rapid abandonment mirrors the characters' internal disarray and desolation.
His Taipei is a city with no points of reference, where prosperity vies with environmental degradation and people come together and disconnect in a seemingly random fashion. There are no landmarks, only neon-lit overpasses, unmarked highway crossings and fast-food restaurants serving green drinks in underground shopping malls. Homes, whether luxurious or spartan, are merely provisional shelters, thrown up haphazardly. Water pools around clogged drains or runs down from leaky ceilings, overflowing and uncontainable. And, in a prefabricated apartment, a father, mother and son cross paths without speaking, as if they were boarders rather than family.
This poet of urban anomie grew up in rural Malaysia, one of seven children born to Chinese immigrant farmers. "I lived mostly with my grandparents, who were noodle sellers," he recalled. "Their only hobby was watching movies. Every night they'd take me."
Malaysia's cinemas were filled with commercial Hong Kong fare. But after moving to Taiwan in 1977, and while studying drama at the Chinese Cultural University in Taipei, Mr. Tsai encountered the works of European auteurs from the 60's and 70's like Michelangelo Antonioni, Rainer Werner Fassbinder and Francois Truffaut. "The revelation was that I could be real in my creativity," he said. "That plots didn't have to be linear, and that style, form and content could be close to life."
Lee Kang-sheng, the star of all Mr. Tsai's films (like a Taiwanese James Dean, but more reserved and quizzical), was discovered by Mr. Tsai while working in a shop. Lu Yi-ching (formerly known as Lu Hsaio-ling), who frequently plays Mr. Lee's mother, owns the Taipei cafe where Mr. Tsai wrote scripts for his early television melodramas. As the father, Miao Tien, a veteran actor in martial arts dramas, completes the shifting Oedipal triangle that recurs in Mr. Tsai's work and that captures (like Truffaut's Antoine Doinel, played by Jean-Pierre Leaud in four films) a decade of lives on screen.
"He's created his own cosmos," said Kent Jones, associate director of programming at the Film Society of Lincoln Center. "His is a hair-raisingly coherent oeuvre."
Taiwanese directors who emerged in the 1980's, like Hou Hsaio-hsien and Edward Yang, were fueled by the need to question the military-controlled, emigre Nationalist government's official version of history. Mr. Tsai's preoccupations are more contemporary and personal, including Taipei's restless youth and gay subcultures, troubled father-son relationships and the effects of unbridled capitalism on private life and public spaces.
In his first film, "Rebels of the Neon God" (1992), Mr. Lee plays a bored student who flirts with delinquency, as his taxi driver father looks on impassively and his skinny, agitated mother consults spiritualists about her son's increasing distraction. The three share an apartment but inhabit separate spheres.
"Living in Taiwan encourages a certain isolation," said Chen Shiang-chyi, who appears in "What Time Is It There?" and "The River." "The island itself is so small and isolated."
"Vive l'Amour" (1994) is set in one of Taipei's many vacant luxury condominiums, remnants of an economic boom that quickly faded. Mr. Lee plays a lonely door-to-door salesman of niches in a crematorium, who secretly squats in the apartment. Yang Ku-mei (star of "The Hole") is a real estate agent showing the unit. At night, she sometimes has sex there with an itinerant street vendor whom she picked up in a shopping mall. Between her huge, unsaleable properties and the tiny, final resting places offered by Mr. Lee's character, the city seems to provide no space for a living existence.
The pick-up scene is filmed in one exquisite, silent, long take, where the two strangers communicate desire through subtle but unmistakable signals. A similar scene occurs in "The River" (1996), which resurrects the family from "Rebels of the Neon God," though this time it's the father who takes the bait of a young gay hustler, while his wife carries on a listless affair with a man who sells pornographic videos. One day their son accompanies an acquaintance to a film set, where the director asks him to stand in for a floating dummy that appears too fake. He takes a dip in the polluted river and awakens the next morning with neck pain that gradually increases until his entire body is wracked with it.
An exacting, physical sense of comedy accompanies the horror of these skewed relations. Yet the film's most striking image is a poignant one. When the son's twisted neck causes him to fall off his motorbike, the father sits behind him, holding his head, like a ghost or the guiding hand of tradition, allowing him to steer straight in a world awry.
"What Time Is It There?" which shared the technical prize at Cannes for its art direction and cinematography, is Mr. Tsai's most explicit homage to the golden age of art house cinema, incorporating clips from Truffaut's classic "The 400 Blows" into a story split between Taipei and Paris, and a meditation on the time zones we inhabit when we travel, look at films or mourn someone.
"A lot of people associate me with the 60's, and with the kinds of films that were made then," Mr. Tsai admitted with a laugh. "In fact, I'm totally anti-modern. I feel like I was born in the wrong era. But a lot of other people feel the same way. So I guess that's why I still have a few admirers."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Lu Hsiao-ling and Lee Kang-sheng as a mother and son in the 1977 film "The River," directed by Tsai Ming-liang, far left. (Film Society of Lincoln Center); (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
A Team With More Smoke Than Fire

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
AN opportunity has arisen to examine the obstacles that have prevented architecture from re-establishing itself in New York as a medium of civil discourse. The occasion appeared two weeks ago with the announcement of the winners of a competition to design a nine-acre property, the so-called Con Ed site, on an East River stretch of Midtown Manhattan.
 The competition, organized earlier this year, raised public expectations that New York was finally poised to embrace architecture, as many other cities have, as a means of reckoning with the challenges of a changing world. The outcome -- the choice of two long-established New York firms to create a master plan for the site -- fell far short of those expectations. 
 It is possible, even imperative, to retrieve something of value from this disappointment. It's too big a deal to pass by. Not just because the site is important, but because the competition has affirmed the disbelief that serious architecture is a viable option for New York. And it did so at a time when that disbelief was beginning to dissolve. 
The competition epitomizes what is sometimes called the marginalization of architecture -- the reduction of this art form to the superficial decoration of plans already determined by political and economic factors. Beyond that, the competition embodies a value structure that has distorted the meaning of architecture in New York for more than a generation.
It will take more than one article to trace the elements of that value structure and the links among them. Virtually all of them, however, were present in the Con Ed competition. The developers hope to have their master plan completed sometime this fall. I have my own master plan for the months ahead. I do not expect to affect the outcome of the competition, much less to liquidate the status quo. My plan is more manageable. I want to try out some techniques for describing projects like this on the level of ideas.
The Con Ed site consists of four parcels south of the United Nations, between 35th and 41st Streets, stretching from First Avenue to the East River. The property, purchased from Consolidated Edison for $680 million, includes a century-old steam generating plant, which the developers plan to demolish. They envision a mixed-use project, largely dominated by tall residential buildings, along with office and retail space, parks and other public areas. The developers are FBS East River Associates, a partnership between Fisher Brothers and Sheldon H. Solow.
The competition was led by Bill Lacy, president of the State University of New York at Purchase and director of the Pritzker Architecture Prize.
The five competing teams ranged aesthetically from the commercial firm HOK, based in St. Louis, to the New York architect Peter Eisenman. Three of the competing architects were Pritzker Prize winners: Richard Meier, Christian de Portzamparc and Rem Koolhaas. Hugh Hardy, a stalwart civic leader and the world's leading restoration architect, was part of the team that included Eisenman and Meier. Toyo Ito, from Japan, the landscape architect Julie Bargmann, of Virginia, and the Cambridge firm Machado & Silvetti also brightened the roster. Jorge Machado is a member of the Pritzker Prize jury.
This was intended to be a competition of ideas, rather than fully worked-out designs. The developers, who served as the competition's jurors, reserved the right to accept or reject any of the ideas proposed, or to start over from scratch. The teams signed agreements to this effect and were awarded $100,000 each to develop their proposals.
On June 9, the results of the competition were announced. None of the teams had been chosen as originally composed. Instead, a new team would be formed, led by members of two of the competing groups: Henry Cobb, of Pei Cobb Freed, and Marilyn Jordan Taylor, of Skidmore Owings & Merrill. Machado & Silvetti was listed as a consultant, along with the Olin Partnership, Philadelphia-based landscape designers. The news release announcing the outcome was headlined in part, "Global Search Yields Dream Team."
Oh dear, oh dear. What had happened to the architects? To Koolhaas, Ito, Eisenman, Meier, Portzamparc and Bargmann? To those Pritzker Prize luminaries? Those blazing talents? Those figures who had given this event whatever luster it could claim? Is it possible that the winning team could be called a "Dream Team" precisely because none of them were on it? Because architecture is in truth a developer's worst nightmare?
What can one say, at this point, about the principal firms in the winning team? In terms of vision, both firms have been coasting for some years. Pei Cobb Freed still basks in the aura of its founding partner, I. M. Pei, one of the world's greatest living architects. James Ingo Freed designed one of the most important buildings of the past decade, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington. Henry Cobb's contribution to American architecture is largely confined to the 1970's, when he developed a cool, minimalist formal vocabulary for projects like Boston's Hancock Tower.
Skidmore Owings & Merrill has always seen itself as a purveyor of top-value design services for corporate America. In the 1950's and 60's, with a series of landmark buildings by Gordon Bunshaft, the firm provided these services with distinction. More recently, under the direction of David Childs, the firm has specialized in a denatured Art Deco style with vague pretensions to classical gravitas.
Both firms now specialize in what, to paraphrase Virginia Woolf, one might call the architecture of $19.99. Now, $19.99 is not a large sum, but neither is it a small sum: "It is a moderate sum, a mediocre sum. No vulgar riot of ideas tumble expensively in these architects' heads; equally, cheapness is abhorrent to them, and vulgarity anathema. One can imagine better: one can imagine worse." Per square inch of floor area, mullion, granite veneer, or however glass and cast stone buildings are sold, the price invariably works out to $19.99.
In a recent conversation, Childs expressed the hope that commissions for individual buildings might be awarded to younger New York architects of talent. He mentioned a few names. They were indeed talented. But I wasn't cheered by this prospect. What cities need now is greater understanding of the complex relationships between architecture and planning. The Con Ed project is an ideal opportunity to address that need. It will not be addressed by a plan that reduces our most talented architects to sitting on the bench. 
I regard the Con Ed competition as an act of aggression. Against architecture, certainly, but also against the terms of civil discourse. Against the idea that the qualitative values of architecture and the quantitative values of real estate represent two different realities. Against the clarity and intellectual integrity required to keep these realities distinct. 
The competition has drawn a line in the sand. On one side is the culture of ideas, an environment where serious architecture can occur. On the other side is a culture of expediency, where words have no meaning, and architecture is nothing more than a word. The competition would be less disturbing had the developers described it as a search for "people we feel comfortable doing business with." But by introducing the concept of "ideas" they made themselves accountable for producing some.
Here's the most agonizing aspect of this episode. In the public mind, architecture is no longer marginalized. This represents a remarkable shift. In the late 1980's, the apogee of the prematurely named post-Modern movement, architecture was scarcely worth getting out of bed for. Who wanted to see yet one more cheap remake of some great Art Deco skyscraper? In recent years, architecture has surged back to the center of the cultural arena. Thanks to work by Eisenman, Meier, Gehry, Koolhaas, Libeskind, Mayne, Nouvel, Diller and Scofidio and many others, public interest in this art form has never been more intense.
One assumes that the developers are aware of this. Even if they staged the competition only to gain government concessions by demonstrating their interest in quality design, at least they must know that quality design is valued highly enough to merit such concessions. (One assumes that similar reasoning led them to break news of the competition through a cultural rather than a real estate reporter.) If the developers have nothing substantial to contribute to the cultural life of the city, why don't they stand aside and let architecture take its course?
William Morrish, former head of the Design Center for American Urban Landscape at the University of Minnesota, has long spoken of the need to go "further upstream" in describing architectural objects. It is not enough, Morrish insists, to confine our attention to the description and appraisal of the models and drawings that are typically presented to journalists like canapes on a tray. We have to trace the genealogy of these objects to their sources, in politics, sociology, commerce, psychology, technology and other fields of information.
I do not like reducing architecture to a mere expression of social and economic forces. I prefer to report on work that reckons creatively with the conditions of modern life. In the case of the Con Ed competition, no such response has materialized, so this in itself becomes a cause for interpretation. The Dream Team is only the latest manifestation of an ensconced value structure that has made New York an architectural void. Ready or not, that structure is now being beckoned for its close-up.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Carving a Pop Niche in Japan's Classical Tradition

BYLINE:  By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
TAKASHI MURAKAMI is a hot item on the international circuit. He's here; he's there; he's everywhere, surrounded by a flying wedge of assistants, turning out immaculately polished Pop-style product, from cartoonlike paintings to dolls and T-shirts. Psychedelic, cute, sexy, creepy, his work is part of how "new" is spelled in art at the moment.
 But Mr. Murakami is no infant phenomenon. He's 38. He's hip to history. He knows a lot about recent American art; the examples of Andy Warhol and Jeff Koons have shaped his career. He wrote a doctoral dissertation on the conservative, modern, Western-inflected Japanese painting style known as nihonga, which he has also practiced. 
 And in the group show "Superflat," which he organized in Tokyo last year (it recently appeared at the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art), he shrewdly mixed his own work with that of some of his contemporaries and inserted their collective neo-Pop style into the classical lineage of Japanese art. 
He proposed that as a group their style exemplifies a distinctive Japanese aesthetic, one that collapses distinctions between high and low and formally favors line over volume, surface over depth, ornament over realism. This art of flatness, he argued, follows a direct line from centuries-old scrolls and screens to his own media-saturated work.
This month at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, which has the most comprehensive collection of Japanese art outside of Japan itself, he is exploring this idea in a broad historical context. The museum is presenting a solo show of his work, on view through Sept. 3, pointedly titled "Made in Japan," and incorporating within it paintings by the 18th-century artist Soga Shohaku, whom Mr. Murakami regards as a neo-Pop pioneer.
Simultaneously, the presence of another show at the museum, "Japan at the Dawn of the Modern Age: Meiji Prints From the Jean S. and Frederic A. Sharf Collection," suggests a link between Mr. Murakami's art and narrative woodblock prints from the reign of the emperor Meiji (1868-1912) when Japan sailed into the modern age, and Japanese and Western culture intermeshed.
That fusion was replayed in Mr. Murakami's life. Born in Tokyo at the start of the postwar economic boom, he grew up with American rock music, films and advertising -- his father worked at a United States naval base -- as well with a Japanese pop culture centered on the printed cartoons called manga and the animations that derived from them, called anime.
In the 1980's, he enrolled at Tokyo University of Arts and Music, where he studied nihonga, a style invented or identified in part by the American scholar and collector Ernest Fenollosa (1853-1908), who was the first curator of Japanese art at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.
Nihonga still has some cachet in Japan; the imperial family has always been partial to it. But Mr. Murakami left it behind in the 1990's when, after seeing a show of Jeff Koons's erotic sculptures in New York, he turned his attention to manga and anime.
Both are ubiquitous in Japan; they've inspired a lucrative commercial industry and a fetishistically devoted following. They range in subject from religion and sports to science fiction and erotica. Their stylistic formula includes clearly outlined forms, toothsome colors and blankly smiling images of prepubescent innocence, sometimes laced with undercurrents of sex and violence.
At their most inventive, they're like Disney on amphetamines: addictively pleasurable and weirdly, unpredictably perverse. The combination has proved irresistible to a subculture of young males known as otaku or geeks, Trekkie-style cultists who inhabit a hermetic manga-anime universe. At the same time, the generic cartoon sensibility has saturated mainstream advertising. It's part of everyday Japanese life, and has a global reach.
Cartoon culture is certainly the main ingredient in Mr. Murakami's work. But it is the subtle emphasis on classical influences that gives the Boston show, organized by Cheryl Brutvan, the museum's curator of contemporary art, its interest.
Once you start looking, the mix is everywhere. The painting titled "Cosmos" imitates the format of a Rinpa-school floral screen. But it is done in five panels rather than the standard four; its surface is covered in silver acrylic paint rather than applied gold leaf, and its flowers have grinning Happy Faces.
Two large paintings, one titled "Milk," the other "Cream," appear to be abstract: in each, a thick, faceted, liquid-looking line arcs across a monochrome ground. The lines suggest calligraphy and spattered fluid. (Mr. Murakami gives them explicit sexual meanings elsewhere.) They are actually adapted from the image of a cosmic eruption in 1979 animation by the manga artist Yoshinori Kanada. And he lifted his own version from a print by Katsushika Hokusai (1761-1849), the artist who coined the term manga in the first place.
Much of the rest of the work in the show is figurative and focuses on the infantile, mouselike creature named Mr. Dob, who has become Mr. Murakami's logo, and by a population of mushrooms covered with wide-open, triple-lashed eyes. They all meet the manga cuteness quotient, then turn strange. The mushrooms suggest phalluses, bad trips and atom-bomb clouds. Mr. Dob morphs into a piranhalike creature with razor-sharp teeth and staring eyes. (New York commuters will be familiar with Mr. Dob from the sampling of Mr. Murakami's work temporarily installed at Grand Central Terminal this spring; he had a one-person show at the Marianne Boesky Gallery in Chelsea at the same time.) 
If this blend of the fanciful, the sexual and the macabre virtually defines the otaku sensibility, it is also characteristic of the work of a group of unorthodox painters -- among them Katsushika Hokusai, Ito Jakuchu, Kano Sansetsu and Soga Shohaku -- who lived during the Edo period (1615-1868).
Shohaku (1730-1781) was one of the outstanding oddballs of his day. He claimed to be a descendant of the great 15th-century painter Soga Jasoku, though he was not. A technical virtuoso, he produced devastating, Mad magazine parodies of subjects religious and secular. He was prolific, and Boston has 50 paintings by him, thanks to the acquisitive zeal of Fenollosa, a major Shohaku fan.
Two pairs of scrolls, both on Chinese themes, have been included in Mr. Murakami's show. In one, titled "The Taoist Immortals Li Tieguai and Liu Haichan," two grotesque figures, hilarious and repellent, are composed of twisting linear patterns. The immortals were thought to have discovered the secret of longevity, but it doesn't make a pretty picture: Li Tieguai appears to be senile, and Liu Haichan's flesh seems to be melting from his bones.
In the other pair of scrolls, "Dragon and Tiger," the figures are similarly stylized, with the dragon's form dissolving into a single, arching sweep of brushed ink as abstract and propulsive as Mr. Kanada's explosions. In both sets of scrolls, elevated themes and low-comedy effects merge in the synthetic brilliance that was an Edo innovation and that Mr. Murakami sees as an otaku sensibility in the bud.
More Edo work is on display in the museum's Asian galleries, where Mr. Murakami's show was installed for the first two weeks of its run. And another, more recent link in a neo-Pop lineage might be detected in the exhibition of ukiyo-e woodblock prints from the Meiji era (1868-1911), organized by Anne Nishimura Morse, curator of Japanese art, and running through July 15.
Influenced by European news illustrations, one group of prints shows Japan as a vision of mock-Tudor buildings and women in bustles, with planes of color and perspectival vistas in woozy collision. Even more surreal are the "documentary" scenes of the Sino-Japanese and Russo-Japanese wars. Steam-powered battleships sink under Hokusai waves; dead bodies are rendered with photographic precision; searchlight beams pierce the night as if emanating from spaceships. It all has the high-key drama and graphic audacity of manga at its best.
The fact that Boston's Japanese collection was being formed at precisely the time these prints were made adds a further dimension to an art-historical picture brought right into the present by Mr. Murakami's solo show. (He will be seen in a very different context at the Brooklyn Museum of Art this summer in the exhibition titled "My Reality: Contemporary Art and the Culture of Japanese Animation," which puts Japanese and American artists together.)
Whether Mr. Murakami's art sustains interest when considered beside his historical models in Boston is, of course, a question, but surely not one to be answered quite yet. He is, after all, still producing surprises and very much on the move. More important is seeing that he has these models, and that he has clearly paid close attention to them. Suddenly, flatness gains interesting depths.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 8, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on June 24 about two shows of Japanese art at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston misidentified the curator of one of the shows, "Japan at the Dawn of the Modern Age: Meiji Prints From the Jean S. and Frederic A. Sharf Collection." She is Louise Virgin, not Anne Nishimura Morse.

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
Too Few American Maestros? Try Making Them

BYLINE:  By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
AWADAGIN PRATT is to perform here on Saturday evening on the Millennium Stage at the Kennedy Center. There would be little news in this statement if Mr. Pratt were playing piano, for he is widely known on that instrument, in concert and on records. Even the actual news, that he will be conducting the National Symphony Orchestra in Beethoven's Eighth Symphony, is less than earthshaking, for many instrumentalists are taking up the baton these days in varying states of preparedness and with varying success. In fact, Mr. Pratt, who is also a trained violinist and who won a Young Maestro Award in connection with his conducting studies at the Peabody Institute in Baltimore in 1995, has already conducted several orchestras.
 What makes this occasion noteworthy is that he and three other fledgling maestros, though far from world-class, will be taking the podium in a fine state of preparedness, as the climax of the National Conducting Institute. The institute, in its second season under the sponsorship of the Kennedy Center and the orchestra, and the directorship of Leonard Slatkin, the orchestra's music director, is that rare program that offers more than its name might promise. At a time when many on the American musical scene are lamenting the relative paucity of rising American music directors at major orchestras, the institute is geared to help train young Americans to assume just such posts. 
 Conducting, in the strictest sense -- the sheer technique of conveying meter, tempo and expression -- may be the least of it. Not that there is nothing to be learned on that count. "I found his instruction tremendously helpful to gain independence in my left hand," Mr. Pratt said of Mr. Slatkin.
But the hard lessons come elsewhere. On this subject, Robert Spano -- who, as the music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic and, come September, the Atlanta Symphony, proves the exception to that lack of young American maestros -- likes to quote his teacher Max Rudolf, the author of the textbook "The Grammar of Conducting."
"The best way to learn conducting is by doing it," Rudolf is supposed to have said. "The second-best is by observing. The third-best is having a teacher."
The National Conducting Institute, in three isolated weeks each year, offers opportunities for all of the above, and more. It addresses the broader aspects of conducting: everyday practicalities, rehearsal techniques and psychological factors. Although these lessons, too, will require actual podium time to sink in, Mr. Slatkin, with vast experience of his own, can at least point to a few head starts and shortcuts.
But the most unusual feature of this program is a week spent basically without Mr. Slatkin, presented in partnership with the Orchestra Leadership Academy of the American Symphony Orchestra League. The participants are immersed in management, meeting intensively with orchestra administrators and league representatives. As one exercise, each participant submits a plan for an entire season of programs, which is then scrutinized from a real-world perspective. How expensive will it be, and what simple, harmless economies might be possible? How will it play at the box office? Does any particular combination of works place unreasonable demands on players?
"It does a wonderful job of preparing you to deal with a large orchestra," Kenneth Allen Woods, the music director of the Oregon East Symphony and the Grande Ronde Symphony, also in Oregon, said of that first week, in April. "But I was also overflowing with ideas of what to take back to a small orchestra, of ways of working with unusual resources." In particular, he began to explore possibilities for joint efforts with a nearby Indian reservation in a serious treatment of folk music. Mr. Woods will conduct Strauss's "Till Eulenspiegel" on Saturday.
The institute, "designed to assist talented conductors of academic, community or part-time orchestras make the transition to conducting and leading major, full-time, professional orchestras," in the words of a brochure, is a brainchild of Mr. Slatkin's.
"When I was just starting out, even with all the musical background I had, I didn't know what to say to an orchestra, what to do," Mr. Slatkin said. His parents -- Felix Slatkin, a violinist and conductor, and Eleanor Aller, a cellist -- were both members of the acclaimed Hollywood String Quartet, and their home was a constant center of musical activity.
Mr. Slatkin was speaking in a rare free moment during the second week of the institute last month. The four participants and six auditors dogged his every step. They watched him rehearse the orchestra for the conclusion of a three-week British Festival, a hectic final weekend of 18 works. Then they met with him and with several members of the orchestra in mentoring sessions to discuss the pieces to be performed this week and more general matters.
Mr. Slatkin has accumulated a quarter-century of wisdom since his days as a speechless neophyte. "If you feel uncomfortable talking to the players, talk to the personnel manager," he said now, dispensing random advice at a couple of working lunches. "Everything has to run through the personnel manager, the one person who operates between management and the orchestra."
He veered in a new direction: "Whenever possible, try to get to where you're conducting the night before. This is for your own well-being and contractual safety. In fact, the New York Philharmonic now has it in my contract."
Transportation delays, he went on to explain, had caused him to miss the opening piece on a program in two consecutive appearances with the Philharmonic. In one case, grounded in Washington, he took a bus to Philadelphia and, after further complications, a taxi to New York. "Unfortunately," he added, "I can tell you that a cab from Philadelphia to New York costs $275."
He raised other musical and practical issues in scattershot fashion:
*"The art of collaborating in concertos is the most important thing a conductor has to do, because you have to learn to listen."
*"With a reduced orchestra, I do at least one rehearsal with one extra player on a part, in case anyone gets sick."
*"The more you can show in a read-through with body language, the more respect you'll get."
*"I don't know any soloist who ever thinks the orchestra is quiet enough."
THEN it was on to the assigned works. Martin Hackleman, the principal horn player, discussed the opening horn solos in "Till Eulenspiegel," allowing the maestro to eat.
"It's nice not to get pointed at," Mr. Hackleman said, arguing for a certain freedom of interpretation. "But I don't want the conductor to ignore me, either." He used the evocative term "vulnerable player" for a soloist in such an exposed circumstance.
Another player, Alice Weinreb, a flutist, was crucial throughout the discussion of Ravel's "Daphnis et Chloe" Suite No. 2. But Mr. Slatkin set the tone. "I would start the piece without a stick," he said. "It sends the wrong message. You convey sound with gesture, and here the gesture dictates the whole mood of the piece."
The Ravel, it turns out, will be conducted on Saturday by Eugene Castillo, though no one (except, perhaps, Mr. Slatkin) knew that at the time. Mr. Castillo is the music director of the Camellia Symphony Orchestra in Sacramento and a former staff conductor of the San Francisco Ballet.
"There is nothing quite like this program for someone like me," Mr. Castillo said. "Nobody tells you how to talk to the press, the community, the orchestra. Here it's an information overload."
Comparable institutes are the venerable conducting program at the Tanglewood Music Center in Massachusetts, now directed by Mr. Spano, and the American Academy of Conducting at the Aspen Music Festival in Colorado, also in its second year, directed by David Zinman, who was long the music director of the Baltimore Symphony. Although both extend over longer terms, neither offers a comparable exposure to the overall workings of an orchestra or the opportunity to conduct a professional orchestra. At Tanglewood, the participants work not with the resident Boston Symphony but with the Music Center Orchestra, made up of students. At Aspen, an orchestra of 55 is constituted for the purpose, including the 24 participants themselves.
"There is nothing like this, working with an orchestra of this caliber," said Paul Haas, who will conduct Copland's "Salon Mexico" on Saturday. Mr. Haas is the pops conductor of the Corpus Christi Symphony and an assistant conductor of the Haddonfield Symphony in New Jersey and the National Repertory Orchestra.
On this point, all the participants this year agree. "The most important aspect of the institute is the performance experience," Mr. Woods said. "You're not just being thrown to the wolves or given a junk assignment, the two things that typically happen to young conductors. Here the players have made an investment in preparing us, and they'll try to make it work."
An opportunity to conduct the orchestra is extended even to the auditors, also young conductors who, like the participants, pay tuition. Throughout, they play a more active role in the institute than their title might imply. They take part in discussions. They do not get to rehearse and perform publicly, but they conduct a reading of a movement: this year, from Dvorak's Seventh Symphony or Brahms's First. Even this is a valuable experience, a chance to test Mr. Slatkin's maxim that "you should be able to show almost everything you're trying to get through gestures."
Mr. Pratt, the pianist, was an auditor last year. And in response to a question about the progress of women through the program, Mr. Slatkin suggested that one of the current auditors could well return next year as the first female participant.
As for the participants last year, one of them, Jason Weinberger, who recently earned his master's degree from the Peabody Institute, served as a cover conductor for the National Symphony a number of times last season, including that week of the British Festival.
"The scope of the program here is totally unique, showing how a music director works and what he does," Mr. Weinberger said. "That may be even more valuable than doing the performance. I learned more here than I learned in graduate school."
Robert C. Jones, the orchestra's president, hopes that Mr. Weinberger is not the only loyal alumnus. "We have to continue to maintain the people we've developed," he said. "We encourage them to think of the orchestra as an alma mater."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leonard Slatkin, left, the director of the National Conducting Institute in Washington, in discussion with Awadagin Pratt, a noted pianist and one of the participants. (Susana Raab for The New York Times)
