HEADLINE: In St. Louis, Office Buildings Are Becoming Lofts 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT SHAROFF 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS 

 BODY:
THE renovation of a dozen or so former office buildings into residential lofts here is raising hopes that Washington Avenue, formerly the home of the city's premier footwear and apparel manufacturing companies, will provide St. Louis with something it has lacked for most of its history -- a strong downtown residential base.
 "Downtown St. Louis has always been pretty successful as a central business district," said Craig Heller, managing partner of Loftworks, a local developer with a number of properties in the area. "It wasn't until 10 to 15 years ago that the garment district buildings started to empty out and prices dropped to the point where residential was feasible." 
 "We have a long way to go," said Zachary Boyers, vice president of Firstar Bank's Community Development Corporation, which has invested about $97 million in downtown residential projects in the last three years. "But I don't think St. Louis is any different than other major cities that have undergone revitalization in recent years. If we create a great neighborhood with great housing, people will want to live there." 
Despite several new office towers, downtown St. Louis has largely missed out on the wave of new development that has transformed the skylines of many cities in the last decade. The overall office vacancy rate for downtown is 15 percent, with most of that space concentrated in the kind of older buildings now being renovated. Also, apparel and footwear have largely ceased to play a major role in the city's economy.
As recently as two years ago, office buildings along Washington Avenue could be acquired for $2 per square foot and sometimes for considerably less. (The deal of the decade happened in 1993 when Robert Cassilly, the founder of City Museum, a new children's museum in the former International Shoe Company headquarters at 1509 Washington, paid just 69 cents a foot for the entire two building, 760,000-square-foot facility.) Today, prices range from $6 a square foot to $20.
So far, about 280 lofts have been built and another 1,800 units are either planned or are under construction. The projects tend to be small in scale, with most having fewer than 50 units although one project has almost 100 units. 
The developers are a diverse assortment, ranging from small local companies like Loftworks and McGowan Brothers to large national companies like the St. Louis-based Gundaker Commercial Group and the New Orleans-based Historic Restoration Inc. 
The development centers on one of the most historic commercial streets in St. Louis. According to the AIA Guide to St. Louis, "early 20th century St. Louis is better preserved along Washington Avenue than in any other downtown section." It is one of the few streets in St. Louis where one experiences the canyon effect so common in cities like New York and Chicago. The buildings, many of which are national landmarks, are massive and heavily ornamented. 
"They're perfect for loft development," said Kevin McGowan, president of McGowan Brothers, which recently completed a 13-unit project at 1221 Washington Avenue. The company owns more than a dozen other properties in the area and has plans to develop another 250 units over the next two years. "Most of them are warehouses with very open layouts, so there's very little interior demolition work to be done. All a developer has to do is come in and install new infrastructure."
THE city is also about to begin a $17.5 million streetscape renovation plan for Washington that will, among other things, double the width of the sidewalks to 18 feet for a six-block stretch between Tucker and 18th Streets and install new streetlights and planters.
"The idea is to put in some significant public infrastructure to bolster the private investment that has already taken place along the street," said Thomas Reeves, executive director of Downtown Now, a private nonprofit advocacy group.
Until now, developers have mainly built rental apartments, since only rental projects are eligible to receive federal historic tax credits. These credits, combined with state historic tax credits, are seen as key financing elements.
"They allow developers to recoup up to 45 percent of their post-purchase development costs," said Kevin Montgomery Smith, residential marketing manager of the Downtown St. Louis Partnership, a private advocacy group for downtown development. "Without them, we wouldn't be seeing this level of activity."
But the runaway success of a recent condominium project has tilted the balance toward for-sale projects. The project in question is 10th Street Lofts, which is just off Washington Avenue in an old brick warehouse building.
The developer of 10th Street is Craig Heller, who left his job as president of Pyramid Construction Inc., another local developer, to focus on downtown loft development.
"I wanted to build a neighborhood, and downtown seemed like an area with a lot of potential," he said. "There's great building stock and great incentives. The only question was the market. Even in the city's heyday in the 1950's, there weren't many people living downtown. We didn't know how people would respond."
Mr. Heller paid $1.70 a square foot for the 150,000-square-foot building, which was constructed as an annex to the nearby Merchandise Mart Building in 1913, and carved out 31 lofts ranging in price from $120,000 to $290,000 and in size from roughly 1,500 to 4,000 square feet. 
The results were impressive. "We had an open house in September of 1999, and 2,000 people showed up," said Judith Korn, a saleswoman with Re/Max Properties West in suburban Chesterfield, the brokerage that handled the sales. "We sold 15 units in one day and the rest within six weeks."
One buyer was Margaret Newman, a writer and video producer who was moving to St. Louis from Chicago. "I saw a living space I could only dream about in Chicago," she said of her 4,000-square-foot loft. "The opportunity to get in on something like this is gone in most cities."
The largest condominium project to date is the Terra Cotta Lofts, a project in the General American Life Insurance Building a block south of Washington at 1501 Locust Street. The developers are the Orchard Investment Company of Chicago and Joseph Freed & Associates of Wheeling, Ill. The project is costing about $20 million, of which $4.5 million went for the 200,000-square-foot building plus several adjacent properties.
THE 98 units in the building range in size from 1,000 to 2,000 square feet and are going for $120,000 to $275,000. According to Jay Case, a principal with Orchard Investment, about 25 units have been sold and the first residents will move in early next year.
"Washington Avenue is a great urban streetscape," he says. "It makes sense for the city to concentrate its energies here."
Another project that is raising the residential profile of the street is the Merchandise Mart Building, which occupies a block between 10th and 11th Streets. The building, which dates from 1889, was recently acquired by Historic Restoration Inc. of New Orleans, which plans to spend $40 million to convert the structure into 219 rental apartments.
The Mart is Historic Restoration's second project on Washington Avenue. The first is a large commercial venture, the $250 million renovation of the long-vacant Statler and Lennox Hotels, which it is doing in partnership with the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, based in Irving, Tex. The two hotels are across the street from each other at 8th Street at the eastern end of the area being redeveloped. When finished, both will carry the Marriott Renaissance nameplate and will be convenient to the nearby America's Center, St. Louis's convention center. 
"The hotels are an economic engine to provide employment opportunities downtown and spur housing development," said Ronald Silverman, vice president and regional manager of Historic Restoration Inc. "We have a strong commitment to restoring neighborhoods, and Washington Avenue at one time was a fabulous street. We hope to do a number of projects here."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Terra Cotta Lofts, left, consists of 98 units in the General American Life Building, and the building at 1221 Washington Avenue, with the awnings, has 13 units. Map of St. Louis, Missouri, highlighting Terra Cotta Lofts.
